IN THE COURT OF THE LIII ADDL, CITY CIVIL AND SESSIONS JUDGE AT BANGALORE Special Court (CCH-54) DATED THIS THE 25th DAY OF NOVEMBER, 2015. PRESENT: Smt. H. G. Vijayakumari. , B. Sc. ,LLB. , LIII Addl. City Civil & Sessions Judge, Bangalore. Spl. C. C. No. 60/2015 COMPLAINANT State by Subramanyapura Police Station, Bangalore. (By Public Prosecutor, Bangalore. ) ACCUSED Sawalram Patel, S/o. Madharam Patel, Age: 42 years, No. 15, Rushshyashrunga Road, Old Bank Colony, Konanakunte, Bangalore City. Native of: Dabli Village, Shivana Taluk, Asamudri Thana Badker District, Rajastan State. (By Sri. -K. V. S. - Advocate) 1. Date of Commission Of Offence: One year prior to 03. 11. 2014 2. Date of Report Of Offence 03. 11. 2014 3. Date of arrest of accused 07. 11. 2014 4 Date of release on Bail 28. 01. 2015 Period undergone in Judicial Custody 71 days 6 Name of the: Manjunath complainant 7. Date of Commencement of recording evidence 26. 10. 2015 8. Date of Closing of Evidence 05. 11. 2015 9. Offences complained of: Section 354, and 376 of Indian Penal Code and section 5(L)(M) R/w. 6 of POCSO Act 2012 10. Opinion of the Judge: Accused is found not guilty 11 Order of the Court: As per final order JUDGMENT The Police Inspector of Subramanyapura Police station, Bangalore City has filed charge sheet against the accused for the offences punishable under section 354, 376 of Indian Penal Code and 5(L)(M) and 6 of POCSO Act 2012. 2. In brief the case of the prosecution as per Ex. P. 2 is as under: - That victim girl has given a letter to the coordinator, BOSCO Child Line, Bangalore on 03. 11. 2014 alleging that accused misbehaving with her by touching her private parts since she was of 7 years old, since one year back, she was sexually abused by the accused by showing the obscene video telling that he will purchase new dresses for her and also threatened her not to disclose the incident to anyone. Based on the said letter, the complainant has lodged the complaint as per Ex. P7 and case has been registered by the Investigation Officer and charge sheet has been filed against the accused. 3. As soon as charge sheet was filed and the prosecution papers were made available to the accused as required under section 207 of Criminal Procedure Code, the learned counsel appearing for the accused and the learned Public Prosecutor were heard regarding the framing of charge under section 354 and 376 Indian Penal Code and 5(L)(M) R/w. 6 of POCSO Act 2012. Charge was framed and read over and explained to the accused. Accused pleaded not guilty and claimed to be tried. Therefore the case was posted for evidence of the prosecution. 4. In order to prove the alleged offences the prosecution examined 6 Witness as PWs 1 to 6 and documents have been marked as per Ex. P. 1 to Ex. P. 7. No incriminating articles have been marked. 5. Heard Learned Public Prosecutor for the state, and learned counsel appearing for the accused. 6. Now the point that arise for my consideration are: 1) Whether prosecution proves beyond all reasonable doubt: (a) That accused since from 2 years attempted to outrage the modesty of the victim girl by showing obscene videos and thereby committed the offence Punishable U/sec. 354 of Indian Penal Code? (b) That since from one year accused committed rape against the victim girl against her will and thereby committed the offence Punishable U/sec. 376 of Indian Penal Code? (c) That accused had sexually assaulted the victim girl aged below 12 years and thereby committed the offence Punishable U/sec. 5(L) R/w. 6 POCSO Act 2012? (d) That accused committed sexual assault against the victim girl more than once and thereby committed the offence Punishable U/ sec. 5(M) R/w. 6 of POCSO Act? 2) What Order? 7. My findings above points are as under: - Point No. 1 (a): In the negative Point No. 1 (b): In the negative Point No. 1 (c): In the negative Point No. 1 (d): In the negative Point No. 2: as per final Order REASONS 8. Point No. 1(a) to (d): - All the points are taken up together as they are inter related to each other. 9. The burden is on the prosecution to prove that accused since from one year back accused committed sexual assault against the victim girl Cw2 against her will and since from 2 years accused used to touch her body and used to show obscene videos and misbehaved with her. 10. Now let me consider the other oral evidence adduced by the prosecution. 11. Pw1 victim girl deposed in her evidence that she has not given statement before the police alleging that accused misbehaved with her and committed sexual assault and she is not aware of the contents written in Ex. P1 and Ex. P2, wherein she put her signature. She also treated as hostile witness by the prosecution and she denied that she has lodged complaint as per Ex. p2 alleging that accused misbehaved with her and committed sexual assault and raped her and police drew mahazer as per Ex. P1. She also denied that she has given statement before the police as per Ex. P3 stating that accused misbehaved with her and committed rape showing obscene videos. She also stated that Ex. P2 is not in her hand writing and she only signed Ex. P2. 12. Pw2 Bhavani Devi mother of the victim girl deposed that she has not given statement before the police regarding the alleged incident. The said witness is also treated as hostile witness by the prosecution and she has given statement before the police as per Ex. P4 stating that she came to know the accused misbehaved with the victim girl and sexually harassed her. 13. Pw3 Balaram deposed in his evidence that victim girl is his sister's daughter. He has not given statement before the police that accused misbehaved with the victim girl. The said witness is also treated as hostile witness by the prosecution and he denied that he has given statement before the police that he came to know that accused misbehaved with the Pw2 and sexually harassed her. 14. Pw4 Ravi Kumar who is a mahazer witness deposed in his evidence that he put his signature to mahazer Ex. P1 about one year back in Subramanyapura police station and not known the contents. He also treated as hostile witness by the prosecution and he denied that police drew the mahazer on 07. 11. 2014 at House No. 27, 1st floor, Byraveswara Nilaya, ABM colony, Bangalore and after knowing the contents of the mahazer, he has signed and deposing falsely. 15. Pw5 Annappa who is also mahazer witness deposed in his evidence that he put his signature to mahazer Ex. P6 in the police station and not known the contents. He also treated as hostile witness by the prosecution and he denied that police drew the mahazer on 07. 11. 2014 at House No. 15, 2nd floor, Old Bank Colony, Rushyashrunga Road, Bangalore and seized the mobile. 16. Pw6 Manjuanth complainant deposed in his evidence that on 01. 11. 2014 at 5-00 p. m. , received the phone message from the public, it was attended by Idayith attender and on the same day at 6-00 p. m. , Idayith told that he received from phone message from the public with respect of sexual assault. On the next day, he went to the shop of the accused along with Akshitha and introduced as BEO Office officials came to enquire about the victim, as she has not attended the classes. Accused called his wife to bring the victim girl. Victim girl and her mother came at 12-20 p. m. , take away the victim girl in the Jeep and she disclosed the sexual assault by the accused since two years and also gave it in writing and reported the matter to the Director and Coordinator. Thereafter, lodged the complaint as per Ex. P7. 17. On perusal of the evidence of Pw1, Pw1 and Akshitha representing themselves that they are from BEO office had come to enquire about the victim girl, as why she has not attending the school regularly. Accused asked to bring the victim girl and victim girl was brought by her mother at 12-20 p. m. , and on enquiry the victim girl narrated the incident and also in writing as per Ex. P2. 18. It is clear from the records that case has been registered based on the complaint lodged by the complainant. It is the case of the complainant that he was not in the office while Idayith attender received the phone call. Idayith attender of Child Line is not examined by the prosecution. Pw6 also admits that they have maintained the registers for having received the phone calls from the public. It is clear from the evidence of Pw1 that immediately after he came to know about the incident, he has not reported the incident to the Special Juvenile Unit or the Local police U/Sec. 19(1)(a)(b) of POCSO Act 2012. Pw6 admits that he has not furnished the copy of the register maintained by them regarding phone call received in their office to the jurisdictional police. On perusal of the prosecution papers, Investigation Officer has not enquired Idayith attender of the Child Line who received the phone call from the public. On perusal of the evidence of Pw6, he lodged the complaint as per Ex. P7, after discussion with his superior officers and immediately he has not brought to the notice of the jurisdictional police with respect of the alleged incident. 19. The prosecution case is not supported by the evidence of Pw1 victim girl and she denied the incident in toto. She denied the sexual harassment by the accused and denied the contents of Ex. P1 and Ex. P2 is known to her. She denied that she has given complaint to the Child Line as per Ex. P2 and police drew mahazer on 07. 11. 2015. She also stated that Ex. P2 is not in her hand writing and she only signed and she does not know to read and write English and Kannada. The prosecution case is also not supported by the evidence of Pw2 Bhavani Devi mother of the victim girl and Pw3 Balaram relative of the complainant. They have denied the incident and also denied that they have stated before the police as per Ex. P3 to Ex. P5. 20. Ex. P1 mahazer dated 07. 11. 2014 alleged to have been drawn in the house of the victim girl is not supported by the victim girl and Pw4 Ravi Kumar deposed that he has signed the mahazer in the police station. Ex. P6 mahazer dated 07. 11. 2014 is also not proved by the prosecution. Pw5 Annappa who is a mahazer witness deposed in his evidence that he has not known the contents of Ex. P6 and he put his signature about 6 months back at Subramanyapura police station and not known its contents. Hence, Ex. P7 mahazer is also not proved by the prosecution satisfactorily. 21. In an offence under section 376 of Indian Penal Code the evidence of the prosecution plays a vital role. The evidence of the victim girl can be accepted without there being corroboration. However, if there are any inconsistency or discrepancies in the evidence of the prosecution witnesses, then the court has to look for corroboration to the evidence of the victim girl, but the prosecution case is not supported by the evidence of the victim girl herself. 22. The prosecution case is also not supported by the evidence of Pws. 1 to 3 and mahazer witness Pw4 and Pw5. The Investigation Officer is also not examined. The mobile phone which accused used to show obscene videos to the victim girl is also not seized by the Investigation Officer. 23. Thus the prosecution has failed to prove the guilt on the part of the accused beyond all reasonable doubt. Hence, in view of all these reasons, I answer point No. 1(a) to 1(d) in the negative. 24. Point No. 2: - In view of the aforesaid reasons and findings on point Nos. 1(a) to (d), accused is found not guilty for the above said offences, in the result, I proceed to pass the following: ORDER Acting under section 235(1) of Criminal Procedure Code, accused is acquitted for the offences punishable Under Section 354 and 376 of Indian Penal Code and section 5(L)(M) R/w. 6 of POCSO Act 2012. Bail bonds and surety bonds shall stands cancelled. (Dictated to the Judgment writer, corrected and then pronounced in Open Court on this the 25th day of NOVEMBER, 2015. ) (H. G. [case 10]
IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 27-04-2016 CORAM: THE HONOURABLE DR. JUSTICE P. DEVADASS Crl. M. P. No. 3669 of 2016 in Crl. A. No. 235 of 2016 Suresh. . Petitioner -vs- State Represented by The Inspector of Police, All Women Police Station-Udhagamandalam, Udhagamandalam, Nilgiris District. (Crime No. 1 of 2015). . Respondent Petition filed under Section 389(1) of Cr. P. C. , to suspend the sentence of imprisonment passed in Spl. S. C. No. 4 of 2015 dated 27. 11. 2015 by the learned Additional Sessions Judge, Fast Track Mahila Court, Udhagamandalam, Nilgiris District and release the petitioner on bail pending disposal of the Criminal Appeal. For Petitioner: Mr. J. T. Rajasuriya For Respondent: Mr. P. Govindarajan, Additional Public Prosecutor. O R D E R The sole accused in the Special Sessions Case in Spl. S. C. No. 4 of 2015 on the file of the learned Additional Sessions Judge, Fast Track Mahila Court, Nilgiris District at Udhagamandalam seeks suspension of his sentence of imprisonment. In the said Court, after trial, the trial Court convicted the accused under Section 7 read with Section 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (hereinafter POCSO Act) and sentenced him 3 years R. I. and fined him Rs. 5, 000/- and directed him to pay a compensation of Rs. 1, 00, 000/-, i/d 2 years RI. The learned Judge also directed him payment of further compensation of Rs. 2, 00, 000/- out of Victim Assistance Fund. PW-2 is the daughter of PW-1. The accused has been prosecuted for he having sexually abused her. The Trial Court believed her and construed his act as a sexual assault and thus convicted and sentenced him as stated above. The learned counsel for the petitioner/appellant would contend that the petitioner as well as the accused fancied each other. They fell in love. To distance him from her daughter, PW-1 had engineered this case. The prosecution version is the concocted brainchild of PW-1 in an unholistic alliance with the obliging police. The learned counsel for the petitioner further contended that in this case the two instances of occurrence have been projected. However, on this aspect, there is material contradictions as between the mother (P. W. 1) and the daughter/P. W. 2. It is PW-1 vs. PW-2. The learned counsel for the petitioner would also contend that top of it, there is material variation in the testimony of PW-2 before and during trial. Before trial before a Magistrate under Section 164 Cr. P. C. So also in her police statement. P. Ws. -2 and 1 were inconsistent as to the alleged date of occurrence, more particularly, PW-1 introduces a date, namely, 5. 3. 2015 which is nobody's case. 5. 3. 2015 was not uttered either by PW-2 nor prosecution. Thus, PW-1's version is a coloured version. In such circumstances, placing implicit reliance on the testimony of PWs-1 and 2 and inflict punishment upon the accused is too dangerous. Thus, there is prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. He will not run away. He has no bad history/antecedents. In the circumstances, he may be granted appeal bail. On the other hand, the learned Additional Public Prosecutor would submit that the Court can keep aside PW-1 because she is not the victim and focus its attention mainly on the victim/PW-2. Her evidence is crystal clear that the accused prayed on PW-2 like a vulture. He committed the inhuman act upon a minor child. Her solemn statement as to the sexual violence committed upon her. There is no significant reason for PW-1 as against the accused to implicate the accused risking the life and future of unmarried school going minor daughter. Very grave allegations are made as against the accused. There is no prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. This case is not a fit case for the grant of appeal bail. I have anxiously considered the rival submissions, perused the Trial Court's judgment and the piece of evidence referred to by both sides. In the facts and circumstances, now the question is whether the petitioner could be granted appeal bail under Section 389(1) Cr. P. C. Regular bail in a non-bailable offence in fit cases are being granted by the Magistrates under Section 437 Cr. P. C. While other Courts and the High Court exercises concurrent jurisdiction to grant bail in non-bailable cases under Section 439 Cr. P. C. The remand prisoners, under-trials could seek bail under the said provisions during pre-conviction stage of a criminal case. During that stage, it is pertinent to note that the presumption of innocence of an accused is intact because everyone is presumed to be innocent till the guilt alleged against the accused is proved beyond all reasonable doubts. However, once conviction is recorded, the said presumption is replaced by a Criminal Court judgment. Thereafter, also the conviction person can seek bail under Section 389 (1) Cr. P. C. Thus, the consideration for the grant of bail to an accused during the pre-conviction stage (before judgment) and post-conviction stage (after judgment) are different. So far as appeal bail under Section 389(1) Cr. P. C. is concerned, the Court has to find out is there any prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. While doing so, the Court should not indulge in meticulous examination of the evidence of the accused because the main appeal is not heard. It is still pending. To find out the prima facie case, the Trial Court has to refer to the findings recorded by the trial Court and the relevant evidence referred to. Further, it must also take into account the nature of the accusation made as against the accused. In view of the large scale violence committed upon the children, in 2012, the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (Act No. 32 of 2012) has been enacted. It is a Central Act. It contains provisions ensuring confidentiality of the victim of the offence, her family details and also conducting of the trial in a child friendly atmosphere and it had also introduced a legal fiction as to the criminal propensity, mental faculty of the accused, through Sections 29 and 30(1) of the Act. However, under Section 30(2), the Act one's right of presumption of innocence until he is otherwise held guilty by legal evidence has been preserved. Thus, it is Indianised version of admixture of English Criminal Law (Common System of Law) and French Criminal Law (Continental System of Law). Now, in a prosecution launched under POCSO Act, age of the victim is very important because only upon the victim being below 18 years that she is a 'child' the stringent provisions of POCSO Act will apply and consent of the victim being immaterial under POCSO Act. POCSO Act is much more wider in scope in prosecuting an accused than prosecuting accused under Section 376 IPC. In this case, start of the offence was stated to be on 21. 2. 2015 in the house of PW-1, when her mother was away. During that time, PW-2 was studying VIII Standard in a school. It is stated that then she was 13 years old. Ex. P-3 School Certificate, Ex. P-8 Medical Certificate, Ex. P-9 age Certificate and the evidence of PW-7 School Headmaster and PW-5 Doctor beyond pale of any controversy establishes that at the time when the alleged occurrence took place, she was below 18 years. So she is a child within the meaning of Section 2(d) of POCSO Act. So the provisions of POCSO Act became applicable to this case. PW-2 is stated to be the victim of a sexual violence. Her evidence shall be treated as the evidence of an injured witness. If her evidence is consistent, cogent, unimpeachable unless there is acceptable reasons to implicate the accused, her evidence can be acted upon. The question of looking for corroboration for her evidence arises when her evidence appears to be murky. This is a rule of prudence and not a rule of law. Thus, corroboration cannot be insisted upon as a condition precedent to act on the testimony of a victim in a sexual violence case. But while appreciating their evidence, the Court must fathom out the reality of the situation and the truth of the allegations. While doing so, the Court cannot mistake every difference in evidence as a material contradiction. It cannot go blow out a contradiction beyond proportion. It cannot mistook a mole a mountain. In a sexual violence case, honour of two persons, namely, the victim as well as the accused is involved. When the allegations are very serious, the Court must be very serious of proving those allegations. Even to impute culpable mental state to the accused, there must be some material for the Court to have reason to believe the existence of such a fact (See Sections 29 and 30(2) of POCSO Act, 2012). Now, in this case, PW-2 the minor child had the countenance of the accused, a Book-Seller for the first time when he came to their house to market his books. PW-1 forewarned him not to visit again since there are ladies in her house. According to PW-2, on the fateful day, namely, on 21. 2. 2015, at about 2 p. m. , while she was alone in her house, the accused came, pressed her breasts, pushed her to the bed, sexually abused her private parts by placing his private part. Subsequently, on 28. 3. 2015 around 2 p. m. , when again the accused came to her house with similar motive, PW-2 raised alarm, the accused took to his heels, PW-1 came, PW-2 recounted the whole incident and also the earlier incident that took place on 21. 2. 2015. Thereafter, police complaint was lodged. Thereafter, medical examination was conducted and there was no presence of external injuries on her private part. It is pertinent to note that the actual physical violence was not on 28. 3. 2015. Even as per the version of PW-2, it was on 21. 2. 2015 and thus, by the time the medical examination was conducted more than a month had passed away, the evidence on her person had fade away. PW-2, being a child was under extreme trauma, normally a child like her, when placed in such grim situation, will not be forthcoming and will try to hide the shame. But, in this case, as per PW-2 when again the accused attempted to make her sexual assault on her, unable to put up with the shame, she cried and the accused was caught. Reading the evidence of PWs-2 and 1 and other witnesses and the complaint, the substratum of the case that the accused on the first occasion had sexually assaulted the victim has been brought out by the prosecution. The attempt of the defence to dilute the effect of the said evidence by clinging to some difference in the evidence of PWs-1 and 2 and in the statement of the victim girl recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. which are not so material and are not significant enough to shake the veracity of the testimony of the victim girl has not been shattered by this adventure of the defence which has become a misadventure. Further, there is no convincing reason or motive supported by any material or acceptable reason to view the evidence of PW-2 with a jaundiced eye. The nature of the allegations made as against the accused is very serious. Thus, the fallout is that there is no prima facie case in favour of the petitioner. Thus, I am not inclined to grant him appeal bail. In view of the foregoings, this petition is dismissed. However, it is made clear that the observations made in this order are only for the purpose of finding out a prima facie case to take a decision in this petition and it has nothing to do with the disposal of the main Criminal Appeal. The Registrar (Judicial) is directed to make ready the booklet expeditiously as and when the appeal is ripe for disposal, it shall be included in the causelist under the caption 'Accused in Jail cases'.

[case 11]
IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 27-04-2016 CORAM: THE HONOURABLE DR. JUSTICE P. DEVADASS Crl. M. P. No. 3669 of 2016 in Crl. A. No. 235 of 2016 Suresh. . Petitioner -vs- State Represented by The Inspector of Police, All Women Police Station-Udhagamandalam, Udhagamandalam, Nilgiris District. (Crime No. 1 of 2015). . [case 12]
Vasu @ Vasappa vs The State Of Karnataka By on 31 January, 2024 -1- NC: 2024: KHC: 4254 CRL. RP No. 1073 of 2017 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 31ST DAY OF JANUARY, 2024 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR JUSTICE S RACHAIAH CRIMINAL REVISION PETITION NO. 1073 OF 2017 BETWEEN: VASU @ VASAPPA S/O YANKAPPA AGED ABOUT 24 YEARS OCC: AGRICULTURIST R/O MACHIHALLI VILLAGE HARAPPANAHALLI TLAUK Digitally signed by SUDHA S Location: HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA. .. PETITIONER (BY SRI. R B DESHPANDE, ADVOCATE) AND: THE STATE OF KARNATAKA BY HARAPANAHALLI POLICE STATION DAVANAGERE DISTRICT - 583 131. (REPRESENTED BY STATE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR HIGH COURT BUILDINGS BENGALURU - 560 001. .. .RESPONDENT (BY SRI. RAHUL RAI K, HCGP) THIS CRL. RP IS FILED U/S. 397 R/W 401 CR. P. C PRAYING TO SET ASIDE THE JUDGMENT AND ORDER OF CONVICTION AND SENTENCE DATED 21. 07. 2017 PASSED BY THE I ADDITIONAL DISTRICT AND SESSIONS JUDGE, DAVANAGERE IN CRL. A. NO. 78/2013 PARTLY CONFIRMING THE ORDER DATED 11. 07. 2013 PASSED BY THE JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE FIRST CLASS, HARAPANAHALLI IN C. C. NO. 378/2012 AND ETC. , THIS PETITION, COMING ON FOR FINAL HEARING, THIS DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING: -2- NC: 2024: KHC: 4254 CRL. RP No. 1073 of 2017 ORDER 1. This revision petition is arising out of the concurrent findings of the Courts below wherein the Trial Court recorded the conviction of the petitioner under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of Indian Penal Code (for short 'IPC'). In the appeal, the Appellate Court allowed the appeal partly and set aside the judgment of conviction in respect of the provision under Section 504 of IPC and confirmed the sentences of the remaining provisions. Being aggrieved by the same, the petitioner herein has preferred this revision petition. 2. The rank of the parties in the Trial Court will be considered henceforth for convenience. Brief facts of the case are as under: 3. It is the case of the prosecution that, on 12. 12. 2011 at about 11. 00 a. m. , at Machihalli Koracharahatti village, Government Anganavadi school, when the complainant was discharging her duties as a Anganavadi Teacher, the accused went there and picked up quarrel with the complainant by stating that she should not have informed the marriage which he had intended to marry the minor girl, who is aged about 14 years, to the Women and Child Welfare Department, Harapanahalli. The accused abused in a filthy language and slapped her on the face and asked her to marry him and also assaulted her and pulled her saree and outraged her modesty. Further he has threatened her with dire consequences. Based on the complaint lodged by the complainant, the respondent / police have registered a case in Crime No. 175/2011 for the offences punishable under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of IPC. After investigation, the respondent / police have submitted the charge sheet. 4. To prove the case of the prosecution, the prosecution examined 6 witnesses as PWs. 1 to 6 and got marked 7 documents as Exs. P1 to P7. Both the Courts have concurrently held that the petitioner committed the offences stated supra and recorded the conviction. Hence this revision petition. 5. Heard Shri R. B. Deshpande, learned counsel for the petitioner and Shri Rahul Rai K, learned High Court Government Pleader for the respondent - State. 6. It is the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner that, the concurrent findings recorded by the Courts below in convicting the petitioner / accused appears to be perverse, illegal and the same is liable to be set aside. 7. It is further submitted that there are no independent witnesses to the said incident. The complainant deliberately exaggerated the incident as if the petitioner has outraged her modesty and narrated in her complaint which is beyond truth. It is further submitted that the prosecution has not produced any document to show that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl. In the absence of the said document, it is not appropriate to arrive at a conclusion that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl / victim and the same was informed to the Women and Child Welfare Department. The said aspect should have been considered by the Courts below before recording the conviction. 8. It is further submitted that the Trial Court convicted the petitioner on the basis of the surmises and conjectures which are alien to the criminal jurisprudence. Therefore, the findings recorded by the Courts below are required to be set aside. Making such submission, learned counsel for the petitioner prays to allow the petition. 9. Per contra, learned High Court Government Pleader (for short 'HCGP) for the respondent-State vehemently justified the concurrent findings and submitted that the name of the victim with whom the marriage of the accused was proposed to be carried out, was studying at Kasturba Residential School and the said proposed marriage was informed to the complainant. After receiving the said information, the complainant has informed the same to the Women and Child Welfare Department. Due to the said enmity, the petitioner has committed the offences as stated supra. Both the Courts have concurrently held that the petitioner has committed the offences and therefore, interference with the said findings may not be appropriate and not required. Making such submission, learned HCGP prays to dismiss the petition. 10. Having heard the submissions of learned counsels for the respective parties and also perused the findings of the Courts below in recording the conviction, it is the case of the prosecution that the marriage between the petitioner and the minor girl was fixed and it was brought to the notice of PW. 1 by the villagers. The complainant has informed the said fact to the higher authority. The petitioner after having learnt that PW. 1 has informed the same to the higher officials, he has gone to the office of PW. 1 and started abusing, assaulting and insulting PW. 1 in one or other pretext and said to have committed the offences as stated supra. 11. Having regard to the scope and ambit of the Revisional jurisdiction in interfering with the findings of the Courts below, it is appropriate to have a cursory look upon the evidence of all the witnesses, to ascertain as to whether any error committed by the Courts below in appreciating both oral and documentary evidence on record. 12. PW. 1 being a Teacher who was working at Machihalli Anganvadi. On 12. 12. 2011, when she was working at the Anganvadi, she has learnt that the marriage of the minor girl was fixed with the petitioner and she had informed the same to the higher officials who visited the house of the victim / minor girl. Being enraged of the visit of the higher officials to the house of the minor girl, the petitioner went to Anganvadi Centre and questioned her as to why she has stopped the marriage and said to have pulled her saree, assaulted her in front of others. By that time, CW. 4 intervened and pacified the matter. Thereafter, PW. 1 went to the police station and lodged a complaint against the petitioner. She was cross-examined at length and she has admitted that she had not gone to the marriage negotiations proposed to be held between the petitioner and the minor girl. In spite of lengthy cross-examination being subjected to PW. 1, PW. 1 withstood the same and supported the case of the prosecution. 13. PW. 2 - an independent witness, supported the case of the prosecution and narrated the incident as how the petitioner had assaulted PW. 1 and the manner in which he has outraged her modesty. When a specific question was put to her that she is a relative of PW. 1, she has admitted the relationship. However, she has assertively stated that the incident had taken place in her presence and she has seen the assault having been made by the petitioner. 14. PW. 3 - witness to spot panchanama, which is marked as Ex. P2 and he has supported the case of the prosecution. 15. PW. 4 also witness to Ex. P2 and supported the case of the prosecution. 16. PW. 5 - Doctor who treated PW. 1, issued wound certificate as per Ex. P5. As per the said wound certificate, PW. 1 sustained three injuries. Though several suggestions are made about the methods and possibilities of sustaining the injuries, he has supported the case of the prosecution. 17. PW. 6 was working as PSI, stated to have received the complaint on 12. 12. 2011 and conducted the investigation and submitted the charge sheet. 18. As per the averments of the complaint and also the evidence of PWs. 1 and 2, the incident said to have taken place on 12. 12. 2011, on the same day, a complaint came to be registered by the complainant. The FIR was sent to the Jurisdictional Magistrate on the same date at 05. 20 p. m. The evidence of PWs. 1 and 2 are clinching and reliable. These two witnesses have been subjected to lengthy cross-examination; however, nothing has been elicited to disbelieve their version. In addition to their evidence, the evidence of the Doctor - PW. 5 who treated PW. 1 and issued wound certificate as per Ex. P5 which clearly indicates that PW. 1 sustained injuries. The incident had taken place when she was discharging her official duty as Anganvadi Teacher. 19. The prosecution even though examined PWs. 1 and 2 as witnesses to the incident, no independent witnesses have neither been cited nor examined as witnesses to the incident. As per the case of the prosecution, the alleged incident said to have taken place in the village, if such incident had taken place in the Anganavadi, certainly many people would have gathered, either to witness the incident or to pacify the same. Not citing the independent witnesses in such incident by the Investigating Officer, which appears to be strange and unbelievable. 20. The motive for the said incident is that PW. 1 has informed to the higher officials regarding the proposed marriage of the petitioner with a minor girl. The prosecution has failed to produce any document to show that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl and further the prosecution failed to cite the officials of the Department of Women and Child Welfare to substantiate the case. When the prosecution has failed to establish the motive for commission of such offence, the commission of offence appears to be doubtful and it may be said that the prosecution has failed to prove the case beyond all reasonable doubt and therefore, the petitioner is entitled for acquittal in this case. However, the Courts below have failed to take note of these aspects and recorded the conviction which appears to be erroneous and not proper. Therefore, the conviction has to be set aside. 21. In the light of the above observations, I proceed to pass the following: ORDER (i) The Criminal Revision Petition is allowed. (ii) The judgment and order dated 11. 07. 2013 passed in CC. No. 378/2012 by the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Harapanahalli and the judgment and order dated 21. 07. 2017 passed in Crl. A. No. 78/2013 by the I Additional District and Sessions Judge, Davanagere are set aside. (iii) The petitioner is acquitted for the offences punishable under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of IPC. (iv) Bail bonds executed, if any, stand cancelled. Sd/- JUDGE BSS List No. : 1 Sl No. : 49

[case 13]
Vasu @ Vasappa vs The State Of Karnataka By on 31 January, 2024 -1- NC: 2024: KHC: 4254 CRL. RP No. 1073 of 2017 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 31ST DAY OF JANUARY, 2024 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR JUSTICE S RACHAIAH CRIMINAL REVISION PETITION NO. 1073 OF 2017 BETWEEN: VASU @ VASAPPA S/O YANKAPPA AGED ABOUT 24 YEARS OCC: AGRICULTURIST R/O MACHIHALLI VILLAGE HARAPPANAHALLI TLAUK Digitally signed by SUDHA S Location: HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA. .. PETITIONER (BY SRI. R B DESHPANDE, ADVOCATE) AND: THE STATE OF KARNATAKA BY HARAPANAHALLI POLICE STATION DAVANAGERE DISTRICT - 583 131. (REPRESENTED BY STATE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR HIGH COURT BUILDINGS BENGALURU - 560 001. .. .RESPONDENT (BY SRI. RAHUL RAI K, HCGP) THIS CRL. RP IS FILED U/S. 397 R/W 401 CR. P. C PRAYING TO SET ASIDE THE JUDGMENT AND ORDER OF CONVICTION AND SENTENCE DATED 21. 07. 2017 PASSED BY THE I ADDITIONAL DISTRICT AND SESSIONS JUDGE, DAVANAGERE IN CRL. A. NO. 78/2013 PARTLY CONFIRMING THE ORDER DATED 11. 07. 2013 PASSED BY THE JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE FIRST CLASS, HARAPANAHALLI IN C. C. NO. 378/2012 AND ETC. , THIS PETITION, COMING ON FOR FINAL HEARING, THIS DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING: -2- NC: 2024: KHC: 4254 CRL. RP No. 1073 of 2017 ORDER 1. This revision petition is arising out of the concurrent findings of the Courts below wherein the Trial Court recorded the conviction of the petitioner under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of Indian Penal Code (for short 'IPC'). In the appeal, the Appellate Court allowed the appeal partly and set aside the judgment of conviction in respect of the provision under Section 504 of IPC and confirmed the sentences of the remaining provisions. Being aggrieved by the same, the petitioner herein has preferred this revision petition. 2. The rank of the parties in the Trial Court will be considered henceforth for convenience. Brief facts of the case are as under: 3. It is the case of the prosecution that, on 12. 12. 2011 at about 11. 00 a. m. , at Machihalli Koracharahatti village, Government Anganavadi school, when the complainant was discharging her duties as a Anganavadi Teacher, the accused went there and picked up quarrel with the complainant by stating that she should not have informed the marriage which he had intended to marry the minor girl, who is aged about 14 years, to the Women and Child Welfare Department, Harapanahalli. The accused abused in a filthy language and slapped her on the face and asked her to marry him and also assaulted her and pulled her saree and outraged her modesty. Further he has threatened her with dire consequences. Based on the complaint lodged by the complainant, the respondent / police have registered a case in Crime No. 175/2011 for the offences punishable under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of IPC. After investigation, the respondent / police have submitted the charge sheet. 4. To prove the case of the prosecution, the prosecution examined 6 witnesses as PWs. 1 to 6 and got marked 7 documents as Exs. P1 to P7. Both the Courts have concurrently held that the petitioner committed the offences stated supra and recorded the conviction. Hence this revision petition. 5. Heard Shri R. B. Deshpande, learned counsel for the petitioner and Shri Rahul Rai K, learned High Court Government Pleader for the respondent - State. 6. It is the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner that, the concurrent findings recorded by the Courts below in convicting the petitioner / accused appears to be perverse, illegal and the same is liable to be set aside. 7. It is further submitted that there are no independent witnesses to the said incident. The complainant deliberately exaggerated the incident as if the petitioner has outraged her modesty and narrated in her complaint which is beyond truth. It is further submitted that the prosecution has not produced any document to show that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl. In the absence of the said document, it is not appropriate to arrive at a conclusion that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl / victim and the same was informed to the Women and Child Welfare Department. The said aspect should have been considered by the Courts below before recording the conviction. 8. It is further submitted that the Trial Court convicted the petitioner on the basis of the surmises and conjectures which are alien to the criminal jurisprudence. Therefore, the findings recorded by the Courts below are required to be set aside. Making such submission, learned counsel for the petitioner prays to allow the petition. 9. Per contra, learned High Court Government Pleader (for short 'HCGP) for the respondent-State vehemently justified the concurrent findings and submitted that the name of the victim with whom the marriage of the accused was proposed to be carried out, was studying at Kasturba Residential School and the said proposed marriage was informed to the complainant. After receiving the said information, the complainant has informed the same to the Women and Child Welfare Department. Due to the said enmity, the petitioner has committed the offences as stated supra. Both the Courts have concurrently held that the petitioner has committed the offences and therefore, interference with the said findings may not be appropriate and not required. Making such submission, learned HCGP prays to dismiss the petition. 10. Having heard the submissions of learned counsels for the respective parties and also perused the findings of the Courts below in recording the conviction, it is the case of the prosecution that the marriage between the petitioner and the minor girl was fixed and it was brought to the notice of PW. 1 by the villagers. The complainant has informed the said fact to the higher authority. The petitioner after having learnt that PW. 1 has informed the same to the higher officials, he has gone to the office of PW. 1 and started abusing, assaulting and insulting PW. 1 in one or other pretext and said to have committed the offences as stated supra. 11. Having regard to the scope and ambit of the Revisional jurisdiction in interfering with the findings of the Courts below, it is appropriate to have a cursory look upon the evidence of all the witnesses, to ascertain as to whether any error committed by the Courts below in appreciating both oral and documentary evidence on record. 12. PW. 1 being a Teacher who was working at Machihalli Anganvadi. On 12. 12. 2011, when she was working at the Anganvadi, she has learnt that the marriage of the minor girl was fixed with the petitioner and she had informed the same to the higher officials who visited the house of the victim / minor girl. Being enraged of the visit of the higher officials to the house of the minor girl, the petitioner went to Anganvadi Centre and questioned her as to why she has stopped the marriage and said to have pulled her saree, assaulted her in front of others. By that time, CW. 4 intervened and pacified the matter. Thereafter, PW. 1 went to the police station and lodged a complaint against the petitioner. She was cross-examined at length and she has admitted that she had not gone to the marriage negotiations proposed to be held between the petitioner and the minor girl. In spite of lengthy cross-examination being subjected to PW. 1, PW. 1 withstood the same and supported the case of the prosecution. 13. PW. 2 - an independent witness, supported the case of the prosecution and narrated the incident as how the petitioner had assaulted PW. 1 and the manner in which he has outraged her modesty. When a specific question was put to her that she is a relative of PW. 1, she has admitted the relationship. However, she has assertively stated that the incident had taken place in her presence and she has seen the assault having been made by the petitioner. 14. PW. 3 - witness to spot panchanama, which is marked as Ex. P2 and he has supported the case of the prosecution. 15. PW. 4 also witness to Ex. P2 and supported the case of the prosecution. 16. PW. 5 - Doctor who treated PW. 1, issued wound certificate as per Ex. P5. As per the said wound certificate, PW. 1 sustained three injuries. Though several suggestions are made about the methods and possibilities of sustaining the injuries, he has supported the case of the prosecution. 17. PW. 6 was working as PSI, stated to have received the complaint on 12. 12. 2011 and conducted the investigation and submitted the charge sheet. 18. As per the averments of the complaint and also the evidence of PWs. 1 and 2, the incident said to have taken place on 12. 12. 2011, on the same day, a complaint came to be registered by the complainant. The FIR was sent to the Jurisdictional Magistrate on the same date at 05. 20 p. m. The evidence of PWs. 1 and 2 are clinching and reliable. These two witnesses have been subjected to lengthy cross-examination; however, nothing has been elicited to disbelieve their version. In addition to their evidence, the evidence of the Doctor - PW. 5 who treated PW. 1 and issued wound certificate as per Ex. P5 which clearly indicates that PW. 1 sustained injuries. The incident had taken place when she was discharging her official duty as Anganvadi Teacher. 19. The prosecution even though examined PWs. 1 and 2 as witnesses to the incident, no independent witnesses have neither been cited nor examined as witnesses to the incident. As per the case of the prosecution, the alleged incident said to have taken place in the village, if such incident had taken place in the Anganawadi, certainly many people would have gathered, either to witness the incident or to pacify the same. Not citing the independent witnesses in such incident by the Investigating Officer, which appears to be strange and unbelievable. 20. The motive for the said incident is that PW. 1 has informed to the higher officials regarding the proposed marriage of the petitioner with a minor girl. The prosecution has failed to produce any document to show that the marriage was fixed between the petitioner and the minor girl and further the prosecution failed to cite the officials of the Department of Women and Child Welfare to substantiate the case. When the prosecution has failed to establish the motive for commission of such offence, the commission of offence appears to be doubtful and it may be said that the prosecution has failed to prove the case beyond all reasonable doubt and therefore, the petitioner is entitled for acquittal in this case. However, the Courts below have failed to take note of these aspects and recorded the conviction which appears to be erroneous and not proper. Therefore, the conviction has to be set aside. 21. In the light of the above observations, I proceed to pass the following: ORDER (i) The Criminal Revision Petition is allowed. (ii) The judgment and order dated 11. 07. 2013 passed in CC. No. 378/2012 by the Judicial Magistrate First Class, Harapanahalli and the judgment and order dated 21. 07. 2017 passed in Crl. A. No. 78/2013 by the I Additional District and Sessions Judge, Davanagere are set aside. (iii) The petitioner is acquitted for the offences punishable under Sections 504, 323, 353, 354, 506 of IPC. (iv) Bail bonds executed, if any, stand cancelled. Sd/- JUDGE BSS List No. : 1 Sl No. : 49

[case 14]

Vasu @ Vasappa vs The State Of Karnataka By on 31 January, 2024 -1- NC: 2024: KHC: 4254 CRL. RP No. 1073 of 2017 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 31ST DAY OF JANUARY, 2024 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR JUSTICE S RACHAIAH CRIMINAL REVISION PETITION NO. 1073 OF 2017 BETWEEN: VASU @ VASAPPA S/O YANKAPPA AGED ABOUT 24 YEARS OCC: AGRICULTURIST R/O MACHIHALLI VILLAGE HARAPPANAHALLI TLAUK Digitally signed by SUDHA S Location: HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA. .. Kerala High Court
Abdul Khadir vs State Of Kerala on 31 May, 2021
Author: V Raja Vijayaraghavan
Bench: V Raja Vijayaraghavan
BAIL APPL. NO. 3485 OF 2021 1
IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM
THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V
MONDAY, THE 31ST DAY OF MAY 2021 / 10TH JYAISHTA, 1943
BAIL APPL. NO. 3485 OF 2021
S. C. No. 629 of 2020 on the file of the Special Court for trial of offences
relating to atrocities against women and children including POCSO cases,
Additional Sessions Court 1, Alappuzha
SON OF ABDUL HAKKIM, RAMACHANDRAPUR, NEAR OKHIYA
MASJID KADAMTALI, MALDA, WEST BENGAL, NOW
RESIDING AT MUPPARUTHIL CHIRAYIL HOUSE, CARE OF
NIRANAM NORTH P. O. , NIRANAM VILLAGE, THIRUVALLA,
PATHANAMTHITTA DISTRICT

GOKUL DAS V. V. H.

STATE OF KERALA

ERNAKULAM, PIN - 682031
SRI AJITH MURALI-PUBLIC PROSECUTOR
THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON
31. 05. 2021, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY DELIVERED THE
BAIL APPL. NO. 3485 OF 2021 2
This application is filed under Section 439 of the Cr. P. C.
2. The applicant is the sole accused in S. C. No. 629 of 2020 on the
file of the Special Court for trial of offences relating to atrocities against
women and children including POCSO cases, Additional Sessions Court 1,
Alappuzha registered under Sections 363, 370, 342, 376AB, 354 A of the
Indian Penal Code and under Sections 4 r/w 3(a), 5(m) r/w 6(1), 8 r/w 7,
10 r/w 9 (l) & (m) of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act,
3. A minor child aged about 4 years is the victim in the instant
case. The prosecution allegation is that on 30. 8. 2020 at noon, the
applicant, with intent to commit sexual assault of the minor child, entered
the house of the child and kissed her. Later on 31. 8. 2020 at about 9. 45
am, the applicant is alleged to have taken the child to the rear side of the
building No XXII/530 of Alappuzha Municipality and subjected the child to
penetrative sexual abuse.
4. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submitted that
the applicant was arrested in connection with the aforesaid crime on
31. 8. 2020 and he has been in judicial custody since then. According to
BAIL APPL. NO. 3485 OF 2021 3
the learned counsel there is some delay in setting the law in motion which
renders the whole prosecution version on suspicion. It is further
submitted that now that the final report has been laid, further detention in
custody is unwarranted.
5. The learned Public Prosecutor on instructions submitted that the
investigation conducted would disclose that a child of tender age was
subjected to penetrative sexual abuse by the applicant. Referring to the
medical records, it was contended that the allegation is clearly
substantiated by the injuries noted by the doctor. The severity of the
allegations is highlighted by the learned Public Prosecutor to persuade this
Court to refuse bail to the applicants.
6. The principles, which the Court must consider while granting or
declining bail, have been stated by the Apex Court in a catena of cases. In
Prahlad Singh Bhati v. NCT, Delhi [(2001) 4 SCC 280], it was held
"The jurisdiction to grant bail has to be exercised on
the basis of well-settled principles having regard to
the circumstances of each case and not in an
arbitrary manner. While granting the bail, the court
has to keep in mind the nature of accusations, the
nature of the evidence in support thereof, the
severity of the punishment which conviction will
entail, the character, behaviour, means and standing
of the accused, circumstances which are peculiar to
BAIL APPL. NO. 3485 OF 2021 4
the accused, reasonable possibility of securing the
presence of the accused at the trial, reasonable
apprehension of the witnesses being tampered with,
the larger interests of the public or State and similar
other considerations. It has also to be kept in mind
that for the purposes of granting the bail the
legislature has used the words "reasonable grounds
for believing" instead of "the evidence" which means
the court dealing with the grant of bail can only
satisfy itself as to whether there is a genuine case
against the accused and that the prosecution will be
able to produce prima facie evidence in support of
the charge. It is not expected, at this stage, to have
the evidence establishing the guilt of the accused
beyond reasonable doubt. "

[case 17]
Smt. Tammanna And Another vs State Of U. P. And 5 Others on 30 July, 2019
? Court No. - 42
Case: - HABEAS CORPUS WRIT PETITION No. - 723 of 2019
Petitioner: - Smt. Tammanna And Another
Respondent: - State Of U. P. And 5 Others
Counsel for Petitioner: - Ved Mani Sharma
Counsel for Respondent: - G. A.
Hon'ble Manoj Misra, J.
Hon'ble Virendra Kumar Srivastava, J.
Heard learned counsel for the petitioners; the learned A. G. A. for the respondents 1 to 5; and perused the record.
This habeas corpus petition has been filed with multiple prayers, one of them is that a writ in the nature of certiorari be issued quashing the order dated 06. 07. 2019 passed by the Child Welfare Committee, Shahjahanpur by which the corpus Tammanna has been placed in the care and protection of Children Protection Home (Girls), Hathaura Bujurg, Shahjahanpur.
A perusal of the record would reveal that Case Crime No. 149 of 2019 was registered at P. S. Jalalabad, District Shahjahanpur, under Sections 363, 366 I. P. C. and section 7/8 Pocso Act on the FIR lodged by Asif (respondent no. 6), father of the corpus, wherein it was alleged that Tamanna (minor daughter of the informant) was enticed away by accused persons including the petitioner no. 2. The corpus was recovered and produced before the Child Welfare Committee. The Child Welfare Committee found that the educational certificate of the victim disclosed her date of birth as 08. 05. 2003 though medical examination of the victim suggested that she was above 18 years. The Child Welfare Committee accorded primacy to the date of birth entered in the educational certificate and, as the victim had refused to go with her parents, directed her placement in the Child Protection Home (girls) in exercise of power conferred by Section 37 (1)(c) of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 (for short J. J. Act, 2015)
Learned counsel for the petitioners has submitted that in a Criminal Misc. Writ Petition No. 9222 of 2019, the arrest of the accused (petitioner no. 2) has been stayed after considering the statement of the victim and the date of birth in her adhar card as per which she is an adult.
Learned A. G. A. has submitted that entry of date of birth entered in the adhar card is not conclusive with regard to its holder and as the age of a child victim is to be determined by applying the principles embodied in Section 94 of the J. J. Act, 2015, under which, primacy is to be accorded to date of birth entered in educational certificate over medical evidence, the order of the Child Welfare Committee is not illegal or perverse so as to warrant issuance of writ of habeas corpus or to invoke the writ jurisdiction, particularly, when alternative remedy is available under Section 101 of the J. J. Act, 2015.
Having noticed the rival submissions, before we proceed to address the issues, it would be apposite to observe that the Apex Court had consistently been of the view that the principles applicable for determining the age of juvenile in conflict with law are to be applied for determining the age of child victim (vide Jarnail Singh Vs. State of Haryana, (2013) 7 SCC 263; State of M. P. Vs. Anoop Singh, (2015) 7 SCC 773; and Mahadeo Vs. State of Maharashtra, (2013) 14 SCC 637).
Section 94 of the J. J. Act, 2015 provides for presumption and determination of age. Sub-section (2) of section 94 of the J. J. Act, 2015, which is relevant, is extracted below:
"(2) In case, the Committee or the Board has reasonable grounds for doubt regarding whether the person brought before it is a child or not, the Committee or the Board, as the case may be, shall undertake the process of age determination, by seeking evidence by obtaining--
(i) the date of birth certificate from the school, or the matriculation or equivalent certificate from the concerned examination Board, if available; and in the absence thereof;
(ii) the birth certificate given by a corporation or a municipal authority or a panchayat;
(iii) and only in the absence of (i) and (ii) above, age shall be determined by an ossification test or any other latest medical age determination test conducted on the orders of the Committee or the Board:
Provided such age determination test conducted on the order of the Committee or the Board shall be completed within fifteen days from the date of such order. "
From above, it is clear that primacy is to be accorded to the date of birth certificate from the school, or the matriculation or equivalent certificate from the concerned examination Board, and, in the absence thereof, to the birth certificate given by a corporation or municipality or panchayat. Only in absence of above evidence, medical evidence is to be taken.
Section 37 (1) (c) of the J. J. Act, 2015 empowers the Child Welfare Committee to place a child in need of care and protection in a Children's Home or fit facility for temporary care.
Section 2 (14) of the J. J. Act, 2015 defines a child in need of care and protection. Clauses (iii), (viii) (xii) of sub-section (14) of Section 2 of the J. J. Act, 2015 are relevant for the purpose of deciding this case. The said clauses along with the opening part of sub-section (14) of section 2 of the J. J. Act, 2015 are extracted below:
"Section 2(14) "child in need of care and protection" means a child--
(iii) who resides with a person (whether a guardian of the child or not) and such person--
(a) has injured, exploited, abused or neglected the child or has violated any other law for the time being in force meant for the protection of child; or
(b) has threatened to kill, injure, exploit or abuse the child and there is a reasonable likelihood of the threat being carried out; or
(c) has killed, abused, neglected or exploited some other child or children and there is a reasonable likelihood of the child in question being killed, abused, exploited or neglected by that person; or

[case 18]
Smt. Tammanna And Another vs State Of U. P. And 5 Others on 30 July, 2019
? Court No. - 42
Case: - HABEAS CORPUS WRIT PETITION No. - 723 of 2019
Petitioner: - Smt. Tammanna And Another
Respondent: - State Of U. P. And 5 Others
Counsel for Petitioner: - Ved Mani Sharma
Counsel for Respondent: - G. A.
Hon'ble Manoj Misra, J.
Hon'ble Virendra Kumar Srivastava, J.

[case 19]
Madhya Pradesh High Court Nikhil Sarathe vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 28 August, 2018 1 M. Cr. C. No. 16856 of 2017 HIGH COURT OF MADHYA PRADESH PRINCIPAL SEAT AT JABALPUR Single Bench: Hon'ble Shri Rajeev Kumar Dubey, J. Misc. Criminal Case No. 16856/2017 Nikhil Sarathe vs. State of M. P. and Others -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Shri Alok Bagrecha and Shri Pushpendra Dubey, learned counsel for the applicant. Shri Manish Awasthi, Govt. Advocate for the respondent/State. Shri Vivek Agrawal, learned counsel for the respondent no. 2/prosecutrix. None for the respondent No. 3/complainant though served. -------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- ORDER Reserved on: 21/08/2018 Delivered on: /08/2018 This petition has been filed under Section 482 of Cr. P. C. seeking quashing of the F. I. R. of crime No. 293/2016 registered at PS Kotwali Bhopal for the offence punishable under Sections 363, 376, 120-B, 212 of IPC and Section 3, 4 of POCSO Act and consequential proceedings thereto. Brief facts of the case are that on 29/12/2016, the father of the prosecutrix lodged a report at P. S. Kotwali Bhopal averring that his daughter (prosecutrix) age about 17 years was not at home since six 'o'clock in the morning and she was not found even after enough search. Someone had abducted her. On that police registered crime No. 293/16 for the offence punishable under section 363 of I. P. C. and investigated the matter and during investigation on 23/01/17 police rescued the prosecutrix from the custody of applicant and recorded the statement of the prosecutrix. In her statement prosecutrix stated that she had known applicant Nikhil for the last five years and there was a love affair between them. On 29th December 2016, Nikhil had asked him to escape from the house in order to marry with him. On this, around 5-6 o'clock in the morning without informing her family members she went to the Hawa Mahal, where she met Nikhil who took her to Arya Samaj Mandir situated at Nehru Nagar, where both of them got married, then they went to Shirdi where they stayed for four or five days. Thereafter they came back to Bhopal and stayed there for 5-6 days at Nikhil's friend's house situated at Neelbad area in Bhopal. During that period Nikhil also made physical relationship with her, after which Nikhil's friend Shubham (co-accused) took them to Jabalpur, where they stayed in the house of a person, who happened to be an acquaintance of Shubham, as a guest for 6-7 days. There too applicant Nikhil Had sex with her four to five times. On that police also added offences under section 368, 376, 120-B, 212 of IPC and Section 3, 4, 5, 6, 11 (i) and 12 of POCSO Act and after investigation of the crime police filed charge-sheet against the applicant. On that charge-sheet S. T. No. 28/18 was registered. Applicant is facing trial in that case before 7 th A. S. J. Bhopal and filed this petition for quashing the F. I. R. of the crime No. 293/16 registered at P. S. Kotwali Bhopal and the proceedings of S. T. No. 28/18. Learned counsel for the applicant submitted that the prosecutrix was major at the time of incident and went with the applicant on her own will. In the birth certificate of the prosecutrix, her date of birth is mentioned as 30/11/1998. According to that certificate, prosecutrix was major at the time of incident. The prosecutrix in her statement recorded by the JMFC under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. also deposed that she went with the applicant at her own will and she had married with applicant and is living with him. Since prosecutrix was major at the time of incident and went with applicant own her on will, no offences under Section 363, 376, 120-B, 212 of IPC and Section 3, 4 of POCSO Act is made out against the applicant. He further submitted that if it is assumed that the age of the prosecutrix was 17 years two months at the time of incident as appears on the basis of school entry register produced by the prosecution along with the charge sheet even then no offence is made out against the applicant from the charge-sheet because prosecutrix went with the applicant on her own will. In this regard, he also placed reliance on Delhi High Court judgment passed in Laxmi Devi & Anr. ; Maha Dev & Devender @ Babli v. State reported in (2012) DLT 619 and Apex Court judgment passed in Satish Mehra Vs. State reported in 2013 CrLJ 411, Rajeev Thaper Vs. Madan Lal reported in (2013) 3 SCC 330 and Independent thought Vs. Union of India reported in (2017) 10 SCC 800, and State of Karnataka Vs. L. Muniswamy and others reported in 1977 CRLJ 1125. Learned counsel for the prosecutrix also submitted that prosecutrix was major at the time of incident and went with the applicant on her own will and at present she is living with the applicant and also married with the him, so offence registered against the applicant should be quashed. Learned counsel for the State opposed the prayer and submitted that according to school entry register the date of birth of the prosecutrix is 23/10/1999 and on that basis the age of the prosecutrix was below 18 years at the time of incident i. e. 29/12/16 and she was minor at the time of incident. Applicant abducted the prosecutrix and made sexual relations with her, so offence under Section 368, 376 of IPC and Section 3/ 4 and 12 of POCSO is clearly made out against the applicant and prays for rejection of petition. This Court has gone through the record and arguments put forth by the learned counsel for both the parties. In the entry of school register, the date of prosecutrix is mentioned 23/10/1999 and on that basis the age of the prosecutrix appears to be below 18 years at the time of incident i. e. 29/12/16 and she was minor at the time of incident. Applicant took the prosecutrix and made sexual relations with her. Although applicant produced Birth certificate of the prosecutrix in which the date of birth of prosecutrix is mentioned as 30/11/1998 but authenticity of that certificate has to be tested and it requires evidence to decide. So at this stage only on that basis it can not be said that prosecutrix was major at the time of incident. Fact of the cases relied on by the learned counsel of the applicant do not match with the instant case. The case Laxmi Devi & Anr. ; Maha Dev & Devender @ Babli v. State (supra) relate to the incidents that occurred before November 2012 when POCSO Act was not in force. While this incident occurred on 29/12/2016 when POCSO Act had come into force and according to section 3 of the POCSO Act intercourse with a woman below 18 years of age is the offence irrespective of the fact that she is a wife of accused. in the case of Satish Mehra v. State (NCT of Delhi), (Supra) apex court held "charge sheet only quashed if the attending facts and circumstances satisfy the narrow test that even accepting all the allegations levelled by the prosecution, no offence is disclosed. While in this case offence under POCSO Act is prima facie made out against applicant. Because on the basis of school entry register and the statement of parents of the prosecutrix her age appeared to be below 18 years. In the case of Rajeev Thaper Vs. Madan Lal (supra) apex court held "To invoke its inherent jurisdiction under Section 482 CrPC, the High Court has to be fully satisfied that the material produced by the accused is such that would lead to the conclusion that his/their defence is based on sound, reasonable, and indubitable facts; but the material relied upon by the accused should be of sterling and impeccable quality. " While in this case the authenticity of birth certificate of the prosecutrix has to be proved which requires evidence. On the other hand prosecution produced entry of school admission register to prove the age of prosecutrix in which date of birth of prosecutrix is mentioned as 23/10/1999. In the case of Independent thought Vs. Union of India (Supra) apex court held that Exception 2 to Section 375 I. P. C. in so far as it relates to a girl child below 18 years is liable to be struck down on the following grounds: - (i) it is arbitrary, capricious, whimsical and violative of the rights of the girl child and not fair, just and reasonable and, therefore, violative of Article 14, 15 and 21 of the Constitution of India. In the case of State of Karnataka Vs. L. Muniswamy and others (supra) Apex court held that High Court is entitled to quash a proceeding if it comes to conclusion that allowing the proceeding to continue would be an abuse of the process of the court or that the ends of the justice requires that the preceding out to quashed. While in this case if it is proved that prosecutrix was below 18 years of age at the time of incident, there is sufficient evidence to proceed against the applicant in the case. So these judgements do not help applicant much. Hon'ble Supreme Court in the case of Yogendra Yadav and others vs. State of Jharkhand and another (2014) 9 SCC 653 held that offences which involve moral turpitude, grave offences like rape murder cannot be effaced by quashing proceedings under section 482 because they have harmful effect on society and are not restricted to two individuals or group quashing of such offences may send a wrong signal to society. In the case in hand prosecution produced the entry of school register along with charge sheet in which date of birth of prosecutrix is mentioned 23/10/1999 and on that basis the age of the prosecutrix appears to be below 18 years at the time of incident i. e. 29/12/16 and she was minor at the time of incident. Applicant took the prosecutrix along with him and made sexual relations with her. So from the charge sheet offence under section 3/4 of the POCSO Act is prima facie made out against the applicant. So FIR and the proceedings of S. T. No. 28/18 can not be quashed at this stage. Although applicant produced Birth certificate of the prosecutrix in which the date of birth of prosecutrix is mentioned as 30/11/1998 but authenticity of that certificate has to be tested and it requires evidence to decide. Applicant is free to raise this issue before trial court at the appropriate stage and produce the evidence in support of his defence which will consider by the trial court on merits. Accordingly, petition is disposed of. (Rajeev Kumar Dubey) Judge vs Digitally signed by VARSHA SINGH Date: 2018. 08. 29 17: 55: 33 +05'30'

[case 20]
Mahalakshmy P. C vs State Of Kerala on 21 February, 2025. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE C. JAYACHANDRAN FRIDAY, THE 21ST DAY OF FEBRUARY 2025 / 2ND PHALGUNA, 1946 CRL. MC NO. 925 OF 2024 CRIME NO. 811/2021 OF BINANIPURAM POLICE STATION, ERNAKULAM IN CC NO. 29 OF 2022 OF JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE OF FIRST CLASS-II, ALUVA PETITIONERS/ACCUSED: 1 MAHALAKSHMY P. C AGED 34 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT. , PIN - 683516 2 CHITHARANJAN AGED 66 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT. , PIN - 683516 3 SIVESWAR P. C AGED 30 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT, PIN - 683516 BY ADV N. P. PRAJEESH RESPONDENTS/COMPLAINANT: 1 STATE OF KERALA REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM, KOCHI. , PIN - 682031 2 SARASAMMA W/O MOHANAN, MOOPPAN PARAMBIL HOUSE, MUPPATHADAM, KADUNGALLUR P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT, PIN-683110 Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -2- THIS CRIMINAL MISC. CASE HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 21. 02. 2025, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -3- C. JAYACHANDRAN, J. ------------------------------------ Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 ------------------------------------ Dated, this the 21st day of February, 2025 ORDER The petitioners herein are the accused persons in Crime no. 811/2021 of Binanipuram Police Station (Annexure-I), now pending as C. C. No. 29/2022 before the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court-II, Aluva. The petitioners seek quashment of the said crime and all further proceedings therein. 2. Heard the learned Counsel for the petitioners and the learned Public Prosecutor. Perused the records. 3. Learned Counsel for the petitioners submits that, the 1st petitioner is the legally wedded wife of one Pramod, who is the son of the defacto complainant in the instant crime. There were matrimonial disputes and due to harassment, the 1st petitioner/1st accused left the matrimonial home and started residing in her parental home. Petitioners 2 and 3 are her father and brother respectively, who were accused nos. 2 and 3 in the subject Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -4- crime. The 1st petitioner got information that during the subsistence of marriage with her, her husband Pramod is going to remarry. Accordingly, she lodged Annexure-V complaint before the jurisdictional Police, seeking police protection, so as to enable her to go back to the matrimonial home and reside there. Accordingly, on 06. 07. 2021, at 2 p. m, the petitioners reached the matrimonial home, where she was cruelly manhandled by the present defacto complainant, her husband and neighbours. A case has been registered in respect of the incident as Crime no. 810/2021 (Annexure-VII). According to the learned Counsel, the instant crime bearing no. 811/2021 is a counter blast to the same. It was also pointed out that the allegations leveled in the F. I. S. are trivial in nature, as against the 1st accused. There is no allegation, whatsoever, as against accused nos. 2 and 3 (petitioners 2 and 3), except that they have not opposed the acts of the 1st petitioner/1st accused. Learned Counsel would submit that, a perusal of Annexure-VII F. I. R. would indicate that it was the petitioners herein, who were abused and manhandled by the defacto complainant and others. Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -5- 4. This application was seriously opposed by the learned Public Prosecutor. 5. Having heard the learned Counsel appearing for the respective parties, this Court finds that the Crl. M. C. is liable to be allowed in part, as against petitioners 2 and 3. This Court perused the F. I. S. , which forms part of Annexure-I F. I. R. The allegations constituting the crime are extracted here below: " (06. 11. 2009)       ,    .            .          .                 .                         .               . " Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -6- 6. It could be seen from the above that the solitary allegation against the petitioners 2 and 3 (accused nos. 2 and 3) is that, they spoke in support of the 1 st accused/1st petitioner. The offences alleged are under Sections 323, 447, 341, read with Section 34 of the Penal code. This Court fails to understand as to how the Investigating Officer has concluded, on the basis of the above referred solitary statement contained in the F. I. S. , that accused nos. 2 and 3 have committed the offences alleged. This Court cannot, but observe that the Investigating Officer was so casual in arriving at the complicity of petitioners 2 and 3 (accused nos. 2 and 3). There exists no material, which would tend to implicate the said persons. It may have to be observed that the Investigating Officer has acted in tune with the sinister motive of the defacto complainant, insofar as their allegations against petitioners 2 and 3 are concerned. Thinking from another angle, the mischief is done by the Investigating Officer; and not by the defacto complainant. The defacto complainant has only stated the true facts. It was for the Investigating Officer to arrive at a conclusion that such allegation that petitioners 2 and 3 spoke in favour of A1 (daughter of A2 and sister of A3) was only a natural reaction, incapable of constituting any crime as alleged. 7. The outcome of the above discussion is that the proceedings against petitioners 2 and 3 vide Crime no. 811/2024 - now pending as C. C. no. 29/2022 before the Judicial First Class Magistrate Court-II, Aluva - cannot be sustained. The same is hereby quashed. 8. Coming to 1st petitioner/1st accused, there is an allegation that she caught hold of the hand of the defacto complainant and pushed down herself and her son Pramod. This Court is not in a position to ascertain the veracity of the submission that the said allegations, as also, the instant crime, is only a counter blast to Annexure-VII crime. That is a matter which has to be evolved during the course of evidence. In the circumstances, the prayer sought for, insofar as the 1 st petitioner/1st accused is concerned, cannot be allowed and the Crl. M. C. will stand dismissed as against the 1st petitioner/1st accused. However, the same will stand allowed, as already indicated, against petitioners 2 and 3. 9. Learned Counsel for the petitioners submits that, the 1st petitioner/1st accused is having a child, aged ten years and her personal appearance may be exempted, except for crucial dates. The said relief is only to be allowed. Accordingly, the personal appearance of the 1st petitioner/1st accused will stand exempted. However, during the course of trial, the 1 st petitioner/1st accused shall be present. On any other date, if the 1st petitioner's presence is found necessary, the learned Magistrate will notify the same, on which date the 1st petitioner/1st accused shall be present. With the above directions, the Crl. M. C. will stand disposed of. Sd/- C. JAYACHANDRAN JUDGE SKP/24-02 Crl. M. C. No. 925 of 2024 2025: KER: 15509 -9- APPENDIX OF CRL.
