M. C NO. 1111/2022 ANNEXURE-IX CERTIFIED COPY OF THE FINAL REPORT IN CRIME NO. 554/2015 OF BINANI PURAM POLICE STATION DATED 04. 09. 2015 TRUE COPY P. A. TO JUDGE

[case 21]
This application under Section 482 of Cr. P. C. / 528 of BNSS has been filed seeking quashment of FIR in Crime No. 273/2019 registered at Police Station Mahila Thana, Gwalior for offence under Sections 498-A, 506 and 34 of IPC and under Section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act. It is submitted by counsel for the applicants that charge-sheet has been filed and on one occasion although the complainant was present but her evidence could not be recorded at the request of counsel for the applicants. According to prosecution case the respondent No. 2 lodged an FIR on 15/11/2019 alleging inter alia that she got married to the applicant No. 1 on 7/5/2014 in accordance with Hindu rites and rituals. At the time of her marriage, her father had given sufficient dowry including household articles and gold ornaments as per the demand raised by the applicants. In all approximately an amount of Rs. 22 lacs was spent. A car was also given which is still in possession of the applicants. Applicants were not happy with the articles which were given in dowry and therefore they started harassing her physically and mentally by alleging that less dowry and less cash amount has been given. Applicant No. 2 was posted as a Deputy Ranger in Forest Department, whereas, applicant No. 3 is a housewife. They used to pass taunts frequently on the ground that she has come from the house of a beggar and sufficient dowry has not been given. They were demanding Rs. 5 lacs and a gold chain of 3 Tolas. However, she continued to live in her matrimonial house in spite of mental harassment and cruelty and she gave birth to a girl child on 5/9/2015. All the delivery expenses were borne by her father and now the applicants have kept the daughter with them against the wishes of respondent No. 2 and they are not permitting her to meet with her. A lot of efforts were made for compromise and accordingly out of love and affection towards her daughter, she went to her matrimonial house on 29/9/2019; where, the applicants did not allow her to meet with her daughter and insisted that unless and until she brings an amount of Rs. 5 lacs and a gold chain of 3 Tolas, she should not come back otherwise, she should stay back in her parental home. The applicant No. 1 also assaulted her on that issue. A threat was also extended that in case if any effort is made in future to meet her daughter then she would be killed. Accordingly, an application was given to the Police Station and case was fixed for reconciliation on 4/9/2019 but the reconciliation failed. Challenging the FIR, it is submitted by counsel for the applicants that the applicants had issued a notice on 10/8/2017 and immediately thereafter she made a complaint on 13/8/2017 and reconciliation proceedings were undertaken. Copy of the reconciliation proceedings have been placed on record. It is submitted that in the reconciliation proceedings, it was alleged by respondent No. 2 that she is being harassed by the applicants but the applicant No. 1 refuted the same and also expressed that he can reside separately from applicants No. 2 and 3. On 27/8/2017, applicant No. 1 informed that they had resided for some time but now the respondent No. 2 has gone back to her parental home and on 10/9/2017, both the parties expressed that they are residing amicably and peacefully. It is submitted that the applicant No. 1 had taken a house on rent and had started residing separately with respondent No. 2, therefore, from year 2017, applicants No. 2 and 3 have separated themselves from applicant No. 1, therefore, there is no question of demand of dowry or committing cruelty. Per contra, the application is vehemently opposed by counsel for the State. It is submitted that where the allegations make out a cognizable offence, then the FIR can be lodged. In the present case there is a specific allegation that the applicants had treated the respondent No. 2 with cruelty. The extent of cruelty has gone to the extent of separating her daughter from respondent No. 2 and they had not allowed her to even meet her. In absence of any order from the Court with regard to custody of daughter, the conduct of the applicants in forcibly separating a minor daughter aged about 2-3 years from her mother, who is the natural guardian itself would amount to cruelty. Respondent No. 2 is being compelled to reside in her parental home, therefore, it is clear that all the applicants are guilty of committing cruelty and thus, no case is made out for quashment of FIR. Heard learned counsel for the parties. So far as the submission that the applicant No. 1 had taken a house on rent and had started residing separately after the reconciliation proceedings which took place in year 2017 is concerned, the applicants have not filed any document to show that any separate house on rent was taken. Thus, the verbal submissions made by counsel for the applicants that the applications No. 2 and 3 have started residing separately from the year 2017 is misconceived and cannot be accepted at this stage. Furthermore, in the FIR, it is specifically mentioned that on 29/9/2019 when she went to her matrimonial house in order to meet her daughter then not only she was abused in filthy language but she was beaten by applicant No. 1. Separating a mother from her 2-3 years old minor daughter without any order from the Court by itself would be a cruelty because mother being the natural guardian is entitled for the custody of her minor daughter. Be that whatever it may be. Compelling a married woman to live in her parental home on account of non-fulfillment of demand of dowry by itself is a cruelty. The Supreme Court in the case of Rupali Devi v. State of U. P. , reported in (2019) 5 SCC 384 has held as under: "Cruelty which is the crux of the offence under Section 498-A IPC is defined in Black's Law Dictionary to mean the intentional and malicious infliction of mental or physical suffering on a living creature, esp. a human; abusive treatment; outrage (abuse, inhuman treatment, indignity)". Cruelty can be both physical or mental cruelty. The impact on the mental health of the wife by overt acts on the part of the husband or his relatives; the mental stress and trauma of being driven away from the matrimonial home and her helplessness to go back to the same home for fear of being ill-treated are aspects that cannot be ignored while understanding the meaning of the expression "cruelty" appearing in Section 498-A of the Penal Code. The emotional distress or psychological effect on the wife, if not the physical injury, is bound to continue to traumatise the wife even after she leaves the matrimonial home and takes shelter at the parental home. Even if the acts of physical cruelty committed in the matrimonial house may have ceased and such acts do not occur at the parental home, there can be no doubt that the mental trauma and the psychological distress caused by the acts of the husband including verbal exchanges, if any, that had compelled the wife to leave the matrimonial home and take shelter with her parents would continue to persist at the parental home. Mental cruelty borne out of physical cruelty or abusive and humiliating verbal exchanges would continue in the parental home even though there may not be any overt act of physical cruelty at such place. This Court in the case of Amar Singh vs. Smt. Vimla decided on 22. 06. 2021 in Criminal Revision No. 2376/2020 (Gwalior Bench) has held that compelling a married woman to live in her parental home amounts to cruelty. The Supreme Court in the case of Taramani Parakh Vs. State of M. P. and Ors. has held as under: "The law relating to quashing is well settled. If the allegations are absurd or do not make out any case or if it can be held that there is abuse of process of law, the proceedings can be quashed but if there is a triable case the court does not go into reliability or otherwise of the version or the counter-version. In matrimonial cases, the courts have to be cautious when omnibus allegations are made particularly against relatives who are not generally concerned with the affairs of the couple. We may refer to the decisions of this Court dealing with the issue. " Furthermore, it is well established principle of law that at the stage of quashment of FIR or the proceedings under Section 482 of Cr. P. C. , this Court has to consider uncontroverted allegations and only if the uncontroverted allegations do not make out an offence then the proceedings can be quashed. This Court has already considered the allegations made in the FIR. Trial is pending and whenever the complainant appeared before the trial Court, applicants ensured that her evidence is not recorded. Under these circumstances, where the FIR makes out a cognizable offence, this Court is of considered opinion that no case is made out warranting interference. Application fails and is hereby dismissed.

[case 22]
By this common order, both the aforesaid criminal revisions are being decided. Both the criminal revisions arise out of order dated 23. 07. 2019 passed by the Principal Judge, Family Court, Bhind (M. P. ) in Case No. 138/2017 MJCR by which application for grant of maintenance under Section 125 of Cr. P. C. filed by Smt. Priyanka Rajawat has been rejected on the ground that she is residing separately without any reasonable reason whereas Virat Rajawat has been granted maintenance at the rate of 4, 000/- per month. Criminal Revision No. 5206 of 2019 has been filed by Rahul Singh @ Vijay Singh Rajawat who is husband of respondent No. 1-Smt. Priyanka Rajawat and father of respondent No. 2-Virat Rajawat against maintenance amount awarded to his son respondent No. 2-Virat Rajawat whereas Criminal Revision No. 4107 of 2019 has been filed by Smt. Priyanka Rajawat and Virat Rajawat against the rejection of claim of applicant No. 1-Smt. Priyanka Rajawat for maintenance under Section 125 of Cr. P. C. The facts of Criminal Revision No. 5206 of 2019 shall be referred to. The undisputed facts are that applicant- Rahul Singh @ Vijay Singh Rajawat and respondent No. 1-Smt. Priyanka Rajawat are the legally wedded husband and wife whereas respondent No. 2-Virat is the child born out of their wedlock. Respondents No. 1 and 2 filed an application under Section 125 of Cr. P. C. alleging that respondent No. 1 and applicant got married on 30. 04. 2015 in accordance with Hindu rites and rituals. It is the case of respondent No. 1 that applicant as well as his family members were not satisfied with the dowry brought by her. They were alleging that a four wheeler vehicle was decided to be given in dowry which was not done. Accordingly, it was alleged that applicant and his family members were harassing her physically and mentally. Even after respondent No. 1 got pregnant, still the cruelty did not come to an end. The entire expenses of delivery were borne by respondent No. 1 and her family members. Panchayats were convened and accordingly for sometime respondent no. 1 was kept properly but thereafter she was continuously harassed physically and mentally. On 23. 05. 2017 at about 06: 00 pm when respondent No. 1 was in her matrimonial house then her mother-in-law and father-in-law abused her filthily and after assaulting her by fists and blows turned her out of her matrimonial house along with her small child. It was alleged that respondent No. 1 does not have any independent source of livelihood whereas applicant is working as Panchayat Secretary earning a monthly salary of Rs. 15, 000/-. Apart from that he is having land and house and accordingly, it was alleged that applicant is having monthly income of Rs. 30, 000-35, 000/-. Applicant- Rahul filed his reply and denied the allegations. It was alleged that in fact it was respondent No. 1 who was creating all sorts of nuisance in the house. It was also stated that the delivery expenses were borne by applicant. It was further alleged that respondent No. 1 had voluntarily left the house. On 14. 01. 2017 and on 04. 06. 2017, he also went to the house of parents of respondent No. 1 to bring her back but she did not come back. Accordingly, it was alleged that he has filed an application under Section 9 of the Hindu Marriage Act for restitution of conjugal rights. The Trial Court, after recording the statements of witnesses, rejected the application filed by respondent No. 1 whereas allowed the application filed respondent No. 2 and awarded Rs. 4, 000/- per month as maintenance. The reason for rejecting the claim of respondent No. 1 was that she was residing separately without any reasonable reason. Challenging the order passed by the Trial Court in granting monthly maintenance of Rs. 4, 000 to respondent No. 2, it was submitted by counsel for applicant that since respondent No. 1 is residing separately without any reasonable reason, therefore, respondent No. 2 is also not entitled for maintenance, whereas in Criminal Revision No. 4107 of 2019 it was contended by counsel for Smt. Priyanka Rajawat that Trial Court has committed material illegality by holding that she was residing separately without any reasonable reason. In reply, it was submitted by counsel for applicant-Rahul Singh Rajawat (respondent in Criminal Revision No. 4107 of 2019) that finding with regard to non-entitlement of Smt. Priyanka Rajawat to get the maintenance is based on sound principles of law and reasoning and therefore does not require any interference. Undisputedly, Virat Rajawat is minor boy born out of wedlock of Smt. Priyanka Rajawat and Rahul Singh Rajawat. He cannot be held responsible for any dispute which is going on between husband and wife. The father is under an obligation to maintain his child. Furthermore, it is the case of respondent No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat that monthly income of Rahul Singh Rajawat is 30, 000-35000/-. Accordingly, this Court is of the considered opinion that looking to the age of Virat Rajawat, the maintenance amount of Rs. 4, 000/- per month awarded by the Trial Court cannot be said to be either on lower side or on higher side. Accordingly, the maintenance amount of Rs. 4, 000/- per month awarded to Virat Rajawat is hereby affirmed. It is the case of applicant Rahul Singh Rajawat that it was respondent No. 1 Smt. Priyanka Rajawat who voluntarily left her matrimonial house and her behaviour towards her in-laws was also not proper. It was further submitted that an FIR was also lodged under Section 498A of IPC because father of respondent No. 1 Smt. Priyanka Rajawat is working as a Head Constable. Per contra, it is submitted by counsel for respondent No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat that merely because of an application under Section 9 of Hindu Marriage Act was filed would not mean that respondent No. 1 Smt. Priyanka Rajawat left her matrimonial house on her own volition. However, it is further submitted that even the application under Section 9 of Hindu Marriage Act was withdrawn by her husband Rahul Singh Rajawat. Considered the submissions made by counsel for the parties. The moot question for consideration is as to whether merely filing an application under Section 9 of Hindu Marriage Act would make the wife ineligible for grant of maintenance or not? If wife is being treated with cruelty then she cannot be compelled to live in her matrimonial house. Under these circumstances, mere filing of an application under Section 9 of Hindu Marriage Act ipso facto would not make the wife disentitled for grant of maintenance. Supreme Court in the case of Rina Kumari @ Rina Devi @ Reena Vs Dinesh Kumar Mahto @ Dinesh Kumar Mahato and another, Special Leave Petition (Crl. ) No. 5896 of 2024 decided on 10. 01. 2025, has held that even if decree under Section 9 of Hindu Marriage has been passed, still the wife can claim maintenance amount. Where the parties are at loggerheads and an FIR under Section 498A of IPC has also been lodged, under these circumstances, this Court is of the considered opinion that rejection of claim of respondent No. 1 (Smt. Priyanka Rajawat) for grant of maintenance appears to be contrary to law. The reasoning assigned by the Trial Court for holding that respondent No. 1-Smt. Priyanka Rajawat was living separately without any reasonable reason cannot be affirmed. Under these circumstances, order dated 23. 07. 2019 with regard to rejection of claim of respondent No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat for grant of maintenance cannot be upheld and it is accordingly set aside. Now, the next question for consideration is that what should be the maintenance amount for respondent No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat? According to respondent No. 1-Smt. Priyanka Rajawat, monthly income of applicant- Rahul Singh Rajawat is Rs. 30, 000-35000/-. Although it is the contention of applicant-Rahul Singh Rajawat that father of respondent No. 1 is working as Head Constable in police department and therefore, she is not ready to adjust in the family of applicant but during the course of arguments it was also admitted by applicant that his father is also working in the police department. Under these circumstances, this Court is of considered opinion that monthly maintenance amount of Rs. 6, 000/- to respondent No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat would be sufficient. Accordingly, it is held that respondent No. 1-Priyanka Rajawat is entitled for monthly maintenance at the rate of Rs. 6, 000/-. In the light of judgment passed by the Supreme Court in the case of Rajnesh Vs. Neha reported in (2021) 2 SCC 324, the aforesaid amount shall be payable from the date of application. With aforesaid observations, Criminal Revision No. 5206 of 2019 is hereby dismissed whereas Criminal Revision No. 4107 of 2019 is allowed to the extent of applicant No. 1- Smt. Priyanka Rajawat. No order as to costs.

[case 23]
Case: - CRIMINAL MISC ANTICIPATORY BAIL APPLICATION U/S 438 CR. P. C. No. - 5511 of 2021
Applicant: - Chokhelal
Opposite Party: - State of U. P.
Counsel for Applicant: - Pushpendra Singh
Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A.
Hon'ble Siddharth, J.
As per Resolution dated 07. 04. 2021 of the Committee of this Court for the purpose of taking preventive and remedial measures and for combating the impending threat of Covid-19, this case is being heard by way of virtual mode.
Heard learned counsel for the applicant and learned A. G. A for the State through video conferencing.
The instant anticipatory bail application has been filed on behalf of the applicant, Chokhelal, with a prayer to release him on bail in Case Crime No. 338 of 2018, under Section-363, 366, 376 I. P. C. , and section 4 of POCSO Act and 3(2) (V) of SC/ST Act Police Station- Dewarnia, District-Bareilly, during pendency of trial.
Prior notice of this bail application was served in the office of Government Advocate and as per Chapter XVIII, Rule 18 of the Allahabad High Court Rules and as per direction dated 20. 11. 2020 of this Court in Criminal Misc. Anticipatory Bail Application U/S 438 Cr. P. C. No. 8072 of 2020, Govind Mishra @ Chhotu Versus State of U. P. , hence, this anticipatory bail application is being heard. Grant of further time to the learned A. G. A as per Section 438 (3) Cr. P. C. (U. P. Amendment) is not required.
There is allegation of enticement of minor girl against the applicant. Learned counsel for the applicant has submitted that at the relevant time the girl was not minor. She has married with the applicant. The applicant has been falsely implicated in this case. The victim has not supported the prosecution case in her statement under section 164 Cr. P. C. . The present application is supported by the affidavit of the girl herself. A child has been born out of their wedlock. Therefore, it would not be in the interest of justice not to grant protection to the applicant since there is no one to look after his family. She is living with the applicant. The charge sheet has already been submitted against the applicant. The applicant will cooperate with the trial. He has no criminal history to his credit. The applicant has a definite apprehension that he may be arrested by the police any time.
Learned A. G. A. has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail of the applicant. He has submitted that in view of the seriousness of the allegations made against the applicant, he is not entitled to grant of anticipatory bail. The apprehension of the applicant is not founded on any material on record. Only on the basis of imaginary fear, anticipatory bail cannot be granted.
After considering the rival submissions, this Court finds that there is a case registered against the applicant. It cannot be definitely said when the police may apprehend him. After the lodging of F. I. R, the arrest can be made by the police at will. There is no definite period fixed for the police to arrest an accused against whom an F. I. R has been lodged. The courts have repeatedly held that arrest should be the last option for the police and it should be restricted to those exceptional cases where arresting the accused is imperative or his custodial interrogation is required. Irrational and indiscriminate arrests are gross violation of human rights. In the case of Joginder Kumar v. State of Uttar Pradesh AIR 1994 SC 1349, the Apex Court has referred to the third report of National Police Commission wherein it is mentioned that arrests by the police in India is one of the chief sources of corruption in the police. The report suggested that, by and large, nearly 60 percent of the arrests were either unnecessary or unjustified and that such unjustified police action accounted for 43. 2 percent of expenditure of the jails. Personal liberty is a very precious fundamental right and it should be curtailed only when it becomes imperative. According to the peculiar facts and circumstances of the case, the arrest of an accused should be made.
Hence without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case and considering the nature of accusations and antecedents of applicant and also the second surge in the cases of novel coronavirus and possibility of further surge of the pandemic, he is directed to be enlarged on anticipatory bail as per the Constitution Bench judgment of the Apex Court in the case of Sushila Aggarwal vs. State (NCT of Delhi)- 2020 SCC Online SC 98. The future contingencies regarding anticipatory bail being granted to applicant shall also be taken care of as per the aforesaid judgment of the Apex Court.
In the event of arrest, the applicant shall be released on anticipatory bail. Let the applicant involved in the aforesaid crime be released on anticipatory bail on furnishing a personal bond with two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the trial court concerned with the following conditions: -
1. The applicant shall, at the time of execution of the bond, furnish his address and mobile number and shall not change the residence till the conclusion of investigation/ trial without informing the Investigating Officer of the police/ the Court concerned of change of address and the reasons for the same before changing the same.
2. The applicant shall not leave the country during the pendency of trial/investigation by police without prior permission from the concerned trial Court.
3. The applicant shall not obstruct or hamper the police investigation and not play mischief with the evidence collected or yet to be collected by the Investigating Officer of the police;
4. The applicant shall surrender his passport, if any, to the concerned Court/Investigating Officer forthwith. His passport will remain in custody of the concerned Court/ Investigating Officer till the investigation is completed. In case he has no passport, he will file his affidavit before the Court/ Investigating Officer concerned in this regard.
5. That the applicant shall not, directly or indirectly, make any inducement, threat or promise to any person acquainted with the facts of the case so as to dissuade him from disclosing such facts to the Court or to any police officer;

[case 24]
Case: - CRIMINAL MISC ANTICIPATORY BAIL APPLICATION U/S 438 CR. P. C. No. - 5511 of 2021

4. The applicant shall surrender his passport, if any, to the concerned Court/Investigating Officer forthwith. His passport will remain in custody of the concerned Court/ Investigating Officer till the investigation is completed. In case he has no passport, he will file his affidavit before the Court/ Investigating Officer concerned in this regard.
5. That the applicant shall not, directly or indirectly, make any inducement, threat or promise to any person acquainted with the facts of the case so as to dissuade him from disclosing such facts to the Court or to any police officer;

[case 25]
Case: - CRIMINAL MISC ANTICIPATORY BAIL APPLICATION U/S 438 CR. P. C. No. - 5511 of 2021
Applicant: - Chokhelal
Opposite Party: - State of U. P.
Counsel for Applicant: - Pushpendra Singh
Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A.
Hon'ble Siddharth, J.
As per Resolution dated 07. 04. 2021 of the Committee of this Court for the purpose of taking preventive and remedial measures and for combating the impending threat of Covid-19, this case is being heard by way of virtual mode.
Heard learned counsel for the applicant and learned A. G. A for the State through video conferencing.
The instant anticipatory bail application has been filed on behalf of the applicant, Chokhelal, with a prayer to release him on bail in Case Crime No. 338 of 2018, under Section-363, 366, 376 I. P. C. , and section 4 of POCSO Act and 3(2) (V) of SC/ST Act Police Station- Dewarnia, District-Bareilly, during pendency of trial.
Prior notice of this bail application was served in the office of Government Advocate and as per Chapter XVIII, Rule 18 of the Allahabad High Court Rules and as per direction dated 20. 11. 2020 of this Court in Criminal Misc. Anticipatory Bail Application U/S 438 Cr. P. C. No. 8072 of 2020, Govind Mishra @ Chhotu Versus State of U. P. , hence, this anticipatory bail application is being heard. Grant of further time to the learned A. G. A as per Section 438 (3) Cr. P. C. (U. P. Amendment) is not required.
There is allegation of enticement of minor girl against the applicant. Learned counsel for the applicant has submitted that at the relevant time the girl was not minor. She has married with the applicant. The applicant has been falsely implicated in this case. The victim has not supported the prosecution case in her statement under section 164 Cr. P. C. . The present application is supported by the affidavit of the girl herself. A child has been born out of their wedlock. Therefore, it would not be in the interest of justice not to grant protection to the applicant since there is no one to look after his family. She is living with the applicant. The charge sheet has already been submitted against the applicant. The applicant will cooperate with the trial. He has no criminal history to his credit. The applicant has a definite apprehension that he may be arrested by the police any time.
Learned A. G. A. has opposed the prayer for anticipatory bail of the applicant. He has submitted that in view of the seriousness of the allegations made against the applicant, he is not entitled to grant of anticipatory bail. The apprehension of the applicant is not founded on any material on record. Only on the basis of imaginary fear, anticipatory bail cannot be granted.
After considering the rival submissions, this Court finds that there is a case registered against the applicant. It cannot be definitely said when the police may apprehend him. After the lodging of F. I. R, the arrest can be made by the police at will. There is no definite period fixed for the police to arrest an accused against whom an F. I. R has been lodged. The courts have repeatedly held that arrest should be the last option for the police and it should be restricted to those exceptional cases where arresting the accused is imperative or his custodial interrogation is required. Irrational and indiscriminate arrests are gross violation of human rights. In the case of Joginder Kumar v. State of Uttar Pradesh AIR 1994 SC 1349, the Apex Court has referred to the third report of National Police Commission wherein it is mentioned that arrests by the police in India is one of the chief sources of corruption in the police. The report suggested that, by and large, nearly 60 percent of the arrests were either unnecessary or unjustified and that such unjustified police action accounted for 43. 2 percent of expenditure of the jails. Personal liberty is a very precious fundamental right and it should be curtailed only when it becomes imperative. According to the peculiar facts and circumstances of the case, the arrest of an accused should be made.
Hence without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case and considering the nature of accusations and antecedents of applicant and also the second surge in the cases of novel coronavirus and possibility of further surge of the pandemic, he is directed to be enlarged on anticipatory bail as per the Constitution Bench judgment of the Apex Court in the case of Sushila Aggarwal vs. State (NCT of Delhi)- 2020 SCC Online SC 98. The future contingencies regarding anticipatory bail being granted to applicant shall also be taken care of as per the aforesaid judgment of the Apex Court.
In the event of arrest, the applicant shall be released on anticipatory bail. Let the applicant involved in the aforesaid crime be released on anticipatory bail on furnishing a personal bond with two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the trial court concerned with the following conditions: -
1. The applicant shall, at the time of execution of the bond, furnish his address and mobile number and shall not change the residence till the conclusion of investigation/ trial without informing the Investigating Officer of the police/ the Court concerned of change of address and the reasons for the same before changing the same.
2. The applicant shall not leave the country during the pendency of trial/investigation by police without prior permission from the concerned trial Court.
3. The applicant shall not obstruct or hamper the police investigation and not play mischief with the evidence collected or yet to be collected by the Investigating Officer of the police;
4. The applicant shall surrender his passport, if any, to the concerned Court/Investigating Officer forthwith. His passport will remain in custody of the concerned Court/ Investigating Officer till the investigation is completed. In case he has no passport, he will file his affidavit before the Court/ Investigating Officer concerned in this regard.
5. That the applicant shall not, directly or indirectly, make any inducement, threat or promise to any person acquainted with the facts of the case so as to dissuade him from disclosing such facts to the Court or to any police officer;

[case 26]
Shri. Kamlesh Prabhakar Paradkar vs Smt. Sapana Dayanand Sawant Alias on 20 November, 2024
IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA, DHARWAD BENCH DATED THIS THE 20TH DAY OF NOVEMBER, 2024 PRESENT THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE H. T. NARENDRA PRASAD AND THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE VENKATESH NAIK T MISCELLANEOUS FIRST APPEAL NO. 100826 OF 2021 (MC)
BETWEEN: SHRI. KAMLESH PRABHAKAR PARADKAR AGE: 46 YEARS, OCC: SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH ASSISTANT, C/O. PRABHAKAR NANA PARADKAR, A-22, SARVAMANGAL C. H. S. , 6TH FLOOR, LOK PRIYA PARK, BHANDUP VILLAGE, BHANDUP EAST, MUMBAI-400042, MAHARASHTRA. .. .APPELLANT (BY SRI. A. A. KALEBUDDE, ADVOCATE)
AND: SMT. SAPANA DAYANAND SAWANT @ PREETI W/O. KAMLESH PARADKAR, AGED 39 YEARS, OCC: SERVICE, R/O. JOSHIWADA, NANDANGADDA, KARWAR-581301, DIST: UTTARA KANNADA, KARNATAKA. .. .RESPONDENT (NOTICE TO RESPONDENT HELD SUFFICIENT) THIS MFA IS FILED U/S. 28 OF THE HINDU MARRIAGE ACT, 1955, AGAINST THE JUDGEMENT AND DECREE DATED 23. 03. 2020 PASSED IN MATRIMONIAL CASE NO. 44/2015 ON THE FILE OF THE PRINCIPAL SENIOR CIVIL JUDGE, KARWAR, PARTLY ALLOWING THE PETITION FILED U/SEC. 13(1)(ia)(ib) OF THE HINDU MARRIAGE ACT, 1955. THIS APPEAL, COMING ON FOR ORDERS, THIS DAY, JUDGMENT WAS DELIVERED THEREIN AS UNDER: CORAM: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE H. T. NARENDRA PRASAD AND THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE VENKATESH NAIK T ORAL JUDGMENT (PER: THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE VENKATESH NAIK T) This appeal is filed by the husband challenging the judgment and decree dated 23. 03. 2020 passed in M. C. No. 44/2015 by the learned Principal Senior Civil Judge, Karwar, allowing the petition filed by the wife under Section 13(1)(ia) and (ib) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 (hereinafter referred to as 'the Act', for short) dissolving the marriage solemnized between the appellant and the respondent on 23. 06. 2007. The appellant/husband was the respondent and the respondent/wife was the petitioner in M. C. No. 44/2015 before the Family Court. For the sake of convenience, the parties are referred to as per their rank before the Family Court henceforth. Brief facts of the case are that, the marriage of the petitioner with the respondent was solemnized on 23. 06. 2007 at Jain Mandir, LBS Road, Bhandup West Mumbai as per Hindu rites, rituals and custom prevailed in their community. The petitioner is a B. Com graduate and the respondent is a B. E. Mechanical Engineer and working as Scientific Research Assistant for Baba Atomic Research Centre at Mumbai. After marriage, the petitioner was taken to flat of the respondent at No. A/22, Sarvamangal CHS, 6th floor, Bhandu. Since the brothers and their wives of the respondent were employed, the petitioner was put under pressure to secure a job. The respondent and his mother hit the petitioner, abused and adversely compared her with the daughter-in-law who was working as steno in the Ministry. The petitioner secured job at S. K. Group company on monthly salary of Rs. 5, 000/-. After sometime she became pregnant and she had to quit the job. The respondent and his mother were against the pregnancy and pressurized the petitioner to terminate the pregnancy to which she did not agree. Therefore, the petitioner hit the petitioner with broom, due to which she started bleeding. The respondent did not take the petitioner for medical treatment and she herself got admitted to the hospital and the respondent and his family members did not assist the petitioner in any way. The mother of the petitioner requested the respondent to be kind with the petitioner, but the respondent continued to abuse and ill treat the petitioner. It is contended that the respondent is actively participating with black magic with the help of Babas and Maulvis. The respondent took the petitioner to them and also to psychiatrist and enquired the doctors about aborting the child. Therefore, the petitioner came to her parental house at Karwar at seven months of pregnancy and gave birth to a baby boy and neither the respondent nor his family members attended the cradle ceremony on 05. 06. 2008. After three months, the petitioner returned to house of the respondent. It is contended that the child was admitted to an expensive school by the respondent and he took money from the petitioner for the fees and due to the extravagant behaviour of the respondent, the petitioner had to take up employment with Manha finance and later at Forties Hospital Pvt. Ltd. On 23. 08. 2015, the respondent beat the petitioner and driven out her from the house. Police complaint was also lodged in that regard and she has taken shelter at Sri. Mukti Sangathana and after intervention of police and Sangathana, she went to live with the respondent. After a couple of days, he thrashed her again with slipper in front of the maid servant who rescued her and unable to bear the same, she returned to her parental home at Karwar. Hence, she filed a petition seeking a decree for dissolution of her marriage with the respondent. After institution of the petition before the Family Court, the respondent/husband appeared through counsel and filed a detailed objection admitting their marriage, qualification and the child born out of their wedlock but, however, denied the allegation of use of abusive words, assault and harassment both physically and mentally. The petitioner, in order to prove her case, got examined herself as PW-1 and got marked three document as Exs. P1 to P-3. On behalf of the respondent, the respondent except examining himself as RW. 1, did not produce any documents. The Family Court after considering the oral and documentary evidence on record, allowed the petition in part by awarding decree of divorce and granting permanent alimony of Rs. 10, 00, 000/- to the petitioner. Being aggrieved by the impugned order, the respondent/husband has filed this appeal. Learned counsel for appellant/husband vehemently contended that, the petitioner/wife is a B. Com graduate. The petitioner, prior to the marriage was working and earning good amount of salary and currently she is working at Forties Hospital, Goa as an accountant. The respondent/husband is a Mechanical Engineer and is working as a Scientific Research Assistant at Bhaba Atomic Research Centre at Mumbai. Learned counsel for the appellant contended that the appellant has no grievance with respect to the order of decree of divorce granted by the Family Court, but is aggrieved by the direction of the Family Court to pay permanent alimony of Rs. 10, 00, 000/- to the respondent. He contended that since the respondent is working at Forties Hospital, Goa as an accountant, grant of permanent alimony to the petitioner/wife does not arise. Hence, the learned counsel prays to reduce the grant of permanent alimony to the petitioner/wife. Heard the learned counsel for the appellant/husband. Though the respondent/wife is served, she remained absent. We have perused the entire material available on record. Since, as contended by the learned counsel for the appellant that he has no grievance with regard to the decree of divorce granted by the Family Court, we restrain ourselves from considering the said aspect. So far as the grievance of the appellant with respect to grant of permanent alimony is concerned, from the perusal of the oral evidence of PW. 1, RW. 1 and Exs. P-1 to 3, it clearly establish that the respondent is working and from the evidence it reveals that the petitioner/wife is working at Forties Hospital, Goa, as an accountant. Further the petitioner/wife and the respondent/husband have a son who is studying in PUC. Therefore, it is the duty of the respondent, who being the father and husband, has to look after his son as well as his wife/petitioner. Considering the status of the parties, including the education of their son, their avocation, cost of living in the present society and with regard to the facts and circumstances of the present case, it is just and necessary to reduce the permanent alimony of Rs. 10, 00, 000/- awarded by the Family Court to Rs. 5, 00, 000/- which would meet the ends of justice. Hence, we proceed to pass the following: ORDER i) The appeal is allowed in part. The judgment and decree dated 23. 03. 2020 passed in M. C. No. 44/2015 by the learned Principal Senior Civil Judge, Karwar, is hereby confirmed. However, the permanent alimony granted by the family Court is reduced to Rs. 5, 00, 000/- from Rs. 10, 00, 000/-. ii) The appellant/husband is directed to pay permanent alimony of Rs. 5, 00, 000/- to the respondent within four months from today.

P. & Anr. on 20 July, 2021 Author: Alok Mathur Bench: Alok Mathur HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD, LUCKNOW BENCH? Court No. - 15 Case: - BAIL No. - 6901 of 2020 Applicant: - Avinash Tripathi Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. & Anr. Counsel for Applicant: - Prashant Singh Gaur, Anil Kumar Dwivedi, Sudhanshu Mishra, Umesh Kumar Yadav Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A. Hon'ble Alok Mathur, J. 1. Heard Sri Umesh Kumar Yadav, learned counsel for applicant as well as learned Additional Government Advocate. 2. Office has reported by means of report dated 01. 03. 2021 that respondent No. 2 has been served but no one has put in appearance on her behalf, the Court has proceeded to hear the bail application. 2. This application has been filed by the applicant who is an accused in connection with Case Crime No. 0108/2018, under Sections 376(D), 506 I. P. C. and 3/4 POCSO Act, Police Station - Rajesultanpur, Ambedkar Nagar. 3. It has been submitted by learned counsel for applicant that the first information report was lodged by the prosecutrix herself who stated that she is 17 years of age and the occurrence relates to six months prior in time. One Prashant Mishra has been accused of dragging her into the field and sexually assaulted the prosecutrix. At the time of lodging of the first information report, it was stated that the prosecutrix was pregnant for six months and that the said accused therein, namely, Prashant Mishra has refused to marry her and consequently the first information report was lodged. The statement under Section 161 of Cr. P. C. was recorded after six months on 18. 06. 2018 where she has reiterated the contents of the first information report and named Prashant Kumar as to the person who has sexually assaulted the prosecutrix. The statement under Section 164 Cr. P. C. was recorded on 18. 07. 2018, it is stated that the applicant has been named as one of the person who has sexually assaulted the prosecutrix and consequently he was shown as an accused and chargesheet has been filed in the court of competent jurisdiction. 4. It has been submitted by learned counsel for applicant that the entire story as narrated by the prosecutrix is unbelievable and not worthy of any credence. He submits that the first information report was lodged by the prosecutrix herself and that too after six months of the incident and there is no explanation that as to why the applicant was not named as an accused or any other perosn who has sexually assaulted the prosecutrix in the F. I. R. itself. 5. It has further been submitted that the statement under Section 161 Cr. P. C. was recorded after six months where again the name of the applicant has not been shown as an accused. He submits that it is in the statement recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. where the name of the applicant has come up and there is no reason that as to why the applicant was named in the statement recorded under Section 161 Cr. P. C. 6. It has further been submitted that D. N. A. test of the child was conducted for comparing to the same with the D. N. A. of the prosecutrix and to the said Prashant Mishra and the D. N. A. testing was confirmed that the father of the child is Prashant Mishra and not the applicant. 7. It has lastly been submitted that the applicant is in jail since 26. 06. 2020. 8. Learned A. G. A. opposed the prayer for bail and submits that the applicant has clearly named the applicant in the Statement recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. , therefore the applicant is not entitled for bail looking into the of his complicity in the case. 9. I have heard learned counsel for parties and perused the record. It is clear that there is no reason forth coming as to why the prosecutrix has not named the applicant either in the first information report or in the statement recorded after six months under Section 164 Cr. P. C. Coupled with the fact that the D. N. A. report has not confirmed the parentage of the child to that of the applicant herein and also considering the nature of allegations, arguments advanced by the learned counsel for the parties as well as the fact that applicant has in jail since 26. 06. 2020 where he has spent nearly one year in judicial custory, without expressing any opinion on the merit of the case, I find it to be a fit case for granting bail. 10. Let the applicant/Avinash Tripathi involved in Case Crime No. 0108/2018, under Sections 376(D), 506 I. P. C. and 3/4 POCSO Act, Police Station - Rajesultanpur, Ambedkar Nagar be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned with the following conditions which are being imposed in the interest of justice: - (i) The applicant shall file an undertaking to the effect that he shall not seek any adjournment on the dates fixed for evidence when the witnesses are present in court. In case of default of this condition, it shall be open for the trial court to treat it as abuse of liberty of bail and pass orders in accordance with law. (ii) The applicant shall remain present before the trial court on each date fixed, either personally or through his counsel. In case of his absence, without sufficient cause, the trial court may proceed against him under Section 229-A of the Indian Penal Code. (iii) In case, the applicant misuses the liberty of bail during trial and in order to secure his presence, proclamation under Section 82 Cr. P. C. is issued and the applicant fails to appear before the court on the date fixed in such proclamation, then, the trial court shall initiate proceedings against him, in accordance with law, under Section 174-A of the Indian Penal Code. (iv) The applicant shall remain present, in person, before the trial court on the dates fixed for (i) opening of the case, (ii) framing of charge and (iii) recording of statement under Section 313 Cr. P. C. If in the opinion of the trial court absence of the applicant is deliberate or without sufficient cause, then it shall be open for the trial court to treat such default as abuse of liberty of bail and proceed against him in accordance with law. 11. In case of breach of any of the above conditions, the Court below shall be at liberty to cancel the bail and proceed against the applicant in accordance with law. 12. The application stands disposed of. 13. The party shall file computer generated copy of order downloaded from the official website of High Court Allahabad, self attested by him alongwith a self attested identity proof of the said person(s) (preferably Aadhar Card) mentioning the mobile number(s) to which the said Aadhar Card is linked before the concerned Court/Authority/Official. 14. The concerned Court/Authority/Official shall verify the authenticity of the computerized copy of the order from the official website of High Court Allahabad and shall make a declaration of such verification in writing. [case 29]
This revision under Section 102 of the Juvenile Justice ( Care and Protection of Children), Act, 2015 has been preferred by the revisionist Satyam Yadav, (Minor) through his father Jai Prakash Yadav against the judgment and order dated 21. 10. 2021 passed by learned Special Judge (POCSO) Act, Pratapgarh in criminal appeal no. 40 of 2021 and impugned order dated 22. 6. 2021 passed by the learned Juvenile Justice Board, Pratapgarh in case crime no. 247 of 2021 under Sections 302, 307, 34 I. P. C. and under Section 3 (2) (v), 3 (2) (Va) of the Scheduled Castes And the Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, 1989, Police Station- Kotwali City, district- Pratapgarh. He heard learned counsel for the revisionist and learned A. G. A for State of U. P. Learned counsel for the revisionist has submitted that the revisionist is juvenile and has falsely been implicated in the present case. The revisionist is not named in the F. I. R. The name of the revisionist has been disclosed after 62 days of the alleged incident only on the basis of the statement of the injured- Jangbahadur. He further submitted that no body has seen the occurrence. The main role has been assigned to Luvkush. Thus, applicant has been named in the present case only on the basis of the suspicion but there is no cogent and credible evidence against him. The false recovery of danda has also been shown from the possession of the revisionist. Similarly co-accused- Jai Prakash Yadav has been granted bail by this Court in Criminal Appeal no. 1004 of 2021 on 19. 8. 2021. No specific role has been assigned against him. No incriminating fact has been mentioned in the report submitted by the District Probation Officer. If he is released on bail, he will not misuse the liberty of bail. He is languishing in remand home since 19. 3. 2021. The impugned orders are against the provision of law which are liable to be set aside. Learned A. G. A has vehemently opposed the prayer made by the learned counsel for the revisionist and submitted that if the revisionist is released on bail, he will join in the company of habitual criminal, hence he is not entitled for bail. The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection) Act, 2015 (Act) has been enacted with object to reform and protect the future career of children below the age of 18 years. The main purpose of this Act is to keep the juvenile out of company and society of habitual criminals and to keep them in place of safety. The parameter and guidelines for assessment of plea of bail of a juvenile has been provided in Section 12 of the Act which is as under: - "When any person accused of a bailable or non-bailable offence, and apparently a juvenile, is arrested or detained or appears or is brought before a Board, such person shall, notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (2 of 1974) or in any other law for the time being in force, be released on bail with or without surety 1[or placed under the supervision of a Probation Officer or under the care of any fit institution of fit person] but he shall not be so released if there appear reasonable grounds for believing that the release is likely to bring him into association with any known criminal or expose him to moral, physical or psychological danger or that his release would defeat the ends of justice. When such person having been arrested is not released on bail under sub-section (1) by the officer incharge of the police station, such officer shall cause him to be kept only in an observation home in the prescribed manner until he can be brought before a Board. When such person is not released on bail under sub-section (1) by the Board it shall, instead of committing him to prison, make an order sending him to an observation home or a place of safety for such period during the pendency of the inquiry regarding him as may be specified in the order. " Thus it is clear that the provision for release to a juvenile has overriding effect to any provision contained in Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 or in any other law for the time being in force. According to this provision, a duty has been cost to grant bail to a juvenile unless there is a reasonable ground for plea that the release is likely to bring the juvenile into association with any known criminal or exposed the said juvenile to moral, physical or psychological danger or that his release would defeat the end of justice. Plea of bail raised by juvenile cannot be rejected in a mechanical manner. While considering the parameter provided in Section 12 of the Act, nature of offence, role played by the juvenile in committing the offence, his family background, his association with known or unknown criminals or bad elements of society, number of person named in the occurrence and future carrier of juvenile should also be taken into consideration by Juvenile Justice Board or court concerned in addition to the other factors. It has been held by the supreme court in Dr. Subramaniam Swamy vs Raju, 2014 (86) ACC 637 that a juvenile has to be released on bail unless the court has a reasonable ground to believe that his release will bring him into association of some known criminal, or will expose him to moral, physical or psychological danger or his release would defeat the ends of justice. Section 15 of the Amending Act only provides for transfer of a juvenile to the Children Court for trial as an adult. Where the child has attained the age of 16 years and has been alleged to have committed heinous offence, the JJ Board is required to conduct a preliminary inquiry with regard to his mental and physical capacity to commit offence, ability to understand the consequence of the offence and the circumstances in which the offence was committed considering their physical, psychological and mental status in commission of crime. Section 18(3) of the Act provides that after making the assessment under section 15, JJ Board comes to a conclusion that there is a need for trial of the child as an adult, the Board may pass an order for the transfer of the trial of the case to the Children Court. In this case the revisionist was aged about 16 years at the time of occurrence. Admittedly the revisionist was juvenile at the time of occurrence. No material is available on record whereby it can be presumed that the revisionist was in association of any criminal or bad elements. From perusal of impugned judgement and order passed by the appellate Court as well as passed by the Board, it transpires that both the trial court have passed the impugned judgement and orders in cursory manner without placing due reliance on the report submitted by the District Probation Officer as well as facts and circumstances of this case. The impugned judgment and orders are liable to be set aside. Consequently, the revision succeeds and is allowed. Both the impugned judgment and order 21. 10. 2021 and 22. 6. 2021 are hereby set aside. Let the revisionist Satyam Yadav through his natural guardian/father Jai Prakash Yadav be released on bail in the aforesaid criminal case and be given into custody of aforesaid natural guardian on furnishing a personal bond with two solvent sureties of relatives of the aforesaid natural guardian each in like amount to the satisfaction of Juvenile Justice Board concerned on the following conditions. (i)That, Jai Prakash Yadav natural guardian of the revisionist will furnish an undertaking that upon release on bail, the juvenile will not be permitted to go into contact or association with any known or unknown criminal or exposed to any moral or physical danger and will not indulge in any criminal activity and aforesaid natural guardian will make best effort for improvement of juvenile's carrier. (ii)That the revisionist and his aforesaid natural guardian shall remain present before the trial court on each date fixed, either personally or through counsel. Order Date: - 24. 1. 2023

[case 30]
IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT: THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE SUNIL THOMAS MONDAY, THE 25TH DAY OF JUNE 2018 / 4TH ASHADHA, 1940 Bail Appl. .No. 4054 of 2018 (CRIME NO. 548/2018 OF OTTAPALAM POLICE STATION, PALAKKAD) PETITIONER(S)/ACCUSED 1 SANAL KUMAR K. , AGED 36 YEARS, S/O. K. M. UNNIKRISHNAN, ANASWARA, KOOTHAKKURISSY, PANAMANNA P. O. , OTTAPPALAM, PALAKKAD DISTRICT-679 501. 2 UNNIKRISHNAN K. M. , AGED 67 YEARS, ANASWARA, KOOTHAKKURISSY, PANAMANNA P. O. , OTTAPPALAM, PALAKKAD DISTRICT-679 501. 3 RADHA, W/O. UNNIKRISHNAN K. M. , ANASWARA, KOOTHAKKURISSY, PANAMANNA P. O. , OTTAPPALAM, PALAKKAD DISTRICT-679 501. BY ADV. SRI. M. T. SURESHKUMAR RESPONDENT(S)/COMPLAINANT: STATE OF KERALA, REPRESENTED BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM-682031. R BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR SMT. V. SREEJA THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING BEEN FINALLY HEARD ON 19-06-2018, THE COURT ON 25/6/2018 PASSED THE FOLLOWING: ORDER The accused in Crime No. 548/2018 of Ottappalam Police station for offences punishable under sections 7 & 8 of POCSO Act 2012 and under section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Care and Protection of Children Act 2015, are the petitioners herein. 2. Admitted facts are as follows; The first petitioner had married the defacto complainant on 27/4/2009. Thereafter, they resided together for some time. The second petitioner is his father and the third petitioner is his mother. A girl child was born, who is aged 7 years now. Matrimonial dispute arose between the parties. It is stated that, on 5/9/2017, the wife left the matrimonial home. The child was in the custody of the petitioners till 15/9/2017, on which day the child was entrusted with the parents of the defacto complainant. The present complaint was laid by the wife alleging that the first petitioner had sexually abused the seven year old girl on few days between 5/9/2017 to 15/9/2017 at the matrimonial home and other places. Apprehending arrest, the petitioners herein have approached the court. 3. The specific contention of the petitioners herein is that, the defacto complainant was a quarrelsome person and matrimonial relationship became incompatible. It was alleged that, the defacto complainant had developed a close intimacy with one doctor who was younger to her. She was found making secret audio and video calls to him over the mobile phone. When the relationship went beyond a limit, the husband intervened and she was warned. It was later understood that she continued to maintain even physical relationship with him. On being confronted with materials, she is stated to have abandoned the child and left the matrimonial home on 5/9/2017. Thereafter, the first petitioner herein entrusted the child to the defacto complainant and her parents, considering the education of the child. The first petitioner herein initiated matrimonial proceedings, including an application for custody of the child. The present complaint was filed belatedly raising absolutely false allegations with the intention of denying him the custody of the child. It was vehemently contended that, the first petitioner herein has not committed any sexual abuse on the minor girl and it was purposefully and belatedly set up. 4. Annexure A1 is a copy of the petition in O. P. (HMA) No. 649/2017 dated 27/10/2017 filed by the first petitioner herein before the Family Court, Malappuram. He claimed divorce on the ground of adultery of the defacto complainant with the doctor, who was arrayed as the second respondent in that O. P. It was alleged therein that, she was having continuous physical relationship with that doctor and was caught with evidence. Annexure A2 is a copy of O. P. ( G & W) No. 356/2018 filed by the first petitioner herein on 24/5/2018 before the Family Court, Malappuram claiming custody of the child. Thereafter, Crime was got registered by the wife at Bangalore as Crime No. 703/2017 on 11/12/2017 against the petitioners herein alleging matrimonial cruelty. The first petitioner sought bail which was granted by Annexure A3 order. It is seen that, she alleged that the petitioners herein committed acts of matrimonial cruelty and demanded dowry and thereby committed offences punishable under section 498A IPC and the provisions of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The petitioner was granted anticipatory bail. Annexure A5 is a complaint filed by the defacto complainant before the State Commission for Protection of Child Child Rights of Kerala and Karnataka, with copies to the various authorities. It was alleged that, the father-in-law of the defacto complainant had made sexual advances towards her. She alleged that, in-laws had administered various medicines on her body. It was also alleged that, the child was physically assaulted by the petitioners during the period from 5/9/2017 to 15/9/2017. There is an allegation that, the grandfather used to beat her on her groin and grand mother had beaten the child with a chapathy rolling pin. Annexure A6 is the complaint No. 20/2018 filed on 24/1/2018 by the defacto complainant under the provisions of the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act. 5. The above documents clearly show that, at no point of time earlier, the defacto complainant had a case that the child was sexually abused by the father. Even though physical assault is alleged against the petitioners, there was absolutely no reference anywhere that the child was subjected to sexual abuse by the father. 6. It seems that, for the first time such a complaint is seen raised in the present crime(Crime No. 548/2018 of Ottappalam Police station). Crime was thereupon registered for offences punishable under sections 7 & 8 of POCSO Act and Section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Care and Protection of Children Act 2015. The crux of the allegation in the FIS is that, during the period when the child was in the custody of the petitioners, the father of the child used to give her a bath. He used to undress her, remove his dress and give her bath. It was stated that in the course of bathing her, the first petitioner used to tickle her. The child has stated that, she did not like boys giving her bath. Pursuant to it, section 164 Cr. P. C. statement of the victim was also recorded, which is substantially in tune with FI statement. 7. It is pertinent to note that the only allegation raised against the first petitioner is as above. Even if the entire statement made by the child is taken at its face value, crucial question that arises is whether the father had any sexual intent while giving the daughter a bath. This has to be appreciated in the background that the allegation comes only at a highly belated stage, when the father himself had sought custody of the child. No explanation is forthcoming for the delay in giving complaint. Hence, the question to be investigated by the police is only whether the first petitioner herein with sexual intention had committed any act. For that, custodial interrogation does not appear to be warranted. It is also clear that, in such a very strained matrimonial relationship a belated allegation of this nature has to be considered carefully and it may not be safe to order custodial interrogation. 8. Having regard to the above, I am inclined to grant benefit of anticipatory bail to the petitioners herein subject to the following conditions: i). Petitioners shall appear before the investigating officer within ten days from today and shall undergo interrogation. Thereafter, if they are proposed to be arrested, they shall be released on bail on each of the petitioner executing a bond for a sum of Rs. 50, 000/-(Rupees fifty thousand only) with two sureties for the like sum each. ii). They shall appear before the Investigating Officer as and when called for and co-operate with the investigation. Anticipatory Bail Application is allowed.

[case 33]

It seems that, for the first time such a complaint is seen raised in the present crime(Crime No. 548/2018 of Ottappalam Police station). Crime was thereupon registered for offences punishable under sections 7 & 8 of POCSO Act and Section 75 of the Juvenile Justice Care and Protection of Children Act 2015. The crux of the allegation in the FIS is that, during the period when the child was in the custody of the petitioners, the father of the child used to give her a bath. He used to undress her, remove his dress and give her bath. It was stated that in the course of bathing her, the first petitioner used to tickle her. The child has stated that, she did not like boys giving her bath. Pursuant to it, section 164 Cr. P. C. statement of the victim was also recorded, which is substantially in tune with FI statement. It is pertinent to note that the only allegation raised against the first petitioner is as above. Even if the entire statement made by the child is taken at its face value, crucial question that arises is whether the father had any sexual intent while giving the daughter a bath. This has to be appreciated in the background that the allegation comes only at a highly belated stage, when the father himself had sought custody of the child. No explanation is forthcoming for the delay in giving complaint. Hence, the question to be investigated by the police is only whether the first petitioner herein with sexual intention had committed any act. For that, custodial interrogation does not appear to be warranted. It is also clear that, in such a very strained matrimonial relationship a belated allegation of this nature has to be considered carefully and it may not be safe to order custodial interrogation. Having regard to the above, I am inclined to grant benefit of anticipatory bail to the petitioners herein subject to the following conditions: i). Petitioners shall appear before the investigating officer within ten days from today and shall undergo interrogation. Thereafter, if they are proposed to be arrested, they shall be released on bail on each of the petitioner executing a bond for a sum of Rs. 50, 000/-(Rupees fifty thousand only) with two sureties for the like sum each. ii). They shall appear before the Investigating Officer as and when called for and co-operate with the investigation. Anticipatory Bail Application is allowed.

[case 34]
Delhi District Court State vs. Dilip S/O Sh. Kamal Kishore Yadav on 24 September, 2015 IN THE COURT OF SH. SIDHARTH SHARMA ADDITIONAL SESSIONS JUDGE-01 & SPECIAL JUDGE (NDPS) SHAHDARA DISTRICT, KARKARDOOMA COURTS, DELHI FIR No. : 17/2013 Under Sections: 509 IPC and 12 POCSO Act Police Station: Anand Vihar Sessions Case No. : 107/2013 Unique ID No. : 02402R0305352013 In the matter of: STATE Vs. DILIP S/o Sh. Kamal Kishore Yadav R/o D-540, LN 30 D-Block, Harsh Vihar, Delhi. .. .. .. .Accused Date of institution: 18. 09. 2013 Date of reserving judgment: 23. 09. 2015 Date of pronouncement: 24. 09. 2015 JUDGMENT 1. Briefly stated, the facts of the prosecution case are that on 11. 01. 2013, the minor child (female), aged 16 years (hereinafter referred as minor victim/prosecutrix), came at PS Anand Vihar and made a complaint against the accused Dilip for outraging her modesty by making gesture and using abusive language to her. SI Gunjan Singh present at the PS recorded statement of the prosecutrix wherein prosecutrix stated that she had studied upto 5th class and her parents run a stall of ironing the clothes in front of B-124, Anand Vihar, Delhi. She further states that one Dilip s/o Sh. Kamal Kishore Yadav, r/o D-540, LN 30 D-Block, Harsh Vihar, Delhi, aged 27 years who is a driver at B-70, Anand Vihar is known to her for last two years. He used to watch her for last few days and used to make gestures by waiving his hands and by making comments and used to ask her to have friendship with him. The complainant/prosecutrix alleged that on 10. 01. 2013, at 07. 00 p. m. , accused made a call to her and at that time her parents saw her while talking to him over phone and in anger, they gave beatings to her. She alleged that said Dilip had outraged her modesty by making gestures and making comments and prayed for legal action against the accused. 2. On the aforesaid complaint of prosecutrix, offences u/s 509 IPC and Section 12 POCSO Act were made out against the accused and accordingly IO SI Gunjan Singh got lodged the present case FIR and conducted the investigation. During investigation, IO arrested the accused; produced the prosecutrix before ld. MM who recorded her statement u/s 164 Cr. PC wherein she supported her statement made to the police; recorded statement of witnesses and after completion of investigation, filed the charge-sheet. 3. Vide order dated 09. 12. 2013, my ld. Predecessor framed the charge for offence u/s 509 IPC and 12 POCSO Act against the accused to which he pleaded not guilty and claimed trial. 4. The prosecution in support of its case examined five witnesses: (a) PW1 Smt. Laxmi is the mother of the prosecutrix. (b) PW2 is the prosecutrix who turned totally hostile to the case of prosecution. (c) PW3 is Smt. Geeta, Primary Teacher from Nigam Pratibha Vidyalaya, Anand Vihar, who proved the date of birth of prosecutrix as 15. 012. 1996 as per school record. (d) PW4 HC Prakash Veer is the Duty Officer. He proved the present case FIR. (e) PW5 is HC Narender Kumar who proved DD No. 21-A regarding information received from PCR about the incident of present case. 5. It was seen that the prosecution cited total 10 witnesses out of which 5 witnesses were examined in this case and PW1 and PW2 who are the only material witnesses in this case, did not support the case of prosecution and were declared hostile and were cross-examined by ld. Addl. PP for State. In these circumstances, no useful purpose would have been served in continuing the trial as the prosecution could not have succeeded in securing conviction of the accused even after examining the remaining witnesses who are formal in nature. Hence, the prosecution evidence was closed. 6. Statement of accused u/s 313 Cr. PC was recorded wherein he stated that he was innocent and was falsely implicated in this case by the police. He stated that prosecutrix was his friend and while she was talking to him over phone, her mother gave her merciless beatings and that is why he made a call at 100 and thereafter, as a counter-blast present false case was lodged against him. 7. I have heard submissions from Sh. Anil Kumar, learned Additional Public Prosecutor for State and from Sh. V. S. Chauhan Advocate for accused. I have also gone through the record. 8. For proving the offence u/s 509 IPC, the essential ingredient of mens-rea on the part of the accused is that there should be a clear intention to outrage the modesty of a woman and thereafter word or gesture had been made by the accused which intrudes the privacy of such woman. Similarly, for proving the offence u/s 12 POCSO Act, it is seen that sexual harassment upon the child by the accused should be with 'sexual intent' i. e. mens-rea of sexual intent before making any sound or gesture is a pre-requisite. 9. In order to appreciate if the ingredient of mense-rea have been satisfied, the evidence of material witnesses is required to be appreciated. The fate of this case depends upon the testimony of both the material witnesses examined in this case i. e. PW2 prosecutrix and PW1 Smt. Laxmi, mother of the prosecutrix as other witnesses are formal witnesses. PW2 the minor victim/prosecutrix/complainant is the star material witness and on her statement the present case FIR was registered. In her testimony before the court, she did not support her allegations as leveled by her in her statements to police as well as before ld. MM. On the contrary, PW1 deposed that in the summer of 2013 at about 01. 00 p. m. , while she was talking to the accused Dilip on the mobile phone sent by him, her parents noticed the same and gave beatings to her daughter/ prosecutrix. PW1 further stated that she saw the accused making some gesture with his hand towards the prosecutrix. However, in her cross-examination, PW1 admitted that her daughter had voluntarily taken mobile phone from the accused due to which she gave beatings to her daughter/prosecutrix. She admitted that her daughter was talking to the accused voluntarily and thereafter, she scolded her. She also admitted that it was the accused who had made call at 100 number after seeing that she was beating her daughter. She admitted that she did not make any call or complaint to the police. 11. Upon perusal of the testimony of both the material witnesses i. e. PW1 Smt. Laxmi and PW2 prosecutrix, I am of the considered opinion that both the material witnesses are totally hostile to the case of prosecution and have failed to prove the ingredients of offence u/s 509 IPC and u/s 12 POCSO Act against the accused. There is not even an iota of evidence to prove the ingredients of the aforesaid offences so as to make the case of prosecution stand on its own legs. Thus, prosecution miserably failed to prove its case against the accused and therefore, accused is entitled for acquittal. Therefore, I acquit the accused Dilip of the offences for which he has been charged with in the present case. Accused is on bail. His bail bond stands cancelled and surety is discharged. 12. However, accused is directed to furnish Personal Bond and Surety Bond u/s 437-A Cr. PC in sum of Rs. 10, 000/- each for a period of six months, within a week from today. 13. File be consigned to Record Room after due compliance. Announced in the open court today on 24th September, 2015 (SIDHARTH SHARMA) Addl. Sessions Judge-01 & Spl. Judge (NDPS) Shahdara/Karkardooma Courts/Delhi

[case 35]

[case 36]
AGAINST THE ORDER IN CRMC 856/2021 OF SPECIAL COURT UNDER POCSO
CRIME NO. 114 OF 2021 OF CHERUPUZHA POLICE STATION
PETITIONER/ACCUSED:
BY ADV P. P. RAMACHANDRAN
RESPONDENT/COMPLAINANT:
STATE OF KERALA
(S. H. O. CHERUPUZHA POLICE STATION) REPRESENTED BY PUBLIC
PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM - 682 031.
BY ADV SHRI. P. NARAYANAN, ADDL. PUBLIC PROSECUTOR
THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON
11. 08. 2021, THE COURT ON 13. 08. 2021 PASSED THE FOLLOWING:
DATED THIS THE 13TH DAY OF AUGUST, 2021
This application for regular bail has been filed by the
petitioner/the accused in Crime No. 114 of 2021 of Cherupuzha
Police Station registered for the offences punishable under Section
306 of Indian Penal Code, Sections 4 read with Section 3(a), 12
read with 11(iv) of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act,
Sections 3(1), (W), 3(2)(V) of Scheduled Caste/Scheduled Tribe
Prevention of Atrocities Act and Section 67B of Information
Technology Act.
The petitioner has been in custody since 16. 06. 2021.
The prosecution case is that a minor girl aged 17
years who belongs to Scheduled Caste community, the daughter of
the informant's uncle, was found dead on 09. 06. 2021. She was
found hanging in her bedroom in the wee hours of 09. 06. 2021.
Though she was rushed to the hospital by the relatives including
the informant, she was declared dead. A crime was registered
under Section 174 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. Thereafter
postmortem examination was conducted on the body of the
deceased in the Medical College, Pariyaram where it was found by
the doctor who conducted the autopsy that she was subjected to
penetrative sexual assault. Then case was registered under
Sections 376(2) of IPC and Section 3(a) read with Section 4 of the
Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. Subsequently,
investigation has started and thus the sections have been altered
as aforementioned.
According to the learned appearing for the petitioner,
he has been falsely implicated in the case at the instance of some
of his friends who are on inimical terms with him. Absolutely he
has no role in the alleged incident and he never abetted the girl to
commit suicide at any point of time as alleged by the prosecution.
He has also not committed any kind of sexual abuse or harassment
as alleged, still he is undergoing unnecessary incarceration and
hence, this application.
Per contra, the learned Additional Director General of
Prosecution vehemently opposed the application. It was pointed
out that this petitioner came in contact with the deceased through
Facebook. Thereafter he managed to develop intimacy with the
minor girl by making frequent calls and also sending messages.
When the intimacy had developed, he used to take the victim girl to
various places and started to abuse her sexually. When the minor
girl was residing along with her grandmother he had even
approached her and stayed at their house by making them to
believe that he would marry her when she attains the age of
majority. In fact, the mobile phone which was found in the
possession of the minor child was presented by this petitioner so as
to trap her in the relationship, so as to satisfy his lust. He was
working as a bus conductor and he exploited the innocence of this
girl by making frequent calls and messages and she had even
forwarded her nude photographs to him as instigated by him, and
he had sex with this minor girl quite frequently. But later when she
made the request to marry her, he had deviated from his promise
and had tried to keep away from her and in fact his reluctance or
refusal to marry her, had led her to commit suicide and thus he
abetted her to commit suicide on 09. 06. 2021, is the argument
advanced by the learned ADGP.
Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner as well
the learned ADGP. Perused the CD file.
As mentioned earlier, the records would reveal that the
case was actually registered under Section 174 of the Cr. P. C. ,
on 09. 06. 2021. Later, on receipt of the postmortem report, the
police has investigated the case and then it was revealed that her
death was because of the involvement of some perpetrator and
when the call details of her mobile phone were collected by the
investigating agency, it unfolded the mysterious relationship of this
petitioner with the deceased. Thereafter further investigation by
recording the statements of the relatives, friends and others who
are closely connected with the deceased was conducted and then
only it was realized that this petitioner was taking advantage of his
intimacy with her and he had abused her sexually though she was a
minor girl. The CD file further reveals that he used to visit her
quite often and sent obscene messages to her and prompted her to
send her nude photographs after giving a false promise that he
would marry her in near future. So, she was having close
acquaintance with him and it was exploited by him for having
sexual relationship with her. She was residing along with her
grandmother and he had visited her at that house and even stayed
with her under that false promise of marriage. The last visit of this
petitioner to her residence was on 13. 02. 2021. As the petitioner
had indulged in instigating her to commit suicide, the investigating
agency has to probe into the details of the mysterious death, to
collect more materials for the prosecution to prove the case.
It is also pointed out by the learned ADGP that this
petitioner, who was working as a bus conductor was having another
case of similar nature, registered in the year 2015. In that case
also, he adopted the very same modus operandi to get
acquaintance with a minor child and thereafter used her for his
sexual lust. That case is also pending for trial before the court
concerned. Since the investigating agency requires more time to
collect the entire evidence for the prosecution, I find that granting
