He submits that the evidence of the victim girl clearly shows that she was acting under the influence of her parents and therefore, she is a tutored witness. Hence, it is not safe to act upon such evidence particularly when the medical evidence does not corroborate with the evidence of the victim. He therefore submits that the impugned Judgment and Order of conviction and sentence passed by the trial Court be set aside and the appeal be allowed. ..

[case 54]
Madhya Pradesh High Court Manju Shrivastava vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 16 January, 2025. This revision under Section 438 read with Section 442 of the BNSS has been preferred by the petitioner being aggrieved by the order dated 02. 06. 2024 passed by the trial Court whereby her application under Section 319 of the Cr. P. C. has been rejected. As per the prosecution, on 18. 02. 2019 a complaint was lodged by the petitioner to the effect that she is residing at her house along with her husband and son and his three children. On 09. 02. 2019 her son had come home and had fallen ill. She had called her daughter and son-in-law to her home for his treatment. On seeing them his son beat them and abused her. He also beat his children and stated that he shall take them with him to Banglore and if he is stopped he shall kill them. On the basis of the complaint lodged by the petitioner investigation was commenced during the course of which statements of children of the accused were recorded in which they stated that their father has been responsible for the death of their mother and he had not given her proper treatment. After that he has been touching them with a bad touch and has been committing various heinous acts with them. He used to get females from his office at home. He always used to drink and make them sleep with him in the bed. Various other allegations as regards unnatural sexual advances were made. On the basis of the complaint and the investigation FIR was registered against the accused and the matter was proceeded with. After completion of the investigation charge-sheet has been filed before the Court concerned. During proceedings before the trial Court the petitioner filed an application under Section 319 of the Cr. P. C. for impleading one Sanjeev Ameen also as an accused in the case. It was submitted that in the statements of the minor children (victims) recorded by the Child Welfare Committee, Indore name of Sanjeev Ameen had been clearly revealed. In their statement under Section 164 of the Cr. P. C. also and in evidence before the trial Court his name has been specifically mentioned by the victims. The application was contested by the accused and has been rejected by the trial Court by the impugned order primarily on the ground that in the complaint and her statement the petitioner had not stated anything against Sanjeev Ameen. The victims had also not made any such statement. Earlier a complaint was preferred by the petitioner against Sanjeev Ameen which was dismissed with liberty that in case it is found during investigation that he has committed any offence he may be impleaded as an accused or the petitioner may file a separate complaint. Thereafter charge-sheet has been filed before the Court in which he has not been made an accused. The application has been preferred belatedly. As per Section 319 of the Cr. P. C. it is not only during course of inquiry but also during course of trial that a person may be impleaded as an accused and be proceeded with if it appears that he has committed any offence for which he could be tried together with the already impleaded accused. The trial Court has relied upon the proceedings prior to filing of the chargesheet and during investigation which were not relevant. If earlier a complaint had been filed by the petitioner which had been dismissed with observations and liberty, that did not preclude the power of the Court to array any person as an accused if during trial it appeared that he had committed any offence. The liberty granted to the petitioner earlier would not arrest the power of the Court so also the reason that the investigating agency has not chosen to implead Sanjeev Ameen as an accused. The impleadment can be done during course of trial hence the ground of delay in rejecting the application does not hold good. It is not to be seen as to whether the person sought to be made an accused has not been named initially but it has to be seen as to whether there is any material showing his involvement at any stage. Reliance by the trial Court on the initial complaint made by the petitioner, application made by her to the Police Station and the omission of the victims to name Sanjeev Ameen in their statements under Section 161 of the Cr. P. C. were hence wholly irrelevant. In the statement given by them under Section 164 of the Cr. P. C. they had specifically named him. In the letter dated 06. 03. 2019 written by Child Welfare Committee also the allegations as leveled by the victims against Sanjeev Ameen were mentioned. Despite that if the prosecution has not arrayed him as an accused it did not denude the trial Court of its power for directing his impleadment as an accused. In his statement recorded before the trial Court as PW-1, the victim No. 1, who is son of the present accused, has clearly stated that the accused used to come drunk at night and used to beat him and her sisters and used to do dirty acts with him and her sisters. He clearly stated that along with him his friend Sanjeev Ameen also used to come home and used to touch him in an inappropriate manner and also used to touch his private part. There is hence clear statement by one of the victims as regards the criminal act having been committed by Sanjeev Ameen. This in itself was sufficient for him to be impleaded as an accused. The trial Court in view of the statement ought to have itself made him an accused in the case but it did not do so and when application was preferred by the petitioner for the said purpose has dismissed the same on wholly irrelevant considerations. In view of categoric statement of one of the victims impleadment of Sanjeev Ameen as an accused is legally warranted and imperative in the matter. As a result of the aforesaid discussion, in my opinion, the trial Court has erred in rejecting the application under Section 319 of the Cr. P. C. preferred by the petitioner. The impugned order dated 02. 06. 2024 passed by it is set aside and the application preferred by the petitioner stands allowed. The trial Court is directed to proceed further in accordance with law. The petition is accordingly allowed and disposed off.

[case 55]
Deepu B @ Kuttan vs State Of Kerala Represented By Public Prosecutor on 21 August, 2020. This Bail Application filed under Section 439 of Criminal Procedure Code was heard through Video Conference. The Petitioner is the accused in Crime No. 263 of 2020 of Hosdurg Police Station, Kasargod District. The above case is registered against the petitioner alleging offences punishable under Section 376AB of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) r/w. Sections 6 r/w 5(m)(n) of the Protection of Children From Sexual Offences Act (POCSO Act). The petitioner is in custody from 20. 6. 2020 onwards. The prosecution case is that, on 1. 4. 2020, the accused sexually abused a minor girl aged 4  years by touching the genital organ of the victim. It is the case of the defacto complainant, the mother of the victim girl that, the child complained about a pain on her private parts and when the defacto complainant enquired about the same, the child disclosed to the defacto complainant that the petitioner committed the above activities. The alleged incident happened on 1. 4. 2020. The F. I. statement was given on 12. 5. 2020. The petitioner was arrested on 20. 6. 2020. Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned public prosecutor. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that, the petitioner is innocent in this case. The counsel submitted that, this is a false case foisted against the petitioner by the mother of the victim. The counsel submitted that, there is some difference of opinion between the defacto complainant and her husband. The petitioner is a close relative of the husband of the defacto complainant. The counsel submitted that, the petitioner supported the husband of the defacto complainant when there was a dispute between the defacto complainant and her husband. According to the petitioner, at that time, the defacto complainant threatened that, she will foist a false case against the petitioner. The counsel submitted that, the husband of the defacto complainant filed an affidavit before this Court. The counsel submitted that, in the affidavit, it is stated by the father of the victim, who is the husband of the defacto complainant that, this is a false case foisted against the petitioner. The father of the victim clearly stated that the petitioner is innocent in this case. The learned public prosecutor seriously opposed this bail application. The public prosecutor submitted that the allegations against the petitioner are very serious. The allegation is that, the petitioner committed sexual assault on a minor girl aged 4  years. The public prosecutor submitted that the petitioner is not entitled orders under Section 439 Cr. P. C. at this stage. After hearing both sides, I think, this bail application can be allowed, on stringent conditions. Admittedly, the petitioner is in custody from 20. 6. 2020 onwards. The alleged incident happened on 1. 4. 2020 and the F. I. statement was given only on 12. 5. 2020. Admittedly, there is some matrimonial dispute between the defact complainant and her husband. It is also an admitted fact that, the petitioner is a close relative of the husband of the defact complainant. It is true that, an affidavit is filed by the father of the victim girl exonerating the petitioner from the allegation. I do not want to make any observation about the contents in the affidavit at this stage. This is a matter to be investigated by the investigating officer. Considering the entire facts and circumstances of this case, I think, this bail application can be allowed on stringent conditions. There can be a direction to the petitioner not to enter the jurisdictional limit of Hosdurg Police Station till a final report in Crime No. 263 of 2020 of Hosdurg Police Station, is filed. Moreover, considering the need to follow social distancing norms inside prisons so as to avert the spread of the novel Corona Virus Pandemic, the Hon'ble Supreme Court in Re: Contagion of COVID-19 Virus In Prisons case (Suo Motu Writ Petition(C) No. 1 of 2020) and a Full Bench of this Court in W. P(C)No. 9400 of 2020 issued various salutary directions for minimizing the number of inmates inside prisons. Moreover, it is a well accepted principle that, the bail is the rule and the jail is the exception. The Hon'ble Supreme Court in Chidambaram P. v. Directorate of Enforcement observed that, the basic jurisprudence relating to bail remains the same inasmuch as the grant of bail is the rule and refusal is the exception so as to ensure that the accused has the opportunity of securing fair trial. Considering the dictum laid down in the above decision and considering the facts and circumstances of this case, this Bail Application is allowed with the following directions: 1. The petitioner shall be released on bail on executing a bond for Rs. 50, 000/- (Rupees Fifty Thousand only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the jurisdictional Court; 2. The petitioner shall appear before the Investigating Officer for interrogation as and when required. The petitioner shall co-operate with the investigation and shall not, directly or indirectly make any inducement, threat or promise to any person acquainted with the facts of the case so as to dissuade him from disclosing such facts to the Court or to any police officer; 3. The petitioner shall not leave India without permission of the jurisdictional Court; 4. The petitioner shall not commit an offence similar to the offence of which he is accused, or suspected, of the commission of which he is suspected; 5. The petitioner shall not enter the jurisdictional limit of Hosdurg Police Station, except for the purposes mentioned above, till a final report in Crime No. 263 of 2020 of Hosdurge Police Station is filed. 6. The petitioner shall strictly abide by the various guidelines issued by the State Government and Central Government with respect to keeping of social distancing in the wake of Covid 19 pandemic; 7. If any of the above conditions are violated by the petitioner, the jurisdictional Court can cancel the bail in accordance to law, even though the bail is granted by this Court. Sd/- P. V. KUNHIKRISHNAN JUDGE

Xxxxxx vs State Of Kerala on 6 February, 2025. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT THE HONOURABLE MRS. JUSTICE C. S. SUDHA Thursday, the 6th day of February 2025 / 17th Magha, 1946 CRL. M. APPL. NO. 1/2022 IN CRL. A NO. 907 OF 2022 SC 35/2017 OF THE (FAST TRACK) SPECIAL COURT, THRISSUR PETITIONERS/APPELLANT: XXX RESPONDENT/RESPONDENT: STATE OF KERALA REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROCECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, KOCHIN, PIN - 682031. Application praying that in the circumstances stated therein the High Court be pleased to suspend the sentence in SC No. 35/2017 on the files of the Special Judge's Court (POCSO), Thrissur. If the sentence is not so suspended, the petitioner would be put to irreparable injuries and hardships. On the other hand, no prejudice will be caused to any of the respondent if the sentence is so suspended. This Application coming on for orders upon perusing the application and upon hearing the arguments of M/S. SARATH BABU KOTTAKKAL, REBIN VINCENT GRALAN, Advocates for the petitioner and of PUBLIC PROSECUTOR for the respondent, the court passed the following: C. S. SUDHA, J. -------------------------------------------------------------- Crl. M. Appl. No. 1 of 2022 in Crl. Appeal No. 907 of 2022 --------------------------------------------------------------- Dated this the 6th day of February 2025 ORDER This application under Section 389 Cr. P. C. has been filed seeking suspension of sentence of the applicant/accused in S. C. No. 35 of 2017 on the file of the Special Judge's Court (PoCSO), Thrissur. He has been found guilty of the offences punishable under Sections 6 read with 5(l) and (m) of the PoCSO Act and Sections 342 and 376(2)(i) IPC. He has been sentenced to varying terms of imprisonment for the aforesaid offences. The sentences have been directed to run concurrently. The maximum period of imprisonment he will have to undergo is 20 years. It is submitted by the learned counsel for the applicant/accused that there are several inconsistencies in the statements as well as in the testimony of PW2, the victim, as well as PW1, her mother who had given Ext. P1 FIS. It is pointed out that the case of penetrative sexual assault is not supported by the medical evidence. It is also pointed out that there is no consistent evidence relating to the date of the alleged incident. In addition to the aforesaid aspects, it is also pointed out that the applicant/accused is a 75 year old man suffering from Hydrocele and Bradycardia and that he requires surgery. Earlier, he was granted interim bail for a period of one month for the purpose of undergoing surgery. However, as his blood pressure could not be brought under control, the surgery could not take place and hence on medical grounds also the suspension is sought for. The learned public prosecutor opposes the application and submits that the victim child, who was only 10 years old, has clearly deposed before the court that she was unable to recall the date on which the incidents of abuse took place. However, she has clearly deposed that on three different occasions, the accused herein had committed digital rape on her. This probably must be the reason why she was unable to recollect the exact dates on which the incident took place. The learned public prosecutor also draws my attention to the testimony of PW4, a consultant pediatrician, Sun Hospital, Thrissur, to substantiate the argument that the medical evidence is also there to support the prosecution story. Heard both sides. I was taken through Ext. P1 FIS as well as the testimony of PW2, the victim; PW1, the mother and PW9, the doctor who examined the victim child on 24/11/2016. Ext. P1 FIS is seen given by the mother on 24/11/2016. In the FIS, the allegation is that the incident of abuse took place on 22/11/2016. According to the testimony of PW1, the mother, the incident took place on 24/11/2016 and it was on the same day she had taken PW2 to the hospital as she had seen injuries on the private parts as well as a hair inside the mouth of PW2. However PW9, the doctor who examined the child on 24/11/2016 in Ext. P6 medical certificate records that there was no external injury. As far as the testimony of PW4 is concerned, it is seen that there are absolutely no records to support his testimony that he had examined the child sometime in November 2016. It is also brought to my notice that the victim child had stated in her 161 statement that the incident took place on 23/11/2016 whereas in her chief examination, her testimony was that the incident took place on 22/11/2016. This contradiction was brought out in her examination and proved through the testimony of PW6 and the same has been marked as Ext. D2. On going through the testimony of the material prosecution witnesses, I think that the learned counsel for the applicant/accused is justified in arguing that there are inconsistencies in the testimonies and that doubts arise from the materials on record. It appears that the applicant/accused has got a good arguable case and therefore in the aforesaid circumstances and on medical ground, the sentence of the applicant/accused is suspended till the disposal of the appeal. It is submitted that the fine amount has already been deposited before the trial court. Hence, the sentence imposed on the applicant/accused is suspended on the following conditions: i) The applicant/accused shall be released on bail on executing a bond for 50, 000/- (Rupees fifty thousand only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the trial court; ii) He shall not in any way contact or attempt to contact the victim or family member(s) in any manner; iii) He shall not commit any offence(s) while on bail; iv) If the conviction and sentence of the applicant is upheld or even modified, the time during which he is so released shall be excluded in computing the term of his sentence as provided in Section 430(4) BNSS; v) It is also made clear that if any of the conditions are violated, the bail shall stand cancelled. Post on 27/10/2025. Sd/- C. S. SUDHA JUDGE Jms 06-02-2025 /True Copy/ Assistant Registrar

Karnataka High Court Gumabai vs The State Of Karnataka And Ors on 13 January, 2025 Author: S. Vishwajith Shetty Bench: S. Vishwajith Shetty -1- NC: 2025: KHC-K: 147 CRL. P No. 201425 of 2024 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA, KALABURAGI BENCH DATED THIS THE 13TH DAY OF JANUARY, 2025 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE S. This petition under Section 439(2) of Cr. P. C. , is filed by the de facto complainant with the prayer to cancel the anticipatory bail granted to accused Nos. 2 and 3 in Crime No. 177/2024, registered by Indi Rural Police Station for the offenses punishable under Sections 85, 103(1), 80 read with Section 3(5) of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Act, 2023 and Sections 3 and 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act, 1961 by the Court of II Additional District and Session Judge, Vijayapura in Criminal Misc. No. 1421/2024. 2. Heard the learned counsel for the parties. 3. FIR in Crime No. 177/2024, was registered by Indi Rural Police Station, Vijayapura, for the offenses punishable under Sections 85, 103(1), 80, read with Section 3(5) of Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Act, 2023 on the basis of the first information dated 31. 07. 2024 received by Smt. Gumabai, mother of deceased Reshma as against Vikram and the respondent Nos. 2 and 3 herein who are the parents of accused No. 1 Vikram. Apprehending their arrest in said case, the respondent Nos. 2 and 3 herein had filed Criminal Misc. No. 1421/2024 before the II Additional District and Sessions Judge, Vijayapura, which was allowed on 08. 10. 2024 and the respondent Nos. 2 and 3 herein were granted anticipatory bail subject to certain conditions. Investigation of the case is completed and the charge sheet has been filed. Being aggrieved by the anticipatory bail granted to accused Nos. 2 and 3, the de facto complainant is before this Court 4. Perusal of the averments made in the first information dated 31. 07. 2024 would reveal that, the marriage of accused No. 1 who is the son of the respondent Nos. 2 and 3 herein, with the daughter of the first informant was performed in the year 2021 and from the said wedlock the couple had a child. On 30. 07. 2024, the accused No. 1 had informed the first informant that, Reshma had suffered low blood pressure and had died. On 31. 07. 2024 the first informant and her family members had gone to the house of accused No. 1 and had found the dead body of their daughter Reshma inside the compound wall of a school near Aluru Tanda, within the jurisdiction of Indi Rural Police Station. Since the first informant suspected with regard to the cause of death of her daughter, she had approached the police and had submitted first information, based on which an FIR was registered against Vikram and the respondent Nos. 2 and 3 herein. The police after investigation have filed charge-sheet against three persons. Respondent Nos. 2 and 3 have been arraigned as accused Nos. 2 and 3 in the charge-sheet. As per the charge-sheet allegations, on 30. 07. 2024, at about 7: 30 pm, when accused No. 1 and his wife Reshma were traveling in a car along with their child aged about six months, they had fought against each other and accused No. 1 - Vikram had made a demand with his wife to bring a sum of Rs. 5, 00, 000/- from her parents house. When the car in which accused No. 1 and his wife were traveling reached near Indi railway station, all of a sudden accused No. 1 got down from the car and after abusing his wife, with the help of a plastic cover which was in the hind seat of the car, he had strangulated the neck of his wife and had committed her murder. Thereafter, he drove the car to his parents' house and informed them that his wife had died as a result of low blood pressure and as per the advice of his parents he had left the dead body inside the compound wall of the school. Except this, there is no other allegation as against the parents of accused No. 1 who are respondent Nos. 2 and 3 in the present petition. Accused No. 2 is a teacher in a Government School and accused No. 3 who is his wife is a House maker. The learned Session Judge having appreciated all these aspects of the matter, has granted anticipatory bail to them and in compliance of the bail conditions they had appeared before the Investigating Officer and have co-operated with him for the purpose of investigation. 5. Under the circumstances, I do not find any good ground to interfere with the order of anticipatory bail granted to accused Nos. 2 and 3 in the present case. Accordingly, the following order: ORDER The criminal petition is dismissed. Sd/- (S. VISHWAJITH SHETTY) JUDGE SVH List No. : 1 Sl No. : 9 CT: PK

IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED 03. 07. 2018 CORAM THE HONOURABLE Mr. JUSTICE P. N. PRAKASH CRL. O. P. No. 16922 of 2018 and CRL. M. P. No. 8740 of 2018 Damodaran. . Petitioner Vs State by The Inspector of Police, All Women Police Station, Ayanavaram, Chennai-23. .. Respondent Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 Cr. P. C. , praying to call for the entire records connected with the order in Crl. M. P. No. 7906 of 2018 in S. C. No. 226 of 2016 dated 21. 05. 2018 passed by the Mahila Court, Chennai insofar as dismissing the petition under Section 311 Cr. P. C. for cross-examination of PW2, PW8 and PW9 and direct the Mahila Judge, Chennai permitting the petitioner to cross-examine PW2, PW8 and PW9. For Petitioner: Mr. B. Janakiram For Respondent: Ms. P. Kritika Kamal, GA [Crl. Side] O R D E R This Criminal Original Petition has been filed praying to set aside the order dated 21. 05. 2018, passed by the learned Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Chennai in Crl. M. P. No. 7906 of 2016 in S. C. No. 226 of 2016. 2. Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Government Advocate [Crl. Side] appearing for the respondent. 3. On the complaint lodged by Regina Mary that her six year old daughter[x] was sexually abused by the petitioner herein, the respondent Police registered a case in Crime No. 9 of 2015 and after completing the investigation, have filed a final report and trial in S. C. No. 226 of 2016 is pending on the file of the Mahila Court, Chennai for various offences under POCSO Act. Charges were framed against the petitioner/accused and the prosecution witnesses were examined. The victim girl-x was examined as PW2 on 09. 02. 2017. She was not cross-examined by the accused. The prosecution examined 11 witnesses, who were not cross-examined by the accused. After 1= years, the accused filed Crl. M. P. No. 7906 of 2018 in S. C. No. 226 of 2016 under Section 311 Cr. P. C. to recall PW1 to PW11, which has been partly allowed by the trial Court. Challenging which, the accused is before this Court. 4. On a reading of the impugned order, it is seen that the trial Court has refused permission to recall the victim girl-x [PW2]. But, whereas, the trial Court has ordered the recall of PW1, PW3 to PW7, PW10 and PW11. 5. Learned counsel for the accused submitted that a false case has been foisted on the accused and therefore, it is necessary for the accused to recall the victim girl-x and the two Doctors, namely, PW8 and PW9, who have examined the victim girl and the accused. He placed strong reliance on the judgment of the Supreme Court in Mannan SK and Others Vs State of West Bengal and Another, wherein, the Supreme Court has held as follows: The second part of the Section uses the word 'shall'. It says that the court shall summon and examine or recall or re-examine any such person if his evidence appears to it to be essential to the just decision of the case. The words 'essential to the just decision of the case' are the key words. The court must form an opinion that for the just decision of the case recall or re-examination of the witness is necessary. Since the power is wide it's exercise has to be done with circumspection. It is trite that wider the power greater is the responsibility on the courts which exercise it. .. . 6. This Court gave its anxious consideration to the rival submissions. It is true that power under Section 311 Cr. P. C. can be invoked at any time before the judgment is delivered, if it is found that the evidence of a particular witness is just and essential. In this case, the victim girl was examined on 09. 02. 2017. She was not cross-examined by the counsel. 7. Learned counsel for the accused submitted that the earlier counsel had bungled and therefore, on change of counsel, an opportunity should be given to recall the victim girl. Section 33[5] of the POCSO Act states that a child witness should not be called repeatedly to the Court for the purpose of examination. The idea behind this provision is that a child will suffer psychological trauma, if she is made to repeat the ordeal that was undergone by her. In this case, the victim is a nine year old girl. Proviso to Section 309 Cr. P. C. reads as follows: [b] the fact that the Pleader of a party is engaged in any other Court, shall not be a ground for adjournment. Thus, the statute says that just because the pleader of a party is engaged in another Court, that cannot be a ground for adjournment. It will be a travesty of justice to overlook Section 309 Cr. P. C. and Section 33[5] of POCSO Act and say that on account of change of counsel, the victim girl should be recalled. 8. As regards PW8 and PW9, they are Government Doctors, whose time is indeed precious. In Vinodh Kumar Vs State of Punjab reported in 2015[1] MLJ [Crl] 288, the Supreme Court has taken note of the pernicious practice that is prevailing in the trial Courts today, whereby no witness is cross-examined on the day they are examined in-chief, they recalled after several days and in the meantime, they are either intimidated or won over. 9. In Mannan S. K. case relied upon by the learned counsel for the accused, the prosecution wanted to recall the Investigating Officer, who had recorded the statement of the deceased at the scene of the offence. Since the statement of the deceased is relevant as dying declaration under Section 32 of the Evidence Act, the Supreme Court thought it fit, not to shut out such a valuable piece of evidence. 10. In A. G. Vs Shiv Kumar Yadav reported in 2015[9] Scale 649, the Supreme Court has stated that a petition under Section 311 Cr. P. C. cannot be allowed, on the mere asking even if the accused is in judicial custody. The reasons given by the accused to recall PW2, PW8 and PW9 does not pass muster, the law laid down by the Supreme Court in Vinodh Kumar's case and A. G. Vs Shiv Kumar Yadav's case. Under such circumstances, this Court does not find any infirmity in the order passed by the trial Court warranting interference and this petition stands dismissed. Consequently, connected Miscellaneous Petition is closed.

[case 60]

Punjab-Haryana High Court
Rakesh Kumar vs State Of Haryana on 5 September, 2018
Author: H. S. Madaan
Bench: H. S. Madaan
CRM-M-34093-2018 -1-
IN THE HIGH COURT OF PUNJAB AND HARYANA AT
CRM-M-34093-2018
Date of decision: -5. 9. 2018
State of Haryana
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE H. S. MADAAN
Present: Mr. Karan Singh, Advocate
for the petitioner.
Mr. Gaurav Bansal, AAG, Haryana.
Mr. G. C. Shahpuri, Advocate
for the complainant.
H. S. MADAAN, J.
This petition under Section 438 Cr. P. C. for pre-arrest bail has
been filed by the petitioner - Rakesh Kumar, an accused in FIR No. 30
dated 6. 7. 2018 under Section 8 of POCSO Act and 216 IPC, registered at
Women Police Station, Yamuna Nagar.
Briefly stated, the facts of the case, as per the prosecution
story, are that on 29. 12. 2017 when the prosecutrix aged about 16 years
had gone to her BARA from her house at village Dhaurang, District
Yamuna Nagar, then Rakesh son of Subhash (present petitioner) resident
of that very village misbehaved with her catching hold of arm of
prosecutrix. The prosecutrix narrated the entire story to her parents, then
police was informed by moving a written application at Women Police
Station, Yamuna Nagar at Jagadhri.
Apprehending his arrest in this case, the petitioner had
approached the Court of Sessions seeking grant of pre-arrest bail by filing
an application, however, his such request was declined by learned
Additional Sessions Judge (Exclusive Court for Heinous Crimes against
Women and Children), Yamuna Nagar at Jagadhri vide order dated
2. 8. 2018. As such, the petitioner has approached this Court asking for
the same relief.
Notice of the petition was given to respondent - State, which
put in appearance through counsel. The complainant has also appeared
through counsel.
I have heard learned counsel for the parties besides going
through the record and I do not find any merit in the present petition.
Learned counsel for the petitioner has argued that as a matter
of fact on 29. 12. 2017, the complainant Subhash Chand and his family
members had attacked family of petitioner causing injuries to them and on
that very day, Smt. Parveena wife of Mahinder Kumar had submitted a
complaint to SHO, Police Station Sadar, Yamuna Nagar regarding the
incident on which DDR No. 7 dated 30. 12. 2017 was entered in daily diary
and the present FIR is just a counter-blast to the complaint dated
29. 12. 2017 against family members of the complainant.
Whereas, learned State counsel and learned counsel for the
complainant submitted that the incident as per FIR in this case took place
on 29. 12. 2017. Admittedly, no action has been taken on the alleged
complaint submitted by Smt. Parveena regarding Subhash Chand and his
family allegedly attacking family of the petitioner and causing injuries to
them. If the police had found merit in the allegations observing that
commission of cognizable offence was disclosed, then FIR would have
normally been registered, which was not so done, rather it appears that the
DDR in question was lodged to create defence in the present FIR as a
pressure tactic and to set up a parallel case.
After hearing the rival contentions of learned counsel for the
parties, I find that the incidents of child abuse and molestation of young
girls are increasing day by day. It is not safe for the womenfolk to venture
out of their houses even. A serious law and order problem in that regard is
fast emerging. In case precautionary measures are not taken at the initial
stage, the things may get out of hand and would be very difficult to
control. The persons harassing molesting and sexually abusing young girls
need to be dealt with iron hand and no leniency can be shown to them.
Here the allegations against the petitioner are quite serious and grave. Pre
arrest bail is a discretionary relief and is to be granted in exceptional cases
and not in routine. It is meant to save the innocent persons from
harassment and inconvenience and not to screen the culprits from
custodial interrogation.
Custodial interrogation of the petitioner is definitely required
for complete and effective investigation. In case custodial interrogation of
the petitioner is denied to the investigating agency that would leave many
loose ends and gaps in the investigation affecting the investigation being
carried out adversely which is not called for.
Thus finding no merit in the petition, the same stands
5. 9. 2018 (H. S. MADAAN)
Brij JUDGE
Whether reasoned/speaking: Yes/No
Whether reportable: Yes/No

[case 61]
Mohd. Aleem, vs The State Oftelangana, on 13 September, 2022. The petitioners claim to be the joint owners of Plot No. 64, admeasuring 267 sq. yards situated in Sy. No. 844/16 forming part of Annapurna Cooperative Housing Society Limited, Malkajgiri, Ranga Reddy District, having purchased the same under registered sale deed dated 29. 09. 2010. Subsequently the petitioners constructed Ground plus Three floors (G+3) by obtaining permission from GHMC and the property was assessed with H. No. 17-119/A64. The petitioners had been staying in the ground floor of the said building. The petitioners gave first, second and third floor of the building to M/s. Save a Child, a private organization, represented by Sri M. Sunit Kumar, S/o. Christopher, under rental agreement dated 03. 07. 2014 for a period of 11 months. The lease was extended from time to time. While so, the respondent No. 2 addressed a communication dated 22. 06. 2017, along with a copy of a note approved by the Collector, Medchal-Malkajgiri District, stating that sexual abuse has happened on an inmate of 'Save a Child' orphanage by the founder M. Sunit Kumar and in that connection, the District Collector has given instructions to close and seize the movable and immovable property and bank accounts of the orphanage located in the premises of the petitioners. On the instructions of the District Collector, the respondent No. 4 directed the Village Revenue Officer, Malkajgiri, to seize the orphanage, which was being run in the first, second and third floors of the building of the petitioners. Accordingly, three floors were seized on 24. 06. 2017 under cover of panchanma. Learned counsel for the petitioners submitted that the 'Save a Child' orphanage is the tenant of the petitioners. In the process of taking action against the founder of the orphanage, the property of the petitioners could not have been seized. A request was made by the petitioners vide representation dated 08. 10. 2017 to the respondent No. 3 for releasing the seized property. The petitioners have given the property on lease to the orphanage for a monthly rent of Rs. 41, 000/-. The petitioner is put to loss since July 2017. There are several maintenance issues in the property. Learned Assistant Government Pleader for Women Development and Child Welfare Department submitted that the orphanage was seized for violation of the provisions of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 and the National Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Model Rules, 2016. The petitioners should have checked the registration certificate of the orphanage before giving the property on rent or lease. The petitioners allowed the founder of the orphanage to run a home for children in need of care and protection illegally. The orphanage management did not submit original copies of the rental agreement at the time of inspection. The petitioner did not register the lease deed of the building at the concerned Sub-Registrar. FIR No. 446 of 2017 was registered against Sunith Kumar, in-charge of the orphanage, under Section 12 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012 and under Section 376-C and 506 IPC with L. B. Nagar Police Station. The seized movable and immovable property of the orphanage was kept in the building of the petitioners. As per the orders of the I Additional cum Metropolitan Sessions Judge, L. B. Nagar, action will be taken on the movable and immovable properties. Learned counsel for the petitioners submitted that the petitioners are not the accused in FIR. No. 446 of 2017. The petitioners are only the owners of the subject premises and the seizure is illegal. As such, there is no requirement for the petitioners to approach the concerned Court for release of the premises/property. It is not in dispute that the petitioners are the owners of the property and the orphanage is the tenant. The contention of the learned Assistant Government Pleader that the petitioners should have registered the lease deed and should have checked the antecedents of the orphanage before giving the property on lease is without any merit. The petitioners, being landlords, would only enquire whether the tenant has the capacity to pay the rents and also ensure that illegal activities are not carried out in the tenanted premises. The misuse of the tenanted property by the tenant and that too after the property was taken on lease cannot in any manner be attributed to the petitioners. The petitioners are not involved in the criminal case, so also the petitioners do not have any civil liability for the illegal activities committed by their tenant and as such, the seizure of the premises is ex facie illegal. However, as the property is stated to have been seized pursuant to registration of FIR. No. 446 of 2017, it would be appropriate to dispose of the writ petition with the following directions: 1. The petitioners shall submit an application to the I Additional cum Metropolitan Sessions Judge, L. B. Nagar, seeking release of the subject premises, seized by the Village Revenue Officer, on the directions of the respondent No. 4 on 24. 06. 2017 under the cover of panchanama. 2. The application filed by the petitioners shall be considered and appropriate orders shall be passed forthwith by the I Additional cum Metropolitan Sessions Judge, L. B. Nagar, releasing the subject premises of the petitioners by imposing reasonable conditions. 3. The documents, movable properties, articles etc. of the orphanage viz. Save a Child, shall be forthwith shifted by concerned police with due intimation to the I Additional District Judge cum Metropolitan Sessions Judge, L. B. Nagar and the same shall be kept in the custody of the police station or the Court or any other safe place in accordance with law. If necessary, permission of the Court shall be taken by the police for shifting the documents, movable properties, articles etc. The miscellaneous petitions pending, if any, shall stand closed. There shall be no order as to costs.

[case 62]
CRR No. 2085 of 2016 (O&M) Date of Decision: July 17, 2018 Dharambir. .. Petitioner Versus State of Haryana and another. .. Respondents CORAM: - HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE JAISHREE THAKUR Present: - Mr. S. S. Momi, Advocate for the petitioner. Mr. P. P. Chahar, DAG Haryana. Mr. J. S. Mehndiratta, Advocate for respondents No. 2 and 3. This is a criminal revision filed against the order dated 13. 05. 2016 passed by the Additional Sessions Judge, Sonepat, where the application filed by the petitioner-complainant under Section 216 of Code of Criminal Procedure for amendment in the charges, by way of framing the charge under Section 305 of Indian Penal Code instead of 306 of IPC and for further framing the charge under Section 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of the POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC against the accused persons, has been dismissed. In short, the facts of the case are that FIR No. 452 dated 05. 09. 2015 came to be registered under Section 306 read with Section 34 of IPC at Police Station Sadar, Sonipat against respondents No. 2 and 3 herein on the complaint of petitioner-complainant that on 05. 09. 2015 at around 05. 00 his daughter Deepika committed suicide due to threatening given by Hanni and his mother Suman (respondents No. 2 and 3 herein). It was also alleged that when his daughter went to South Point School tour to Delhi, accused Hanni also reached there and did obscene act with his daughter. When his daughter Deepika returned back, she disclosed this incident to her mother, on which they narrated this matter to Hanni's family, but instead of rebuking her son, Hanni's mother insulted Deepika. Hanni's mother also went to South Point School and insulted his daughter Deepika. Deepika was very upset with the behaviour of Hanni and his mother Suman, compelling her to the extreme step of committing suicide. During the course of investigation, a suicide note was recovered from the lower/trouser worn by the deceased at the time of her death, which was sent to FSL for verification of handwriting of the deceased and as per the report of Forensic Science Laboratory, the handwriting on the suicide note is of the deceased. After completing the investigation, final report under Section 173 Cr. P. C. was filed in the court against respondents No. 2 and 3 under Sections 306/34 of IPC and thereafter, the trial court framed the charges under Sections 306/34 of IPC by an order dated 11. 12. 2015. Thereafter, the petitioner-complainant moved an application under Section 216 Cr. P. C. for amendment of charge on the ground that since the deceased in the instant case was less than 18 years of age, she was a child, and therefore, charge under Section 305 of IPC is required to be framed instead of Section 306 of IPC, but the said application came to be dismissed on 27. 01. 2016. Thereafter, a supplementary challan was filed by the police under Section 173(8) of the Cr. P. C containing documents, birth certificate of Deepika (deceased) and statement of her mother Ishwanti. After that, the petitioner-complainant filed another application under Section 216 of Cr. P. C. for amendment in the charges, by way of framing the charge under Section 305 of IPC instead of 306 of IPC and for further framing the charge under Section 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of the POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC against the accused persons, which application came to be dismissed by the impugned order dated 13. 05. 2016. Mr. S. S. Momi, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner argues that it is an admitted fact on the case file the date of birth of deceased Deepika was 09. 11. 2000 and on the date of the occurrence, the deceased was minor, aged about 14 years, at the time when she committed suicide. The age of the deceased is mentioned as 14 years on the postmortem report. It is contended that as per the suicide note, the accused committed 'jabardasti' with the deceased. Meaning thereby, the deceased was molested and sexually abused and as such, charges under Sections 305, 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC are made out against the accused. Mr. J. S. Mehndiratta, learned counsel appearing on behalf of respondents No. 2 and 3 argues that there is nothing on record to amend the charges already framed. It is submitted that the earlier application filed by the learned Public Prosecutor under Section 216 of Cr. P. C. for amendment of charge has already been dismissed by the trial court and the suicide note was already on the file at the time of framing of charges in the present case. I have heard learned counsel for the parties, apart from perusing the record. On the basis of the complaint filed by the petitioner-complainant and the investigation done by the police, final report under Section 173 Cr. P. C. was filed under Section 306 read with Section 34 of IPC. The earlier application moved under Section 216 Cr. P. C. came to be dismissed on 27. 01. 2016 by the trial court, while observing that there is no material pertaining to date of birth of the deceased in the form of birth certificate or in the statement of her father has been found. Thereafter, a supplementary challan came to be filed under Section 173(8) Cr. P. C. containing the date of birth certificate of the deceased. However, the trial court has not said anything about the date of birth certificate of the deceased. The trial court further observed the suicide note prima facie makes out an offence under Section 306 of IPC, although the trial court did not consider the date of birth certificate of the deceased, submitted in the form of supplementary statement. Under these peculiar facts and circumstances, prima facie, at this stage, a case under Section 305 read with Section 34 of IPC is made out against the accused persons and the charge is required to be altered accordingly. In view of the above, the criminal revision in hand is partly allowed and the impugned order passed by the trial court is set aside to the above extent only.

[case 63]
CRR No. 2085 of 2016 (O&M) Date of Decision: July 17, 2018 Dharambir. .. Petitioner Versus State of Haryana and another. .. Respondents CORAM: - HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE JAISHREE THAKUR Present: - Mr. S. S. Momi, Advocate for the petitioner. Mr. P. P. Chahar, DAG Haryana. Mr. J. S. Mehndiratta, Advocate for respondents No. 2 and 3. This is a criminal revision filed against the order dated 13. 05. 2016 passed by the Additional Sessions Judge, Sonepat, where the application filed by the petitioner-complainant under Section 216 of Code of Criminal Procedure for amendment in the charges, by way of framing the charge under Section 305 of Indian Penal Code instead of 306 of IPC and for further framing the charge under Section 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of the POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC against the accused persons, has been dismissed. Hanni's mother also went to South Point School and insulted his daughter Deepika. Deepika was very upset with the behaviour of Hanni and his mother Suman, compelling here to the extreme step of committing suicide. During the course of investigation, a suicide note was recovered from the lower/trouser worn by the deceased at the time of her death, which was sent to FSL for verification of handwriting of the deceased and as per the report of Forensic Science Laboratory, the handwriting on the suicide note is of the deceased. After completing the investigation, final report under Section 173 Cr. P. C. was filed in the court against respondents No. 2 and 3 under Sections 306/34 of IPC and thereafter, the trial court framed the charges under Sections 306/34 of IPC by an order dated 11. 12. 2015. C. for amendment of charge on the ground that since the deceased in the instant case was less than 18 years of age, she was a child, and therefore, charge under Section 305 of IPC is to be framed instead of Section 306 of IPC, but the said application came to be dismissed on 27. 01. 2016. After that, the petitioner-complainant filed another application under Section 216 of Cr. P. C. for amendment in the charges, by way of framing the charge under Section 305 of IPC instead of 306 of IPC and for further framing the charge under Section 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of the POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC against the accused persons, which application came to be dismissed by the impugned order dated 13. 05. 2016. Mr. S. S. Momi, learned counsel appearing on behalf of the petitioner argues that it is an admitted fact on the case file the date of birth of deceased Deepika was 09. 11. 2000 and on the date of the occurrence, the deceased was minor, aged about 14 years, at the time when she committed suicide. The age of the deceased is mentioned as 14 years on the postmortem report. It is contended that as per the suicide note, the accused committed 'jabardasti' with the deceased. Meaning thereby, the deceased was molested and sexually abused and as such, charges under Sections 305, 376 of IPC and Sections 6, 8, 12 of POCSO Act read with Section 120-B of IPC are made out against the accused. Mr. J. S. Mehndiratta, learned counsel appearing on behalf of respondents No. 2 and 3 argues that there is nothing on record to amend the charges already framed. It is submitted that the earlier application filed by the learned Public Prosecutor under Section 216 of Cr. P. C. for amendment of charge has already been dismissed by the trial court and the suicide note was already on the file at the time of framing of charges in the present case. I have heard learned counsel for the parties, apart from perusing the record. On the basis of the complaint filed by the petitioner-complainant and the investigation done by the police, final report under Section 173 Cr. P. C. was filed under Section 306 read with Section 34 of IPC. The earlier application moved under Section 216 Cr. P. C. came to be dismissed on 27. 01. 2016 by the trial court, while observing that there is no material pertaining to date of birth of the deceased in the form of birth certificate or in the statement of her father has been found. Thereafter, a supplementary challan came to be filed under Section 173(8) Cr. P. C. containing the date of birth certificate of the deceased. However, the trial court has not said anything about the date of birth certificate of the deceased. The trial court further observed the suicide note prima facie makes out an offence under Section 306 of IPC, although the trial court did not consider the date of birth certificate of the deceased, submitted in the form of supplementary statement. Under these peculiar facts and circumstances, prima facie, at this stage, a case under Section 305 read with Section 34 of IPC is made out against the accused persons and the charge is required to be altered accordingly. In view of the above, the criminal revision in hand is partly allowed and the impugned order passed by the trial court is set aside to the above extent only.

[case 64]
2. Heard Sri Rajiv Kumar Tripathi, learned counsel for the applicant as well as Sri Sunil Kumar, learned A. G. A. for the State and perused the record.
3. Applicant seeks bail in Case Crime No. 39 of 2024, under Sections 498-A, 304-B, 323, 504, 506 I. P. C. and 3/4 D. P. Act, Police Station- Kailiya, District- Jalaun, during the pendency of trial.
PROSECUTION STORY:
4. The marriage of the applicant was solemnized with the daughter of the informant as per Hindu Rites on 12. 5. 2018. The applicant and other family members are stated to have subjected her to cruelty for demand of a motorcycle as dowry, thereby, leading her to death on 26. 6. 2024.
ARGUMENTS ON BEHALF OF APPLICANT:
5. The applicant is absolutely innocent and has been falsely implicated in the present case.
6. The FIR is delayed by about one day and there is no explanation of the said delay caused. No time of offence is mentioned in the FIR.
7. The informant herein is Panch witness no. 1 in the inquest proceedings, which was undertaken on the information given by the brother of the applicant to the police. The inquest report was already complete on 26. 6. 2024 at 08: 45 p. m.
8. The victim was depressed as she could not bear any child and the applicant had dark complexion.
9. Several other submissions have been made on behalf of the applicant to demonstrate the falsity of the allegations made against him. The circumstances which, as per counsel, led to the false implication of the applicant have also been touched upon at length.
10. There is no criminal history of the applicant. The applicant is languishing in jail since 6. 7. 2024 and is ready to cooperate with trial. In case, the applicant is released on bail, he will not misuse the liberty of bail.
ARGUMENTS ON BEHALF OF STATE/OPPOSITE PARTY:
11. The bail application has been opposed but the submissions raised by the learned counsel for the applicant could not be disputed.
12. In light of the judgement of the Supreme Court passed in Niranjan Singh and another vs Prabhakar Rajaram Kharote and others AIR 1980 SC 785, this Court has avoided detailed examination of the evidence and elaborate documentation of the merits of the case as no party should have the impression that his case has been prejudiced. A prima facie satisfaction of case is needed but it is not the same as an exhaustive exploration of the merits in the order itself.
13. The well-known principle of "Presumption of Innocence Unless Proven Guilty" gives rise to the concept of bail as a rule and imprisonment as an exception.
14. A person's right to life and liberty, guaranteed by Article 21 of the Indian Constitution, cannot be taken away simply because the person is accused of committing an offence until the guilt is established beyond a reasonable doubt. Article 21 of the Indian Constitution states that no one's life or personal liberty may be taken away unless the procedure established by law is followed, and the procedure must be just and reasonable. The said principle has been recapitulated by the Supreme Court in Satender Kumar Antil Vs. Central Bureau of Investigation and Ors. , 2022 INSC 690.
15. Reiterating the aforesaid view the Supreme Court in the case of Manish Sisodia Vs. Directorate of Enforcement 2024 INSC 595 has again emphasised that the very well-settled principle of law that bail is not to be withheld as a punishment is not to be forgotten. It is high time that the Courts should recognize the principle that bail is a rule and jail is an exception? .
16. Learned AGA could not bring forth any exceptional circumstances which would warrant denial of bail to the applicant.
17. It is settled principle of law that the object of bail is to secure the attendance of the accused at the trial. No material particulars or circumstances suggestive of the applicant fleeing from justice or thwarting the course of justice or creating other troubles in the shape of repeating offences or intimidating witnesses and the like have been shown by learned AGA.
18. Considering the facts and circumstances of the case, submissions made by learned counsel for the parties, the evidence on record, and without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case, the Court is of the view that the applicant has made out a case for bail. The bail application is allowed.
19. Let the applicant- Dilip involved in aforementioned case crime number be released on bail on furnishing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned subject to following conditions.
(i) The applicant shall not tamper with evidence.
(ii) The applicant shall remain present, in person, before the Trial Court on dates fixed for (1) opening of the case, (2) framing of charge and (3) recording of statement under Section 313 Cr. P. C. /351 B. N. S. S. If in the opinion of the Trial Court absence of the applicant is deliberate or without sufficient cause, then it shall be open for the Trial Court to treat such default as abuse of liberty of bail and proceed against him in accordance with law.
20. In case of breach of any of the above conditions, it shall be a ground for cancellation of bail. Identity, status and residence proof of the applicant and sureties be verified by the court concerned before the bonds are accepted.
21. It is made clear that observations made in granting bail to the applicant shall not in any way affect the learned trial Judge in forming his independent opinion based on the testimony of the witnesses.
Order Date: - 10. 1. 2025/ Vikas
(Justice Krishan Pahal)

[case 65]
Madras High Court Ravichandiran vs State Rep. By on 26 February, 2024 Author: T. V. Thamilselvi Bench: T. V. Thamilselvi Crl. O. P. No. 6605 of 2022 IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 26. 02. 2024 CORAM: THE HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE T. V. THAMILSELVI Crl. O. P. No. 6605 of 2022 and Crl. M. P. No. 3751 of 2022 1. Ravichandiran 2. Chandira 3. Deepika. .. Petitioners Versus 1. State rep. by, The Inspector of Police, All Women Police Station, Villianur, Puducherry. Crime No. 5 of 2019 2. Sreemathy. .. Respondents PRAYER: Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code, praying to call for the records in C. C. No. 548 of 2021 pending on the file of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Puducherry and quash the same. This petition has been filed to quash the proceedings in C. C. No. 548 of 2021 pending on the file of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Puducherry in which cognizance was taken for the offence under Sections 498(A), 324, 406, 294(B), 120(B), 506(ii) IPC r/w 34 IPC @ u/s 498(A), 406, 294(B), 120(B), 506(ii) IPC r/w 34 IPC and Sec. 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act. The case of the prosecution is the 1st and 2nd petitioners / A2 & A3 are the father-in-law and mother-in-law of the 2nd respondent / defacto complainant. The 3rd petitioner / A4 is the sister in law of the 2nd respondent. A1/ Dhinesh Raj is the husband of the defacto complainant. The petitioners along with A1 had subjected the defacto complainant to cruelty and harassed during her marital period by demanding more dowry and abused in filthy languages and threatened her with dire consequences of her life and also misappropriated her sridhana properties and gold items. Hence, the complaint. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the marriage took place between A1 and 2nd respondent on 21. 04. 2017 at Raja Thirumana Mahal, Villianur Bypass Road, Pondicherry, out of the wedlock, a female child was born. He further submitted that the based on the complaint given by the defacto complainant the respondent police had conducted enquiry and closed the complaint. Thereafter, the defacto complainant filed a petition under Section 156(3) CrPC before the learned Chief Judicial Magistrate, Puducherry in Crl. M. P. No. 3071 of 2019. The learned trial Judge passed an order to direct the 1st respondent to conduct and enquiry and report. Thereafter, the respondent police registered the case against the petitioners and A1 / Dhinesh Raj under Sections 498A, 324, 406, 294(B), 120(B), 506(ii) IPC r/w 34 IPC in Crime No. 05/2019 dated 04. 12. 2019. Subsequently, the sections were altered under Section 498(A), 406, 294(B), 120(B), 506(ii) IPC r/w 34IPC and Section 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act. The same has been reported before the learned trial Judge on 30. 06. 2021 by the 1st respondent. He also submitted that the petitioners are innocent and they have been falsely implicated in this case. The petitioners are never harassed the defacto complainant at any point of time and they are not demanding dowry from the defacto complainant. He further submitted that the petitioners returned the Jewels and Sreedhana Articles belongs to the defacto complainant and also there is no specific overt act against these petitioners. Hence, he prays to quash the CC. No. 548 of 2021, against the petitioners. The learned Government Advocate (Crl. Side) submitted that there was a matrimonial dispute among the petitioners & A1 and the defacto complainant. Due to the harassment and dowry demand of the petitioners, the defacto complainant lodged a complainant before the 1st respondent. Based on the complaint FIR was registered in Crime No. 5 of 2019 and have been taken cognizance for the offences under Sections 498(A), 406, 294(B), 120(B), 506(ii) IPC r/w 34 IPC and Sec. 4 of Dowry Prohibition Act. During the pendency of the proceedings, the learned Advocate Commissioner was appointed to take inventory of the articles in Bank locker stands in the name of A1 and 2nd petitioner with the help of bank officials, SBI Branch, Villiyanur, Pondicherry and identify the jewels and file a inventory report along with photographs before this Court on or before 26. 02. 2024.  On 21. 02. 2024 at 2. 50 p. m. , the learned Advocate Commissioner was opened the locker in the presence of Branch Manager, Cash Officer and parties with advocates, wherein one Tiffin Box, two small jewel boxes and one family partition document and Kalayan Jewellery Card were being kept in the locker. The jewels found in the locker was belonged to the mother-in-law of the defacto complainant and the defacto complainant also identified and admitted that Jewels kept in the locker was not belonged to her. The safe deposit locker account was opened in the name of Chandra on 11. 01. 2016 and later it was converted into joint account on the request from Chandra to add his son name Dinesh Raj /A1. Thereafter, the locker was operated by mother-in-law and her husband / A1 in joint account commenced from 15. 04. 2016. According to the defacto complainant, after the marriage all the jewels were kept in the Bank locker. But, the learned counsel for the petitioners submitted all her jewels and sreedhana articles were returned to the defacto complainant when she left her matrimonial home. The defacto complainant and A1 appeared in person before this Court, and they have some telephonic conversations with regard to return of jewels. It can be proved only before the trial and they also raise all their defence before the trial Court. Hence, this Court declines to quash the proceedings in C. C. No. 548 of 2021 pending on the file of the Chief Metropolitan Magistrate, Puducherry. Accordingly, this Criminal Original Petition is dismissed. The Advocate Commissioner report shall form part and parcel of this order. Consequently, the connected Miscellaneous petition is closed.

[case 67]
CisSc No. 7095/16 State vs. Fareem Beg Page 1 Of 6 on 30 May, 2017. IN THE COURT OF SHRI BALWANT RAI BANSAL ADDITIONAL SESSIONS JUDGE1 (SOUTH), NEW DELHI. CIS  Sessions Case No. 7095/16 FIR No. 391/15 Police Station: Mehrauli In the matter of: State VERSUS Fareem Beg S/o Sh. Mahboob Beg Present Address:  Coconut Shop situated at CNG Pump, Dera Road, Rajpur Khurd, Delhi Permanent Address:  V. P. O. Mavai Kajiyan Tehsil Baheri, PS Sher Garh, District Bareilly, U. P. Date of Institution: 11. 12. 2015 Date of Reserving judgment: Not reserved Date of pronouncement: 30. 05. 2017 JUDGMENT 1. In the present case, accused Fareem Beg S/o Mahboob Beg has been charged and facing trial for the commission of offences punishable under section 354 of Indian Penal Code (in short 'IPC') and section 10 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (in short 'POCSO Act'), 2012 r/w section 9 of the said Act on the allegations of outraging the modesty of a girl child, namely, V (real name withheld in order to conceal her identity), aged about 8 years and committing aggravated sexual assault upon her. 2. The FIR in question was registered on the complaint of Raju Yadav, the father of the victim girl, who in his complaint has alleged that on 23. 08. 2015 at 6. 00 PM, accused Fareem Beg along with his two associates namely Naim and Sehzad misbehaved with his victim daughter, abused her and gesturing with her and when he objected to the same, he was threatened by accused and his associates. On the said complaint of the father of the victim, the present FIR was registered u/s 506/509 of IPC and section 12 of POCSO Act on 24. 08. 2015 and the investigation was commenced. 3. During course of investigation, counseling of victim girl was conducted by NGO Mehar Charitable Society through DCW and her statement under section 161 of Cr. P. C. was recorded and site plan of place of occurrence was prepared at the instance of complainant Raju Yadav. Statement of the victim under section 164 of Cr. P. C. was also got recorded. During further investigation, date of birth proof of the victim girl was collected and accused Fareem Beg was arrested on 13. 10. 2015 and was sent to judicial custody. However, subsequently he was granted bail by the Hon'ble High Court of Delhi vide order dated 27. 04. 2016. Another accused Shezad had joined the investigation but no sufficient evidence against him was found and therefore IO kept his name in column No. 12 of the chargesheet. The coaccused namely Faim @ Naim who is brother of accused Fareem Beg was evading and he is at large. NBWs against him were taken. On the basis of the statement of the victim girl recorded under section 164 of Cr. P. C, section 506/509 IPC and Section 12 of POCSO Act were added and challan was prepared under sections 354/506/509/34 of IPC and section 8 & 12 of POCSO Act and put up before the court on 11. 12. 2015 for trial against the accused Fareem Beg. 4. On 29. 02. 2016, after hearing the Ld. Defence Counsel for the accused Fareem Beg and the Ld. Special Public Prosecution, Charge for the offences punishable under sections 354 of IPC and. 5. The victim and the complainant, who is also father of the victim on whose complaint the present FIR got registered against the accused Fareem Beg, are the star and material witnesses of the prosecution, who could have proved the allegations levelled against the accused. But the prosecution has miserably failed to examine both the witnesses despite availing sufficient opportunities. The prosecution even could not trace out the victim and her father and they could not be served despite best efforts made by the prosecution. The victim girl though in her statement recorded u/s 164 Cr. P. C. stated that she was playing at 6'O clock in the evening and at that time Naim, Fareem (accused in the present case) and Shejzaad came there. Naim caught her, Fareem caught and kissed her and put his both the hands in her panty and tried to open her pajama. She shouted loudly then her father came and they all fled away. She further sated that Fareem and Naim came to her father later and threatened him if he would make any complaint in this regard, they would kill her father. But the victim girl did not appear in the witness box to prove all these allegations. In the absence of testimony of victim and her father, no incriminating evidence has come on record against the accused. There is no other eyewitness to the incident. Rest of the witnesses are formal i. e. the counselor who counseled the victim, the principal to prove the age of the victim, DO to prove the registration of FIR, IO and the Ld. MM who recorded the statement of victim u/s 164 Cr. P. C. Hence, it will be a futile exercise to examine rest of the witnesses in this case, as none of them is an eyewitness to the incident. Continuing with this trial any further, will only result in wastage of time and resources, and there will be no impact on the result of this trial. Hence, the prosecution evidence is closed and the SA of the accused is dispensed with. 6. In the overall facts and circumstances of the case, there being no material or incriminating evidence against the accused Fareem Beg, he cannot be said to be guilty of committing the offences as charged against him and he is entitled to be acquitted. Accordingly, Accused Fareem Beg is acquitted of the offences punishable under sections 354 of IPC and section 10 of POCSO Act. 7. However, Fareem Beg is required to furnish bail bond under section 437A of Cr. P. C, which shall remain in force for a period of six months. 8. File be consigned to Record Room, after due compliance of provisions of section 437A of Cr. P. C. by Fareem Beg. Pronounced in the open Court (Balwant Rai Bansal) on 30th of May, 2017. Additional Sessions Judge01 South District: Saket Courts: New Delhi.

[case 68]
The brief facts of the case of the appellant are that the appellant married the respondent on 17. 08. 2001 as per Christian rites and customs. Due to wedlock, they begotten two children. The respondent/wife filed a petition before the lower Court for divorce on the ground of cruelty and the appellant herein resisted the same by filing counter. However, the lower Court, only on considering the oral evidence adduced by the respondent side has granted the decree of divorce. Hence, the present appeal.
Learned counsel for the appellant would state that the divorce petition was filed on the ground of cruelty but the respondent/wife has not proved that the same. The further allegation of the respondent against the appellant that he is not maintaining the family was also not proved. Even when the respondent was cross examined as P. W. 1, she had categorically stated that her father is not helping her for running the family. Therefore, it is proved that only the appellant is maintaining the family. It was also alleged by the respondent that the appellant had assaulted the respondent and the appellant married one Beula. The said allegation was also not proved. The respondent did not give any complaint to the police for assaulting her and she did not file any document to prove the alleged marriage of the appellant with Beula. Without considering all these aspects and without any basis, the lower Court had erroneously passed the decree of divorce as against the appellant. Hence, the learned counsel prays to set aside the judgement and decree passed by the lower Court.
Per contra, learned counsel appearing for the respondent would state that though the appellant and the respondent loved each other and got married with the consent of their parents, the appellant did not spare a single paise to meet the domestic expenses and education expenses of the children. When the same was questioned, the appellant assaulted her and abused her in unparliamentary words and harassed her both physically and mentally and the same had become a routine affair in day to day life. Further, the appellant pressurized the respondent to bring more money from her parents for his extravagance. The appellant created unhealthy atmosphere in the marital home. The appellant had association with anti-social elements and was also arrested in a case of attempt to murder and later, remanded to judicial custody. The respondent mobilized funds and spent about Rs. 2 lakhs for getting the appellant on bail. But the appellant did not choose to clear the debts borrowed by the respondent for his release on bail. When the respondent advised him to rectify his adamant character, he threatened her and assaulted her. Further, the appellant developed intimacy with another lady viz. , R. Beula. When the respondent lodged a complaint against him before the All Women Police Station, he accepted that he had married her. Thereafter, the appellant deserted the respondent and two children and is living with the said Beula. The appellant had deserted the respondent and two children and unable to tolerate the cruelty, the respondent came under the shelter of her parents along with her children. Therefore, the learned counsel for the respondent would state that only on considering all the above factual aspects, the lower court had granted the decree of divorce and the same need not be interfered with.
Heard the learned counsel for the appellant, learned counsel for the respondent and perused the materials available on record.
It is not in dispute that the respondent is a Hindu and the appellant is a Christian and they got married as per the Christian rites and customs. Due to wedlock, two children were born to them. From the records, it is seen that the appellant did not provide any monetary help to the respondent. The evidence of P. W. 2, who is the father of the respondent, would also go to show that he is only looking after his daughter and her children till date and the appellant used abusive language and beat his daughter when she questioned his irresponsible behaviour. The second marriage of the appellant with one Beula and that he got a girl child through Beula was also proved by examining one P. W. 3, who is none other than the cousin brother of the appellant. Contracting second marriage while the first marriage is in existence would not only amount to bigamy but also amount to cruelty. In view of the above, we are of the view that the lower Court, on considering the oral and documentary evidence had rightly granted divorce on the ground of cruelty, with which, we find no infirmity or illegality to interfere with. Accordingly, the Civil Miscellaneous Appeal fails and the same stands dismissed. No costs. Consequently, connected miscellaneous petition is closed.

[case 69]

[case 70]
Dated: 14-07-2023 Shri F. A. Shah- Advocate for the appellant. Dr. Anjali Gyanani - Public Prosecutor for respondent/State. Heard on I. A. No. 7003 of 2023, which is first application under Section 389(1) Cr. P. C. filed on behalf of appellant-Akhtar Khan seeking suspension of sentence and grant of bail. Appellant-Akhtar Khan stood convicted under Section 4(2) of POCSO Act and sentenced to undergo 20 years' R. I. with a fine of Rs. 2, 000/- and under Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and sentenced to undergo 2 years' R. I with a fine of Rs. 1, 000/- with default stipulations vide judgment of conviction and order of sentence dated 15/12/2022 passed by Special Judge (POCSO Act), Shivpuri (M. P. ) in Special Case No. 124/2019. Present appellant so far has undergone incarceration of about 17 months in toto, as transpired during the course of hearing. Co-accused/Appellant No. 1 in Criminal Appeal No. 838 of 2023-Shakil Khan is the biological father of the prosecutrix as after the demise of his first wife and mother of the prosecutrix, he married to co-accused Shehnaz Bano. As per prosecution story, the prosecutrix claiming herself to be 14 years of age, on 20/09/2019, lodged an FIR to the effect that for the last 4-5 years since the time her mother expired, she was ill-treated by her step-mother Shehnaz Bano off and on. She, therefore, had left the house and started living with her grand-parents. Thereafter, on 1/1/2019, while she was staying with her maternal uncle's house, step-mother Shehnaz came there and against her wishes brought her back. Thereafter, she started searching for the match though she was not major. She manipulated her marriage (Nikah) with accused/appellant Akhtar and Farukh Khan had reduced in writing the process of Nikah. After so-called solemnization of marriage (Nikah), she was subjected to forcible sexual abuse against her wishes by Akhtar from 24/08/2019 to 28/08/2019. Thereafter, accused/appellant Akhtar called her grand-parents to the Kota Court and whereafter, signing of certain documents, she was given in custody of her grand-parents. Thereafter, she came back to her grand-parents' house from Kota. It is alleged that appellant Akhtar had also threatened the prosecutrix with dire consequences, if she divulged the factum of marriage and that of sexual abuse. In the aforesaid backdrop, the prosecutrix filed the complaint and the same was registered at Crime No. 213/19. Based thereupon, investigation was set in motion. The Investigating Officer, upon collection of incriminating evidence, filed challan. The Special Court upon critical evaluation of the evidence placed on record convicted and sentenced the present appellant as aforesaid. Learned counsel for the appellant while taking exception to the impugned judgement submits that the prosecutrix in her statement before the Court has clearly stated that her date of birth is 11/10/2000 as recorded in Aadhar Card and therefore, she was major as on the date of incident. However, the trial Court in Para-20 of the judgement, ignored the same and relied upon her date of birth as per the certificate of the Municipal Corporation, Kota (Ex. P/10) as 11/10/2005. That apart, she has turned hostile and belied the story of prosecution. Shakil Khan, co-convict/appellant No. 1 in Criminal Appeal No. 838 of 2023, has already been admitted to suspension of sentence and grant of bail vide order dated 27. 04. 2023. On such grounds, learned counsel prays for suspension of sentence and grant of bail to the present appellant. Per contra, learned Public Prosecutor for respondent/State, while opposing the application supporting the judgment impugned submits that looking to the gravity of offence, no exception can be taken in the matter of suspension of sentence and grant of bail to the present appellant. Upon hearing learned counsel for the parties, though this Court refrains from commenting upon rival contentions touching merits of the case but regard being had to the fact that co-convict/appellant No. 1 -Shakil Khan in Criminal Appeal No. 838 of 2023 has already been admitted to suspension of sentence and grant of bail vide order dated 27. 04. 2023, the present appellant has so far undergone incarceration of 17 months in toto coupled with the fact that appeal is of the year 2023 and there is no likelihood of its early hearing in near future and therefore, in the obtaining facts and circumstances, we hereby extend the benefit of suspension of sentence and grant of bail to present appellant-Akhtar Khan. Accordingly, I. A. 7003 of 2023 stands allowed and it is directed that the jail sentence of appellant-Akhtar Khan shall remain suspended during pendency of present appeal and he shall be released on bail, subject to verification of amount of fine being deposited and on his furnishing a personal bond in the sum of Rs. 2, 00, 000/- (Rupees Two Lacs only) with one solvent surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of the Trial Court. Appellant-Akhtar Khan is directed to appear before the Registry of this Court first on 13. 09. 2023 and on other subsequent dates as may be fixed by Office in this behalf. Observations on facts, if any, are only for the purpose of disposal of the application for suspension of sentence and shall have no bearing on the merits of the appeal. Certified copy as per rules. (ROHIT ARYA) (SANJEEV S KALGAONKAR) JUDGE JUDGE pd
