IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT: THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V THURSDAY, THE 12TH DAY OF JULY 2018 / 21ST ASHADHA, 1940 Bail Appl. .No. 4577 of 2018 ------------------- CRIME NO. 388/2018 OF KILIKOLLOOR POLICE STATION, KOLLAM PETITIONER/ACCUSED. BABU @ BABU RAJAN PILLAI, AGED 52 YEARS, S/O RAGHAVAN PILLAI, MANGALAM NAGAR 122, PUNTHALATHAZHAM, VADAKKEVILA VILLAGE, KILIKOLLOOR, KOLLAM. BY ADV. SRI. BIJU C. ABRAHAM RESPONDENT/STATE. STATE OF KERALA REPRESENTED BY THE INSPECTOR OF POLICE, KILIKOLLOOR, KOLLAM DISTRICT, THROUGH THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM. BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR MR. C. N. PRABHAKARAN THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 12-07-2018, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V. , J ================== B. A. No. 4577 of 2018 ================== Dated this the 12th day of July, 2018 ORDER This application is filed under B' 439 of the Cr. P. C. 2. The applicant herein is the accused in Crime No. 388 of 2018 of the Kilikolloor Police Station, registered under B' 354A of the IPC, B' 9(n) r/w. B' 10 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012, and also under B'75 of the Juvenile Justice (Care & Protection of Children) Act, 2015. 3. The de facto complainant is the mother of the survivor child, who is aged about 14 years and studying in the IX Standard. She alleged that her daughter was found missing on 11. 6. 2018 from school. A crime was registered under Section 57 of the Kerala Police Act, 2011. The minor child was traced out later. She disclosed that she was in love with a boy and she had eloped with him. She also disclosed that she has had an active sexual relationship with the said boy, who is aged 19 years. In the said statement, she also disclosed that the applicant herein, who is her step-father, has touched her breasts with sexual intent on more than one occasion. On these allegations, two Crimes were registered. Crime No. 387 of 2018 was registered against her 19 year old lover under B'B' 366 and 376(2)(n) of the IPC and under B' 5(1) r/w. B' 6 of the POCSO Act, 2012. Immediately thereafter, the instant crime was registered against the applicant for sexually harassing the child. 4. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submitted that he has been implicated as his step-daughter felt that he was responsible for the arrest and detention of her lover. As the child was quite young, the applicant herein along with his wife had strongly opposed the relationship that she had with the accused in Crime No. 387 of 2018. It is contended that after the death of the father of the minor child about three years back, the applicant has married her mother and he has been caring and protecting the family. Finally, it is submitted that the applicant has been in custody from 12. 6. 2018 and prays that orders for his release be issued. 5. Heard the learned Public Prosecutor, who has opposed the prayer. It is submitted that the medical examination report of the child shows that she has been subjected to penetrative sexual assault by the 1st accused. It is further submitted that the child has unequivocally stated that the applicant herein had abused her on more than one occasions. 6. I have considered the submissions advanced and have gone through the case diary. It appears that the applicant herein has been residing with the family after marrying the mother for the past more than two years. Allegations have been levelled against him only after registration of the crime against the lover of the child. The contention of the learned counsel that he has been implicated for his exuberance in prosecuting the lover of the survivor cannot be ruled out at this stage. Furthermore, serious allegations are levelled against the 1 st accused. The investigation appears to have progressed much and in the facts and circumstances further detention in custody of the applicant may not serve any purpose. By imposing appropriate conditions, for safeguarding the interest of the prosecution as well as the protection of the minor child, the applicant can now be released. 7. In the result, this application will stand allowed. The applicant shall be released on bail on his executing a bond for Rs. 1, 00, 000/-(Rupees one lakh only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the court having jurisdiction. The above order shall be subject to the following conditions: 1). The applicant shall appear before the Investigating Officer on all Saturdays between 10 a. m. and 1. 00 p. m. , for 3 months or till final report is filed, whichever is earlier. 2). He shall not enter the limits of Kilikkolloor Police Station for a period of six months except for complying with the conditions of this order. If for any extraordinary reason the applicant requires to enter the limits, previous permission has to be obtained from the jurisdictional Court. 3). He shall not intimidate or attempt to influence the witnesses; nor shall he tamper with the evidence. He shall not contact the victim or her family members. 4). He shall not commit any offence while he is on bail. 5). He shall not leave India without the permission of the Court and if having passport, shall deposit the same before the Trial Court within a week; If release of the passport is required at a later period, he shall be at liberty to move appropriate application before the Court having jurisdiction. In case of violation of any of the above conditions, the jurisdictional Court shall be empowered to consider the application for cancellation, if any, and pass appropriate orders in accordance with the law. Sd/- Raja Vijayaraghavan V. , Judge

[case 73]
Riyazahmed Imamsab Bagwaan vs State Of Karnataka on 5 July, 2024 -1- NC: 2024: KHC-D: 9250 CRL. P No. 101901 of 2024 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA, DHARWAD BENCH DATED THIS THE 5TH DAY OF JULY, 2024 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR JUSTICE S. RACHAIAH CRIMINAL PETITION NO. 101901 OF 2024 (439) BETWEEN: RIYAZAHMED IMAMSAB BAGWAAN, AGE: 36 YEARS, OCC: BUSINESS, R/O: JAMKHANA GALLI, NAVALGUND, DHARWAD DIST. .. .PETITIONER (BY SRI. R. M. JAVED, ADVOCATE) AND: STATE OF KARNATAKA THROUGH NAVALGUND P. S. , DHARWAD, REP BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HGH COURT OF KARNATAKA, DHARWAD BENCH, DHARWAD. .. .RESPONDENT CHANDRASHEKAR LAXMAN (BY SRI. PRAVEENA Y. DEVAREDDIYAVARA, HCGP) THIS CRIMINAL PETITION IS FILED U/S 439 OF CR. P. C. , SEEKING TO ALLOW THE PETITION AND ENLARGE THE PETITIONER/ACCUSED NO. 1 ON BAIL IN CONNECTION WITH NAVALGUND P. S. CRIME NO. 47/2024 FOR THE ALLEGED OFFENCES PUNISHABLE U/S 498A, 306 and 34 of IPC ON SUCH TERMS, AND CONDITIONS THAT THIS HON'BLE COURT MAY BE PLEASE TO IMPOSE IN THE ITEREST OF JUSTICE AND EQUITY. THIS PETITION COMING ON FOR ORDERS, THIS DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING: -2- NC: 2024: KHC-D: 9250 CRL. P No. 101901 of 2024 ORDER Heard Sri. R. M. Javed, learned counsel for the petitioner and Sri. Praveena Y. Devareddiyavara, learned HCGP for the respondent-State. 2. The petitioner/accused No. 1 is seeking regular bail in Crime No. 47/2024 of respondent Police Station for the offences punishable under Sections 498-A, 306 and 34 of IPC. Brief facts of the case are: 3. It is the case of the prosecution that the father of the deceased lodged a complaint stating that he performed the marriage of his daughter with the petitioner on 27. 12. 2018. The couple had three children. All the three children are female children. The deceased was being subjected to cruelty and harassment for having begotten three female children. She was always being scolded for not having begotten male child. In the meantime, she was also being scolded for not having proper cooking and doing household works properly. -3- NC: 2024: KHC-D: 9250 CRL. P No. 101901 of 2024 4. On 31. 03. 2024, the petitioner herein being a husband stated to have scolded his wife as she did not prepared food for dinner and it was Ramzan month. At about 8. 30 p. m. , the deceased stated to have committed suicide by hanging herself. Thereafter, it was informed to the complainant and the complainant and others went to the house of the deceased and saw that she was hanging with her saree which was tied to ceiling fan. On enquiry, the complainant learnt that there was a quarrel taken place between the husband and the deceased, consequently, she committed suicide. Therefore, complainant lodged a complaint. The jurisdictional police after registering the case conducted investigation and submitted the charge sheet. 5. It is the submission of the learned counsel for the petitioner that the petitioner has not committed any offence, he has been falsely implicated in this case. He is having three female children and he has to take care of them and he is the only earning member of the family. The entire family is depending on his income. 6. It is further submitted that there is no nexus between the death and the petitioner. The complainant learnt that, prior to the incident there was a quarrel taken place between husband and wife. However, he is a hearsay witness. None of the witnesses have spoken about the harassment, instigation or incitement to commit suicide. The law is well settled that even if a person says 'Go and die' it is not an offence under Section 306 of IPC. Therefore, the petitioner may be enlarged on bail by imposing suitable conditions. 7. Per contra, learned HCGP vehemently opposed the bail petition and submitted that the petitioner being a husband, insulted and always abusing her in a filthy language as she could not get a male child and sometimes, she was being scolded that she was not cooking properly and not doing household work as well. The instigation to commit suicide has been established by the averments of the complaint. The entire allegations rests on accused No. 1 and therefore, he is not entitled for bail. 8. Having heard the learned counsel for respective parties and also perused the averments of the charge sheet, it appears that on 31. 03. 2024 around 4. 00 p. m. , the accused No. 1 stated to have quarreled with his wife in respect of cleaning his fasting in Ramzan period. As the petitioner had scolded his wife, she stated to have committed suicide. It was informed to the complainant and the complainant and other members came to the spot and after seeing the incident and also received the information regarding said incident, lodged a complaint. However, the entire episode of what the complainant has received is nothing but hearsay and therefore, it is appropriate to grant him bail by imposing suitable conditions. 9. Hence, I proceed to pass the following: -6- NC: 2024: KHC-D: 9250 CRL. P No. 101901 of 2024 ORDER The petition is allowed. The petitioner is ordered to be enlarged on bail in Crime No. 47/2024 of respondent Police Station, on executing a personal bond in a sum of Rs. 1, 00, 000/- (Rupees One lakh only) with one surety for the likesum to the satisfaction of the Trial Court, subject to the following conditions: a) The petitioner shall not threaten or tamper the prosecution witnesses nor hamper the proceedings of the Court. b) The petitioner shall appear before the Trial Court on all dates of hearing without fail. In case, if the petitioner violates any of the bail conditions as stated above, the prosecution will be at liberty to seek for cancellation of bail. Sd/- JUDGE RKM CT: ANB List No. : 1 Sl No. : 8

[case 74]
This is an application for regular bail under Section 439 of Cr. P. C.
The applicant is the sole accused in Crime No. 630/2020 of Mattannur Police Station for having allegedly committed the offences punishable under Sections 388 and 506(i) of the I. P. C. and under Section 4 read with Section 3(c) of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSO Act). The applicant was arrested on 24. 07. 2020 and he seeks regular bail. The prosecution case, in brief, is that on 20. 06. 2020, the applicant had allegedly committed unnatural offence and penetrative sexual assault on the victim, who is a 13 year old boy. The victim's father had allegedly contacted the Childline Centre and subsequently the matter was informed to the Police, in consequence of which the crime was registered. It is alleged that the incident took place in a toilet inside the compound of a hotel at a place called '19th Mile'. The applicant states that he is innocent, he has no other criminal antecedents and he is only 20 year old and that the entire allegations are false. It is stated that a similar incident had allegedly taken place on 19. 06. 2020 concerning the very same victim and he was allegedly sexually assaulted by a person named Siraj and in consequence of which Crime No. 623/2020 as lodged against the said Siraj on 26. 06. 2020 in Mattannur Police Station. Even then, crime against the applicant was not registered and ultimately it was registered only on 02. 07. 2020. The delay, according to the applicant is very crucial. It is stated that the applicant is the leader of a youth organization and because of the action taken against him for registering the crime against Siraj, the applicant has been deliberately implicated in this crime also. He was arrested on 24. 07. 2020 and has been in custody for about 58 days, and therefore, seeks regular bail. Heard the learned Counsel for the applicant and the learned Public Prosecutor. The learned Public Prosecutor has vehemently opposed application for bail stating that the applicant has committed a heinous crime attracting the offence under the I. P. C. and also for offences under Section 4(1) of the POCSO Act. It is stated that the incident which took place on 19. 06. 2020 involving the accused-Siraj and the present incident which took place on 20. 06. 2020, were in two different places. But in both these cases, the victim was sexually abused. In connection with Crime No. 623/2020 registered against Siraj, the statement of the victim was recorded by the Magistrate on 27. 06. 2020 and in that statement the victim revealed the involvement of Siraj in committing the offence on 19. 06. 2020 and also revealed the involvement of the applicant herein in another similar offence, which occurred on the successive date. The investigating officer got a copy of the statement under Section 164, Cr. P. C. from the Magistrate's Court on 02. 07. 2020 and immediately this crime was registered. Hence it is submitted by the learned Public Prosecutor that the delay is not very crucial. It is also submitted by the learned Counsel appearing for the applicant that Siraj, the accused in Crime No. 623/2020 of Mattannur Police Station, had approached this Court for anticipatory bail and the same was rejected by this Court. But the accused in that crime has not been apprehended. It is submitted by the learned Public Prosecutor that in case the applicant is released on bail, there is every possibility that the victim and his family members may be threatened. There is also an offence under Section 506(i) of the I. P. C. registered against the applicant and it is because the applicant had put the victim to fear of death and also causing hurt to his family members and that the victim had not come forward with a complaint against the applicant. Under the circumstances, it is submitted that the release of the applicant at this stage would be detrimental to the investigation and also to the victim and his entire family. Moreover, it is submitted that investigation is complete and final report has already been filed. The applicant's contention that he has no criminal antecedents may not make a weigh in his favour, particularly for the reason that the applicant had intimidated the victim from disclosing the alleged occurrence. The incident did not take place in the very same place and the attempt made by the applicant to suggest that the actual incident of sexually abusing the victim had taken place on 19. 06. 2020 and that the assailant was Siraj and with other political motives, the applicant has been falsely implicated as an accused. This submission cannot be accepted for the reason that in the confession statement allegedly given by the victim on 27. 06. 2020 before the Magistrate he has clearly revealed the involvement of the applicant in this crime. The fact is that both the crimes took place on consecutive days. The fact that the applicant had intimidated the victim and that subsequently the relatives of the applicant had also intimidated the family members of the victim also would go a long way in refusing bail to the applicant. In the result, I find that the applicant, who is accused of committing a very heinous crime against a child, is not entitled to any leniency, and therefore, the application is dismissed. The learned designated Court is directed to expedite the trial and in case there is any delay in concluding the trial because of the pandemic situation, the applicant is given the liberty to approach the jurisdictional court again for bail afresh.

[case 75]
THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 13-06-2018,
THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING:
1. This application is filed under Section 439 of the Code of
Criminal Procedure.
2. The applicant herein is the accused in Crime No. 133 of 2018
of Faroke Police Station, registered under Sections 306 and
376 of the IPC and Section 3 r/w Sec. 4, 9(m) r/w Sec. 10
and 11(v) r/w Sec. 12 of Protection of Children from Sexual
Offences Act, 2012.
3. According to the prosecution, the applicant herein is a near
relative of the victim girl who was just 15 years of age.
They became close to each other and by misusing the
relationship, started having a sexual relationship. He also
used to take photographs and videos of their intimate acts.
Later, their relationship became strained when the applicant
started to have a liking towards another girl. It is alleged
that when the victim questioned the applicant, he
threatened her with the photographs and videos which were
in his possession. This tormented the minor girl and she
decided to take her own life. Initially, the Crime was
registered on 23. 3. 2018 under Section 174 of the Cr. P. C.
Later, on the basis of an additional statement given by the
brother of the victim, the offences under the POCSO Act
and other grave offences under the IPC were incorporated.
4. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submits that
a detailed statement of the brother of the victim as well as
all the near relatives were recorded immediately after the
registration of the Crime. No one had a case that the
applicant herein had anything to do with the minor girl. It
was much later, i. e. , on 3. 4. 2018, the allegation of sexual
abuse and other grave acts were raised by the brother. The
drastical turnaround would affect the credibility of his version
is the submission. Finally, it is submitted that the applicant
was arrested on 05. 04. 2018 and having regard to the period
of incarceration undergone and the stage of investigation,
he be released.
5. The learned Public Prosecutor while opposing the prayer
submitted that the allegations are extremely grave. The
applicant herein is a near relative of the victim girl and there
is no reason to believe the version of the brother of the
victim. It is submitted that the applicant by feigning love
have sexually abused the minor child.
6. I have considered the submissions advanced and have gone
through the materials and records. Though the allegations
are grave, the fact remains that the investigation has made
much headway and has reached the final stages. As
submitted by the learned counsel, the brother of the victim
did not state before the investigating officer while furnishing
his initial statement that on the day prior to the death of the
child, he had an occasion to interact with her and that she
had divulged about the horrendous acts committed by the
7. Having regard to the nature and gravity of the allegations,
the material in support thereof, the stage of investigation
and the period of incarceration undergone, I am of the view
that the applicant can now be enlarged on bail.
8. In the result, this application will stand allowed. The
applicant shall be released on bail on his executing a bond
for Rs. 1, 00, 000/-(Rupees One lakh only) with two solvent
sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the court
having jurisdiction. The above order shall be subject to the
following conditions:
1). The applicant shall appear before the
Investigating Officer on all Saturdays between
9 a. m. and 10 a. m. , for 2 months or till final
report is filed, whichever is earlier.
2). The applicant shall not intimidate or attempt
to influence the witnesses; nor shall he tamper
with the evidence.
3). The applicant shall not commit any offence
while he is on bail.
4). The applicant shall not leave India without
the permission of the Court and if having
passport, shall deposit the same before the Trial
Court within a week; If release of the passport
is required at a later period, the applicant shall
be at liberty to move appropriate application
before the Court having jurisdiction.
In case of violation of any of the above conditions, the
jurisdictional Court shall be empowered to consider the
application for cancellation, if any, and pass appropriate
orders in accordance with the law.

[case 76]
Karnataka High Court Ashok S/O Punnu Rathod vs The State Of Karnataka on 18 November, 2016. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA KALABURAGI BENCH DATED THIS THE 18TH DAY OF NOVEMBER, 2016 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE S. N. SATYANARAYANA CRIMINAL APPEAL No. 200125/2016 Between: Ashok S/o Punnu Rathod Age: 27 years, Occ: Coolie R/o Ingalgi, L. T. No. 2, Tq. Indi, Dist. Vijayapur. .. Appellant (By Smt Ratna N. Shivayogimath and Sri Sharanabasappa K. Babshetty, Advocates) And: The State of Karnataka Through the CPI Indi Circle Dist Vijayapur Represented by SPP High Court of Karnataka at Kalaburagi Bench. .. Respondent (By Sri Sheshadri Jaishankar, HCGP) This Criminal Appeal is filed under Section 374(2) of the Cr. P. C. , praying to set aside the judgment and sentence dated 19. 10. 2015 and 21. 10. 2015 passed by the special judge and II Addl. Sessions Judge, Vijayapur, at Vijayapur in Special Case (POSCO) No. 21/2014, and acquit the appellant in the said case. This appeal is coming on for admission this day, the Court delivered the following: JUDGMENT The accused in Special Case (POCSO) No. 21/2014 on the file of II Addl. Sessions Judge, Vijaypur has come up in this appeal challenging the order of conviction and sentence. In the proceedings before Session's Court, charge sheet was filed against the appellant herein for the offence punishable U/Sec. 3(a) (b), 4, 5(m) and 6 of Protection of the Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and U/Sec. 376(f) of Indian Penal Code. The aforesaid charge sheet is filed based on a complaint wherein it is stated that on 6. 1. 2014 appellant herein is said to have sexually abused victim girl CW-4 namely Sujata who is aged about 8 years and resident of Ingalagi Tanda. On the ill-fated day when she had gone to attend nature call at about 6. 15 p. m. , in the evening, by luring the said child with chocolates and biscuits accused forcibly took her into the field of one Kulkarni wherein Jawar crop was standing. The accused is said to have made the child to lay on the ground, removed her under garment and slept on her. It is also accused that he inserted his finger into her vagina, pressed in it and bit her lips and subsequently committed rape on her. A complaint was filed in this behalf, wherein, investigation was conducted and thereafter charge sheet was filed and the matter was committed to Sessions wherein cognizance for the offence was taken on 18. 7. 2014. After the charges are framed, same was read over to him. Since he pleaded not guilty, matter was taken up for trial. On behalf of prosecution, in all 17 witnesses are examined and 26 documents are marked. The material objects produced at MOs-1 to 5 are also taken into consideration. In the Court below, P. Ws. 6 and 8 are the parent of victim girl. It is seen that P. Ws. 9, 10, 11 and 12 have turned hostile and did not support the prosecution. Even P. Ws. 1 and 7 panch witnesses to the spot panchanama Ex. P-1 and seizure panchanama Ex. P-2 except admitting their signature on said panchanamas, they have not supported the case. Therefore, in the Court below, they were treated as hostile witnesses and they were subjected to cross examination by prosecution. It is seen, in this proceedings that even the complainant - father of victim himself has turned hostile. However, after he was subjected to cross examination, the learned Session's Judge was able to elicit from him and as well as other witnesses that the injuries suffered by the child P. W. 2 Sujata to her private part is not due to fall in the field and it is due to heinous act committed by the accused. On going through the judgment impugned, it is clearly seen that the prosecution and learned Sessions Judge has taken enormous strain to see that the truth is elicited from the victim as well as her family members to reconstruct the whole incident to bring the guilt of accused to the books, when all of them conspired together to bury the truth either for fear of shame in the society or fearing retaliatory action from the accused. On giving careful consideration to the entire judgment of the Court below, one thing is clear that the manner in which the entire prosecution has sought to be suppressed not only by the witnesses but also by the family members considering the future of the victim girl who is aged about 8 years, this Court is sympathetic to the family of the victim who have not supported the prosecution, who have given false evidence against the interest of their own child who is victim of sexual abuse. In any event, with proper appreciation of material on record, the Session's Court has been able to bring the accused to books and convict him for the offences punishable under the aforesaid provisions. On careful consideration of the judgement impugned as well as the material available in the form of evidence of the witnesses more particularly their cross examination, it is clearly seen that no grounds are made out by the accused in Spl. Case (POCSO) No. 21/2014 to convert the finding of Session's Court in the aforesaid judgment to convert the conviction to an acquittal and also to disturb the sentence imposed on him. In fact this Court feels that considering the nature of offences, the punishment imposed is liberal one. In any event, since there is no appeal on behalf of the prosecution challenging the sentence disturbing the sentence does not arise. Accordingly, this appeal filed by the accused is hereby dismissed.

[case 77]
HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD, LUCKNOW BENCH Case: - CRIMINAL MISC. BAIL APPLICATION No. - 2004 of 2025 Applicant: - Dharmdev Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. Thru. Prin. Secy. Home U. P. Lko. And 3 Others Counsel for Applicant: - Yugal Kishor Tripathi Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A. Hon'ble Rajesh Singh Chauhan. J. Heard Sri Yugal Kishor Tripathi, learned counsel for the applicant and Sri Rajesh Kumar, learned A. G. A. for the State. Sri Ram Suphal, Advocate has filed Vakalatnama on behalf of informant/complainant, the same is taken on record. The complainant and prosecutrix both are present in the Court. As per learned counsel for the applicant, the present applicant is languishing in jail since 29. 04. 2024 in Case Crime No. 03/2023 of 2024, under Sections 363, 366, 376(3) IPC and Section 5J2/6 of POCSO Act, Police Station- Manikpur, District- Pratapgarh. He has been falsely implicated in this case as he has not committed any offence as alleged in the prosecution story. Learned counsel for the applicant has stated that under bonafide impression to the effect that the prosecutrix has attained the marriageable age, both have got married since they were in relation. From the aforesaid wedlock, they have been blessed one baby girl, who is presently aged about one and half years. The prosecutrix has not levelled any allegation against the present applicant and presently she is living with the family members of the applicant. The present applicant is having no prior criminal history of any kind whatsoever. Chargesheet has been filed. The prosecutrix, who is present in the Court alongwith her baby girl has submitted that she is present living in the house of the present applicant alongwith her baby girl and she has not grievance against the present applicant or his family members. The complainant, namely, Devkali has also stated that her daughter has married with applicant- Dharmdev and presently living with the family members of the applicant and she has no grievance against the applicant. On the other hand, learned Additional Government Advocate has opposed the prayer for bail of the present applicant by submitting that when the incident took place, the prosecutrix was minor therefore, the FIR was lodged under various Sections of IPC as well as POCSO Act, wherein the trial is going on, therefore, any appropriate direction may be issued in the interest of the prosecutrix. On that, learned counsel for the applicant has stated that he shall look after the prosecutrix and his child properly and if, he is released on bail, he shall abide by all terms and conditions of bail, and shall not misuse the liberty of bail and shall also cooperate with the trial proceedings. Having heard learned counsel for the parties and having perused the material available on record; considering the fact that the prosecutrix, who is present in the Court alongwith her baby girl has submitted that she is presently living in the house of the present applicant alongwith her baby girl and she has not grievance against the present applicant or his family members and the applicant shall look after the prosecutrix and his child properly and if, he is released on bail, he shall abide by all terms and conditions of bail, and shall not misuse the liberty of bail and shall also cooperate with the trial proceedings; the present applicant is having no prior criminal history of any kind whatsoever; without expressing any opinion on merits of the case, I am of the view that the present applicant may be enlarged on bail. Accordingly, the instant bail application is allowed. Let the applicant (Dharmdev), involved in aforesaid case crime be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned with the following conditions which are being imposed in the interest of justice: - (i) The applicant shall file an undertaking to the effect that he shall not seek any adjournment on the dates fixed for evidence when the witnesses are present in court. In case of default of this condition, it shall be open for the trial court to treat it as abuse of liberty of bail and pass orders in accordance with law. (ii) The applicant shall remain present before the trial court on each date fixed, either personally or through his counsel. In case of his absence, without sufficient cause, the trial court may proceed against him under Section 229-A of the Indian Penal Code. (iii) In case, the applicant misuses the liberty of bail during trial and in order to secure his presence proclamation under Section 82 Cr. P. C. may be issued and if the applicant fails to appear before the court on the date fixed in such proclamation, then, the trial court shall initiate proceedings against him, in accordance with law, under Section 174-A of the Indian Penal Code. (iv) The applicant shall remain present, in person, before the trial court on the dates fixed for (i) opening of the case, (ii) framing of charge and (iii) recording of statement under Section 313 Cr. P. C. If in the opinion of the trial court absence of the applicant is deliberate or without sufficient cause, then it shall be open for the trial court to treat such default as abuse of liberty of bail and proceed against him in accordance with law. (v) The applicant shall not leave the country without permission of the Court concerned. Order Date: - 5. 3. 2025

[case 78]
This Criminal Original Petition has been filed to quash the proceedings in Spl. S. C. No. 151 of 2022 on the file of the Principal Special Court for Exclusive Trial of Cases under POCSO Act, Madurai. The case of the prosecution is that the petitioner is the relative of victim. When the victim was studying 11th standard, the petitioner married the victim and out of the wedlock, she became pregnant. Thereafter, the victim was admitted at Government Rajaji Hospital, Madurai, and she gave birth to a male child on 09. 08. 2021. Based on the information given by the hospital authorities, the second respondent lodged a complaint against the petitioner. Hence the case. The learned counsel appearing for the petitioner as well as the learned counsel appearing for the third respondent submitted that now, the petitioner and the third respondent married living together as husband and wife with their child, issues amicable resolved and the third respondent is not willing to proceed further with the criminal case against the petitioner. Today, when the matter was taken up for hearing, a joint Memo of Compromise filed before this Court signed by the petitioner and the third respondent and their respective counsels. The petitioner and the third respondent are present before this Court, identified by the first respondent police, as well as by the learned counsels appearing for the parties. This Court enquired both the parties, satisfied that the parties have come to an amicable settlement between themselves on their own voluntarily without any compulsion. When this Court interacted with the third respondent, she confirmed her marriage with the petitioner and both living as husband and wife happily along with their child and she intends not to pursue the criminal proceedings against the petitioner. The case has been registered for offences under Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and Sections 5(1), 5(j)(ii) r/w Section 6 of POCSO Act. It is settled law that the High Court has inherent power under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to quash the criminal proceedings even for the offences which are not compoundable under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, where the parties have settled their dispute between themselves. However, while quashing the criminal proceedings, based on the settlement arrived at between the parties, the High Court should act with caution and the power should be exercised sparingly only in order to secure the ends of justice and also to prevent abuse of process of any Court. Further, the Hon'ble Apex Court in the case of K. Dhandapani Vs. The State by the Inspector of Police reported in 2022 SCC Online SC 1056, has held as follows: In the peculiar facts and circumstances of this case, we are of the considered view that the conviction and sentence of the appellant who is maternal uncle of the prosecutrix deserves to be set aside in view of the subsequent events that have been brought to the notice of this Court. This Court cannot shut its eyes to the ground reality and disturb the happy family life of the appellant and the prosecutrix. We have been informed about the custom in Tamilnadu of the marriage of a girl with the maternal uncle. The legal position expressed by the Hon'ble Apex Court in the case of Gian Singh vs. State of Punjab and another reported in (2012) 10 SCC 303 and Parbatbhai Aahir @ Parbatbhai Vs. State of Gujarat) reported in (2017) 9 SCC 641 were taken into consideration. Keeping the above principles in mind, let us now consider the instant case as to whether it is a fit case to quash the criminal proceedings based on the settlement arrived at between the parties. In the case at hand, though the petitioner is charged with for the offences punishable Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and Sections 5(1), 5(j)(ii) r/w Section 6 of POCSO Act, now, the petitioner and the third respondent have amicably resolved their dispute between themselves. In this regard, the third respondent has also filed an affidavit. The petitioner is the sole breadwinner, the third respondent and child are solely depend on the income of the petitioner for their livelihood. The petitioner is taking care of the well being of the third respondent and child and they are showered with love and affection. Unless the conviction is set aside, the petitioner, third respondent and the child cannot lead a peaceful and happy family. Considering the welfare and wellbeing of the victim and the child, it would be appropriate to accept the attending circumstances and the compromise arrived. In view of the compromise between the parties, the possibility of conviction is also remote and bleak. In the above circumstances, continuity of the criminal proceedings would only cause oppression and prejudice to the parties, hence, in order to secure the ends of justice, this Court is inclined to quash the criminal proceedings. Accordingly, this Criminal Original Petition is allowed and the criminal proceedings initiated against the petitioner in Spl. S. C. No. 151 of 2022 on the file of the Principal Special Court for Exclusive Trial of Cases under POCSO Act, Madurai, is quashed and the terms of joint compromise memo and affidavit filed by the third respondent shall form part and parcel of this order. Consequently, connected Miscellaneous Petition is closed.

[case 79]
IN THE HIGH COURT OF GUJARAT AT AHMEDABAD R/CRIMINAL MISC. APPLICATION NO. 19565 of 2021 KISHAN @ KISHLO KALUBHAI CHAROLA Versus STATE OF GUJARAT Appearance: MR HARNISH V DARJI(3705) for the Applicant(s) No. 1 for the Respondent(s) No. 2 MS. SHRUTI PATHAK APP(2) for the Respondent(s) No. 1 CORAM: HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE ILESH J. VORA Date: 29/10/2021 ORAL ORDER [1] Mr. R. R. Joshi, learned advocate states that he has instructions to appear for and on behalf of respondent No. 2 - original complainant. He is permitted to file his Vakaltnama. [2] Considering the issues involved in the present application and with consent of the learned advocates appearing for the respective parties as well as considering the fact that the dispute amongst the applicant and respondent No. 2 has been resolved amicably, this application is taken up for final disposal forthwith. [3] Rule. Learned Additional Public Prosecutor as well as learned advocate appearing for the Complainant waive service of Rule on behalf of the respective respondents. [4] By way of this application under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (hereinafter referred to as 'the Code'), the applicant has prayed for quashing and setting aside F. I. R. bearing C. R. No. I-12 of 2019 registered with Chalala Police Station, Dist. Amreli for the offence punishable under Sections363, 376&366 of the Indian Penal Code, Sections 4&18 of the POCSO Act and to quash all other consequential proceedings arising out of the aforesaid FIR qua the applicant. [5] Heard learned advocates for the respective parties. [6] Learned advocate for the applicant submits that the applicant and victim have decided to live together as a husband and wife but due to some technicality of the age, the marriage could not be performed. Due to their relationship, a child is borne. He further submits that the applicant's family has also accepted the victim as daughter-in-law and her child and the the applicant's name is shown as father in the Birth Certificate issued by the Competent Authority. In support of his submissions, he has annexed Birth Certificate to the petition. [7] Both the learned advocates would submit that during the pendency of present application, the matter is amicably settled amongst the parties and therefore, any further continuation of the proceedings pursuant to the impugned FIR would create hardship to the parties and further continuation of the proceedings would amount to abuse of process of law. [8] Learned Additional Public Prosecutor appearing for the State has opposed the present application mainly on the ground that the victim is aged about 17 years and offence is serious in nature, therefore, complaint in question may not be quashed and the present application may be rejected. In support of her submissions, she relied upon the judgment in the case of The State of Madhya Pradesh Vs. Laxminarayan reported in (2019) 5 SCC 688. [9] Learned advocate for respondent No. 2 has placed on record the settlement Affidavit duly sworn by the original complainant. The same is taken on record. The respondent No. 2 has filed affidavit stating inter-alia the fact that the matter is amicably settled with the applicant. The Respondent No. 2 as well as victim are present in person before the Court and are identified by learned advocate for respondent No. 2 and also admits the contents of the Affidavit. On inquiry made by the Court, the respondent No. 2 has declared before this Court that the dispute between the applicant(s) and respondent No. 2 is resolved and therefore, now the grievance stands redressed. It is therefore submitted that the present application may be allowed. [10] This Court has taken into consideration the fact that the victim is residing with the applicant and the parents of the applicant have also accepted as daughter-in-law and her child. The Birth Certificate of the Child is also on record which shows the applicant's name as father of the child. This Court has also taking into consideration the peculiar facts and circumstances of the case as well as facts of settlement and law laid down by the Apex Court [Gian Singh Vs. State of Punjab & Anr. , reported in (2012) 10 SCC 303, Madan Mohan Abbot Vs. State of Punjab, reported in (2008) 4 SCC 582, Nikhil Merchant Vs. Central Bureau of Investigation & Anr. , reported in 2009 (1) GLH 31, Manoj Sharma Vs. State & Ors. , reported in 2009 (1) GLH 190 and Narinder Singh & Ors. Vs. State of Punjab & Anr. reported in 2014 (2) Crime 67 (SC), ] this Court is of the considered view that further continuation of the criminal proceedings in relation to the impugned FIR would nothing but unnecessary harassment to the parties and trial thereon would be futile and further continuation of the proceedings would amount to abuse of process of law. Thus, to secure the ends of justice, the impugned FIR is required to be quashed and set aside in exercise of powers conferred under Section 482 of the Code. [11] Resultantly, this application is allowed and the impugned FIR bearing C. R. No. I-12 of 2019 registered with Chalala Police Station, Dist. Amreli filed against present applicant is hereby quashed and set aside and all other proceedings arising out of the aforesaid FIR are also quashed and set aside qua the applicant. Accordingly, Rule is made absolute. Direct service permitted.

[case 80]
This Criminal Original Petition has been filed, invoking Section 528 of Bharatiya Nagarik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023, seeking orders to call for the records in J. J. No. 120 of 2022, on the file of the Juvenile Justice Board, Sivagangai, and quash the same as illegal, improper and abuse of process of law. The case of the prosecution is that the petitioner on giving false promise to marry the victim/third respondent, sexually assaulted her without her consent and they were eloped. Based on the complaint given by the defacto complainant, who is the mother of the victim, both were secured by the Child Line and the victim was handed over to the TMSS home, Trichy. The learned counsel appearing for the petitioner would submit that the second respondent lodged a complaint before the first respondent and F. I. R. registered in Crime No. 31 of 2022, after investigation, final report filed, the same taken cognizance in J. J. No. 120 of 2022, on the file of the Juvenile Justice Board, Sivagangai, for the offences under Sections 3(2)(va) of SC/ST Act, 363 of IPC r/w Sections 5(1) & 6 of POCSO Act against the petitioner. It is further submitted that the petitioner is a final year student doing Diploma Course in Government Polytechnic College. He was also a minor. Without knowing the consequences, at the adolescent age on compulsion he accompanied the victim and now he realised his mistake. Now, the victim/third respondent has also married. If the case is pending, it would affect the future of the petitioner. The petitioner is the first person in his family, who had reached to this level of education. The case is under trial. By passage of time, the parties have decided to bury their hatchet and compromise the dispute amicably among themselves. Now, both realized their mistakes, reconciled and second respondent agreeing to withdraw the complaint, not willing to pursue the case. A Joint Memo of Compromise, dated 31. 01. 2025 filed before this Court signed by the petitioner and the respondents 2 and 3 and their respective counsels. The petitioner and the respondents 2 and 3 present before this Court, identified by Mr. S. Mala, SSSI, All Women Police Station, Karaikudi, Sivagangai District, as well as by the learned counsels appearing for the parties. This Court enquired the parties, satisfied that the parties have come to an amicable settlement between themselves on their own voluntarily without any compulsion. The second respondent had stated that the victim got married and she is living happily. Therefore, she had intended to withdraw the complaint against the petitioner. Realising that at the adolescent age not knowing the consequences both found missing and complaint lodged, later on enquiry the defacto complainant realised that it is her daughter, who had faced such a situation due to emotional break down complaint given, reconciled to the reality now come forward to withdraw the complaint on own volition at not on compulsion or force. The case has been registered for offence under Section 3(2)(va) of SC/ST Act, 363 of IPC r/w Sections 5(1) & 6 of POCSO Act. It is settled law that the High Court has inherent power under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to quash the criminal proceedings even for the offences which are not compoundable under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, where the parties have settled their dispute between themselves. However, while quashing the criminal proceedings, based on the settlement arrived at between the parties, the High Court should act with caution and the power should be exercised sparingly only in order to secure the ends of justice and also to prevent abuse of process of any Court. The legal position expressed by the Hon'ble Apex Court in the case of Gian Singh vs. State of Punjab and another reported in (2012) 10 SCC 303 and Parbatbhai Aahir @ Parbatbhai Vs. State of Gujarat) reported in (2017) 9 SCC 641 were taken into consideration. Keeping the above principles in mind, let us now consider the instant case as to whether it is a fit case to quash the criminal proceedings based on the settlement arrived at between the parties. In the case at hand, though the petitioner is charged with for the offences punishable under Section 3(2)(va) of SC/ST Act, 363 of IPC r/w Sections 5(1) & 6 of POCSO Act, now, the petitioner and the respondents 2 and 3 have amicably settled their dispute between themselves. The respondents 2 and 3 have also filed an affidavit stating that the victim had married and living happily. In view of the compromise between the parties, the possibility of conviction is also remote and bleak. In the above circumstances, continuity of the criminal proceedings would only cause oppression and prejudice to the parties, hence, in order to secure the ends of justice, this Court is inclined to quash the criminal proceedings. Accordingly, this Criminal Original Petition is allowed and the proceedings in J. J. No. 120 of 2022, on the file of the Juvenile Justice Board, Sivagangai, is quashed as against the petitioner. This case cannot be quoted against the petitioner in any manner for his future education, employment and career and the joint compromise memo shall form part and parcel of this order. Consequently, connected miscellaneous petitions are closed.

[case 81]
This Criminal Petition is filed under Section 439 of Cr. P. C. , praying to enlarge the petitioner on bail in Spl. Case NO. 12/2017 in Crime No. 73/2016 of Mahila Police Station,
Kalaburagi, which is registered for the offences punishable under Sections 363, 376(2)(n) of IPC and Sections 4, 6, 7, 11 and 12 of POCSO Act and also Section 10 of Child Marriage
Restraint Act. Brief facts leading to filing of the complaint are that, on 20. 04. 2016 at about 7. 00 p. m. as the complainant was in her house and there was nobody in the house, petitioner came to the house of the victim, threatened and kidnapped her and thereafter he took her to his uncle's house at Kalaburagi. On 02. 05. 2016, the sister of the accused Roopa, Mahadevi and uncle Sharanappa all together took her to Nagavi Yallamma temple at Chittapur Taluka and there they solemnized the marriage of the victim with accused forcibly. Thereafter, accused kept the victim girl in his house at Kalaburagi and there he forcibly had sexual intercourse with her and the mother of the accused also helped the accused by way of abusing him to keep her in the house. It is further alleged that accused used to sexually harass her and used to have forcible sexual intercourse with her. With the help of others, she escaped and subsequently on 14. 12. 2016 she filed a written complaint. On the basis of the said complaint, a case has been registered against the accused persons. I have heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Additional State Public Prosecutor appearing for respondent-State. The main grounds urged by the learned counsel for the petitioner are that the complaint is baseless and there is a delay in filing the complaint. The said complaint has been filed only with an intention to harass the petitioner. It is also contended that no marriage as alleged in the complaint has been taken place. It is also contended that already charge-sheet has been filed and the remaining accused persons have not been shown as accused. It is further contended that the medical certificate reveals that there is no offence as alleged in the complaint and there are no external injuries found on the victim girl. It is further contended that if the petitioner is detained in custody, it is going to affect his right. Further, it is contended that the petitioner is the permanent resident of Kalaburagi and he is the sole earning member. Further, it is contended that if the petitioner is released on bail, he is ready to abide by the conditions to be imposed by this Court and ready to offer sureties. On these grounds, he prays for allowing the petition. On the contrary, learned Additional State Public Prosecutor appearing for the respondent-State would contend that the petitioner by kidnapping the victim, forcibly got married and thereafter he had sexual assault on a minor girl, who is aged about 16 years. He would also contend that the victim girl has given statement before the Magistrate and the same has been recorded under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. and the learned Magistrate has also been shown as a party to the witness. He would further contend that in the statement of the victim, she has been categorically deposed that the petitioner has threatened and thereafter he had sexually assaulted her. He would further contend that because of the threat and other things the complaint was filed belatedly. At this juncture, if the petitioner is released on bail, he may tamper with the prosecution witnesses, he may abscond and he may not be available for trial. On these grounds, he prays for dismissal of the petition. I have gone through the copy of the complaint and other material produced along with the petition. By going through the contents of the complaint and other material, it indicates that the petitioner had kidnapped the victim on 20. 04. 2016, thereafter he got married her forcibly on 02. 05. 2016 and thereafter by threatening her he harassed her sexually and had a sexual intercourse with her. If the medical certificate is perused, it indicates that there is sexual assault has been made on the victim girl. Though the learned counsel for the petitioner would contend that there are no external injuries and other signs of sexual assault, but by going through the statement of the victim recorded under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. and the medical certificate, they corroborate with the sexual assault committed by the petitioner. When the petitioner has committed a sexual assault on a minor girl, under such circumstances, the said offence is considered to be serious and he does not deserve any consideration. As such, the bail petition stands dismissed. However, since the petitioner is in custody, the Trial Court is directed to expedite the matter.

HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD Case: - CRIMINAL MISC. BAIL APPLICATION No. - 15617 of 2021 Applicant: - Sachin Kumar Opposite Party: - State of U. P. and Another Counsel for Applicant: - Dhirendra Kumar Srivastava, Rajiv Sisodia Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A. Hon'ble Shekhar Kumar Yadav, J. This matter is listed for hearing through video conferencing. Link has been sent to the respective learned counsels. Learned Counsel for the applicant and learned A. G. A for the State are connected through the link. Heard learned counsel for the applicant as well as learned A. G. A for the State and perused the record. By means of this application, the applicant who is involved in Case Crime No. 657 of 2020, under Sections 323, 363, 452 I. P. C. and 7/8 of the POCSO Act, Police Station Seohara, District Bijnor, is seeking enlargement on bail during the trial. Submission made by learned counsel for the applicant is that the applicant has been falsely implicated in the present case. He further submits that the applicant is nothing to do with the aforesaid offence and the present F. I. R. has been lodged due to love affair between the applicant and the victim. He further submits that on 28. 12. 2020 the victim came to the house of the applicant in the night but the family members of the applicant annoyed and requested the victim to go her house and when she declined to go her parents house she was given in the custody of the Child Welfare Committee, Bijnor. He further submits that as per medical report the age of the victim is about 18 years. He further submits that the applicant is a student and studying in B. A. -II year. He further submits that there is contradiction in the statement recorded under Section 161 Cr. P. C and 164 Cr. P. C. The applicant has no criminal history. He further submits that the applicant is innocent and he is languishing in jail since 31. 12. 2020. Learned counsel for the applicant submits that if the applicant is released on bail the applicant undertakes that he will not misuse the liberty of bail. Learned counsel for the informant as well as learned A. G. A opposed the prayer for bail but could not dispute the aforesaid facts and the legal submissions as argued by the learned counsel for the applicant. Keeping in view the nature of the offence, evidence, complicity of the accused and submissions of learned counsel for the parties, I am of the view that the applicant has made out a case for bail. Let the applicant Sachin Kumar, who is involved in Case Crime No. 657 of 2020, under Sections 323, 363, 452 I. P. C. and 7/8 of the POCSO Act, Police Station Seohara, District Bijnor, be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned subject to following conditions. Further, before issuing the release order, the sureties be verified. (i) THE APPLICANT SHALL FILE AN UNDERTAKING TO THE EFFECT THAT HE SHALL NOT SEEK ANY ADJOURNMENT ON THE DATE FIXED FOR EVIDENCE WHEN THE WITNESSES ARE PRESENT IN COURT. IN CASE OF DEFAULT OF THIS CONDITION, IT SHALL BE OPEN FOR THE TRIAL COURT TO TREAT IT AS ABUSE OF LIBERTY OF BAIL AND PASS ORDERS IN ACCORDANCE WITH LAW. (ii) THE APPLICANT SHALL REMAIN PRESENT BEFORE THE TRIAL COURT ON EACH DATE FIXED, EITHER PERSONALLY OR THROUGH HIS COUNSEL. IN CASE OF HIS ABSENCE, WITHOUT SUFFICIENT CAUSE, THE TRIAL COURT MAY PROCEED AGAINST HIM UNDER SECTION 229-A IPC. (iii) IN CASE, THE APPLICANT MISUSES THE LIBERTY OF BAIL DURING TRIAL AND IN ORDER TO SECURE HIS PRESENCE PROCLAMATION UNDER SECTION 82 CR. P. C. , MAY BE ISSUED AND IF APPLICANT FAILS TO APPEAR BEFORE THE COURT ON THE DATE FIXED IN SUCH PROCLAMATION, THEN, THE TRIAL COURT SHALL INITIATE PROCEEDINGS AGAINST HIM, IN ACCORDANCE WITH LAW, UNDER SECTION 174-A IPC. (iv) THE APPLICANT SHALL REMAIN PRESENT, IN PERSON, BEFORE THE TRIAL COURT ON DATES FIXED FOR (1) OPENING OF THE CASE, (2) FRAMING OF CHARGE AND (3) RECORDING OF STATEMENT UNDER SECTION 313 CR. P. C. IF IN THE OPINION OF THE TRIAL COURT ABSENCE OF THE APPLICANT IS DELIBERATE OR WITHOUT SUFFICIENT CAUSE, THEN IT SHALL BE OPEN FOR THE TRIAL COURT TO TREAT SUCH DEFAULT AS ABUSE OF LIBERTY OF BAIL AND PROCEED AGAINST HIM IN ACCORDANCE WITH LAW. (v) THE TRIAL COURT MAY MAKE ALL POSSIBLE EFFORTS/ENDEAVOUR AND TRY TO CONCLUDE THE TRIAL WITHIN A PERIOD OF ONE YEAR AFTER THE RELEASE OF THE APPLICANT. In case of breach of any of the above conditions, it shall be a ground for cancellation of bail. It is made clear that observations made in granting bail to the applicant shall not in any way affect the learned trial Judge in forming his independent opinion based on the testimony of the witnesses. The party shall file computer generated copy of such order downloaded from the official website of High Court Allahabad. The computer generated copy of such order shall be self attested by the counsel of the party concerned. The concerned Court/Authority/Official shall verify the authenticity of such computerized copy of the order from the official website of High Court Allahabad and shall make a declaration of such verification in writing. Order Date: - 23. 6. 2021

[case 83]
Vishal Kannaujiaya vs State Of U. P. And Another on 2 December, 2021
HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD
Case: - CRIMINAL REVISION No. - 31 of 2021
Revisionist: - Vishal Kannaujiaya
Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. And Another
Counsel for Revisionist: - Rajnish Shukla
Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A.
Hon'ble Vikas Budhwar, J.
1. This is a revision under Section 102 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 (in short the J. J. Act, 2015), instituted against the order dated 26. 8. 2020 passed by the Principal Magistrate, Juvenile Justice Board, Gorakhpur in Case Crime no. 09 of 2020 (State Vs. Vishal Kannaujiaya), under Section 376 IPC read with Section 5/6 of the Prevention of Child from Sexual Offence Act, 2012, hereinafter referred to as the 'POCSO Act', P. S. Khajani, District Gorakhpur as well as the order dated 27. 11. 2020 passed by learned Addl. Sessions Judge/ Special Judge (POCSO Act), Court No. 1, Gorakhpur, in Criminal Appeal No. 62 of 2020, Vishal Kannaujiaya Vs. State of U. P. and others refusing the bail to the revisionist.
2. Brief facts of the case setforth by the revisionist are that the prosecution has alleged that the victim Miss Neeraj Kannaujiaya, daughter of Ram Laut Kannaujiaya is 17 years old, as whereas revisionist-juvenile being Master Vishal Kannaujiaya son of Rajesh Kannaujiaya was aged about 16 years, they were found wandering in a suspicious condition in Kasba Khajani on the unlucky day, i. e, 28. 12. 2019. On interception, the juvenile as well as the victim Neeraj Kannaujiaya apprised the police personnel that they were not willing to go to their respective houses as they wanted to live together. Faced with these circumstances, one Sri Rudra Pratap Singh, Sub-Inspector, P. S. Khajani, District Gorakhpur made a communication to the designated official of Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur clearly narrating the fact that the juvenile and the victim both of them were not agreeable to go to their respective houses and further despite the fact that information was provided to the parents of the juvenile and the victim, none of them approached them to take custody of the juvenile or the victim and thus request was being sought to be made to them that the victim as well as the revisionist be taken into the custody of the Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur for their upkeep, care and betterment.
3. It appears that on the same day, i. e. , on 28. 12. 2019, G. D. entry was also made narrating the facts, which had been communicated on 28. 12. 2019 by the Sub-Inspector, P. S. Khajani, Gorakhpur to the Child Welfare Committee, Gorakhpur. Thereafter, FIR was lodged by one Sri Krishna Sinha being the member of the Child Welfare Committee, Gorakhpur before the police station Khajani, Gorakhpur dated 16. 1. 2020 registered as Case Crime no. 0009 of 2020 with an allegation that on 28. 12. 2019 itself the police officials found the revisionist and the victim together in suspicious condition and further on medical examination, it revealed that UPT was positive depicting that she was pregnant. It was also alleged that the father of the victim had not lodged the FIR because the victim was a minor and that will create negative impact upon the character of the victim. Statement of the complainant being Sri Krishna Sinha, Chairman / Member, Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur was recorded on 17. 1. 2020 under Section 161 CrPC, wherein the same facts were reiterated, which already found place in the FIR. It has also come on record that despite being request administered to the parents of the victim, as well as the victim for getting her medically examined, she refused for the same. The statement of the victim was also recorded under Section 164 CrPC, a certified copy of the same is at page 70 of the paper book, wherein the victim has deposed that she is of 17 years of age and she is in love with the revisionist for the past three months and she according to her sweet will has married with the revisionist. Consequent to the initiation of the proceedings emanating from the FIR, the revisionist is in observation home since 22. 7. 2020, and the proceeding has been registered as Case Crime no. 9 of 2020, under Section 376 IPC read with Section 5/6 of POCSO Act.
4. The Court of Addl. Sessions Judge/ Special Judge (POCSO Act), Court No. 1, Gorakhpur in the proceedings in Misc. Case No. 260 of 2020, CNR No. UPGK01-003610-2020 (State of U. P. Vs. Vishal Kannaujiaya) by virtue of the order dated 21. 7. 2020 declared the revisionist to be juvenile, while determining his date of birth to be 1. 4. 2003 holding that he was 16 years 9 months and 15 days of age, i. e. below the age of 18 on the date of occurrence of incident. It has also come on record that District Probation Officer submitted report to the Board on 6. 8. 2020, according to which there was no good ground entitling the revisionist to be bailed out in terms of the provisions contained under Section 12 of the J. J. Act, 2015. A police report dated 25. 8. 2020 was also submitted, which also does not find favour with the revisionist.

Vishal Kannaujiaya vs State Of U. P. And Another on 2 December, 2021
HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD
Case: - CRIMINAL REVISION No. - 31 of 2021
Revisionist: - Vishal Kannaujiaya
Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. And Another
Counsel for Revisionist: - Rajnish Shukla
Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A.
Hon'ble Vikas Budhwar, J.
1. This is a revision under Section 102 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 (in short the J. J. Act, 2015), instituted against the order dated 26. 8. 2020 passed by the Principal Magistrate, Juvenile Justice Board, Gorakhpur in Case Crime no. 09 of 2020 (State Vs. Vishal Kannaujiaya), under Section 376 IPC read with Section 5/6 of the Prevention of Child from Sexual Offence Act, 2012, hereinafter referred to as the 'POCSO Act', P. S. Khajani, District Gorakhpur as well as the order dated 27. 11. 2020 passed by learned Addl. Sessions Judge/ Special Judge (POCSO Act), Court No. 1, Gorakhpur, in Criminal Appeal No. 62 of 2020, Vishal Kannaujiaya Vs. State of U. P. and others refusing the bail to the revisionist.
2. Brief facts of the case setforth by the revisionist are that the prosecution has alleged that the victim Miss Neeraj Kannaujiya, daughter of Ram Laut Kannaujiya is 17 years old, as whereas revisionist-juvenile being Master Vishal Kannaujiaya son of Rajesh Kannaujiaya was aged about 16 years, they were found wandering in a suspicious condition in Kasba Khajani on the unlucky day, i. e, 28. 12. 2019. On interception, the juvenile as well as the victim Neeraj Kannaujiaya apprised the police personnel that they were not willing to go to their respective houses as they wanted to live together. Faced with these circumstances, one Sri Rudra Pratap Singh, Sub-Inspector, P. S. Khajani, District Gorakhpur made a communication to the designated official of Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur clearly narrating the fact that the juvenile and the victim both of them were not agreeable to go to their respective houses and further despite the fact that information was provided to the parents of the juvenile and the victim, none of them approached them to take custody of the juvenile or the victim and thus request was being sought to be made to them that the victim as well as the revisionist be taken into the custody of the Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur for their upkeep, care and betterment.
3. It appears that on the same day, i. e. , on 28. 12. 2019, G. D. entry was also made narrating the facts, which had been communicated on 28. 12. 2019 by the Sub-Inspector, P. S. Khajani, Gorakhpur to the Child Welfare Committee, Gorakhpur. Thereafter, FIR was lodged by one Sri Krishna Sinha being the member of the Child Welfare Committee, Gorakhpur before the police station Khajani, Gorakhpur dated 16. 1. 2020 registered as Case Crime no. 0009 of 2020 with an allegation that on 28. 12. 2019 itself the police officials found the revisionist and the victim together in suspicious condition and further on medical examination, it revealed that UPT was positive depicting that she was pregnant. It was also alleged that the father of the victim had not lodged the FIR because the victim was a minor and that will create negative impact upon the character of the victim. Statement of the complainant being Sri Krishna Sinha, Chairman / Member, Child Welfare Committee, District Gorakhpur was recorded on 17. 1. 2020 under Section 161 CrPC, wherein the same facts were reiterated, which already found place in the FIR. It has also come on record that despite being request administered to the parents of the victim, as well as the victim for getting her medically examined, she refused for the same. The statement of the victim was also recorded under Section 164 CrPC, a certified copy of the same is at page 70 of the paper book, wherein the victim has deposed that she is of 17 years of age and she is in love with the revisionist for the past three months and she according to her sweet will has married with the revisionist. Consequent to the initiation of the proceedings emanating from the FIR, the revisionist is in observation home since 22. 7. 2020, and the proceeding has been registered as Case Crime no. 9 of 2020, under Section 376 IPC read with Section 5/6 of POCSO Act.
4. The Court of Addl. Sessions Judge/ Special Judge (POCSO Act), Court No. 1, Gorakhpur in the proceedings in Misc. Case No. 260 of 2020, CNR No. UPGK01-003610-2020 (State of U. P. Vs. Vishal Kannaujiaya) by virtue of the order dated 21. 7. 2020 declared the revisionist to be juvenile, while determining his date of birth to be 1. 4. 2003 holding that he was 16 years 9 months and 15 days of age, i. e. below the age of 18 on the date of occurrence of incident. J. Act, 2015. A police report dated 25. 8. 2020 was also submitted, which also does not find favour with the revisionist.
