[case 103]
The petitioner herein has been arrayed as the sole accused in the instant Crime No. 336/2019 of Kondotty Police Station, Malappuram, which has been registered for offences punishable under Secs. 354B of the IPC and Sec. 10, 9f & 9m of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offence (POCSO) Act, 2012. The prosecution case in short is that the petitioner/accused aged 62 years is a teacher in the Madrassa, where the minor victim girl aged 9 years used to attend religious instruction classes and that on 26. 06. 2019 at about 9a. m. , the petitioner/accused had sexually abused the minor victim girl aged 9 years, while she is in Madrassa by kissing her face and hands and biting on her lips. In the FI Statement, minor victim girl has stated that on the day in question she was alone in the classroom and the petitioner had demanded her that she should come and sit on his lap and she refused and thereupon he had forced her to sit on his lap and kissed on her cheeks saying that she is his daughter and that he had bitten her lips and that he had lifted her churidar top and touched her stomach and tickled her, etc. and that thereby the petitioner had committed the abovesaid offences. Smt. Noorji Noushad, learned counsel appearing for the petitioner has fervently urged that the petitioner is innocent of the allegations and that he happens to be the innocent scapegoat in the factional fight between the two factions of Sunni viz. , AK faction and PK faction and that the petitioner is teaching in a Madrassa which belongs to one of the groups and that the petitioner has been victimized in the instant case, etc. Further the learned counsel for the petitioner would point out that though the incident is allegedly happened on 26. 06. 2019, the First Information Statement and the crime has been lodged only as late as on 06. 07. 2019 and the long and unexplained delay in the lodging of the crime will go to the root of the prosecution case as it affects the very credibility and believability. Per contra, Sri. Saigi Jacob Palatty, learned Public Prosecutor appearing for the respondent-State would point out that the mother of the victim girl on coming to know about the incident which happened on 26. 06. 2019 had immediately complained to the President of the very same Madrassa, where the petitioner is teaching and that the police has now taken a statement from the said President of the Madrassa, who has stated that as a matter of fact the victim's mother had complained him on the very same day (26. 06. 2019) and that he had immediately authorized the Secretary of the Madrassa to conduct the internal enquiry in the matter. That the parents of the girl were patiently waiting for the action of the Madrassa authorities. That someone else who was interested in the welfare of the child had informed the matter to the childline authorities, which in turn led to the information being conveyed to the police, who in turn had taken the statement from the minor victim girl, which in turn has led to the registration of the instant crime and that the delay in this case cannot be said to be unexplained and serious and that in the light of the abovesaid facts and circumstances, the delay is satisfactorily explained, etc. Further that the petitioner has no case that the President of the Madrassa belongs to an opposite faction as the petitioner is teaching in the same Madrassa and the President of the Madrassa has given the above statement before the police about the information conveyed by the victim girl's mother on the same day itself. After hearing both sides and after careful evaluation of the facts and circumstances of the case, the following directions and orders are passed: (i) The petitioner will immediately surrender and personally appear before the Investigating Officer in relation to the instant crime, for interrogation purposes, without any further delay, at any rate by 9 a. m. on any day on or before 14. 08. 2019. (ii) The petitioner will fully co-operate with the Investigating Officer in the conduct of the above interrogation process. (iii) After completing the above interrogation process, the Investigating Officer will produce the petitioner before the jurisdictional Magistrate court concerned in relation to the instant crime, thereupon the learned Magistrate will consider and pass orders on the bail application of the petitioner on the same day of his production, after hearing the petitioner's counsel and the learned Public Prosecutor and after taking due note of the facts and circumstances of this case. With these observations and directions, the above Bail Application will stand disposed of.

[case 104]
Abdulla Ainulhaq Ansari vs The State Of Maharashtra And Anr on 16 December, 2021. This Appeal is directed against the judgment dated 10th October, 2019 in Special Case No. 211 of 2015. By the impugned judgment, the learned Addl. Sessions Judge & Special Judge, City Civil & Sessions Court, Borivali Division, Dindoshi, Mumbai has convicted the Appellant for offences under Section 376(2)(f) and 506 of Indian Penal Code and under Section 5 (n) r/w. Section 6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSO), and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 10 years and one of Rs. 5000/- I. d. rigorous imprisonment for 3 months for offence under Section 376(2)(f) of IPC; rigorous imprisonment for 10 years and fine of Rs. 5000/- i. d. simple imprisonment for 3 months for offence under Section 5(n) r/w. 6 of POCSO Act; and rigorous imprisonment for one year for offence under Section 506 of IPC. The Appellant (hereinafter referred to as 'the Accused') is the father of the prosecutrix (PW2). The prosecutrix along with her siblings, parents and grand parents was residing at Zore Chawl, Mahatma Kabir Road, Vile Parle, Mumbai. Some time in the year 2013, the prosecutrix was housed in Dongri Bal Sudhar Griha in connection with theft of a laptop. About a month later, the accused brought her home. Some days later, she ran away from home and was seen loitering at Kalyan Railway Station. She gave fake name to the police on duty at Kalyan Railway Station. She was produced before the Committee. She was sent to Bhivandi Bal Sudhar Griha (Children's Home) and four months later, she was shifted to Dongri Bal Sudhar Griha. In September, 2015, PW2 informed the Child Welfare Committee that the accused had subjected her to sexual abuse. Hence, by letter dated 08. 09. 2015, the Chairperson of the Child Welfare Committee directed the police to record the statement of the prosecutrix. Accordingly, PW5- Madhavi Kadav recorded the statement of the prosecutrix (PW2) pursuant to which FIR came to be registered against the Accused for offences under Section 376 (1)(ii), 506 of IPC and Section 6 of POCSO Act. PW5 referred the prosecutrix for medical examination, she conducted spot panchanama, arrested the accused and handed over further investigation to PW6- Sudhir Ghosalkar. PW6 requested the Magistrate to record the statement of the prosecutrix under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. He also referred the accused for medical examination and recorded the statement of the other witnesses and filed the charge sheet upon completion of investigation. The Accused pleaded not guilty to the charge and claimed to be tried. Prosecution in support of its case examined 6 witnesses. Statement of the accused was recorded under Section 313 of Cr. P. C. The defence of the accused was that of total denial. He has stated that the prosecutrix always used to run away from home. He objected to the same as he did not approve of the same. He claims that sometimes he used to beat her and hence she has lodged false complaint against him. The Accused has examined his wife as DW1. After evaluating the evidence adduced by the prosecution, the learned Judge has held that the evidence of the prosecutrix amply proves that the Accused herein had subjected her to rape. Hence, relying upon the sole testimony of the prosecutrix, the learned Judge held the Accused guilty of offence under section 376(ii)(f) of the IPC and section 5(n) of POCSO Act, 2012 and sentenced him as stated above. Being aggrieved by the conviction and sentence, the accused has preferred this Appeal under Section 374 of Cr. P. C. The evidence of PW2 reveals that she was housed in Bal Sudhar Griha for theft of a laptop. About a month later, the accused brought her home. She has deposed that the accused did not allow her to leave the house and used to beat her. She therefore ran away from the house, but the accused brought her back and assaulted her and cut her hair. The evidence of this witness is not reliable and trustworthy. She has not emerged as a truthful witness and has not passed the test of a 'sterling witness' and hence no conviction can be based on the uncorroborated testimony of PW2. The trial Court has based the conviction on conjectures and surmises, which are not well founded. Hence the impugned judgment cannot be sustained. Under the circumstances, the appeal is allowed. The impugned judgment is set aside. The accused is acquitted of offences under Section 376(2)(f) and 506 of Indian Penal Code and under Section 5 (n) r/w. Section 6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSO). His bail bond stands discharged.

Based on the statement of the mother, the Crime was initially registered under Sections 363 and 354 and the relevant provisions of the POCSO Act, 2012. Section 376 of the IPC and graver provisions of the POCSO Act were later incorporated. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant would contend that the applicant is innocent. According to the learned counsel, the applicant was just 19 years old when the offence was committed. The allegation of sexual abuse levelled against him is not true, submits the learned counsel. He is from a poor background, whereas the parents of the victim are affluent. Crime No. 361 of 2018 has also been registered inter alia under Sections 353 and 332 of the IPC as against the applicant. Records would show that he has been in custody from 08. 10. 2018 itself. The final report has already been laid as well. In that view of the matter, I do not think that detaining the applicant for a further period would serve any purpose. By imposing appropriate conditions, for safeguarding the interest of the prosecution as well as the protection of the victim, the applicant can now be released. In the result, this application will stand allowed. The applicant shall be released on bail on his executing a bond for Rs. 1, 00, 000/-(Rupees One lakh only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the court having jurisdiction. The above order shall be subject to the following conditions: 1). The applicant shall appear before the Investigating Officer on all Saturdays between 10 a. m. and 1. 00 p. m. , for a period of 3 months. 2). He shall not enter the limits of Thottilpalam Police Station for a period of six months except for complying with the conditions of this order. If for any extraordinary reason the applicant requires to enter the limits, previous permission has to be obtained from the jurisdictional Court. 3). He shall not intimidate or attempt to influence the witnesses; nor shall he tamper with the evidence. He shall not contact the victim or her family members. 4). He shall not commit any offence while he is on bail. 5). He shall not leave India without the permission of the Court and if having passport, shall deposit the same before the Trial Court within a week; If release of the passport is required at a later period, he shall be at liberty to move appropriate application before the Court having jurisdiction. In case of violation of any of the above conditions, the jurisdictional Court shall be empowered to consider the application for cancellation, if any, and pass appropriate orders in accordance with the law.

[case 108]
Aggrieved by the order of learned Sessions Judge, Dhrangadhra in Sessions Case No. 24 of 2014 dated 8th April 2015, the present revision application has been preferred seeking to challenge the order of rejection of discharge application of the applicants-accused. It is the case of prosecution that the prosecutrix and her parents followed Islam. The marriage of prosecutrix with the original accused no. 7 and the applicant no. 1 herein was performed as per the Muslim Personal law and with the consent of the parties the Nikah had been performed. Under section 11 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 ['POCSO' for short] so also under section 3 & 16 of the said Act and also under Section 376 read with 114 IPC, after the investigation, the chargesheet had been laid. It is the case of the applicants that Islam permits marriage at the age of 15 years, therefore, the limitation prescribed under the law for marriage of 18 years for the girl would not come in the way of the applicants. Moreover, the Court added Sections 4 & 17 of the POCSO which are the provisions prescribed for punishment under Section 3 and 16 respectively, that also has aggrieved the applicants. Learned advocate Mr. Malik appearing for all the applicants has urged that it is an internal dispute of the family which has brought to the fore the factum of child marriage. He has urged that the girl's statement also reveals that the paternal uncle of the girl since did not enjoy good relationship with the family, has complained against such marriage. He urged that the applicants are not only aggrieved by imposition of Section 4 & 17 of the POSCO but also for non grant of their application where they made a request for discharge from all the offences. He has fervently urged that the radiological report is clearly indicative of the fact that the prosecutrix is between 16 -18 years and therefore also, this Court requires to interfere with the order of discharge passed by the learned Sessions Judge, Dhrangadhra. Learned APP Ms. Punani has urged that the very object of the Act of 2012 is to protect the children who are not adequately protected, as they require security at the tender age. She urged that the age of prosecutrix was 13 years at the time of her so-called marriage, and therefore, the trial Court was right in not discharging the applicants-accused of the charges levelled against them. She further urged that Section 3 of the POSCO Act, 2012 speaks of penetrative sexual assault; Section 4 prescribes punishment for penetrative sexual assault and Section 16 likewise is with respect to abetment of an offence and section 17 prescribes punishment for abetment. Such additions, therefore, would not warrant any interference. Having thus heard both the sides, for the reasons to follow hereinafter, this application deserves dismissal. When there is sufficient ground existing for the Court to frame the charges on the basis of evidence that may be adduced by the prosecution by way of paper of chargesheet, the Court can frame the charges. Once the case is presented to the Court, it is required of the Court to sift through the material and it becomes its bounden duty to ensure that the reasonable ground is made out from such material for the Court to frame the charges. The law on the subject is well-settled. It is also reiterated recently, referring to all earlier laws by the Apex Court in case of L Krishna Reddy v. State by Station House Officer & Ors. , reported in (2014) 14 SCC 401. As could be noticed from the material on record, the birth date of the prosecutrix is 10th September 1999. The marriage according to the prosecution took place with the applicant no. 1 herein on 23rd August 2013 when the prosecutrix was only 13 years old. The trial Court has rightly observed that the victim being less than 15 years of age, the provisions of POSCO Act 2012 which are otherwise meant for protecting the abuse of the children have been rightly invoked, even if the parents were agreeable to such marriage, the law will take its own course. Moreover, addition of Sections 4 & 17 is merely incidental as substantive provisions of Sections 3 & 16 were already forming part of the chargesheet. On neither count, this application warrants interference at the hands of this Court. Moreover, there is no grave miscarriage of justice nor there is any manifest illegality which deserves indulgence. Resultantly, Criminal Misc. Application fails and the same is rejected.

[case 109]
K. Vijay vs The State on 29 November, 2022. This Criminal Original Petition has been preferred to call for the records in Spl. SC. No. 27 of 2020 on the file of the Principal District Judge cum Special Judge (Under POCSO Act) Puducherry and quash the same. The first petitioner is the sole accused in Crime No. 92 of 2019 on the file of the first respondent police. The second petitioner is the wife of the first petitioner. The Child Welfare Committee, Puducherry, has given the complaint to the first respondent that the first petitioner had committed sexual offences on the second petitioner. The said case came to be registered when the second petitioner who was conceived then, went to Rajiv Gandhi Government Hospital, Puducherry for medical check up. The second petitioner was married to the first petitioner as early as on 27. 04. 2019 and they started to live as a family at the first petitioner's house at Puducherry. When the second petitioner got pregnant, she was taking treatment at Rajiv Gandhi Government Hospital, Puducherry. During the medical examination, she revealed her age that she was 16 years old and that prompted the Hospital authorities to pass information to the second respondent Child Welfare Committee and the second respondent, in turn, had given a complaint to the first respondent Police on the above allegation; and on which, FIR has been registered under Section 6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 after investigation, final report was filed and the same has been taken on file in Spl. SC. No. 27 of 2020 for the offences under Section 361 IPC read with Section 6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006, on the file of the Principal District Judge cum Special Judge (Under POCSO Act) Puducherry. When the matter is taken up for hearing, both the petitioners present before this Court and filed their respective affidavits dated 10. 11. 2022 stating that the relationship between them is out of their marriage that had been taken place in the year 2019 and their marital life cannot be taken as a criminal offence. At no point of time, the second petitioner had intended to give any complaint against the first petitioner. Because she considers the first petitioner as her husband and for whom, she had delivered one female child. Now, the second petitioner is pregnant for her second child and the matter came to be known only when she had been to the hospital for her routine medical check up. Further, both the petitioners have also filed their respective affidavits dated 10. 11. 2022 stating that the continuation of the prosecution would only spoil their peaceful family life and also the future of their daughter. When enquired, both the petitioners submitted that they fell in love with each other and hence, they got married and their marital life is happy and peaceful. No useful purpose is going to be served by subjecting the first petitioner under trial. Even though the offence is non-compoundable, in the extraneous circumstances of the present case, I feel it is appropriate to rely on the principles laid down by the Honble Supreme Court in the case of PARBATBHAI AAHIR VS. STATE OF GUJARAT [AIR 2017 SC 4843] to quash the proceedings. In the said case, in Paragraph 15, it has held as under: 15. The Broad Principles which emerge from the precedents on the subject, may be summarised in the following propositions: (i) Section 482 Cr. P. C preserves the inherent powers of the High Court to prevent an abuse of the process of any court or to secure the ends of justice. The provision does not confer new powers. It only recognises and preserves powers which inherent in the High Court. (ii) The invocation of the jurisdiction of the High Court to quash a first information report or a criminal proceeding on the ground that a settlement has been arrived at between the offender and the victim is not the same as the invocation of jurisdiction for the purpose of compounding an offence. While compounding an offence, the power of the court is governed by the provisions of Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. The power to quash under Section 482 is attracted even if the offence is non-compoundable. In the result, this Criminal Original Petition is allowed and as a sequel, the further proceedings in Spl. SC. No. 27 of 2020 on the file of the learned Principal District Judge Cum Special Judge (Under POCSO Act) Puducherry is quashed.

J. ,ADVOCATE) AND: STATE OF KARNATAKA, SHO, HASSAN WOMEN PS, HASSAN DISTRICT, REPTD. BY GOVT. PLEADER, HIGH COURT BUILDING, BENGALURU - 560 001. .. .RESPONDENT (BY SRI. K. THIS PETITION, COMING ON FOR ORDERS, THIS DAY, THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING: ORDER Heard the learned counsel for petitioner, the learned High Court Government Pleader for respondent/State and perused the material on record. The petitioner is arraigned as accused No. 2 in Crime No. 117/2023 of Hassan Women Police Station, registered for the offence punishable under Sections 498A, 323, 324, 504, 342, 506 and 313 read with 34 of IPC and Sections 3 and 4 of the Dowry Prohibition Act. The complaint averments reveal that the complainant Smt. Pooja Y. C married accused No. 1 Sri. Venkatesh Gowda T. R on 24. 04. 2023 as per Hindu customs at one Shubhodaya Kalyana Mantapa, Hassan. At the time of marriage 180 grams of gold ornaments and Rs. 3, 00, 000/- dowry was given. The complainant was looked after properly only for two months and thereafter, her husband and mother-in-law i. e; the petitioner started demanding further dowry of Rs. 5, 00, 000/-and in this connection they were giving physical and mental torture to her. It is further alleged that when the complainant was one and half month pregnant, she was forced to abort the child and her husband and mother-in-law abused her and asked her to do all the household works and they have assaulted her and her husband kicked her on her stomach, due to which she got admitted to hospital on 18. 11. 2023 and the child got aborted. The learned counsel for the petitioner has drawn the attention of the Court to the statement of the complainant which was recorded by the police on 28. 10. 2023 i. e. , prior to lodging of the present complaint. It goes to show that the relationship between the husband and wife was strained and therefore, the elders and family members intervened and tried to settle. In her statement she has stated that if their relationship continues to be uncordial, she will settle the matter before the Family Court. The present complaint is lodged on 30. 11. 2023. The allegation of kicking on the stomach of the complainant is against her husband i. e; accused No. 1. It is also alleged that the complainant saw some vulgar messages in his mobile phone and when she questioned him, she was assaulted by him etc. The petitioner is a woman aged about 67 years. She has undertaken to co-operate with the investigation of the case. Considering that the offence alleged are not punishable with death or imprisonment for life, relief sought by the petitioner can be granted imposing conditions. Hence, the following: ORDER i) Petition is allowed. ii) Petitioner/accused No. 2 in Crime No. 117/2023 of Hassan Women Police Station, shall be released in the event of her arrest, subject to following conditions: a) Petitioner shall appear before the Investigation Officer within a period of one week from the date of receipt of a copy of the order and shall execute a bond in a sum of Rs. 1, 00, 000/- (Rupees One Lakh Only) with a likesum surety. b) She shall furnish proof of her residential address and shall inform the Investigation Officer/Court, if there is change in the address. c) She shall be available for the purpose of investigation as and when required and shall co-operate with the investigation. d) She shall not leave the jurisdiction of the trial Court without prior permission till completion of the investigation of the case. e) She shall not tamper with the prosecution witnesses either directly or indirectly. f) She shall be regular in attending the Court proceedings.

Mohammed Abdul Hamid vs The State Rep. By on 2 December, 2022. IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 02. 12. 2022. CORAM: THE HONOURABLE MS JUSTICE R. N. MANJULA. Crl. O. P. No. 29641 of 2022 Mohammed Abdul Hamid. .. Petitioner Vs. 1. The State rep. by Inspector of Police, T-14 Mangadu Police, Chennai  600 056. (Crime No. 76 of 2021) 2. Salim. .. Respondents Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code, to call for the records in Crime No. 76 of 2021 on the file of the 1st respondent and quash the same. For Petitioners: Mr. K. Thenrajan For 1st Respondent: Mr. E. Raj Thilak Additional Public Prosecutor ORDER This Criminal Original Petition has been filed to call for the records in Crime No. 76 of 2021 on the file of the 1st respondent and quash the same. On the complaint given by the 2nd respondent that his sister's daughter was missing from 12. 12. 2021, a case has been registered for girl missing in Crime No. 76 of 2021 on the file of the T-14 Mangadu Police Station, Chennai 600 056 and subsequently the charges have been altered from girl missing to Sections 6 r/w 5J (ii) (i) POCSO Act, 2012. Today when the matter is taken up for hearing, it is submitted that the petitioner had married the victim girl as per Muslim rites and customs and the couple has a three months old infant born out of their marriage. It is further submitted that the de facto complainant who is the paternal uncle of the victim girl has also filed an affidavit by stating that in view of the marriage between the victim and the petitioner, he does not want to pursue the case. The petitioner, the defacto complainant, the victim girl and her mother were present before this Court and they were identified by the Police viz. , Ms. K. Gracy, SSI, SRMC All Women Police Station, Mangadu. The 2nd respondent has produced the copy of the Aadhar Card. A joint compromise memo, dated 02. 12. 2022 has also been filed. The second respondent has stated that she affixed her signature without fear or coercion. The records would reveal that the date of birth of the victim girl is 03. 06. 2004 and she has attained majority. As it has been stated already, the marriage between the victim girl and the accused had taken place and they have constituted a family and become parents for a female child. In such circumstances, if the prosecution is allowed to continue, that will not serve any useful purpose and that will de-stabilize the family equilibrium of the petitioner and the victim. Even though the offences under POCSO Act are non-compoundable in nature, in the circumstances of the present case, I feel it is appropriate to take the cue from the principles laid down by the Honble Supreme Court in the case of Parbatbhai Aahir Vs. State of Gujarat reported in AIR 2017 SC 4843. In the said case, in Paragraph 15, it has held as under: 15. The Broad Principles which emerge from the precedents on the subject, may be summarised in the following propositions: (i) Section 482 Cr. P. C preserves the inherent powers of the High Court to prevent an abuse of the process of any court or to secure the ends of justice. The provision does not confer new powers. It only recognises and preserves powers which inherent in the High Court. (ii) The invocation of the jurisdiction of the High Court to quash a first information report or a criminal proceeding on the ground that a settlement has been arrived at between the offender and the victim is not the same as the invocation of jurisdiction for the purpose of compounding an offence. While compounding an offence, the power of the court is governed by the provisions of Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. The power to quash under Section 482 is attracted even if the offence is non-compoundable. The petitioner who had married the victim girl, if subjected to trial that would affect the interest of the victim girl herself. In order to serve the ends of justice, I feel it is appropriate to quash the criminal proceedings against the petitioner by invoking the powers of this Court under Section 482 of Cr. P. C. In the result, this Criminal Original Petition stands allowed and as a sequel, the further proceedings in Crime No. 76 of 2021 on the file of the 1strespondent, is quashed in terms of compromise. The terms of Joint Compromise Memo, dated 02. 12. 2022 shall form part of this Order.

IN THE HIGH COURT OF GUJARAT AT AHMEDABAD R/CRIMINAL MISC. APPLICATION NO. 10266 of 2021 PRAKASHBHAI GORDHANBHAI METAL (KODI PATEL) Versus STATE OF GUJARAT Appearance: A R KADRI(7330) for the Applicant(s) No. 1 MR PRANAV TRIVEDI APP(2) for the Respondent(s) No. 1 CORAM: HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE S. H. VORA Date: 22/06/2021 ORAL ORDER Rule. Learned APP waives service of notice of rule for the respondent - State. 1. Heard learned advocate for the applicant and learned APP for the respondent State. 2. This application is filed under Section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure for regular bail in connection with F. I. R. registered at C. R. No. 11215029200377 of 2020 with Tarapur Police Station for the offences punishable under Sections 363, 366 and 376 of the IPC and u/s 4, 6 and 18 of the POCSO Act. 3. Learned advocate for the applicant has submitted that the applicant and the prosecutrix were in love with each other and the prosecutrix accompanied the applicant of her own and thereby, abandoned the guardianship of her parents voluntarily. 4. Learned APP, while opposing the application, has submitted that at the relevant time, the prosecutrix was aged 17 years and 07 months. She being the minor, the question of consent does not arise and therefore, the offence u/s 376 read with POCSO Act has been committed and therefore, the applicant may not be enlarged on bail. 5. Heard learned advocates appearing for the respective parties in great detail and perused the records. 6. Though the applicant is married having one child fell in love with the victim girl. As the prosecutrix was minor, the applicant is sent behind prison because of the complaint lodged by the complainant. Undoubtedly, a minor girl is to be protected under law as there are number of instances of sexual abuses of minor girls and therefore, there is a special legislation of POCSO in the year 2012 and amendment in sections 375 and 376 of the IPC in 2014. The judiciary takes a very serious note of sexual offences against women and specially against minor girls. Upon reading of the statement of the prosecutrix, they both eloped. Further, the trial Court rejected bail application mainly on the ground that the girl is minor and her consent is immaterial. 7. In the present case, the prosecutrix is 17 years and 07 months old and the accused is 21 years old. It appears from the record and the statement of the prosecutrix that the prosecutrix was in love with the applicant and left the home of her own and moved with the applicant at various places. These are the mitigating factors and therefore, present application deserves consideration. 8. Hence, the application is allowed and the applicant is ordered to be released on bail in connection with C. R. No. 11215029200377 of 2020 with Tarapur Police Station, on executing a bond of Rs. 10, 000/-(Rupees Ten Thousand only) with one surety of the like amount to the satisfaction of the trial Court and subject to the conditions that the applicant shall; [a] not take undue advantage of liberty or misuse liberty; [b] not act in a manner injurious to the interest of the prosecution; [c] not leave the territory of India without prior permission of the Sessions Judge concerned; [d] appear before the Investigation Officer concerned, as and when required for investigation purpose and attend the Court concerned regularly. [e] furnish the present address of residence along with the proof to the I. O. concerned and also to the Court at the time of execution of the bond and shall not change the residence without prior permission of Sessions Court concerned; 9. The competent authority will release the applicant only if the applicant is not required in connection with any other offence for the time being. If breach of any of the above conditions is committed, the Sessions Judge concerned will be free to take appropriate action in the matter. Bail bond to be executed before the lower court having jurisdiction to try the case. It will be open for the concerned Court to delete, modify and/or relax any of the above conditions in accordance with law. At the trial, the trial court shall not be influenced by the observations of preliminary nature, qua the evidence at this stage, made by this Court while enlarging the applicant on bail. 10. Rule made absolute to the aforesaid extent. Direct service is permitted.

State vs. Ajit, on 29 July, 2017 IN THE COURT OF SH. SANJAY GARG, ADDITIONAL SESSIONS JUDGE01, DWARKA COURTS, NEW DELHI. Sessions Case No. 440819/2016 State Vs. Ajit, S/o Sh. Uppender Kumar, R/o A207, J. J. Colony, Manglapuri, PhaseII, Palam, New Delhi. FIR No. : 706/2015 Police Station: Palam Village Under Section: 354A/354D/324 IPC & 12 POCSO Act Date of presentation of charge sheet: 25. 04. 2016 Date on which judgment was reserved: 29. 07. 2017 Date on which judgment was pronounced: 29. 07. 2017 JUDGMENT: 1. The FIR was registered on the complaint lodged by the child victim. At that time, she was about 15 years old. In the complaint, the child victim alleged that the accused used to follow her, hurl vulgar abuses and make indecent gestures to her. She further alleged that on 08. 12. 2015 at about 8 a. m. , when she alongwith her friend was going to school, the accused caught hold of her hand and proposed her for marriage and upon her refusal, he caused injury on her left hand with a blade and thereafter, pushed her due to which, she fell down and sustained injuries on her head. Consequent upon the registration of FIR, the accused was arrested. The statements of the witnesses under Section 161 Cr. P. C. were recorded. The statement of the child victim was also got recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. After completion of investigation, the charge sheet was filed. 2. On 08. 07. 2016, the charge for the offences punishable under Sections 8/12 POCSO Act and Section 324 IPC was framed against the accused Ajit. He pleaded not guilty and claimed trial. 3. The prosecution examined the child victim, her friend, father and mother as PW1 to PW4 respectively. 4. Vide order of even date, the remaining prosecution evidence was closed and the statement of the accused under Section 313 Cr. P. C. was dispensed with. 5. I have heard the Addl. PP for the State and the counsel for the accused. The material on record has also been perused. 6. The child victim and her friend were the star witnesses of the case of the prosecution. The child victim appeared in the witness box as PW1. In her deposition, though she corroborated the incident to the extent that a boy had proposed her for marriage near her school and upon her refusal, he had pushed her resulting in head injury to her but she turned hostile on the aspect of identity of the accused. She was cross-examined by the Addl. PP. In her cross-examination, she denied the suggestion of the Addl. PP that the accused used to follow her and reiterated that he had not met her on the date of the incident. As per the case of the prosecution, the child victim was accompanied with her friend on the date of incident. The friend of the child victim was examined by the prosecution as PW2. In her testimony, she also failed to support the case of the prosecution and did not utter anything incriminating against the accused. Besides the child victim and her friend, the prosecution examined the father and mother of the child victim as PW3 and PW4 respectively. However even they did not support the case of the prosecution and denied the suggestion of the Addl. PP that the child victim had told them that the accused used to follow her and had sexually assaulted her and caused injuries to her on the date of incident. Since the material witnesses had not supported the case of the prosecution, it would have been a futile exercise to examine the remaining prosecution witnesses, who were formal in nature. The prosecution evidence was therefore closed. As no incriminating evidence came on record against the accused, his statement under Section 313 Cr. P. C. was dispensed with. 7. In the light of the above discussion, it is evident that the prosecution has miserably failed to bring home the guilt of the accused. Accordingly, the accused Ajit is acquitted of the charge for the commission of offences punishable under Sections 8/12 POCSO Act and Section 324 IPC. Bail bond in terms of Section 437A Cr. P. C. furnished on behalf of the accused has been accepted, which shall remain in force for a period of six months from today. Pronounced in the open court. (SANJAY GARG) Dated: 29. 07. 2017 Additional Sessions Judge01, Dwarka Courts, New Delhi. Sessions Case No. 440819/2016 State Vs. Ajit Page No. 3/3

[case 115]
Vikas Soni vs State Of U. P. & Another on 5 August, 2021. HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD, LUCKNOW BENCH. Case: - CRIMINAL REVISION No. - 1461 of 2019. Revisionist: - Vikas Soni. Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. & Another. Counsel for Revisionist: - Akhilesh Kumar Pandey. Counsel for Opposite Party: - Govt. Advocate. Hon'ble Mrs. Saroj Yadav, J. This criminal revision has been preferred by the juvenile Vikas Soni through his father, under Section 102 of Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act of 2015 against judgement and order dated 13. 9. 2019 passed by Special Judge, (POCSO Act), Pratapgarh in Criminal Appeal No. 51 of 2019 Vikas Soni Vs. State of U. P. and order dated 2. 7. 2019 passed by the learned Juvenile Justice Board, Pratapgarh in Bail Application No. 39 of 2019 arising out of Case Crime No. 31 of 2018 under Sections 41, 411, 413, 414, 401 of Indian Penal Code, Police Station Government Railway Police, Pratapgarh. The brief factual matrix necessary for disposal of this criminal revision are as under: On 10. 7. 2018, a First Information Report was registered at Crime No. 31 of 2018 at police Station G. R. P. , Pratapgarh under Sections 41, 411, 413, 414, 401 IPC on the basis of recovery memo prepared by Sub Inspector against the revisionist and three others. According to recovery memo, the revisionist alongwith three others was arrested on the information given by a fink at the railway station, Pratapgarh making preparation to commit theft. In search of the person of the revisionist, a mobile Samsung Phone of golden colour was recovered. He confessed that he has stolen the mobile from train 4-5 days back and trying to sell the same. It has also been mentioned in the recovery memo that he is a habitual thief and has committed thefts earlier also. Investigation started. Revisionist claimed juvenility and was so declared by the learned J. J. Board vide order dated 11. 6. 2019. His age was found 16 years. He moved bail application before the J. J. Board and the same was rejected. Against the order of JJ Board, an appeal was preferred under Section 101 of the Act of 2015, that too was rejected. Learned counsel for the revisionist submitted that the revisionist has falsely been implicated in the crime. The recovery has falsely been shown and there is no independent witness of the recovery. He further submitted that the revisionist was below 18 years of age on the date of the alleged crime. There is nothing adverse to the revisionist in the report of District Probation Officer. Learned A. G. A. on the other hand submitted that the revisionist is a habitual thief. Earlier also, he was detained and enlarged on bail for the offence of theft. Hence, judgment of the learned appellate court and the order of the learned J. J. Board are perfectly legal. The revision should be dismissed. Section 12(1) of the Act of 2015 lays down that when any person, who is apparently a child and is alleged to have committed a bailable or non-bailable offence, is apprehended or detained by the police or appears or brought before a Board, such person shall, be released on bail with or without surety or placed under the supervision of a probation officer or under the care of any fit person, provided that such person shall not be so released if there appears reasonable grounds for believing that the release is likely to bring that person into association with any known criminal or expose the said person to moral, physical or psychological danger. The legal position is that, for a juvenile in conflict with law bail is the Rule. The bail to a juvenile can be denied exceptionally. From perusal of the record, it is discernible that the revisionist was arrested. The revisionist is in detention since 11. 7. 2018. He has spent more than three years in detention. Considering the above facts and circumstances, it appears just to set aside the orders passed by the learned J. J. Board and the judgement passed in appeal. The revision is allowed. The juvenile Vikas Soni shall be released on bail. It is pertinent to mention here, since the revisionist has now turned an adult, he shall be released upon furnishing a personal bond himself and two sureties each of the like amount.

[case 116]
Madras High Court Swetha Bhai vs State Rep By The Inspector Of Police on 4 November, 2022 IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 04. 11. 2022 CORAM: THE HON'BLE Ms. JUSTICE R. N. MANJULA CRL. O. P. No. 26875 of 2022 and Crl. M. P. Nos. 16509 & 16547 of 2022 Swetha Bhai. .. Petitioner/A2 Versus State Rep by the Inspector of Police, W-17 All Women Police Station, Peravallur, Chennai 600 082. [Crime No. 05/2022]. .. Prayer: Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to call for the records in Spl. S. C. No. 122 of 2022 on the file of the Special Court for Exclusive Trial of Cases Under POCSO Act-2012, Chennai and quash the same. The petitioner is the mother of the victim child, who was also impleaded as an accused in the case registered by the Respondent/Police in Cr. No. 5/22 of W-17, All Women Police Station, for the offences under Sections 9(m)(n) r/w10 of POCSO Act & 21(1) of POCSO Act, 2012. Heard the submission made by the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Additional Public Prosecutor for the respondent police and perused the materials available on record. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the complaint was given by a CWC Member by name N. Lalitha; the allegation made in the complaint is that the victim child appeared disturbed at her school due to sexual abuse caused by her own father; she revealed the said facts to her teacher; on coming to know this, the Head Master of her School called the Child Help Line and thereafter the CWC members met the child, enquired her and filed this complaint; so far as the allegation against the petitioner is concerned, she did not report the occurrence to the police despite she had knowledge about the sexual abuse caused by her husband on her child. The learned Additional Public Prosecutor appearing for the first respondent police submitted that despite the mother had the knowledge about the occurrence, she did not come forward to give a complaint and only because of that she had been impleaded as an accused. Since the defacto complainant has just set the law in motion and she is not the victim in this case, I feel it is sufficient to hear the learned Additional Public Prosecutor appearing for the respondent police on behalf of the State. The records would show that the mother has been impleaded as an accused in this case on the allegation that she did not report the sexual abuse caused to her own daughter, to the police. It is a sad case where the perpetrator happened to be the very father of the minor child. In this difficult situation, it is not easy for both the victim and her mother to take decision about the appropriate legal action against the accused, who stand in a very close relationship with them. Even according to the complaint the mother of the victim had enquired about this to her husband during February 2022. Though allegations were made that the child had informed the occurrence to her mother during February 2017, the 164 statement of the child would show that she had informed her mother only during February 2022. As stated already, due to the difficult and intimate relationship of the victim and the petitioner with the accused, it can not be inferred that the petitioner had an intention to suppress the occurrence. It is needless to state that in sexual offences, the complaint can be given with some delay. And that may be due to social stigma and familial integrity and all other associated. Though such kind of occurrence should be reported immediately, if the perpetrator happens to be the father of the victim child, the mother cannot be expected to give a complaint without making thorough enquiry and ascertaining the facts from every angle and that may take some time. The gap between the time when the victim informed her mother and the date of the complaint made by the CWC Member is not too long. Hence, I feel the petitioner deserves to be given with the benefit of doubt even at the threshold level without subjected to futher process. In the result, the Criminal Original Petition is allowed and the FIR in Cr. No. 5/22 of W-17, All Women Police Station against the petitioner / A2 alone is quashed.

[case 117]
Muthu Kumar vs The State on 31 January, 2025. This Criminal Appeal arises out of the judgment of conviction and sentence rendered by the learned Sessions Judge, Special Court for Exclusive Trial of Cases under the POSCO Act, Chennai, in Spl. S. C. No. 195 of 2022, dated 31. 10. 2023. The appellant was tried along with one Bhuvaneswari (A2), the mother of the victim girl. The learned trial Judge found A2 guilty for the offence under Section 6 read with Section 17 @ 21(1) of the POCSO Act and convicted and sentenced her to undergo imprisonment for four months, and the period of detention already undergone has been set off under Section 428 Cr. P. C. The victim, P. W. 2, who was born on 15. 09. 2004, was a minor at the time of the incident. She had been living with her mother (A2) since her father separated from the family, taking the victim's brother with him. The appellant, an auto driver, came into contact with the victim's family when he began providing transportation. Later, he informed the victim's mother that he had divorced his wife, and the appellant and A2 began living together with the victim girl. Taking advantage of the mother's absence, the appellant forcibly committed penetrative sexual assault on the victim girl. This abuse continued, and the victim later became pregnant. She gave birth to a male child at home, and when complications arose with the umbilical cord, the victim sought medical treatment. This led to the involvement of the Child Welfare Committee (CWC) and the Police, bringing the crime to light. Following medical treatment, the Primary Health Centre staff, Nammalwarpet reported the case to the CWC after discovering the victim's pregnancy and minor status. The CWC informed the Police, and thereafter, the case was registered in Crime No. 11 of 2022 against the accused for the offences under Sections 5(j)(ii), 6 and 17 of the POCSO Act. During the investigation, the victim's statement was recorded. Subsequently, the victim was produced before a doctor and a Magistrate, where her statement under Section 164 of the Cr. P. C. was recorded. After recording statements from the witnesses and collecting the materials, the accused were arrested. A charge sheet was filed before the trial Court, listing 14 witnesses. Upon completion of the trial, the trial Court convicted the appellant (A1) under Section 6 of the POCSO Act. The second accused (A2) was convicted under Section 6 read with Section 17 @ 21 (1) of the POCSO Act. The learned counsel for the appellant contends that the trial Court's finding is contrary to both the law and the weight of the evidence. The learned counsel submits that the trial Court failed to properly consider the statement made by the victim, P. W. 2, who categorically stated that she and the appellant had got married, and that a male child was born out of their relationship. According to P. W. 2, she and the appellant were living together as husband and wife. P. W. 2 further stated that their baby developed an infection in the umbilical cord, and the baby was taken to the Public Health Centre for treatment. Additionally, the learned Government Advocate (Criminal side) submits that the de-facto complainant in this case is a member of the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), who received information from the Public Health Centre in Nammalwarpet regarding the victim's condition. The trial Court correctly considered all the relevant materials and evidence in this case, including the victim's minor status, the DNA test report, and the statements recorded during the investigation. Based on this thorough and comprehensive analysis, the trial Court concluded that the appellant was guilty of the charges levelled against him. The victim hails from a marginalized background and lives in poverty. It is the appellant's family that takes care of the victim, supports her, and provides aid in all aspects. In the result, the criminal appeal is allowed; the conviction and sentences imposed on the appellant/A1 by judgment dated 31. 10. 2023, in Spl. S. C. No. 195 of 2022, by the learned Sessions Judge, Special Court for Exclusive Trial of Cases under the POCSO Act, Chennai, is set aside and he is acquitted from all the charges.

JAYACHANDRAN FRIDAY, THE 21ST DAY OF FEBRUARY 2025 / 2ND PHALGUNA, 1946 CRL. MC NO. 925 OF 2024 CRIME NO. 811/2021 OF BINANIPURAM POLICE STATION, ERNAKULAM IN CC NO. 29 OF 2022 OF JUDICIAL MAGISTRATE OF FIRST CLASS-II, ALUVA PETITIONERS/ACCUSED: 1 MAHALAKSHMY P. C AGED 34 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT. , PIN - 683516 2 CHITHARANJAN AGED 66 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT. , PIN - 683516 3 SIVESWAR P. C AGED 30 YEARS PULLARKADU HOUSE, MADAPLATHURUTH, MOOTHAKUNNAM P. O, ERANAKULAM DISTRICT, PIN - 683516 BY ADV N. P. 2. Heard Sri Arvind Yadav, learned counsel for the applicant and Sri Jitendra Singh, Advocate holding brief of Sri Rayoof Ali, learned counsel for the informant as well as Sri Ashwani Kumar Tripathi, learned A. G. A. for the State and perused the material placed on record.
3. Applicant seeks bail in Case Crime No. 191 of 2024, under Sections 363, 366, 376 of I. P. C. and Sections 5/6 of POCSO Act, Police Station - Dhanghata, District - Sant Kabir Nagar, during the pendency of trial.
4. Learned counsel for the applicant has argued that the applicant is absolutely innocent and has been falsely implicated in the present case. He has nothing to do with the said offence as alleged in the FIR.
5. Learned counsel has also stated that the victim is the deponent in the instant application. The victim by her looks seems to be major. Learned counsel has also stated that a child has been born out of the said corporeal relationship and the victim has expressed her willingness to spend her life with the applicant.
6. Several other submissions have been made on behalf of the applicant to demonstrate the falsity of the allegations made against him. The circumstances which, as per counsel, led to the false implication of the applicant have also been touched upon at length. There is no criminal history of the applicant. The applicant is languishing in jail since 30. 09. 2024 and he is ready to cooperate with trial. In case, the applicant is released on bail, he will not misuse the liberty of bail.
7. Per contra, learned A. G. A. and learned counsel for the informant have no objection.
8. In light of the judgement of the Supreme Court passed in Niranjan Singh and another vs Prabhakar Rajaram Kharote and others AIR 1980 SC 785, this Court has avoided detailed examination of the evidence and elaborate documentation of the merits of the case as no party should have the impression that his case has been prejudiced. A prima facie satisfaction of case is needed but it is not the same as an exhaustive exploration of the merits in the order itself.
9. Considering the facts and circumstances of the case, submissions made by learned counsel for the parties, the evidence on record, and taking into consideration the settled law of the Supreme Court passed in Satender Kumar Antil vs. Central Bureau of Investigation and Ors. , 2022 INSC 690 and Manish Sisodia vs. Directorate of Enforcement, 2024 INSC 595 and without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case, the Court is of the view that the applicant has made out a case for bail. The bail application is allowed.
10. Let the applicant- Ajay, who is involved in aforementioned case crime be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned subject to following conditions. Further, before issuing the release order, the sureties be verified.
(i) The applicant shall not tamper with evidence.
(ii) The applicant shall remain present, in person, before the Trial Court on dates fixed for (1) opening of the case, (2) framing of charge and (3) recording of statement under Section 313 Cr. P. C. / 351BNSS If in the opinion of the Trial Court absence of the applicant is deliberate or without sufficient cause, then it shall be open for the Trial Court to treat such default as abuse of liberty of bail and proceed against him in accordance with law.
11. In case of breach of any of the above conditions, it shall be a ground for cancellation of bail.
12. It is made clear that observations made in granting bail to the applicant shall not in any way affect the learned trial Judge in forming his independent opinion based on the testimony of the witnesses.

[case 120]
This Civil Revision Petition arise against the order passed by the learned I Additional Principal Judge, Family Court, at Chennai in IA No. 1 of 2023 in IDOP No. 1921 of 2023 dated 01. 12. 2023. The Civil Revision Petitioner is the husband. The wife presented IDOP No. 1921 of 2023 seeking for divorce under Section 10(1)(x) of the Indian Divorce Act. The petitioner married the respondent as per Christian rites and customs on 26. 06. 2013. From the wed-lock, a girl child was born to the couple. Thereafter disputes and differences arose between the parties. Alleging that the husband physically and verbally abused the wife and treated her with cruelty, the wife approached the All Women Police Station at Vepery. Finding that it was not fruitful, she presented the above original petition. Summons was served on the respondent, he has entered appearance. Pending the litigation, she took out an application invoking Section 36 of the Indian Divorce Act, 1869. She sought for a direction to the husband to pay a sum of Rs. 30, 000/- to herself and her child and Rs. 25, 000/- towards maintenance. The husband filed a counter stating that the wife is a triple degree holder and she is working in an I. T. Company under the name and style of Zoho. He would plead that since she is earning a sum of Rs. 45, 000/- per month, she is not entitled to maintenance. Insofar as the litigation is concerned, he would state that the legal services authority is giving free legal aid to litigants and that the party could approach the said Authority for legal defence. Both the parties filed their affidavit of assets and liabilities as directed by the Supreme Court in Rajnesh v. Neha and another, reported in AIR 2021 (SC) 569. The learned Trial Judge came to a conclusion that the husband is earning around Rs. 26, 000/- per month and he is employed with CSS Corp Chennai as Technical Support. Therefore, she concluded that a sum of Rs. 12, 000/- i. e. , Rs. 6, 000/- each to the petitioner and the girl child would be reasonable in the circumstances. Challenging the said order, this revision arise. Mr. P. Sankara Narayanan, learned counsel would plead that the learned Trial Judge did not take into consideration that the wife is earning more than the husband and therefore, she is not entitled for any amount. He would plead that he would take care of the interest of the child, but cannot maintain the wife, on account of the fact that she is earning more than him and also to the fact that he is suffering from physical ailments and has to take care of the needs of his aged mother. Hence he would plead that the revision deserves admission and an interim order. I have carefully considered the submissions of Mr. Sankara Narayanan. At the outset I have to remind myself that the Court sitting under revision under Article 227 of the Constitution of India, would not normally interfere with the order of interim maintenance, unless and until the amount is arbitrary, excessive or bordering on luxury to the respondent. The amount granted to both the parties is only Rs. 12, 000/-. This works out to about Rs. 200/- per day. The parties are residence of Metropolitan City of Chennai. Therefore, the amount which has been awarded by the Court cannot be said to suffer from any of the aforesaid vices. Furthermore, the fact that the wife is earning does not mean she is disentitled to receive maintenance. In terms of Section 36 of the Indian Divorce Act, the wife is entitled to seek maintenance not only for herself but also for the child. The child is around eight years. Her financial demand will obviously be more than the paltry sum of Rs. 6, 000/- that has been fixed by the learned Trial Judge. It is not as if that the amount that is paid to the wife is going to be exclusively used by her. There is no dispute that the mother has the custody of the child and is attending to her day to day needs. Finding that the amount is not excessive, I am not inclined to interfere. The Civil Revision Petition is dismissed. There shall be no order as to costs. Consequently, the connected miscellaneous petition is dismissed.

Chandru vs State Of Karnataka on 4 January, 2024 IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 4TH DAY OF JANUARY, 2024 The appellant was the sole accused in Sessions Case No. 40 of 2016 before the trial Court. For the purpose of convenience, the parties are referred to henceforth according to their ranks before the trial Court. The accused was tried in Sessions Case No. 40 of 2016 for the offences punishable under Section 376 of the IPC and Section 6 of the POCSO Act on the basis of the charge-sheet filed by Kolar Town Police in Crime No. 221 of 2015 of their Police Station. The case of the prosecution in brief is as follows: PW1 is the mother of PW2-victim. She was married to one Venkatesh of Channasandra, Bengaluru, and out of the said wedlock, the couple had two daughters i. e. the victim and CW3. Since three years prior to 17-12-2015, the accused was in illicit relationship with PW1. About two years back, he enticed PW1 with her two daughters and started residing with them at Karanjikatte of Kolar Town taking a house on rent from PW5-Papanna. PW2 and CW3 were aged about 14 and 8 years, respectively. They were studying in Kamala Mahadi Higher Primary School, Kolar. The accused was doing Masonry work and PW1 was working as Domestic help. The accused was addicted to alcohol. Due to his addiction to alcohol, PW1 was not giving him physical proximity. To appease his lust, the accused eyed on PW2. For that purpose, one day in March, 2015 at 1: 00 p. m. , he brought PW2 back home from the school representing that PW1 was unwell and committed penetrative sexual assault on her in the house and threatened her that if she reveals the incident to PW1 or CW3, he will kill all of them. Thereafter, he kept committing penetrative sexual assault frequently. Ultimately, PW2 became pregnant. When she became indisposable due to such conception, PW1 took her to SNR Hospital, Kolar. In the said hospital, PW11-Dr. Shanthi examined PW2 and found her nine months pregnant. On issuance of the MLC intimation, PW3-District Child Protection Officer visited the hospital and their enquiry revealed that the accused sexually abused PW2 and that she was eight months pregnant. PW13-Sunitha Devi, Assistant Sub-Inspector of Police, visited the hospital and recorded the statement of the victim as per Ex. P2 and submitted the report to PW14. Based on Ex. P2, PW14-Sub-Inspector of Police of Kolar Town Police Station registered an F. I. R. against the accused as per Ex. P14 and handed over the case for further investigation to PW15-Shivaprasad. During investigation, PW15 arrested the accused and referred the victim to radiological examination to assess her age. Since she was pregnant, she could not be subjected to ossification test. Pending investigation, the victim delivered a female child on 11-1-2016. The trial Court on hearing the accused, framed the charges against him for the offences punishable under Section 376 of the IPC and Section 6 of the POCSO Act. As the accused denied the charges and claimed to be tried, the trial was conducted. In support of the case of the prosecution, PW1 to PW15 were examined and Exs. P1 to P15 were marked. The trial Court examined the accused under Section 313 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 with reference to incriminating evidence. The accused did not lead any defence evidence. The trial Court on hearing the parties, relying upon the evidence of PWs. 1, 2 and other official witnesses held that the charges against the accused are proved beyond reasonable doubt. By the impugned judgment and order, the trial Court convicted the appellant for the offences punishable under Section 376 of the IPC and Section 6 of the POCSO Act. Further, the trial Court sentenced him to different terms of sentence and imprisonment as per the table below: Convicted for Sl. Sentence Fine in Default the Offence under Section 1. 6 of the Life 10, 000/- Imprisonment POCSO Act Imprisonment of 1 month 2. 376 of the IPC Simple 5, 000/- Imprisonment imprisonment of 10 years The appellant has challenged the said order in the above appeal.

IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT THE HONOURABLE DR. JUSTICE KAUSER EDAPPAGATH Friday, the 18th day of February 2022 / 29th Magha, 1943 CRL. M. APPL. NO. 1/2020 IN CRL. A NO. 437 OF 2020 SC 102/2015 OF THE ADDITIONAL SESSIONS COURT - I, KOTTAYAM PETITIONER/APPELLANT: THOMAS @ JOSHY, AGED 37 YEARS, S/O. THOMMY, PUTHENPURAKAL VEEDU, NAKRAL, PUTHUVAL BHAGOM, PERUNNA WEST KARA, CHANGANACHERRY. RESPONDENT/RESPONDENT: STATE OF KERALA, REP. BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM 682 031. Application praying that in the circumstances stated therein the High Court be pleased to suspend the execution of the sentence imposed on the appellant in the judgment dated 18. 03. 2020 in S. C. No. 102/2015 of the Additional Sessions Judge-I, Kottayam pending disposal of this appeal and to grant bail to the petitioner/appellant. This Application coming on for orders upon perusing the application and upon hearing the arguments of GEORGE SEBASTIAN, SRI. BOBBY JOHN, Advocates for the petitioner and of the PUBLIC PROSECUTOR for the respondent, the court passed the following: ORDER Crl. M. A. No. 1/2020 This is an application filed to suspend the execution of sentence. The petitioner/appellant has been convicted for the offences punishable under Sections 377, 376(2)(f), 376(2)(i), 376(2)(j) and 376(2)(k), 376(2)(n) of IPC and Section 6 read with 5(l), 5(m) and 5(n) of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (POCSO Act for short). He is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for 10 years and to pay a fine of Rs. 30, 000/- for the offence punishable under Section 6 of the POCSO Act. Separate punishment is not ordered under Sections 376(2)(f), 376(2)(i), 376(2)(j) and 376(2)(k) and 376(2)(n) of IPC as provided in Section 42 of the POCSO Act. I have heard Sri. . George Sebastian, the learned counsel for the petitioner and Smt. Sheeba Thomas, the learned Public Prosecutor. The victim is none other than the daughter of the petitioner. The incident had taken place when the victim was only 10 months of age. The petitioner who should have been the protector of the child as a father, turned out to be a demon and sexually abused his own child. I went through the relevant portion of the judgment. Paragraph 12 of the judgment deals with the evidence of PW1 who is the mother of the victim and wife of the petitioner. She specifically deposed that the incident had taken place on 24/1/2015 and 25/1/2015. According to her, she saw traces of semen on the hip and corner of the mouth of the victim, who was only 7 months age at that time. She further deposed that on seeing this, she searched the accused and he was found lying naked on the bed. She further deposed that on the next day she witnessed the accused putting his sexual organ into the mouth of the victim and inserting his finger into her vagina. PW3 is the doctor. Ext. P2 is the wound certificate. Paragraph 24 of the judgment deals with the evidence of the doctor. The doctor deposed that she examined the victim and issued Ext. P2 wound certificate. According to the doctor, PW1 narrated the history of rape, oral sex and putting fingers into the vagina of the victim by the petitioner. The doctor further deposed that on examination, the hymen of the victim was found absent. I am not commenting on these evidence at this stage for the reason that it has to be considered at the time of final hearing. However, the fact remains that the court below believed the testimony of PW1 as well as PW3. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that there is seven days' delay in registering the FIR and no independent witnesses were examined. The learned counsel further submitted that there was marital dispute between the petitioner and PW1 and hence the evidence of PW1 could not have been relied on. I cannot rely on those submissions as such. Those contentions can be raised at the time of final hearing. Considering the heinous nature of crime committed by the petitioner, I am of the view that his sentence cannot be suspended. Accordingly, this application is dismissed.

JUSTICE ALEXANDER THOMAS FRIDAY, THE 15TH DAY OF MARCH 2019 / 24TH PHALGUNA, 1940 Bail Appl. .No. 1715 of 2019 AGAINST THE ORDER/JUDGMENT IN CRMC 321/2019 of DISTRICT COURT & SESSIONS COURT, ERNAKULAM CRIME NO. 31/2019 OF Koothattukulam Police Station, ErnakulamPETITIONER/S: REJI. P, AGED 42 YEARS S/O ITHAPIRI, PUNNEDATH MOOLAYALIL, OLIYAPURAM P. O. OLIYAPURAM, ERNAKULAM, HAVING PERMANENT ADDRESS AT PUNNEDATHUMOOLAYALIL, NERIYAMPARA, KATTAPPANA, IDUKKI. BY ADVS. SRI. SAIGI JACOB PALATTY, PUBLIC PROSECUTOR THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 15. 03. 2019, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: ORDER The petitioner has been arrayed as the sole accused in Crime No. 31/2019 of Koothattukulam Police Station, which has been registered for offences punishable under Sec. 3 r/w Secs. 4 & 9(m) of the POCSO Act. The defacto complainant is involved in the crime is the wife of the petitioner and the alleged victim is the elder minor daughter of the petitioner aged 8 years. The brief of the prosecution allegation is that the when the above persons are living together with their children (2 daughters), the petitioner has sexually abused the elder daughter from the year 2018 and thus committed the abovesaid offence. The petitioner would allege that the petitioner's wife is suffering from Paranioa and she is under treatment of Dr. Suresh Nainan, Psychiatrist, Karithas Hospital, Kottayam, and she was advised to take medicines continuously. Even going by Anx-A1 complaint, which is made to the Taluk Legal Service Committee would disclose that her allegations are raised on the basis of suspicion that the petitioner has sexually abused the elder daughter in her absence. The petitioner would point out that minor victim was under treatment for cyst/constipation and she was under treatment for the same in MOSC Medical Mission Hospital, Kolencherry and requisite ointment was prescribed for medication for the above medical condition as evident from Anx-A2 treatment record and that the petitioner has rectally administered the said ointment to the child only for the purpose of medication as prescribed by the Doctor and that even the version given in Anx-A1 would be indicative of the abovesaid aspects. Further it is submitted that the wife is now residing separately and both the daughter are residing with the wife and the petitioner is residing alone. Taking note of the facts and circumstances disclosed in this petition, this Court is of the view that the plea for pre-arrest bail could be granted subject to necessary conditions. Accordingly, it is ordered that in the event of the petitioner being arrested in connection with Crime No. 31/2019 of Koothattukulam Police Station, then he shall be released on bail on his executing a bond for Rs. 40, 000/- (Rupees Fourty Thousand only) and on furnishing two solvent sureties for the like sum each to the satisfaction of the Investigating Officer concerned. Further it is also ordered that it will be subject to following conditions: (i) The petitioner shall not involve in any criminal offences of similar nature. (ii) The petitioner shall fully co-operate with the investigation. (iii) The petitioner shall report before the Investigating Officer as and when required in that connection. (iv) The petitioner shall not influence witness or shall not tamper or attempt to tamper evidence in any manner, whatsoever. If there is any violation of the abovesaid conditions by the petitioner, then the jurisdictional court concerned stand hereby empowered, to consider the plea for cancellation of bail at the appropriate time. With these observations and directions, the above Bail Application stands allowed.

[case 124]
Pocso Act vs In Re: Narayan Halder on 27 March, 2023. In Re: An application for bail under Section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure filed on 13. 02. 2023 in connection with Tehatta Police Station Case No. 451 of 2022 dated 04. 06. 2022 under Section 376 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of the POCSO Act. Report is placed on record. From the report it appears a panel of three special Public Prosecutors have been notified for the Special Court under POCSO Act at Tehatta sub-division. In view of the aforesaid development, we expect that the trial will proceed with utmost expedition. We have considered the materials on record. There are materials implicating the petitioner in the offence of penetrative sexual assault. Under such circumstances, we are not inclined to grant bail to the petitioner at this stage. The application for bail is thus rejected. Trial court is directed to consider the issue of framing of charge at the earliest and in the event charge is framed, to take the proceeding to its logical conclusion keeping in mind the mandate under Section 35(2) of the POCSO Act. In a number of cases it has come to our notice that adequate number of special Public Prosecutors have not been appointed to the POCSO courts. Section 32 of the POCSO Act requires appointment of special Public Prosecutors who have adequate experience and sensitivity to handle cases of gender violence against minors in POCSO courts. Appointment of competent and efficient Public Prosecutors is a sine qua non for protection of victim interest and effective administration of justice in POCSO cases. In Alarming Rise in the Number of Reported Child Rape Incidents, In re1 the Apex Court held as follows: "8. There is a salutary reason for appointing Public Prosecutors exclusively for POCSO cases. Public Prosecutors must be trained to deal with child victims and child witnesses. They need to understand the psychology of children. They need to empathise with children. They need to know how to bring out the truth from children who are victims of sexual abuse and have to undergo the trauma again while recounting the traumatic experience. 9. The job assigned to the Public Prosecutor for POCSO cases is a very onerous one which must be carried out with great care and sensitivity. Therefore, not only is there a need to have exclusive Public Prosecutors but there is also a need to develop a training programme where these Special Public Prosecutors should be trained to deal with issues which will arise in their courts. These issues may not be confined to legal issues which otherwise Public Prosecutors may be trained to deal with. The issues may be psychological, health and other related issues. 10. Keeping in view these factors, we direct all the States who are present before us to take steps to appoint exclusive Public Prosecutors in all the courts which have been set up exclusively for POCSO cases. It may be relevant to note the expression 'Special Public Prosecutor' for every 'special court' does not bar the Government from notifying more than one special Public Prosecutor for a court in view of heavy pendency of cases in the file of each court. Reference in this regard may be made to Section 13(2) of General Clauses Act which reads as follows: "13. Gender and number. - *** *** *** (1) *** *** *** (2) words in the singular shall include the plural, and vice versa. " Paucity of adequate number of trained Special Prosecutors in POCSO courts requires to be immediately addressed. Legal Remembrancer is directed to submit report with regard to the following: (1) Number of Special Public Prosecutors appointed in each of the POCSO courts in the State of West Bengal; (2) Pendency of cases in each of the courts; (3) Breakup of cases in every court: (i) Where case is pending investigation; (ii) Where charge sheet has been filed; (iii) Where charges have been framed and/or trial has commenced. Let the matter appear on 31. 03. 2023. Report be filed on the adjourned day.

HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD. Neutral Citation No. - 2025: AHC: 546. Court No. - 65. Case: - CRIMINAL MISC. BAIL APPLICATION No. - 32091 of 2024. Applicant: - Deepak. Kerala High Court Liju vs State Of Kerala on 3 April, 2019 Bail Appl. .No. 124 of 2019 CRIME NO. 1641/2018 OF Enathu Police Station, Pathanamthitta PETITIONER/S: LIJU, AGED 21 YEARS S/O RAJU, THENGAMOM MURI, THENGAMAM, ADOOR, PATHANAMTHITTA-691523. BY ADV. SRI. K. SHAJ RESPONDENT/S: 1 STATE OF KERALA, REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM-682031. 2 SUB INSPECTOR OF POLICE, ENATHU POLICE STATION, PATHANAMTHITTA DISTRICT, KERALA-691523. OTHER PRESENT: SRI. C. N. PRABHAKARAN-SENIOR PUBLIC PROSECUTOR THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 03. 04. 2019, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: Bail Appl. .No. 124 of 2019 ORDER Apprehending his arrest, petitioner seeks anticipatory bail under Sec. 438 of Cr. P. C. He is alleged to have committed offences punishable under Sec. 354 of IPC, Sec. 8 of the PoCSO Act and Sec. 75 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act ( JJ Act for short). The police of Enathu police station in Pathanamthitta district has registered a case as crime no. 1641/2018 against the petitioner. Prosecution case goes as follows: It all happened at around 1 p. m on 21. 12. 2018. The victim girl aged 16 years was returning from her school along with her friends. When they reached Karimpara junction, the petitioner who came on a scooter abused the girl. He caught her hand. When she objected, he slapped on her face twice. Heard Sri. K. Shaj, the learned counsel for the petitioner and Sri. C. N. Prabhakaran, the learned senior public prosecutor. It seems that Sec. 75 of the JJ Act is out of question. Sec. 75 provides punishment for cruelty to child. In order to attract Sec. 75, the offender must be a person who is in actual charge of or control over the victim child. The prosecution has no such case. The learned counsel for the petitioner submits that catching the hand or slapping on the face do not attract the penal provisions in Sec. 354 of IPC. It is also alleged that Sec. 8 of the PoCSO Act is not attracted inasmuch as the acts alleged against the petitioner do not fall within the ambit of the definition of sexual assault contained in Sec. 7 of the PoCSO Act. It is also the submission of the learned counsel that there is no allegation against the petitioner that he touched any parts of the body of the girl specifically referred to in Sec. 7. It is also his submission that catching the hand and slapping on the face cannot be termed as an act with sexual intent. It is too premature to have a positive or negative finding on the arguments of the learned counsel. But his arguments cannot be totally ignored or brushed aside. I do not consider the present case to be one where custodial interrogation of the petitioner is an absolute must for an effective investigation of the case. Considering all these matters, I am inclined to grant him bail. The application is allowed. If arrested in connection with crime no. 1641/2018 of Enathu police station, the petitioner shall be released on bail, after interrogation, on his executing a bond for Rs 75, 000/- (seventy five thousand only) with two solvent sureties each for the like sum to the satisfaction of the investigating officer. The petitioner shall co-operate with the investigation. He shall make himself available for interrogation if so required by the investigating officer. He shall report to the investigating officer between 10 am and 11 am on every Saturday for a period of three months or till the filing of the final report, whichever is earlier. The petitioner shall not intimidate or try to influence witnesses. He shall not destroy or tamper with evidence. The court having jurisdiction is hereby empowered to cancel the bail in accordance with law if any of the conditions mentioned above is violated. If the petitioner surrenders before the court concerned, this order will cease to have effect and the said court will pass appropriate orders as if this order has not been passed. A. M. BABU 03/04/19 JUDGE
