Babu vs State Of Kerala on 29 November, 2017. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM. PRESENT: THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V. WEDNESDAY, THE 29TH DAY OF NOVEMBER 2017/8TH AGRAHAYANA, 1939. Bail Appl. .No. 8184 of 2017. PETITIONER(S)/ACCUSED: BABU, AGED 52 YEARS, S/O. THAMPI, CHEMBAKASSERRY HOUSE, PULAYETTIKKARA, ARAYANKAVU, ERNAKULAM DISTRICT. RESPONDENT(S)/COMPLAINANT: STATE OF KERALA. THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 29-11-2017, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: ORDER 1. This application is filed under Section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. 2. The petitioner herein is the sole accused in Crime No. 1336 of 2017 of Mulanthuruthy police station, registered alleging offence punishable under Sections 450, 376(2), (i), (n), 506 IPC and Section 3(d) r/w Sec. 4, 5(1), (m), (n), r/w Sec. 6 of POCSO Act, 2012. 3. The victim in the instant case is a minor girl aged 13 years. Her mother is no more and her father has remarried and is living elsewhere. She is now admitted in the Don Bosco Snehabhavan at Ernakulam. It appears that when she appeared moody and showed behavioral problems, a Counselor interacted with her. The disclosure she made is heart rending. The Counselor informed the child line authorities who in turn intimated the police. It is in the above fact scenario that the crime was registered. 4. According to the victim child, who is now studying in the 8th standard, the petitioner is a near relative and she calls him 'valiachan'. According to her, when she was in the 2nd standard, the petitioner started sexually assaulting her. He used to touch her private parts and used to perform oral sex on her. She was made to touch his genitals as well. On various occasions thereafter, the petitioner repeated the same acts. As she had no one to disclose the sexual abuse that she was being subjected to and as she was confused, she did not reveal this fact to anyone. In the month of September, 2017, the petitioner repeated the same acts. This tormented her and she became moody and restless which fact was noticed by the Counselor. Pursuant to the registration of the crime, the petitioner was arrested on 28. 10. 2017 and has been in custody since then. 5. The learned counsel appearing for the petitioner submits that the petitioner is a 52 year old man and is undergoing treatment for cardiac ailments at the Kottayam Medical College Hospital for the past six months. It is submitted that there are serious inconsistencies in the statement given by the victim child. There was no way that the petitioner could have sexually assaulted the minor child is the submission. 6. The learned Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer and has made available the case diary for perusal. 7. I have gone through the same and It tells a very sad story. The victim child is a destitute with no one to look after and has been housed in various institutions since a very young age. The petitioner, by abusing his status as a near relative, has sexually assaulted the child. The investigation is still in the early stages and I find no reason to release the petitioner on bail. This application is dismissed.

[case 162]
Kerala High Court, Manikandan vs State Of Kerala on 14 July, 2020. The petitioner is the sole accused in SC No. 585 of 2019 pending before the First Additional Sessions Court (Special Court), Palakkad. The case against the petitioner originated on registration of Crime No. 466 of 2018 at the Pudunagaram Police Station for offences under Section 376 (2) (n) of IPC and Sections 6 r/w 5 (j)(ii)(I) of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. The allegation which led to the registration of the Crime is that the petitioner and the victim had eloped on 18. 05. 2018, when the victim was a minor and that, after marrying the victim, the petitioner had subjected her to penetrating sexual assault and had thereby committed the offences. The aunt of the victim, who had filed the complaint leading to registration of the crime has filed an affidavit stating that the victim, whose parents were no more, had eloped with the petitioner and had married him. A legal marriage was conducted on 08. 12. 2019, after the victim became major and the marriage was registered on 25. 02. 2020. One girl child is born out of the relationship between the petitioner and the victim and that the petitioner and the victim are living as husband and wife. The victim has also filed an affidavit reiterating the above facts and further stating that she has no subsisting grievance against the petitioner. It is stated that continuance of the harmonious marital life of the petitioner and the victim require quashing of the criminal proceedings. I heard the learned Public Prosecutor, who, on instructions, submits that the petitioner has no criminal antecedent and that the affidavit seeking quashing of the proceedings was submitted on her own volition. It is submitted that, though the sexual relationship of the petitioner with the victim was immediately prior to the victim becoming major, the fact that the petitioner had married the victim after she became a major and that both of them are leading a harmonious married life, can be taken into consideration. I take note of the fact that both the petitioner and the victim are rustic villagers and that after eloping from their parental homes, had married and lived as husband and wife. Immediately after the victim attaining 18 years, their marriage was registered and they are leading a harmonious marital life. Moreover, in view of the settlement arrived at between the parties, there is no possibility of the criminal proceedings ending in conviction. As such, continuance of the proceeding will amount to an abuse of process of court and hence, in view of the legal position set out by the Hon'ble Supreme Court in Madan Mohan Abbot v. State of Punjab, Gian Singh v. State of Punjab and another, there is no impediment in granting the relief. In the aforementioned peculiar circumstances, I deem it appropriate to allow the Crl. M. C, even though the offences alleged are under Section 376 (2) (n) of IPC and Section 6 r/w 5 (j)(ii)(I) of the POCSO Act. In the result, Crl. M. C is allowed; the proceedings in SC No. 585 of 2019 pending before the First Additional Sessions Court (Special Court), Palakkad, is quashed.

IN THE HIGH COURT OF KERALA AT ERNAKULAM PRESENT: THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V FRIDAY, THE 16TH DAY OF MARCH 2018 / 25TH PHALGUNA, 1939 Bail Appl. .No. 779 of 2018 ------------------------------------------- CRIME NO. 42/2018 OF HOSDURG POLICE STATION, KASARGOD PETITIONER(S)/ACCUSED --------------------------- KANNAN @ KUNHIKANNAN AGED 65 YEARS, S/O. AMBADI, THIRTHAMKARA, KANHANGAD, HOSDURG, KASARAGOD DISTRICT. BY ADV. SRI. T. K. VIPINDAS RESPONDENT(S)/STATE: --------------------------- THE STATE OF KERALA REPRESENTED BY THE PUBLIC PROSECUTOR, HIGH COURT OF KERALA, ERNAKULAM-682031, REPRESENTING S. H. O. HOSDURG POLICE STATION, KASARGOD DISTRICT. R BY PUBLIC PROSECUTOR SRI. AJITH MURALI THIS BAIL APPLICATION HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON 16-03-2018, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING: ORDER 1. This petition seeking an order of pre-arrest bail is preferred by the accused in Crime No. 42 of 2018 of the Hosdurg Police Station, registered under Sections 366 and 377 of the Indian Penal Code and under Sections 5(I), (m) and 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO'). 2. The aforesaid crime was registered on the basis of information furnished by a minor girl who was studying in the IV Standard. She used to travel to the School in the autorickshaw of the petitioner herein. The child in her statement has stated in clear and unambiguous terms that while she was in the III and IV standard, the petitioner used to sexually assault her on multiple occasions. It is further alleged that on 11. 1. 2018, the victim was taken to the residential home of the petitioner herein and after removing her clothes, she was subjected to gross sexual abuse. 3. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the allegations are without basis. According to the learned counsel, even if the allegations are admitted as such, offence under Section 5 r/w. Section 6 of the Act will not be made out. It is further alleged that other crimes have also been registered at the instance of the minor child which would render her case against the petitioner suspect. 4. The learned Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer. It is submitted that the medical examination report of the victim reveal that she was subjected to sexual abuse. 5. I have considered the submissions advanced. 6. Having regard to facts and circumstances, the contention of the learned counsel that the petitioner is totally innocent cannot be countenanced. The medical certificate of the injured sufficiently corroborates the case of the prosecution. In that view of the matter, it does not appear to me that this Court will be justified in arming the petitioner with an order of pre-arrest bail. 7. However, the learned counsel prays for a direction that the petitioner be allowed to surrender before the jurisdictional court. I do not see any need for issuance of any such directions. The petitioner shall surrender as expeditiously as possible and if an application for bail is filed, the same shall be considered and orders shall be passed on its merits. This petition will stand dismissed.

[case 165]
Gurmeet Singh @ Gurmit Singh vs State Of Punjab on 24 September, 2018 The petition under Section 438 Cr. P. C. for pre-arrest bail has been filed by the petitioner - Gurmeet Singh @ Gurmit Singh, an accused in FIR No. 91 dated 12. 8. 2018, under Sections 354, 506 IPC and Section 12 of POCSO Act, registered at Police Station Talwandi Chaudrian, District Kapurthala. Briefly stated, the facts of the case, as per the prosecution story, are that on 12. 8. 2018, the victim aged about 12 years, niece of complainant Mangal Singh, resident of Khijarpur, Police Station Talwandi Chaudrian, District Kapurthala had gone to the fields to pluck chillies, then at about 8: 30 a. m. , Gurmit Singh (present petitioner) caught her from her arm, hugged her, kissed her on face and started doing obscene acts with her; the victim freed herself from his clutches and ran away; the accused had threatened to kill the victim in case she disclosed the incident to anybody. However, on return home, the victim informed her uncle the complainant in that regard, who summoned Gurmeet Singh @ Gurmit Singh to his house and confronted him regarding the incident, then Gurmeet Singh @ Gurmit Singh started giving threats to them. The complainant accordingly reported the matter to the police. Formal FIR was registered. Apprehending his arrest in this case, the petitioner had approached the Court of Sessions seeking grant of pre-arrest bail by filing an application, however, his such request was declined by learned Additional Sessions Judge, Kapurthala vide order dated 24. 8. 2018. As such, the petitioner has approached this Court asking for the similar relief. Notice of the petition was given to respondent - State, which put in appearance through counsel. I have heard learned counsel for the parties besides going through the records. Pre arrest bail is a discretionary relief and is to be granted in exceptional cases and not in routine. It is meant to save the innocent persons from harassment and inconvenience and not to screen the culprits from custodial interrogation. In this case, there are serious allegations against the petitioner/accused of indulging in obscene acts with a minor girl and outraging her modesty. I find that the incidents of child abuse and molestation of young girls are increasing day by day. It is not safe for the womenfolk to venture out of their houses even. A serious law and order problem in that regard is fast emerging. In case precautionary measures are not taken at the initial stage, the things may get out of hand and would be very difficult to control. The persons harassing molesting and sexually abusing young girls need to be dealt with iron hand and no leniency can be shown to them. Custodial interrogation of the petitioner is definitely required for complete and effective investigation. In case custodial interrogation of the petitioner is denied to the investigating agency that would leave many loose ends and gaps in the investigation affecting the investigation being carried out adversely which is not called for. Thus finding no merit in the petition, the same stands dismissed.

[case 166]
This Criminal Original Petition has been filed to quash the proceedings in Spl. S. C. No. 98 of 2024 on the file of the learned Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Theni. The case of the prosecution is that the first petitioner had married the victim girls, who was not attained her majority and the first petitioner also had sexual intercourse with her. Hence, the case has been registered. The learned counsel appearing for the petitioners, learned Counsel appearing for the first respondent and the learned counsel appearing for the second and third respondent submitted that now, the petitioners and the second respondent/defacto complainant have settled the dispute between themselves amicably and the second respondent/defacto complainant is not willing to proceed further with the criminal case. Today, when the matter was taken up for hearing a joint Memo of Compromise was filed before this Court signed by the petitioners and the second respondent and their respective counsels. The petitioners and the second respondent/defacto complainant and the victim girl present before this Court, identified by Mr. P. Chellapandian, SSI, Jeyamangalam Police Station, Theni District, as well as by the learned Counsel appearing for the parties. This Court enquired both the parties, satisfied that the parties have come to an amicable settlement between themselves on their own voluntarily without any compulsion. The third respondent/victim had stated that both the petitioner and the third respondent/victim got married. They are living happily in a separate house and she did not want to pursue with the case. She has also filed an affidavit. The relevant portion of the affidavit reads as follows: 'I respectfully submit that now I realized that the petitioners have not committed any offence as stated above. Further the petitioners have not conducted my marriage and there was no harassment on the part of the first petitioner. ' The FIR and charge sheet were laid by the officials for statistical purpose and now I am living with the first petitioner happily and now the matter has been settled amicable, on intervention of both village and community elders. Since the matter has been settled amicable, I have no objection for quashing the impugned charge sheet against the petitioner in Spl. S. C. 98 of 2024 on the file of the learned Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Theni. The case has been registered for offences under Sections 9, 10 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006 and 4(1) r/w. 17 and 18 of POCSO Act, 2012. It is settled law that the High Court has inherent power under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure to quash the criminal proceedings even for the offences which are not compoundable under Section 320 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, where the parties have settled their dispute between themselves. However, while quashing the criminal proceedings, based on the settlement arrived at between the parties, the High Court should act with caution and the power should be exercised sparingly only in order to secure the ends of justice and also to prevent abuse of process of any Court.

Respondents (RR 5 to 8 were impleaded as per the Orders of this Court dated 28. 11. 2016, 27. 03. 2017, 10. 04. 2017 and 11. 04. 2017 respectively) Prayer: - Petition filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India for issuance of a Writ of Habeas Corpus to the respondents to produce the body of the petitioner's daughter namely Santhiya aged about 17 years, who is a student of 12th standard studying in ARC Higher Secondary School, Chittarkadu, Mayiladuthurai, Nagapattinam district before this Court and set her at liberty. For Petitioner: Mr. D. Veerasekaran For Respondents: Mr. R. Muthukumaraswamy, A. G. 1 to 3, 7 and 8 Asst. by Mr. VMR. Rajendran, APP For Respondent 6: Mr. Su. Srinivasan, Asst. S. G. I. O R D E R (Judgment of the Court was delivered by S. Nagamuthu, J. ) The Cinema is a very powerful medium which can reach out to the people at any part of the globe in lightning speed. It has the potency to influence the minds of the people especially the people of tender age. Therefore, it became all the more necessary for the Government to ensure that the cinema films which are suitable for public exhibition alone are permitted to be exhibited. 2. With the said object, the Cinematograph Act, 1952 was brought into force by the Central Government with effect from 21. 03. 1952. Under the Act, the Board of Film Censors consisting of persons of eminence and responsibility was constituted for the purpose of examining and certifying films as suitable for unrestricted public exhibition or for exhibition restricted to adults. As per Section 4 of the Act, if the Board, after examination, considers that a film is suitable for unrestricted public exhibition or that, although not suitable for such exhibition it is suitable for public exhibition restricted to adults, it shall grant to the person applying for a certificate in respect of the film a 'U' certificate in the former case and an 'A' certificate in the latter case, and shall, in either case, cause the film to be so marked in the prescribed manner, and any such certificate shall, save as hereinafter provided, be valid throughout India [. .. ].

At that time, the accused came and caught hold of the hand of the victim K and also started harassing her and even stated that he loved her. When the victim K shouted and informed the complainant about the activities of the accused, he (accused) threatened them with life. On the basis of the Rukka, the instant FIR bearing No. 538/16 was registered. The victim was medically examined at SRHC Hospital, where she refused to get her internal medical examination done. Accused was also got medically examined. On the pointing out of the complainant, the site plan of the spot of occurrence was prepared, and accused was arrested vide his arrest memo and personal search memo, statements of the witnesses were recorded u/s 161 CrPC. Statement of the victim K was also got recorded u/s 164 CrPC, and after the conclusion of the investigation, chargesheet was filed in the court.

Mrs. Praveena vs The Child Welfare Committee (North) on 5 April, 2024. W. P. No. 4843 of 2024. IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 05. 04. 2024. CORAM THE HONOURABLE MR. JUSTICE S. M. SUBRAMANIAM. Mrs. Praveena. .. Petitioner. Vs. 1. The Child Welfare Committee (North), Through its President / Chairman, 2. Mariyakaya Girls Home. .. Respondents. Prayer: Writ Petition filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India for issuance of a Writ of Mandamus, directing the 1st respondent to consider petitioner representation dated 16. 02. 2024 and to direct the 1st respondent to pass an order to give custody of the petitioner's minor adopted child namely A. Prithika aged about 11 years to petitioner. The petitioner states that she has adopted the minor child from one Mrs. M. Preethi, who had affairs with another person. The child was adopted in the year 2012 and thereafter, it is brought up by the petitioner and another person. The minor girl is aged about 11 years and informed the School Teacher that she had been abused by the said Boopalan in the house. The School Teacher provided information to the Child Help Line, who in turn visited the child and ascertained the facts. Thereafter, took the child to the Government Home. The 1st respondent states that the child now is in safe custody in Government Home Sevasadhan. She is attending the school regularly and living happily. The learned counsel for the petitioner would submit that the child was adopted in the year 2012 and the petitioner is looking after her. Therefore, she is entitled for custody. The Child Welfare Committee-North Zone, Chennai filed a report regarding the factual aspects. In view of the fact that the child informed about her bitter experience in the house of the petitioner and abused by the said Boopalan, the child was referred to the Psychologist / Government Children Home, who in turn submitted a psychological report, which read as under. .. Considering all facts and circumstances, this Court is of the considered opinion that the petitioner is not entitled for custody. More so, the petitioner is having living-in relationship with the said Boopalan. The petitioner is a beautician and considering the nature of relationship between the petitioner and the said Boopalan, it is not advisable to send the child along with the petitioner, which would affect the child psychologically. The child must be allowed to continue her studies by staying at Sevasadhan under the custody of the Government authorities. Further, it is brought to the notice of this Court that the information received by the Child Help Line was informed to the Police for appropriate action. But the Police has not initiated appropriate action nor registered a case. .. . With these observations, the Writ Petition stands dismissed. No costs. Consequently, connected Miscellaneous Petition is closed.

Mahalakshmi vs The District Collector on 19 January, 2021. W. P. (MD)NO. 659 OF 2021. BEFORE THE MADURAI BENCH OF MADRAS HIGH COURT. Prayer: Writ petition is filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, to issue a Writ of Mandamus, to direct the third respondent to terminate the pregnancy of the petitioner's minor niece, namely J, D/o. Late Kaaliappan, aged about 15 within the time frame fixed by this Court. The writ petitioner is the defacto complainant in Crime No. 663 of 2020 registered on the file of the Rajapalayam South police station. The petitioner brought to the notice of the fourth respondent vide complaint dated 02. 11. 2020 that her niece Minor J was missing from the previous day. Steps were taken by the investigation officer to secure the minor. At this stage on 27. 11. 2020, the writ petitioner appeared before the fourth respondent along with the kidnapped minor. It was revealed that J was on friendly terms with one Muthukumar. Muthukumar came to be arrested in some case. Without being aware of the same, J called on his mobile phone. His friend Sundar @ Sundareswaran attended the call. He enticed J and kidnapped her. Sundar had physical intimacy with J several times from 02. 11. 2020 to 24. 11. 2020. After coming to know of her whereabouts, the petitioner brought her back and produced her before the police. J's father Kaliyappan had died in the year 2012 and her mother is mentally unstable. J was with her aunt and uncle but she was not willing to go with them. Therefore, she was admitted to a social welfare home. Since J had become pregnant, the petitioner wants this Court to direct the official respondents to terminate her pregnancy. Considering the urgency of the matter, this Court ordered notice to the respondents. Dr. R. Rajalakshmi, Assistant Surgeon, Virudhunagar Government Medical College and Hospital, after examining the minor girl, categorically opined that her gestational age is about 10-11 weeks and that continuing the pregnancy may endanger her physical and mental health. In her report, she cited the risks involved in continuing pregnancy and called upon this Court to permit termination of pregnancy on medical grounds. The report filed by the police reveals that Sundar is involved in more than 10 cases. The law of the subject is set out in Section 3 of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 which describes the conditions under which a pregnancy can be terminated. In the present case, the minor's father died a long time back. Her mother is mentally unsound. Her uncle Veluchamy informed the Court that he wants the pregnancy to be terminated. The minor girl initially expressed unwillingness to terminate the pregnancy, stating she wanted to continue with it. However, she later changed her mind, stating she agreed to the termination. The Court directed the termination of the pregnancy. ..

The PW1 and the appellant were living separated for the last two years and Nithya (PW1) had left her girl child aged 3 years and 9 months with her parents living in Coimbatore, as she was employed in Bangalore. The victim child was unwell on 07. 10. 2015 and since PW1 was in Bangalore and could not make it, she had requested her husband (Accused) who was living in Coimbatore at Maniyakaranpalayam, Ganapathy, Coimbatore, to take the child to the hospital. The child was reportedly taken to Sri Ramakrishna Hospital and admitted for treatment and subsequently discharged on 08. 10. 2015. Further on 17. 10. 2015 and subsequent days the child was taken out by her father (Accused) at the behest of Nithya (PW1), during which time he committed penetrative sexual assault on his own child under the guise of checking her private part for any insect. The child had symptoms of restlessness, sleeplessness, frequent urination and itchy sensation in her private part and it was on 23. 10. 2015, that the child narrated her ordeal to Meenakshi (PW2) and to Shakunthala (PW4) who are the sister-in-law and mother of PW1 respectively. PW1 was informed immediately and she rushed to Coimbatore and took the child to the Sri Ramakrishna Hospital on 24. 10. 2015 at about 05. 00 PM. .. The damage caused to the psyche of the victim child is devastating and in many cases irreversible too. Sexual assault of a child that too by her own father is even more serious and deserves no leniency and it is a matter of shame that grounds are invented to save the appellant when the child's statements have pinned him down. This is just a tip of the iceberg and therefore such crimes deserve the maximum punishment with no leniency to be shown.

P. and another, reported in (2018) 3 SCC 22, larger mandate of Article 21 of the constitution of India, without expressing any opinion on the merit of the case, let the applicant- Akash, involved in Case Crime No. 448 of 2020, under Sections- 452, 354 (KH), 323, 506 I. P. C. and 7/8 POCSO Act, Police Station- Bhojpur, District Ghaziabad, be enlarged on bail on his executing a personal bond and two sureties each in the like amount to the satisfaction of the court concerned.
This bail order would be subject to the fulfilment of the following conditions:
1. The applicant shall not tamper with the prosecution evidence by intimidating/pressurizing the witnesses, during the investigation or trial.
2. The applicant shall cooperate in the trial sincerely without seeking any adjournment.
3. The applicant shall not indulge in any criminal activity or commission of any crime after being released on bail.
4. The applicant shall remain present before the trial court on each date fixed, either personally or through his counsel. In case of his absence, without sufficient cause, the trial court may proceed against him under Section 229-A of the Indian Penal Code;
5. If in the opinion of the trial court default of this condition is deliberate or without sufficient cause, then it shall be open for the trial court to treat such default as abuse of liberty of his bail and proceed against him in accordance with law.
6. In case the applicant has been enlarged on short term bail as per the order of committee constituted under the orders of Hon'ble Supreme Court, his bail shall be effective after the period of short term bail comes to an end.
In case of breach of any of the above conditions, it shall be a ground for cancellation of bail.

[case 185]
Anmol Vikas Sharma vs The State Of Karnataka, on 15 February, 2017
This Criminal Petition is filed under Section 439 of Cr. P. C. , seeking to allow this petition and enlarge the petitioner on bail in Special Case No. 49/2016 in connection with Crime No. 2/2016 registered in Torangallu Police Station, for the offences under Sections 376(2), 363 of IPC and Section 3, 4 of POCSO Act.
A person by name Ravindra Pal lodged a complaint stating that on 8. 12. 2015, her daughter aged 14 years, had been to the school i. e. , Jindal Adarsh School at Torangal, Sandur Taluk, Ballari District, but she did not return home. On enquiry, the complainant came to know that the petitioner had abducted the victim girl without the permission of the guardian. The said information was given by none other than the brother of the petitioner and he assured the complainant not to lodge any complaint so that he will bring back the said girl. During the course of the investigation, the police have recorded the statement of the victim girl on 09. 01. 2016 wherein she has stated that the petitioner has persuaded her on the ground that her father always used to abuse her, he would look after her with all love and affection and that they can live happily together. On that persuasion, the said girl aged 14 years was kidnapped by him. In her statement she has stated that the petitioner had sexual intercourse with her and also threatened her with dire consequences that, if she disclose the same to anybody, he would kill her. Thereafter, he took her to his village in Uttar Pradesh and they stayed there for 15 days and, thereafter, it appears she was brought back to her house. Looking to the above said facts and circumstances, whether there was any sexual intercourse or not has to be considered by the Court. However the statement of the victim girl made before the police is very much available which is consistent with the statement given under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. with regard to kidnapping the victim girl aged 14 years. I can understand, about the consent, if the girl is on the verge of attaining the age of majority who knows the pros and cons of the act. But, here, the said girl is aged 14 years. The persuasion is apparent on the face of the record. If such situations are allowed to be continued, there would be no safety or security to the girl child in our country. Under the above said circumstances, I am of the opinion that the petitioner, at this stage, is not entitled to be enlarged on bail. The petition deserves to be dismissed. However, since the accused is in judicial custody for more than one year, the Trial Court is hereby directed to expedite the trial and dispose of the matter within six months from the date of receipt of a copy of this order.

FIR No. 741/14: State vs Kapil Singh: PS Aman Vihar on 9 December, 2015. IN THE COURT OF VINOD YADAV: ADDL. SESSIONS JUDGE: (NORTHWEST)01: ROHINI DISTRICT COURTS: DELHI (Sessions Case No. 170/14) Unique ID case No. 02404R0276362014 State Vs. Kapil Singh FIR No. : 741/14 U/s: 354D IPC and 12 of POCSO Act P. S. : Aman Vihar State Vs. Kapil Singh S/o Sh. Satbir Singh R/o A38, Gali no. 4, Agar Nagar, Prem NagarIII, Delhi. Date of institution of case 02. 09. 2014 Date of arguments: 09. 12. 2015 Date of pronouncement of judgment:  09. 12. 2015 JUDGMENT (ORAL): The facts of the case as borne out from the record are that on 13. 07. 2014, on entrustment of DD no. 11, PW7 ASI Naresh Kumar reached at the spot, where complainant I (hereinafter referred to as prosecutrix), aged about 17 years and her mother met him and on coming to know from complainant's mother that it was a matter of chedchad with prosecutrix, he called L/Ct. Seema and NGO official Shashi Sharma and thereafter, they made inquiries from the prosecutrix and recorded her statement in the presence of her mother and in the said statement, the prosecutrix stated that accused Kapil, a resident of her locality, had been harassing her by following her repeatedly and earlier also, the matter was reported to the police and he was warned to be careful, but to no avail. B. I. The investigation of the C. B. I. culminated in a juvenile student of the same school, namely, Bholu [imaginary name given by the trial Court to conceal the identity of the juvenile student] [hereinafter referred to as the 'C. C. L. '] being the sole culprit behind murder of the minor deceased. Moreover, post conducting a through investigation, the C. B. I. also reached a conclusion that, in fact, Ashok Kumar was falsely framed in the murder and he is totally innocent. The further shocking revelations, as emerged from the investigation conducted by the C. B. I. are that, the Special Investigation Team [constituted by Commissioner of Police, Gurugram] not only created false documents, but, also pressurized the material witnesses to depose against Ashok Kumar. Consequently, a supplementary report was filed by the C. B. I. , thereby requesting to accord sanction under Section 197 Cr. P. C. for prosecution of some of the members of the Special Investigation Team [i. e. respondents No. 5 to 8]. This request was declined by the respondent No. 1 through rendering the impugned orders. Therefore, fetching grievance from the impugned orders, the C. B. I. has instituted the instant petition(s).

Ashok Ramchandra Shewale vs The State Of Maharashtra on 30 March, 2021. On 19th April 2019, a complaint was lodged at N. M. Joshi Marg Police Station by the mother of a child, aged 13 years 6 months, reporting about sexual assault upon her special child. It is alleged by her that on 19th April 2019, her another daughter informed that when the victim girl had gone to the toilet on the first floor of a building in a chawl, on 17th April 2019 at 9. 00 p. m, the Applicant - a resident of the same building latched the door from inside and sexually abused her. When the victim girl was taken into confidence, she narrated that after the applicant entered into the toilet and he latched the door, she was kissed by him on her lips and he also inappropriately touched her chest and her private part. He also threatened that if she informed about the said incident, she would have to meet with dire consequences. Thereafter, he opened the door of the toilet and left her. Based on the said narration, the complainant approached the police station on 19th April 2019 about the incident which took place on 17th April 2019 and lodged the FIR. The victim was forwarded for medical examination and was examined on 20th April 2019 after obtaining her consent. The history of the sexual assault narrated by the victim's mother is in sync with what she had disclosed to her mother about the applicant forcibly kissing her and fondling her breast. It is categorically recorded that she did not report any sexual intercourse. The child was medically examined and the opinion in column no. 11 recorded as multiple old healed hymenal tears. The statement of the victim girl was also recorded on 22nd April 2019. Based on the complaint, the FIR was registered under Section 354, 342, 506 read with Sections 4, 6, 8, 10 and 12 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (POCSO Act). When the charge-sheet is filed, Section 376 is also added. In absence of an allegation of 'rape' within the meaning of Section 375, prima facie the charge against the applicant under Section 376 cannot be justified. The medical examination of the victim girl which took place on the third day after the incident indicates 'multiple old healed hymenal tears'. However, neither the victim girl nor her mother had spoken about any penetration into her vagina or insertion of any object other than the penis. The version of the victim girl is only that of inappropriate touching without any reference to penetration. The applicant is arrested and incarcerated since 19th April 2019, and although the charge-sheet charges him with rapes, the trial Court is to determine the validity of this charge.

A. No. 4855 of 2018 Dated this the 31st day of July, 2018 ORDER This application is filed under Section 438 of the Cr. P. C. The applicant herein is the accused in Crime No. 339 of 2018 registered at the Vidyanagar Police Station, under Sections 342 & 363 of the IPC and under Sections 7 & 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. The survivor is a girl aged 15 years. The applicant is alleged to be a near relative of a friend of the victim girl. It is alleged that the victim was informed by the applicant herein that her friend was with him and she was invited to the apartment of the applicant. She reached the apartment at about 9. 45 AM on 26. 06. 2018. She was wrongfully confined in the apartment till 4 P. M. and she was not permitted to leave. The learned counsel appearing for the applicant submits that he is innocent. I am not persuaded to exercise the discretionary powers and grant an order of anticipatory bail to the applicant. The applicant is directed to surrender before the court below and seek regular bail. If an application for bail is preferred, the same shall be considered and order shall be passed expeditiously and on its merits. This application will stand dismissed.

Applicant has no criminal background. Therefore, it has been prayed that applicant be released on bail. Consequently, this first bail application under Section 439 of the Cr. P. C. filed on behalf of applicant, stands allowed. It is directed that applicant-Shivlal be released on bail on his furnishing a personal bond in the sum of Rs. 50, 000/- (Rupees Fifty thousand only) with one solvent surety in the like amount to the satisfaction of the trial Court, for his regular appearance before the trial Court during trial with a condition that he shall remain present before the concerned Court on all the dates fixed by it during trial. This order shall be effective till the end of the trial. However, in case of bail jump and breach of any of the conditions of bail, it shall become ineffective.

C. on behalf of the child victim 'A', through her mother, assailing the order dated 24. 04. 2021 passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge-06, West, Tis Hazari Courts, Delhi in FIR No. 394/2020 registered under Section 363 IPC at P. S. Mundka, Delhi. The present FIR came to be registered on a complaint given by the elder brother of the child victim, wherein it was stated that the child victim, who was aged about 12 years and 02 months, had gone missing and it was suspected that their neighbor had enticed her away. Subsequently, on 30. 03. 2021, the child victim was produced before the concerned Police Station by her brother and her medical examination was conducted at Sanjay Gandhi Memorial Hospital, Mangol Puri, Delhi. At the hospital, the child victim underwent the Urine Pregnancy Test (hereinafter, referred to as the UPT) and the test came out to be positive. The statement of the child victim was recorded under Section 161 Cr. P. C. , wherein she stated that the accused, a neighbour, had forcibly established sexual relations with her and taken her to Bihar without her consent. On the basis of the same, Section 376 IPC and Section 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (hereinafter, referred to as the POCSO Act) were added to the case. Later, on 08. 04. 2021, statement of the child victim was recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. , wherein she did not support the allegations levelled earlier in her statement recorded under Section 161 Cr. P. C. The charge sheet has been filed and charges already framed. The matter is stated to be listed for prosecution evidence. Ms. Supriya Juneja, learned counsel for the child victim, while assailing the impugned order, contends that the impugned order was passed in total contravention of the mandate of Section 33(8) of the POCSO Act and Rule 7 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Rules, 2012 (hereinafter, referred to as the POCSO Rules) (pari materia to Rule 9 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Rules, 2020. ) She further submits that during her medical examination, the UPT of the child victim was conducted and the same was found positive. It is also submitted that in the present case, Section 6 of the POCSO Act is involved and the child victim is yet to be examined in trial. Learned counsel informs that the child victim has also undergone medical termination of pregnancy and submits that in this backdrop, rejection of award of interim compensation was patently illegal.

Vikas Soni vs State Of U. P. & Another on 5 August, 2021. HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD, LUCKNOW BENCH. Case: - CRIMINAL REVISION No. - 1461 of 2019. Revisionist: - Vikas Soni. Opposite Party: - State Of U. P. & Another. Counsel for Revisionist: - Akhilesh Kumar Pandey. Counsel for Opposite Party: - Govt. Advocate. Hon'ble Mrs. Saroj Yadav, J. This criminal revision has been preferred by the juvenile Vikas Soni through his father, under Section 102 of Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act of 2015 against judgement and order dated 13. 9. 2019 passed by Special Judge, (POCSO Act), Pratapgarh in Criminal Appeal No. 51 of 2019 Vikas Soni Vs. State of U. P. and order dated 2. 7. 2019 passed by the learned Juvenile Justice Board, Pratapgarh in Bail Application No. 39 of 2019 arising out of Case Crime No. 31 of 2018 under Sections 41, 411, 413, 414, 401 of Indian Penal Code, Police Station Government Railway Police, Pratapgarh. The brief factual matrix necessary for disposal of this criminal revision are as under: On 10. 7. 2018, a First Information Report was registered at Crime No. 31 of 2018 at police Station G. R. P. , Pratapgarh under Sections 41, 411, 413, 414, 401 IPC on the basic of recovery memo prepared by Sub Inspector against the revisionist and three others. According to recovery memo, the revisionist alongwith three others was arrested on the information given by a fink at the railway station, Pratapgarh, making preparation to commit theft. A mobile Samsung Phone of golden colour was recovered. He confessed to having stolen the mobile from train 4-5 days back. It has also been mentioned in the recovery memo that he is a habitual thief and has committed thefts earlier also. Investigation started. Revisionist claimed juvenility and was so declared by the learned J. J. Board vide order dated 11. 6. 2019. His age was found 16 years. He moved bail application before the J. J. Board and the same was rejected. Against the order of JJ Board, an appeal was preferred under Section 101 of the Act of 2015, that too was rejected. The passage details of the legal arguments submitted by both sides and the court's consideration of these arguments. The Judge emphasized that the juvenile's release on bail should not lead him into association with criminal elements, and must ensure the juvenile's protection from further harm. Given the nature of Vikas Sonis circumstances and the Judges acknowledgment of the lack of adverse reports against him, what is the legal essence that upholds the juvenile's right to be released on bail despite the contention of habitual theft?

[case 200]
This petition has been filed to call for the records pertaining to the proceedings in Crime No. 17 of 2022 on the file of the respondent police and quash the same. The learned counsel for the petitioner submitted that the petitioner/A2 is the father in-law of the defacto complainant/second respondent. The second respondent/defacto complainant who was a divorcee is the second wife of the petitioner's/A2 son. The petitioner's son has already got two sons through his first marriage. He further submitted that the petitioner is having property at Chennai and the second respondent demanded to register the said property in the name of her minor daughter. Since the petitioner/A2 refused to do so, dispute arose between them due to which on 04. 05. 2022 the petitioner gave a police complaint against the defacto complainant before the All Women Police Station, Dharmapuri. The petitioner's son has filed HMOP No. 60 of 2022 on the file of the Additional Sub Court, Dharmapuri for divorce on the ground of desertion and cruelty. In order to take revenge against the petitioner/A2 and his son on 16. 07. 2022, the defacto complainant gave the present complaint against the petitioner/A2 with false allegations under the POCSO Act. Hence he prayed to quash the FIR in Crime No. 17 of 2022. On perusal of the FIR, it reveals that the respondent police had registered a case in Crime No. 17 of 2022 against this petitioner/A2 and another person who is the defacto complainant's husband for the offences under Section 9(1), 9(m), 9(n), 10 of Protection of Child from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and Under Section 506(i) of IPC. The defacto complainant who is the mother of the victim girl has stated that her daughter who is aged about 15 years, was sexually abused by her father-in-law/the petitioner/A2 and by her husband/A1 and that they both threatened the victim girl not to disclose to any one. On coming to know that her daughter was abused sexually, complaint has been lodged. This Court finds that the FIR discloses prima facie commission of cognizable offence and as such, this Court cannot interfere with the investigation. Therefore, it does not meet the parameters laid down by the Supreme Court in State of Haryana vs. Ch. BhajanLal (AIR 1992 SC 604), M/s Neeharika Infrastructure Pvt. Ltd. Vs. State of Maharashtra and others (2021 SCC online 315) & PRATIBHA RANI Vs. SURAJ KUMAR & ANR (1985 Crl. L. J. 817). It is inappropriate to quash the FIR and close the investigation at the beginning stage. Therefore, I find no merits and investigation in this case is to be conducted to find out the truth.

G. Vijayaraj vs The State Rep. By on 7 June, 2018. IN THE HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT MADRAS DATED: 07. 06. 2018 C O R A M THE HONOURABLE Mr. JUSTICE P. N. PRAKASH Crl. O. P. No. 3475 of 2018 and Crl. MP. No. 1541 of 2018 G. Vijayaraj. .. Petitioner Vs. The State rep. by The Inspector of Police W-8, All Women Police Station Thirumangalam, Chennai-600 101. .. . Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 of Cr. P. C to set aside the order dated 22. 01. 2018 in MP. No. 435 of 2018 in S. C. No. 311 of 2016 on the file of the Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Chennai and consequently, re-open and re-call the witnesses of P. W. 2 Miss Sangeetha for the cross examination of the petitioner. This Criminal Original Petition has been filed to set aside the order dated 22. 01. 2018 passed in MP. No. 435 of 2018 in S. C. No. 311 of 2016 on the file of the Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Chennai and consequently, re-open and re-call Sangeetha (P. W. 2) for the cross examination of the petitioner. The petitioner is facing trial in S. C. No. 311 of 2016 before the Sessions Judge, Mahila Court, Chennai for the offence under Section 4 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'the POCSO Act'). It is seen that the victim girl was examined-in-chief on 22. 04. 2017 and she was not cross-examined by the learned counsel for the petitioner herein for the reasons best known to him. Thereafter, the petitioner filed CMP. No. 435 of 2018 in S. C. No. 311 of 2016 under Section 311 Cr. P. C. , to re-call the victim girl for cross-examination, which has been partly allowed by the trial Court on 22. 01. 2018, challenging which, the petitioner/accused is before this Court. Heard Mr. A. M. Venkatakrishnan, learned counsel for the petitioner/accused, who placed strong reliance on the order dated 13. 09. 2017 of the learned Single Judge of this Court made in Crl. OP. (MD). No. 9401 of 2017 and Crl. MP(MD) No. 6403 of 2017. .. . The victim girl who was subjected to sexual abuse cannot be asked to come to the Court again and again and undergo the ordeal and explain how she was subjected to sexual assault. Change of counsel cannot be a reason for re-calling the witnesses. In fact, in Vinod Kumar vs. State of Punjab [2015(1) MLJ (Crl) 288], the Supreme Court has clearly held that the prosecution witnesses should be cross-examined on the day itself, when they are examined in chief. .. . The reasons given by the trial Court for not re-calling the victim girl-P. W. 2 cannot be stated to be perverse warranting interference by this Court. In the result, this petition is dismissed as being devoid of merits.

Sri. Shivakumara vs State By Basavapatna Police on 13 September, 2017. This criminal petition is filed under Section 438 of CR. P. C. , praying to enlarge the petitioners on bail in the event of their arrest in CR. No. 47/2017 of Basavapatna P. S. , Davanagere District for the offences P/U/S 9, 10, 11 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and Sec. 10 of POCSO Act. The allegation is, the 1st petitioner married the complainant, now aged 17 years while she was 15 years of age. The marriage was celebrated on the Basava Jayanthi festival of 2015 and one year after the marriage, the complainant joined the husband and in-laws in the matrimonial home during April 2016. One month thereafter, the 2nd petitioner/mother-in-law used to complain against the complainant with her son and the 1st petitioner used to beat her. He used to come home in drunken condition, abuse her filthily and assault her. They harassed her to get away from the matrimonial home. When she was carrying pregnancy for three months, she was assaulted in the presence of her mother and thrown out of the matrimonial home. Her mother is a daily wager and since unable to maintain her, admitted her to Nirmala Hospital, Shivamogga, where she was provided shelter. The Doctor on coming to know her age as 17 years, took her to District Child Welfare Committee. She was in the Shelter Home and thereafter admitted to Mecgan Hospital, Shivamogga, for delivery. Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the petitioners are from Sillekyathar community and child marriage is very common in their community. They are not aware of the legal impediment against child marriage. They are nomadic people. If the petitioners are arrested, in all probability, it will shut the door of compromise for ever. The complaint allegation is false and probably brought at the instance of third persons. The offence invoked is under Section 10 of the POCSO Act which attracts punishment ranging between 3 years to 7 years. The sensitive question of child born from the marriage between the victim and 1st petitioner cannot be lost sight of. Though the complainant was a minor at the time of the marriage, it is not a marriage void-ab-initio, it is a voidable marriage. Being mindful of the consequence of the situation, this court is of the opinion that it is in the interest of the marriage that the petitioner shall be granted anticipatory bail for a limited period. The petition is allowed. The petitioners are granted anticipatory bail for a period of three weeks in Crime No. 47/2017 registered by the respondent police.

Smt. Mamta Tiwari vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 2 September, 2021. This criminal revision under Sections 397/401 of Cr. P. C. has been filed against the order dated 10. 08. 2018 passed by the Special Judge (POCSO Act), Gwalior in Special Case No. 86/2019, by which the charges under Sections 16 and 17 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (in short "POCSO Act") have been framed. It is submitted by the counsel for the applicant that the applicant is working as a Counsellor and during her routine inspection of Ashram Shanti Niketan Balika Grih, Birla Nagar, Hazira, Gwalior, the prosecutrix, who is mentally retarded minor and is staying in the Ashram informed that Jain Baba posted in the said Ashram was continuously violating her sexually. During the course of investigation, it was found that the applicant was aware of the physical violation of the minor prosecutrix, who was mentally retarded, and in spite of that, she did not take any action against Jain Baba. When the applicant saw misdeeds of Jain Baba, then instead of taking any action against the co-accused Jain Baba, she simply requested him not to do the said act. The Trial Court by order dated 10. 08. 2021 has framed charges under Sections 16 and 17 of POCSO Act. It is submitted that the allegations are false. The witnesses had not spoken against the applicant at the first instance, but only in the supplementary statement, it was alleged that the applicant had seen the misdeeds of co-accused Jain Baba and instead of taking any action against him, he had simply requested Jain Baba not to indulge in the said act. Thus, it is submitted that such allegation is afterthought and cannot be relied upon. Per contra, counsel for the State has supported the impugned order dated 10. 08. 2018. Sections 16 and 17 of POCSO Act read as under: "16. Abetment of an offence. - A person abets an offence, who- First. -Instigates any person to do that offence; or Secondly. - Engages with one or more other person or persons in any conspiracy for the doing of that offence, if an act or illegal omission takes place in pursuance of that conspiracy, and in order to the doing of that offence; or Thirdly. -Intentionally aids, by any act or illegal omission, the doing of that offence. Explanation I. -A person who, by wilful misrepresentation, or by wilful concealment of a material fact, which he is bound to disclose, voluntarily causes or procures, or attempts to cause or procure a thing to be done, is said to instigate the doing of that offence.

Her mother is a daily wager and since unable to maintain her, admitted her to Nirmala Hospital, Shivamogga, where she was provided shelter. The Doctor on coming to know her age as 17 years, took her to District Child Welfare Committee. She was in the Shelter Home and thereafter admitted to Mecgan Hospital, Shivamogga, for delivery. Learned counsel for the petitioners submits that the petitioners are from Sillekyathar community and child marriage is very common in their community. They are not aware of the legal impediment against child marriage. They are nomadic people. If the petitioners are arrested, in all probability, it will shut the door of compromise for ever. The offence invoked is under Section 10 of the POCSO Act which attracts punishment ranging between 3 years to 7 years. The sensitive question of child born from the marriage between the victim and 1st petitioner cannot be lost sight of. Though the complainant was a minor at the time of the marriage, it is not a marriage void-ab-initio, it is a voidable marriage. Being mindful of the consequence of the situation, this court is of the opinion that it is in the interest of the marriage that the petitioner shall be granted anticipatory bail for a limited period. The petitioners are granted anticipatory bail for a period of three weeks in Crime No. 47/2017 registered by the respondent police.

G. Pappuraj vs The Chairman on 4 January, 2018. Before the Madurai Bench of Madras High Court. This Writ Petition is filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India, to issue a Writ of Certiorarified Mandamus, calling for the records pertaining to the impugned notice issued by the 3rd respondent in his proceedings in Na. Ka. No. A3/12750/2017 dated 09. 10. 2017 and quash the same and consequently direct the respondents to appoint the petitioner in the post of Police Constable Grade II - 2017. The Chairman, Tamil Nadu Uniformed Services Recruitment Board, Chennai? 2, issued notification dated 23. 01. 2017 inviting applications for the post of Police Constables? Grade II, Jail Warders? Grade II and Fireman, 2017. The petitioner herein was eligible to apply for the said post. He submitted his application dated 05. 02. 2017. He was issued with the hall ticket. He took part in the selection process and was found to be successful. But, he was denied appointment on the ground that his character and antecedent were not found to be satisfactory. The third respondent issued the impugned memorandum dated 09. 10. 2017 in this regard. The learned Additional Advocate General drew the attention of this Court to the serious allegations made against the writ petitioner. He was implicated not in a petty criminal case, but a serious one. It was a case involving Section 4 of POCSO Act, 2012. The victim child had narrated the sexual abuse and torture to which he was subjected to. However, before the criminal Court, the prosecution witnesses turned hostile. It is obvious that in view of Ex. P7 marked in the said judgment, the acquittal rendered in favour of the writ petitioner cannot be said to be honourable. In all probability, the parents of the victim child were won over by the accused. A Full Bench of this Court held that by virtue of Explanation 1 to clause (iv) of Rule 14(b) of the Tamil Nadu Special Police Subordinate Service Rules, a person acquitted on benefit of doubt or discharged in a criminal case, can still be considered as disqualified for selection to the police service of the State. Considering the serious nature of the case, in which the writ petitioner was involved and the fact that the victim had given a statement under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. , I am of the view that no indulgence deserves to be shown to the writ petitioner. The order impugned in the writ petition is sustained. This writ petition stands dismissed.

[case 214]
The present appeal has been filed by the appellant/State being aggrieved by the order on sentence passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge whereby pursuant to the conviction of the respondent for offences punishable under Section 363 IPC and Section 10 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 ('POCSO Act'), vide order on sentence dated 10th February, 2015, the respondent was released on the period undergone. In this regard, it would be relevant to note the concluding paragraphs of the order on sentence passed by the learned Special Judge. "6. I have considered the rival submissions made by the Ld. APP and of counsel for convict. It is an admitted case that this is the first offence of the convict u/s 363 IPC and Section 10 of POCSO Act which is punishable with maximum imprisonment for five years with fine. Convict is stated to be having responsibility of his family. In the facts, and circumstances, having regard to the fact that this is the first offence of the convict, that offence u/s 363 IPC and 10 of POCSO Act is punishable with maximum five years imprisonment, to the economic condition of the convict's family and recommendation for probation made by the Probation Officer, Rohini, therefore, convict deserves to be given a chance for reformation by taking a lenient view. Accordingly, prayer of counsel for convict is accepted. Instead of sentencing the convict to punishment, convict is given the benefit of probation and is directed to file a personal bond of good behaviour and conduct in the sum of Rs. 10, 000/- with one surety in the like amount for a period of one year with the condition that he shall remain under the supervision of Probation Officer, Rohini Court for one year and shall report before the Probation Officer once every month and shall not commit similar offence during this period of one year and if any such offence is brought to the notice of this court during this period of one year, then this court will be at liberty to impose appropriate sentence upon the convict u/s 363 IPC and Section 10 of POCSO Act. The convict is informed that he has a right to prefer an appeal against this judgment. He has been apprised that if he cannot afford to engage an advocate, he can approach the Legal Aid Cell, functioning in Tihar Jail or write to Secretary, Delhi High Court, Legal Services Committee, 34-37, Lawyers Chamber Block, High Court of Delhi, New Delhi.

[case 215]
Can criminal proceedings involving non-compoundable sexual offences against women and children be quashed upon a compromise between the accused and the victim, invoking section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure? - this is the common issue that falls into consideration in these bunch of cases. The petitioners in all cases are the accused involved in sexual offences either under Chapter XVI of the Indian Penal Code (for short 'IPC') or under Chapter II of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO Act') or both. All of them seek to quash the proceedings on the ground of settlement with the victim. Since there were divergent views on the subject by the Apex Court and High Courts across the country, I have directed the Counsel for the petitioners as well as the Public Prosecutors to address arguments in detail. The learned Counsel for the petitioners submitted that High Court possesses inherent jurisdiction under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure (for short 'Cr. P. C') to annul an FIR or criminal proceeding in appropriate cases where the offender and the victim have settled their dispute notwithstanding the fact that the offence involved is a sexual offence against women or children. The learned counsel further submitted that when the matter has been amicably settled, the victim would not support the prosecution case, and the possibility of conviction would be bleak. The continuation of proceedings, in such circumstances, would be a sheer waste of precious judicial time and public money, submitted the Counsel. Per contra, the learned Public Prosecutors submitted that rape or sexual offence against women or children is a heinous crime against society, and any compromise between the victim and the offender in relation to such an offence could not ordinarily provide for any basis for quashing the criminal proceedings in exercise of the wholesome power of the High Court under section 482 of Cr. P. C. They further submitted that compromises legalise rape and offer an escape route to the perpetrators. However, they fairly concurred with the view expressed by this court that there cannot be total embargo in exercising the extraordinary power vested with this court under section 482 of Cr. P. C. to quash criminal proceedings based on the settlement between the accused and the sexual assault victim in suitable cases to do complete justice to them.

No. 4067 of 2018 ================ Dated this the 26th day of July, 2018 ORDER Application for pre-arrest bail. 2. Petitioner is accused in Crime No. 711/2018 of Karukachal Police Station registered for the offences punishable under Sections 7 & 8 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (POCSO for short). 3. The prosecution allegation is that on 10. 6. 2018, the petitioner had sexually assaulted a minor girl child aged only 9 years and thereby committed the aforesaid offences. 4. Learned counsel for the petitioner has submitted that the petitioner is a pretty old man aged 60 years. He has been falsely implicated in the case. He apprehends arrest and torture by the Police and hence this petition. 5. Learned Public Prosecutor has vehemently opposed this application and submitted that the investigation of the case is only in the initial stage. 6. A perusal of the records would show that the offence alleged against this petitioner is grave and serious in nature. Sexual abuse against women and children are increasing day by day. If anticipatory bail is granted in such cases, it will give a wrong message to the society. More over the investigation is only in the preliminary stage. 7. Considering the gravity of the offence alleged against the petitioner and the present stage of investigation, I think that if bail is granted to him, there is every possibility to intimidate the victim and thus to tamper with the investigation of the case. Hence, I am not inclined to grant pre-arrest bail. Accordingly, this Bail application is dismissed.

Manoj vs State Of Karnataka on 31 October, 2018. THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 31ST DAY OF OCTOBER, 2018 BEFORE THE HON'BLE MRS. JUSTICE K. S. NAMITHA MAHESH, HCGP) THIS CRIMINAL PETITION IS FILED UNDER SECTION 439 CR. P. C PRAYING TO ENLARGE THE PETITIONER ON BAIL IN CR. NO. 13/2018 OF WOMEN POLICE STATION, TUMAKURU FOR THE OFFENCE P/U/S 366(A), 376 AND 417 OF IPC AND SECTION 4, 6, 10 OF POCSO ACT AND SECTION 9 OF PROHIBITION OF CHILD MARRIAGE ACT. THE COURT MADE THE FOLLOWING: ORDER The petitioner is in judicial custody in Crime No. 13/2018 of Women Police Station, Tumakuru. He is charge sheeted in the said case for the offences punishable under Sections 366(A), 376, 417 of IPC and Sections 4, 6 and 10 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO Act') and Section 9 of Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. It is alleged that the petitioner luring CW. 2 aged about 17 years of love and assuring to marry her committed repeated penetrative aggravated sexual assault in her house and on learning that her family members arranged their marriage. It is further alleged that the petitioner luring minor CW. 3 also of love and marriage, kidnapped her from the custody of her parents and took her to Bengaluru and married there in Herohalli Anjaneya Swamy Temple and between 02. 02. 2018 to 07. 02. 2018, lodged her in the house of CW. 7 in Tumakuru town and committed penetrative sexual assault on her. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that as per the complaint, the elders of CW. 2 fixed her marriage with the petitioner after attaining the majority, therefore, the provisions of POCSO Act are not attracted. Learned HCGP submits that as per the charge sheet records, the offence of rape is committed when both CWs. 2 and 3 were minors. The charge sheet contains the statements of victims-CWs. 2 and 3, recorded by the judicial Magistrate under Section 164 of Cr. P. C. The statements and other material on record indicate that both CWs. 2 and 3 were minors when the petitioner sexually abused them. Having regard to the gravity of the offences and materials on record, it is not a fit case to grant bail to the petitioner. Therefore, the petition is dismissed.

[case 220]
The alleged sodomy and brutal murder of a eight year old boy forms the background of this criminal appeal. The appellant has challenged the judgment dated 31. 7. 2002 passed by the Addl. Sessions Judge (Fast Track), Jhunjhunu whereby the appellant has been convicted for offences under Section 377 and 302 IPC. For the former offence, the appellant has been sentenced to 10 years R. I. and fined Rs. 500/- and to further undergo a sentence to fifteen days of simple imprisonment in default thereof. For the latter offence, he has been sentenced to life imprisonment and fined Rs. 2, 000/- and to further undergo two months simple imprisonment in default thereof. The brief facts of the case are that on 7. 9. 2000 Chhala Ram (PW-1) lodged a report (Ex. P. 1) at Police Station, Chirawa wherein he claimed that "his young son Mintu, aged eight years, was missing from the afternoon of 2. 9. 2000. The boy had left the house at 12'O clock in order to play. However, when the body did not return back home till 7'O clock in the evening, he started to search for him. He was told that the child was seen leaving the house of Jai Prakash and after that he was not seen. Therefore, on 3. 9. 2000 he had filed a report for the missing child. He further claimed that in the morning of the 7th, at 6'0 clock, some of the villagers gathered and they started searching near the river. Around 9'O clock Bakhtawar and Jainarain Sharma, who went on the east side of the river among the tall grasses, discovered the dead body of his son and his clothes. He suspected that someone has killed his son. On the basis of the said report the police chalked out a former FIR, FIR No. 226/2000, and commenced the investigation. On the same day, the appellant was arrested as some of the witnesses had stated that they had seen the deceased on the last occasion with the appellant. Eventually, the police filed a charge-sheet for the offences under Section 377 and 302 IPC against the appellant. In order to prove its case the prosecution examined 15 witnesses and submitted 29 documents. Although the defence did not examine any witness, but it did submit the statement of Bakhtawar recorded under Section 161 Cr. P. C. as a document. After considering the oral and documentary evidence, the learned trial court was pleased to convict and sentence the appellant as aforementioned. Hence this appeal before us.

[case 222]
Asif vs State Of Haryana on 16 September, 2021. Asif-petitioner is seeking regular bail in the case bearing FIR No. 79 dated 04. 10. 2018 under Sections 211/343/506/34 of IPC and Section 4 of POCSO Act, registered at Police Station Adarsh Nagar, Ballabgarh. Briefly, the case has been registered on the allegations that the child victim aged about 13 years was sexually abused. The petitioner along with four other persons had sexually abused and committed oral sex. Love-co-accused has also sexually abused the child in the room of Rinku. The petitioner had taken the child to Sergarh where he was kept in custody. It has been argued by the learned counsel for the petitioner that there is no allegation of sexual abuse of the child leveled against the petitioner. The petitioner along with four other persons are facing trial. All the accused except the petitioner and Rahul Kumar have been released on bail. Furthermore, Rahul Kumar, co-accused has also been granted bail by this Court. The petitioner is in custody since 17. 10. 2018 and is not involved in any other case. The statement of the victim as well as his parents have also been recorded. The trial of the case is going at fairly good pace and has opposed the bail application on the score that the co-accused have sexually abused the child aged about 13 years and they were sharing common interest with the petitioner. It is significant to note that the co-accused have been granted bail and the victim and parents have also been examined during the course of trial. There is no allegation with regard to sexual intercourse leveled against the petitioner. The petitioner has undergone incarceration for a period of more than two and a half years. The investigation of the case is complete, challan has already been presented and the conclusion of the trial is likely to take sometime on account of restricted hearing of the Courts due to Covid-19 Pandemic. As such, no fruitful purpose will be served by detaining the petitioner in further custody and sufficient mitigating circumstances are made out to extend the concession of the bail to the petitioner. Without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case, the instant petition is allowed. The petitioner is ordered to be released on bail on his furnishing requisite bail bonds to the satisfaction of the learned trial Court/Duty Magistrate concerned.

By The Inspector of Police, G-9, Perunagar Police Station, Kancheepuram District. (Crime No. 290 of 2015). .. Respondent Petition filed under Section 482 Cr. P. C. seeking to transfer the investigation to CBCID, Kancheepuram. For Petitioner: Mr. M. Mohamed Hasai For Respondent: Mr. C. Emalias, Additional Public Prosecutor ORDER It is the case of the petitioner that his daughter X, a minor girl, was subjected to sexual abuse by one Srinivasan and that she delivered a child on 28. 09. 2015. On a complaint lodged by the petitioner, the respondent Police registered a case in Cr. No. 290 of 2015 for the offence under Section 4 of POCSO Act and Sections 294 (b) and 506(i) IPC against Srinivasan, who was arrested by Police and has now been released on bail. It is the grievance of the petitioner that the investigation is not going on a right line and therefore, he sought for transfer of the same to any Specialized Agency. This Court perused the case diary. Statement of the victim girl has been recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. and she has also been subjected to medical examination. It is the further grievance of the petitioner that the Police have not taken any steps to have the DNA Profiling done between the accused and child. A copy of the statement recorded under Section 164 Cr. P. C. is not available in the case diary. In a case of this nature, it would be sufficient, if the victim girl gives evidence with general corroboration from other sources. Under such circumstances, this Court is of the view, it is not a fit case to transfer the investigation to any other agency. Under such circumstances, this Court, in the interest of justice, directs the Deputy Superintendent of Police, Madhuranthagam, to supervise the investigation in Cr. No. 290 of 2015. The Inspector of Police, Uthiramerur, is directed to proceed with the investigation of the case by taking steps to have the DNA Profiling of the accused and child done by moving the jurisdictional Court. If the accused does not co-operate with the DNA Profiling, it is open to the Police to move an application for cancellation of his bail. With the above direction, this Criminal Original Petition is closed.

This Criminal Petition coming on for orders this day, the court made the following: ORDER
This is a petition under Section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.
The respondent-police registered a complaint against the petitioner in Crime No. 154/2017 for offence under Section 506 IPC and Sections 4, 6 and 9 of POCSO Act. The alleged offence is that on 15. 9. 2017, the petitioner took the victim girl on his motor cycle to a distant place and sexually abused her. Sd/- JUDGE.

[case 237]
Sri. Zabi Ulla vs State By on 4 March, 2025. IN THE HIGH COURT OF KARNATAKA AT BENGALURU DATED THIS THE 4TH DAY OF MARCH, 2025. BEFORE THE HON'BLE MR JUSTICE HEMANT CHANDANGOUDAR CRIMINAL PETITION NO. 5806 OF 2024. The petitioners-accused, who have been charge-sheeted for offences punishable under Sections 363 and 366 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC), as well as Sections 3(a), 4, 5(j)(ii), 5(L), and 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012, and Section 9 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006, are before this Court seeking relief. The prosecution alleges that the petitioners-accused, fully aware that the daughter of petitioner No. 2 (accused No. 2) was a minor at the time of the incident, solemnized her marriage with accused No. 1, and thereafter, accused No. 1 committed forcible sexual intercourse with her. As a result of this wedlock, a girl child was born. The petitioners-accused and the survivor are present before this Court and have filed a joint affidavit stating that the marriage of the daughter of accused No. 2--alleged to be a minor--was solemnized with accused No. 1 due to inadvertence and ignorance of the law. The affidavit further states that from the said wedlock, a girl child was born who is approximately six months old as of today, and that if the petitioners-accused are subjected to trial, it would result in their incarceration, thereby causing additional agony and misery. It is also stated that the survivor and her child are solely dependent on the petitioners-accused for their daily needs. Although the offences are cognizable and non-compoundable, considering that the survivor is approximately 19 years and 4 months old as of today and that a baby girl was born from the wedlock between accused No. 1 and the survivor, subjecting the petitioners-accused to trial would result in their incarceration, thereby causing further misery and agony to the survivor and the child rather than serving the ends of justice. Moreover, the petitioners-accused are illiterate, and the marriage was performed due to ignorance of the law. Under these circumstances, the continuation of criminal proceedings would constitute an abuse of the process of law. Accordingly, the petition is allowed.
