Md. Manjur Sah @ Manjur Sah @ Md. Manjura. .. vs The State Of Bihar on 14 February, 2025. The petitioner is apprehending his arrest in connection with Mahila P. S. Case No. 10 of 2024 registered for the offence under Sections 341, 323, 498-A, 504, 506 and 34 of the Indian Penal Code and section  of the Dowry Prohibition Act, lodged on 03. 03. 2024 by the informant Reshma Khatoon. The allegation in the FIR that the lady was married to this petitioner and was given the dowry. With the passing of time, she was blessed with a female child whereafter the attitude of the petitioner changed and she was tortured and subsequently, allegation is that he also brought a new lady claiming herself to his second-wife. To her further agony, the accused persons including the petitioner stop providing food to the informant and finally she was thrown out of the house. When the parents along with locals visited the place where abused/assaulted. Left with no remedy, the FIR was lodged. Earlier, this Court granted long rope to the petitioner to come to terms and in between the matter was also sent for mediation but as per the Mediator's report dated 01. 10. 2024, the same could not be resolved. Learned counsel for the petitioner submits that only because he has consummated second marriage, the present case has been lodged. She has not been tortured for dowry and he is ready to keep her. Learned counsel for the informant on the other hand opposes the prayer submitting that a bare perusal of the FIR would show that the allegation is that: (i) she was tortured for dowry; (ii) he married again; (iii) she was not provided food and finally thrown out of the home; (iv) when the family members along with villagers wanted to resolve the issue, abused. Having gone through the facts of the case and the submissions put forward by the parties, certainly, the kind of allegation that has come against the petitioner, he does not deserve the anticipatory bail. There is not only allegation of torture for dowry, she was kept without food causing her physical and mental agony, ultimately thrown out of the house and in that background, it would be appropriate that he seeks bail. Accordingly, the anticipatory bail application stands rejected.

[case 240]
X vs State Of Nct Of Delhi (Acting Through Its. .. on 20 October, 2022. The present case raises important questions regarding the child survivors of sexual abuse. Child sexual abuse (hereinafter called "CSA") has been interpreted by the World Health Organisation (hereinafter called "WHO") as the involvement of a child in sexual activity that he or she does not fully comprehend, is unable to give informed consent to, or for which the child is not developmentally prepared and cannot give consent, or that violates the laws or social taboos of society. In a study, it was found that about 37% of India's population comprises children under 18, while around 53% of Indian children reported experiencing different kinds of abuse. The impact of the sexual offence is rightly pointed out in Bodhisattwa Gautam v. Subhra Chakraborty, wherein the Supreme Court reiterated that "Rape is not only a crime against the person of a woman (victim), it is a crime against the entire society. It destroys the entire psychology of a woman and pushed her into deep emotional crises. .. " Owing to various emotional, social, and cultural factors, CSA survivors may not be able to express their feelings and experiences. The main rationale for this is that children are traumatized and are unsure of the proper words to express their encounter. CSA has long-lasting negative effects on mental health. The criminal claims the survivors life, if not physically then affecting their mental and emotional state. It, thus, becomes imperative that the survivor of the crime is not overlooked and rehabilitation for the sufferings of the survivor is not overlooked. There is duty cast on the State to protect their rights and deliver justice to the survivors. This justice, in the form of compensation, should be given its liberal meaning thereby giving the maximum benefit and as quickly as possible. The Law Commissions 154th Report (1996) on reforms in criminal procedure discussed concerns related to victimology.  A whole branch has evolved to make the victim the focus of their study. The tools employed by this study include an understanding of the victim-offender relationship, assessing, and possible ways for compensating the victims.

C for quashment of complaint being FIR No. I-CR No. 119 of 2012 registered with Kalavad Police Station, Jamnagar for the offences punishable under Sections 363, 366 and 376 of IPC and under Section 4 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO'). The complainant is duly served with the notice. Mr. R. V. Vinchi, Police Sub Inspector of Kalavad Town Police Station is present before this Court. According to him, complainant has no resistance, as the prosecutrix girl has already married to the applicant. It appears from the record that the applicant and the prosecutrix are having a child of 1 and  years old. The officer has also ensured that he shall further facilitate amicable settlement between the complainant and daughter. Considering the fact that the relationship of the applicant and the prosecutrix is already converted into a legal relationship of that of wife and the husband and when a child is already begotten out of the said wedlock, no useful purpose is likely to be served in continuing the criminal proceedings in wake of the chronology of events. The prosecution since is not going to result into conviction, the said litigation need not be continued any longer. Bearing in mind the decision of the Apex Court rendered in case of Gian Singh Vs. State of Punjab and Anr. , reported in 2012 (10)SCC 303. The request of the applicant to quash FIR needs to be acceded to.

O. asked the victim that which of the accused caught her hand she took the name of the co-accused Dharmendra, therefore, it has been submitted that it is a fit case for anticipatory bail as there is no allegation against the applicant. It is further submitted that applicant has no criminal history and applicant is prepared to furnish sureties and bonds, there is no possibility of her either fleeing away from the judicial process or tampering with the evidence. Learned AGA has vehemently opposed the prayer of bail and has submitted that the investigation is continuing. Considering the submissions of both the sides. The FIR allegations is specific that assault was committed by the accused persons with intention to outrage the modesty of the victim who happens to be minor child.

State By Hebbal Police vs Puneeth on 22 December, 2015. IN THE COURT OF THE LIV ADDL. , CITY CIVIL & SESSIONS JUDGE AT BANGALORE CITY. Present: SMT. VIJAYALAXMI S. UPANAL, M. A. , LL. M. , LIV ADDL. , CITY CIVIL & SESSIONS JUDGE, BANGALORE CITY. Spl. C. C. No. 463/2014 COMPLAINANT State by Hebbal Police, Bangalore City. (By Learned Public Prosecutor) -Vs - ACCUSED Puneeth, S/o. Late Umesh, 22yrs, R/at. 3rd Cross, B-Narayanapura, Mahadevapura, Bangalore-48. (By Sri. T. D-Advocate. ) 1. Date of commission of offence 15-07-2014 2. Date of report of occurrence 24-07-2014 3. Date of arrest of Accused 26-07-2014 Date of release of Accused 27-12-2014 Period undergone in custody by Accused 05 months & 1 day. 4. Date of commencement of evidence 10-06-2015 5. Date of closing of evidence 18-09-2015 6. Name of the complainant Shashikala 7. Offences complained of Sections 366-A, 376 of IPC & Section 5(l) r/w Section 6 of POCSO Act-2012. 8. Opinion of the Judge Accused found not guilty. 9. Order of sentence As per the final order. JUDGMENT The Police Inspector, Hebbal Police Station, Bangalore has submitted charge sheet against the accused for the offences punishable under Section 363, 366, 376 of IPC and Section 5(l) read with Section 6 of POCSO Act, 2012 in Crime No. 177/2014. The brief facts of the prosecution case are as under: The accused was in love with Cw. 2-the minor victim girl, aged about 17 years. On 15-07-2014 the accused by inducing the victim minor girl kidnapped her from the custody of her lawful guardian, with an intention to compel her to marry him and raped her forcibly and repeatedly. This case illustrates the complexities of underage relationships and whether the young ages of both parties could affect the legal repercussions involved. It is essential for the judicial system to balance protection for minors while also maintaining the integrity of legal proceedings in cases involving accusations. The case highlights the need for clear guidelines on how to navigate such intimate matters while respecting both the rights of victims and defendants under the law.

[case 264]
Karnataka High Court G. Raghu Varma vs The State Of Karnataka on 19 February, 2024. The petitioner - accused is sought to be prosecuted for the offences punishable under Sections 366(A), 376(1) of the IPC and Sections 4 and 6 of the POCSO Act, 2012 and Section 9 of the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006. The case of the prosecution is that, the petitioner - accused fully knowing that the survivor was the minor, solemnized his marriage with her and committed penetrative sexual assault. The survivor and her parents were present before this Court on 20. 12. 2023, and filed a joint affidavit stating that the marriage of the survivor with the petitioner was solemnized inadvertently, and in ignorance of law, and from the said wedlock, a male child was born. They further stated that the survivor and the newly born child are dependent on the petitioner for their livelihood. If the criminal proceedings are allowed to continue, it would result in incarceration of the petitioner which would cause more misery and agony to the survivor and her child rather than securing the ends of justice. The petitioner and the survivor represented by her natural guardian have filed a joint affidavit that the sexual intercourse and the solemnization of their marriage was a consensual one. They would register their marriage upon the survivor attaining the age of majority. The object of POCSO Act is to protect minors from sexual abuse and not to criminalize the consensual relationship between adolescents who had consensual sexual intercourse without knowing the consequences. Though having sexual intercourse consensually with the minor is an offence under the POCSO Act, it would be appropriate to quash the impugned proceedings, otherwise, it would result in miscarriage of justice to the survivor and the child. Accordingly, petition is allowed. The impugned proceedings in Special C. C. No. 2432/2023. .. are hereby quashed. The petitioner to be released from judicial custody forthwith, if he is not required in any other case.

This Bail Application filed under Section 438 of Criminal Procedure Code were heard through Video Conference. Petitioners are the accused in Crime No. 2338/2020 and Crime No. 2337/2020 of Thiruvalla Police Station. The allegation against the petitioner in both the cases are same. Therefore, I am disposing these bail applications by a common order. Both the cases are registered based on the statement of the two kids of the petitioner's son. The allegation is that the petitioner, who is the grandfather of these two kids sexually abused the children in 2016 and 2018. Heard the learned counsel for the petitioner and the learned Public Prosecutor. The counsel for the petitioner submitted that this is a false case foisted against the petitioner. The counsel submitted that there is a matrimonial dispute between the father and mother of the victims. The counsel produced Annexure A e-mail communications between the father and mother of the victim. The counsel submitted that a bare perusal of these e-mails which are in the year 2017 will show that the mother of the victim has got an enmity towards the petitioner. The counsel submitted that the allegation of sexual abuse was there in 2016 also. But such an allegation is not mentioned in these e-mail communications. The counsel submitted that this is false case foisted at the instance of the mother of the victim. The petitioner is aged 70 and is ready to abide by any condition if granted bail. The learned Public Prosecutor opposed the bail application, asserting that serious allegations are there against the petitioner from the children and custodial interrogation is necessary. After hearing both sides, I think, this bail application can be allowed on stringent conditions, considering the aged status of the petitioner. Moreover, it is well accepted that bail is the rule and jail is the exception. This Bail Application is allowed with specific directions regarding conditions to be met by the petitioner to ensure the integrity of the investigation.

HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD Case: - CRIMINAL MISC ANTICIPATORY BAIL APPLICATION U/S 438 CR. P. C. No. - 9864 of 2021 Applicant: - Jitendra Singh @ Jitendra Yadav Opposite Party: - State of U. P. and Another Counsel for Applicant: - Sanjay Pathak Counsel for Opposite Party: - G. A. Hon'ble Pradeep Kumar Srivastava, J. Heard learned counsel for the applicant, learned A. G. A. for the State and perused the record. This is an application for the anticipatory bail given by the applicant Jitendra Singh @ Jitendra Yadav in Case Crime No. 0210 of 2021, under Section 354 I. P. C. and section 7/8 of POCSO Act, P. S. -Kotwali, District - Fatehpur. Submission of the learned counsel for the applicant is that informant side is tenant in the building of applicant and when he went there to demand rent, he has been falsely implicated in this case. Further submission is that he is teacher by profession and due to the F. I. R. police is inclined to make arrest, therefore, a prima facie case for anticipatory bail is made out. It is further submitted that applicant has no criminal history and applicant is prepared to furnish sureties and bonds, there is no possibility of his either fleeing away from the judicial process or tampering with the evidence. Learned A. G. A. has vehemently opposed the prayer of bail and has submitted that offence also pertains to POCSO Act and the victim child has given statement under section 164 Cr. P. C. supporting the F. I. R. version and has stated that applicant sexually abused her, therefore, no prima facie case has been made out for the anticipatory bail. In view of above and also that the case pertains to POCSO Act and the law has been enacted in order to prevent sexual abuse of the children, if in such kind of cases anticipatory bail is granted, this will frustrate the very object of law. I do not find any reason to grant anticipatory bail, therefore, the anticipatory bail application is rejected. Forum for regular bail is always open to the applicant.

[case 274]
E. Govindaraj vs M. Bhuvaneshwari on 13 August, 2024. This civil revision petition arises against the order of the learned II Additional District and Sessions Judge, Ranipet, Vellore District, in Criminal Appeal No. 81 of 2023 dated 23. 08. 2023 in confirming the order of the learned District Munsif cum Judicial Magistrate at Ranipet in CMP. No. 1495 of 2022 in DVC. No. 11 of 2021. DVC. No. 11 of 2021 has been presented by the respondents as against the civil revision petitioner. There is no dispute in the relationship between the parties. The petitioner married the first respondent on 06. 02. 2014 at Chengalpet. From the wedlock, the second respondent was born on 04. 09. 2016. The first respondent alleged that the petitioner never used to lend an ear to the troubles that the first respondent was facing or gave her any financial solace during the time they were living together. She would plead that the civil revision petitioner wanted only a boy child, but since a girl child had been born, and that too with health complications, he had forsaken/deserted the mother and child. Therefore, she had presented the aforesaid Domestic Violence Petition. On being served with the petition, the husband moved an application invoking the provisions of Order VII Rule 11. The learned Judicial Magistrate, on perusal of the complaint, came to the conclusion that the cause of action exists and therefore, dismissed the application on 04. 01. 2023. On appeal, the appeal was dismissed on 23. 08. 2023. Aggrieved by the same, the present revision has been filed. The wife's failure to seek relief under Section 18(1) of the Domestic Violence Act was claimed by the husband to disallowed her petition. However, it is established that under Section 12 of the Act, relief can be sought without necessitating Section 18 specifically. Allegations of verbal, emotional, and economic abuse are mentioned in her complaint, validating her petition. Therefore, the civil revision petition stands dismissed.

Fayazuddin Khan@Badal Khan vs State Of Odisha & Others. .. .. .. .. . on 4 March, 2025. THE HIGH COURT OF ORISSA AT CUTTACK CRLMC No. 3850 of 2024 (In the matter of an application under Section 528 of the Bharatiya Nagarika Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 r/w Section 482 of the Code Of Criminal Procedure, 1973 ) Fayazuddin Khan@Badal Khan. .. .. .. Petitioner -Versus- State of Odisha & Others. .. .. .. Opposite Parties For the Petitioner: Mr. Amitav Tripathy, Advocate For the Opposite Parties: Mr. Bibekananda Nayak, Additional Government Advocate CORAM: THE HONOURABLE SHRI JUSTICE SIBO SANKAR MISHRA Date of Hearing: 18. 02. 2025: : Date of Judgment: 04. 03. 2025 S. S. Mishra, J. The petitioner has filed the present application under Section 528 of the BNSS, 2023 r/w Section 482 of the Cr. P. C. , 1973, seeking quashing of the criminal proceedings arising out of Nayagarh P. S. Case No. 60 of 2022. The prosecution case originates from an FIR lodged by the informant on 10. 05. 2022, alleging that on 09. 05. 2022, the petitioner kidnapped her minor daughter (Opposite Party No. 3) and took away gold ornaments and cash of Rs. 8, 000/- from their house. Based on these allegations, Nayagarh P. S. Case No. 60 of 2022 was registered under Sections 363/366/376(2)(n) of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (IPC) read with Section 6 of the POCSO Act. During the pendency of the trial, the petitioner and Opposite Party No. 3 entered into a marital relationship after the latter attained the age of majority. They are now living together as husband and wife, and the informant (Opposite Party No. 2) has expressed her willingness not to prosecute the matter further. Despite this, the question arises whether personal reconciliations should ever lead to dismissing serious charges such as those under the POCSO Act which were initiated to protect vulnerable minors from exploitation. What parameters can be utilized to assess whether the reconciliation, in this case, dissolves the need for continued legal action?

[case 276]
Dr. Jenbagalakshmi vs The State Of Tamil Nadu on 20 December, 2024. This Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 528 B. N. S. S. , to call for the records in connection with FIR in Crime No. 1 of 2024 on the file of the All Women Police Station, Srirangam, Tiruchirappalli District and quash the same. On the basis of the complaint lodged by the second respondent, FIR came to be registered in Crime No. 1 of 2024 on 28. 02. 2024 against three persons including the petitioner for the alleged offences under Sections 5(l), 5(j)(ii), 6(1) and 21(1) of Protection of Child from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (hereinafter called as 'POCSO Act') and Section 312 IPC. The case of the prosecution is that the victim girl is the younger sister of the second respondent/defacto complainant, that the victim girl, who was aged 17 years, was admitted in Trichy Government Hospital by her maternal aunt Meenakshi and she had called the second respondent to come to Trichy Government Hospital, that when the second respondent had gone to the hospital, it was informed by her maternal aunt that the victim girl was pregnant as she was having a relationship with one Ramkumar. The maternal aunt, to abort the fetus, had taken the victim girl to Sudharsana Hospital on 24. 02. 2024 where a scan was taken. On 26. 02. 2024, the victim girl was brought to Sudharsana Hospital by her maternal aunt to abort the fetus and at the time of abortion, since the victim girl failed to co-operate, she was taken to Trichy Government Hospital in a serious condition and died thereafter. The petitioner, a Senior Doctor, was named as the third accused. The petitioner contends that she refused to perform the abortion and instead referred the victim to a government hospital. The Supreme Court had emphasized that a medical practitioner cannot be held liable simply based on misadventure or an error of judgment. This Court holds that considering the above, the FIR against the petitioner is liable to be quashed.

[case 291]
Abdul Husenmiya Shaikh vs The State Of Maharashtra And Anr on 2 September, 2021. By this application under Section 389 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 the Applicant seeks suspension of substantive sentence imposed by judgment dated 04/03/2021 passed by learned District Judge-2 and Additional Sessions Judge, Thane in Special (POCSO) Case No. 194 of 2018 and enlargement on bail. The Applicant was charged for offences under Sections 323, 354, 376, 377 and Section 506 of the IPC and Sections 4 and 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. By the impugned judgment, the learned Judge has held the Applicant guilty of offences punishable under Sections 323, 354 and 376 of the IPC r/w. Section 4 of the POCSO Act. He has been sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for ten years under Section 376 of the IPC and one year under Section 354 of the IPC and six months under Section 323 of the IPC. No separate sentence is imposed under Section 4 of POCSO Act. Charge against the Applicant is that he had committed rape / penetrative sexual assault on a minor girl aged about 8 years of age. The evidence of the victim prima facie indicates that the Applicant was involved in commission of the said crime. The medical evidence also suggests that there was evidence of penetrative vaginal intercourse. Thus, the material on record indicates that the Applicant, who is over 50 years of age has sexually abused the child who was barely 8 years of age as on the date of incident. The offence is not only grave but heinous in nature. There is prima facie material to believe that the Applicant was involved in commission of the crime. Considering the nature of accusations, gravity of offence and severity of punishment, in my considered view this is not a fit case for suspension of sentence and hence, the application is dismissed.

[case 297]
K. Govindan vs State Of Kerala on 24 August, 2020 The sole accused in S. C. No. 840 of 2014 on the files of the First Additional Sessions Court, Kasaragod has come up in this appeal challenging his conviction and sentence in the said case. The accusation in the case is that from the year 2012, the accused has committed rape on the victim girl aged 12 years in a shed near her house at Adkathbayal Beach, thereby committing offences punishable under Sections 376(2)(f), 376(2)(i) and 376(2)(n) of the Indian Penal Code (the IPC) and Section 3 read with Section 4 and Section 7 read with Section 8 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (the POCSO Act). On the accused pleading not guilty of the charges, the prosecution examined 13 witnesses on its side as PWs. 1 to 13 and proved through them, nine documents as Exts. P1 to P9. Among the witnesses examined, PW1 is the Chairperson of the Kasaragod Child Welfare Committee, PW2 is the victim girl, and the medical evidence in this case throws serious doubt as to the genuineness of the prosecution case as spoken to by the victim girl. It is difficult to believe the case put forth by the victim girl that the accused has committed vaginal intercourse with her on several occasions. I take this view also for the reason that prior to Act 13 of 2013, it was obligatory for the prosecution to establish at least an attempt on the part of the accused to commit vaginal penetration. The maximum punishment provided for the offence under Section 354 of the IPC, prior to Act 13 of 2013 was two years rigorous imprisonment or with fine or with both. In the result, the appeal is allowed in part. The conviction of the appellant is altered to one under Section 354 of IPC and the appellant is sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for two years and to pay a fine of Rs. 10, 000/-.

[case 302]
State (Govt Of Nct) vs Kuldeep Kumar on 24 February, 2016
CORAM: HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE G. S. SISTANI HON'BLE MS. JUSTICE SANGITA DHINGRA SEHGAL SANGITA DHINGRA SEHGAL, J. 1. Present leave to appeal petition has been filed by the State under Section 378 (1) of the Code of Criminal Procedure against the judgment dated 30. 03. 2015 passed by Ms. Neena Bansal Krishna, Additional Sessions Judge-01, Patiala House Courts, New Delhi in Session's Case No. 01/14, whereby the respondent was acquitted of the charges framed under Section 363/376/506 of the Indian Penal Code read with Section 4 of POCSO Act, 2012. 2. The brief facts of this case, as noticed by the learned Trial Court in the judgment are enumerated as under: "The complainant Smt. Neelima Devi, gave a statement on 30. 09. 2013 that her younger daughter aged about fourteen years, had gone to her school in the morning at about 6. 30 AM, but she has failed to return back home. They made a search for her, but have not been able to trace her. On the complaint FIR under Section 363 IPC was registered. Investigations were carried by SI Sandeep Mann. [case 304]
Hafij Ansari @ Chhotey vs State Of U. P. And Another on 7 November, 2019. HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD Case: - APPLICATION U/S 482 No. - 38130 of 2019 Applicant: - Hafij Ansari @ Chhotey Opposite Party: - State of U. P. and Another. The present application has been filed with a prayer to quash the entire proceedings of crime no. 33 of 2018, under Section 363, 366, 376 IPC and 3/4 POCSO Act, PS. Kubersthan, District Kushi Nagar. It has been argued by the learned counsel for the applicant that victim, who is daughter of the opposite party no. 2, has married accused-applicant and has child of six months born out of the wedlock. This aspect has not been taken into consideration by the Investigating Officer and has submitted charge sheet in this case in a routine manner which is nothing but an abuse of process and prosecution needs to be quashed. On the other hand, learned A. G. A. has drawn attention of the court to the statement of the victim under Section 164 Cr. P. C. , in which, she has stated that she had fled from her house of her own free will and has married accused-applicant and she is pregnant of six months. In ossification test, her age is found to be 17 years and 16 years as per F. I. R. , therefore, she was minor on the date of occurrence and was not competent to give consent for marriage, hence offence under Section 3/4 of POCSO Act as well as under Section 376 IPC would be made out in view of judgment of Apex Court rendered in Independent Thought vs. Union of India and another, (2017) 10 SCC 800, in which it is held that if a child is below 18 years, she would be treated to be child irrespective of the fact whether she is married or unmarried. If any intercourse is made with such child, the same would be fall in the category of rape, hence quashing should be refused.

C. , only to falsely implicate the revisionist as all of them were interested witnesses who sought private vendetta with ulterior motive to pressurize the revisionist. No such compelling/cogent reason has been mentioned by the learned court below to justify the summoning of the revisionist. No satisfaction has been recorded by the court below to the effect that the evidence, if un-rebutted, would lead to conviction of the revisionist under Sections 323, 504 and 506 IPC. On the basis of no sufficient material being collected during investigation, charge sheet was not submitted against revisionist and the two other unknown boys.

Anchal, who has been illegally detained in the Children Home (Girl) District Saharanpur.

Madhya Pradesh High Court Sammi @ Vijay Lot vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 22 November, 2016 CRA-1245-2016 (SAMMI @ VIJAY LOT Vs THE STATE OF MADHYA PRADESH) 22-11-2016 Shri Vijay Sharma, learned counsel for the appellant. Shri Pankaj Wadhwani, learned counsel for the respondent/State. Heard learned counsel for the parties on I. A. No. 9318/2016, an application under Section 389(1) Cr. P. C. for suspension of custodial sentence. The appellant has been convicted under Section 3 read with Section 4 of the POCSO Act, 2012 and Section 377 of IPC and has been sentenced to 7 years RI with fine under Section  of POCSO Act. No separate sentence has been imposed for offence under Section 377 IPC. Learned counsel for the appellant has invited the attention of this Court to the Court statement of complainant/victim - a child of about 13 years and has submitted that there are material contradictions and omissions. Per contra, it is submitted by learned counsel for the State that a child of 13 to 14 years was sexually abused and that not only the victim but other witnesses have also deposed about the incident and that learned trial Court after due appreciation of evidence, has recorded the conviction, therefore, considering the seriousness of the offence, it is not a fit case for grant of suspension. After going through the record and on consideration of the submissions made by learned counsel for the parties, this Court is of the considered view that it is not a fit case for suspension of custodial sentence because the victim has clearly spoken about the sexual assault and the learned trial Court after due appreciation has found the same worthy of prudence. Accordingly, the I. A. No. 9318/13 is rejected.

Although the offences alleged are cognizable and non-compoundable, in view of the fact that the parties have amicably resolved the issue among themselves--and the survivor has stated that the sexual intercourse was consensual and that she depends on the petitioner to meet their daily needs--it would be futile to subject the petitioner to trial, as the probability of his conviction is remote and bleak in light of the settlement. The petitioner is a minor girl and a student of Class-VI, aged about 13 years. She is a survivor of aggravated penetrative sexual assault and sexual exploitation, allegedly by a person around 34 years old. The petitioners parents are migrant labourers who used to stay at Assam for earning livelihood and visit their native place once or twice a year. The petitioner, thus, had to stay alone at home with her younger sister. Subsequently, symptoms of pregnancy became visible and the petitioner was taken to the Digha State General Hospital on August 12, 2023. Thereafter, pursuant to a complaint lodged by the Superintendent, Digha SG Hospital, a First Information Report (FIR) was registered, inter alia under Section 376(2)(n) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and Sections 4 and 6 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, 2012. She was taken into safe custody under the Child Welfare Committee (CWC), Purba Medinipur. The petitioner is a victim of rape and aggravated penetrative sexual assault and, as such, the continuance of the pregnancy resulting from such heinous crime constitutes a grave injury to the mental health as well as physical constitution of the victim. Thus, the termination of such pregnancy is immediately necessary to save the life of the pregnant child. Accordingly, the Court directed the respondent to ensure that the petitioner is brought under the care of the Child Welfare Committee and shall undergo medical supervision for termination of pregnancy.

The present bail application has been filed by the applicant in Case Crime No. 0084 of 2019 under Sections 363, 366, 376 IPC and Section 3/4 of POCSO Act, Police Station - Mehanazpur, District - Azamgarh with the prayer to enlarge the applicant on bail. The First Information Report of this incident was lodged by complainant Bhimraj and it was mentioned in the First Information Report that daughter of the complainant is untraceable since 31. 11. 2019. It is submitted by the learned counsel that the alleged victim has herself stated in Court that she is about 20 years of age. Further submission is that the alleged victim has married the present accused Vishal and they have got their marriage registered at District Ghaziabad. It is next contended that a female child was born out of their wedlock and at present the alleged victim is mother of a female child. The learned A. G. A. has opposed the prayer for bail. But he has not disputed the fact that their marriage is registered one. Keeping in view the submission of learned counsel for the parties, period of detention of the applicant and all the attending facts and circumstances of the case, without expressing any opinion on the merits of the case, at this stage, prima facie, a case for bail has been made out. The prayer for bail is granted. The application is allowed.

NO. 1/2014 - acquitting the respondent for the offence punishable under Sections 304B read with Section 34 of IPC and Sec. 3 and 4 of D. P. Act. The petitioner herein, is the mother of the victim in Crime No. 854/2015 of Edakkad Police Station for offences punishable under section 376 IPC read with section 3 & 4 of POCSO Act. The matter is now pending as SC. No. 111/2016 on the files of the Additional District and Sessions Court-I, Thalassery. The allegation is that her child was subjected to sexual abuse, while she was 13 years old. Accused is facing trial. Petitioner sought an early disposal of the case on the ground that the delay is causing great hardship, agony and trauma to the victim. It was stated that the victim was the only crucial witness. The learned Sessions Judge was directed to inform the approximate time limit within which the matter could be taken up, tried and disposed of. The learned Additional District & Sessions Judge-I, Thalassery, by his communication dated 5. 5. 2018, has informed that the total pendency of cases in that court is 1101. 62 cases are more than 5 years old, 22 cases involved under trial prisoners, 54 murder cases and 26 attempt to murder cases. In spite of this substantial pendency of cases which required urgent disposal, the learned Sessions Judge has offered to dispose of the matter within 8 months. Considering the huge pendency of cases, I feel that the learned Sessions Judge was justified in requesting for 8 months. Having considered this, I am inclined to direct the court below to take up SC. No. 111/2016 and dispose it of as expeditiously as possible, at any rate within an outer limit of 8 months from today. The court below shall take into consideration according to the learned counsel for the petitioner the crucial witness is only the victim.

Since the petitioner's complaint is pending for more than five months, the petitioner filed the above writ petition before this court for appropriate orders. Though very many grounds have been raised in this writ petition, learned counsel for the petitioner submits that, it would suffice, if this Court issues a direction to the respondents to expedite the enquiry and investigation on the petitioner's complaint, dated 26. 03. 2024, within a time frame that may be fixed by this Court. Learned Special Government Pleader appearing for the respondents submitted that, the dispute between the petitioner and his wife is a family dispute and the same has to be ventilated only before the family court. However, without doing so, the petitioner has filed a complaint before the 1st respondent, which is wholly unsustainable. Hence, the prayer sought for by the petitioner cannot be granted and the writ petition is liable to be dismissed.

[case 353]
Avtar Singh vs State Of Haryana And Anr on 9 December, 2016. This petition under Section 482 Cr. P. C. has been filed challenging the order dated 09. 03. 2015 passed by Learned Additional Sessions Judge, Karnal, which allowed an application under Section 311 Cr. P. C. by which witnesses have been recalled. In brief, the facts of the case are that FIR No. 412 dated 02. 11. 2013 under Sections 376(f)(i)(g)(m) IPC and 5(F)(M) and 6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (POCSO Act), at Police Station Indri was registered against respondent No. 2. In the said FIR, an allegation was made that respondent No. 2, being Principal of a school, had molested two young children aged four and five years. The matter was committed to the Court of Sessions for trial. After framing charges, many prosecution witnesses were examined, including minor children. By an application dated 05. 05. 2013, the respondent filed a request for summoning of the witnesses for further cross-examination, stating that there were certain documents not put to the witnesses. The Additional Sessions Judge allowed the application, stating that the accused has the right to defend and the minor child's cross-examination would be conducted with care. The petitioner argued that this order should be set aside due to ample opportunity already provided. The court upheld the right to recall witnesses under Section 311 Cr. P. C. but also highlighted the sensitivity needed when dealing with child witnesses under the POCSO Act. Ultimately, it dismissed the petition regarding summoning of the minor child, reflecting on the need to protect the interests and welfare of the child.

[case 354]
Niranjan Jaiswal And Another vs State Of U. P. And 2 Others on 10 February, 2025. High Court of Judicature at Allahabad Case - APPLICATION U/S 482 No. - 43621 of 2024. Applicant - Niranjan Jaiswal And Another. Opposite Party - State Of U. P. And 2 Others. Heard Mr. Anil Kumar Mishra, the learned counsel for applicants, the learned A. G. A. for State and Mr. Vijay Prakash Chaturvedi, the learned counsel representing victim. At the outset, the learned A. G. A. submits that notice of application under Section 482 was served upon first informant. However, no counter affidavit has been filed. The applicants, charge sheeted accused, have approached the Court for quashing the proceedings due to subsequent marriage with the prosecutrix, arguing the prosecution cannot be sustained. The prosecutrix has solemnized marriage with applicant on 17. 01. 2024. Parties entered a settlement outside Court and jointly filed an application for terminating the criminal proceedings. However, the A. G. A. opposed this, asserting that the prosecutrix was a child under the POCSO Act at the time of the offence, hence, the criminality stands. The counsel for the victim stated no objection to quashing the proceedings. This Court noted that compromise between parties can lead to quashing proceedings under certain conditions but risks remain with serious offences like those under POCSO. The court weighed public interest against the facts of the case. It concluded that the marriage and the victim's lawyer supports the application suggesting the criminality stands washed off, allowing the application and quashing the proceedings in Special Session Trial No. 74 of 2023.

[case 358]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD. The applicant seeks bail in Case Crime No. 128 of 2024, under Sections 137(2), 87, 64(1) of B. N. S. and Sections 3/4 of POCSO Act, Police Station - Kailadevi, District - Sambhal, during the pendency of trial. The applicant is stated to have enticed away the daughter of the informant aged about 16 years 6 months. The FIR does not whisper a single word about rape rather the allegations of rape have been added subsequently. There is no medical corroboration as the medical report indicates that LMP was started on 28. 08. 2024 and her medical examination was conducted on 02. 09. 2024. The victim, being 16 years and 6 months, indicates her age in a legally sensitive context as per POCSO. The arguments on behalf of the informant suggest that despite the lack of substantial medical evidence, the court must consider the principles of law regarding sexual assaults and the protection of minors, emphasizing the psychological and legal implications of such allegations. The court recognizes the necessity of the testimony of the victim and underlines the potentially traumatic impact of such incidents, leading to the consideration of bail in a sensitive manner. The court eventually grants bail to the applicant pending trial, emphasizing conditions to prevent tampering with evidence and ensuring presence during trial proceedings. The order emphasizes the necessity of respect for law and protection of victims when discussing criminal allegations. The applicant shall not tamper with evidence and must attend court when required.

[case 361]
Sri Ananda Poojari vs State By Chamarajpet Police on 12 July, 2018. This criminal appeal is filed under Section 374(2) of Cr. P. C praying to set aside the judgment/order of conviction and sentence dated: 31. 05. 2016 passed by the LIII Addl. City Civil and Sessions Judge at Bengaluru City in Spl. Case No. 188/2015 - Convicting the appellant/accused for the offence punishable under Section 9(L)(M)R/w Sec. 10 of POCSO Act, 2012. The appellant/accused is sentenced to undergo R. I. for 5 years and pay fine of Rs. 50, 000/- in default of pay fine, he shall undergo R. I. for one fourth of the period prescribed for the substantive sentence. This appeal is against the judgment which convicted the accused under Section 9(L)(M) r/w Section 10 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offence Act, 2012 and sentencing him to five years of imprisonment. The victim in this case, Disha, was alone at home when the accused entered with a pretext and committed the sexual abuse. The victim screamed and the parents then filed a complaint leading to the arrest of the accused. The trial court held that the prosecution established the guilt against the accused based on the victim's testimony and the complaint made. However, the appeal argues against the conviction alleging that the evidence was not cogent or consistent. The Court found that while the trial had deficiencies concerning evidentiary support and reliance on family testimonies, the accused, having suffered judicial custody for over two years, had his sentence reduced, though the conviction under POCSO was modified due to inconsistencies in evidence conveyed by witnesses.

Niranjan Jaiswal And Another vs State Of U. P. And 2 Others on 10 February, 2025. High Court of Judicature at Allahabad Case - APPLICATION U/S 482 No. - 43621 of 2024. Applicant - Niranjan Jaiswal And Another. Opposite Party - State Of U. P. And 2 Others. Heard Mr. Anil Kumar Mishra, the learned counsel for applicants, the learned A. G. A. for State and Mr. Vijay Prakash Chaturvedi, the learned counsel representing victim. At the outset, the learned A. G. A. submits that notice of application under Section 482 was served upon first informant. However, no counter affidavit has been filed. The applicants, charge sheeted accused, have approached the Court for quashing the proceedings due to subsequent marriage with the prosecutrix, arguing the prosecution cannot be sustained. The prosecutrix has solemnized marriage with applicant on 17. 01. 2024. Parties entered a settlement outside Court and jointly filed an application for terminating the criminal proceedings. However, the A. G. A. opposed this, asserting that the prosecutrix was a child under the POCSO Act at the time of the offence, hence, the criminality stands. The counsel for the victim stated no objection to quashing the proceedings. This Court noted that compromise between parties can lead to quashing proceedings under certain conditions but risks remain with serious offences like those under POCSO. The court weighed public interest against the facts of the case. It concluded that the marriage and the victim's lawyer supports the application suggesting the criminality stands washed off, allowing the application and quashing the proceedings.

[case 377]
Sri X vs The State Of West Bengal And Others on 17 August, 2023
The present writ petition has been filed by the father of an unfortunate minor girl of 11 years who is studying in Class V. The minor was a victim of a gang rape, which invited proceedings under Section 376DB of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) and under Section 6(1) of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. The minor, as of today, is pregnant for about 25 weeks and 6 days. The father of the minor, on her behalf, seeks medical termination of the unwanted and unwarranted pregnancy, in view of the trauma which would be suffered by the minor in the circumstances, if the birth of the child goes through. The learned Senior Advocate appearing for the petitioner cites Sections 3 and 5 of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971 as well as the connected Rules of 2003. It is contended that although under Section 3(2)(b), the outer length of pregnancy which can be medically terminated under the Act is 24 weeks. The Act has to be taken as a whole. Explanation 2 of Section 3(2) provides that for the purposes of Clauses (a) and (b), where any pregnancy is alleged to have been caused by rape, the anguish caused by the pregnancy shall be presumed to constitute a grave injury to the mental health of the pregnant woman. Such circumstances raise critical legal discussions regarding the rights and remedies available to the minor victim, especially focusing on her right to terminate the pregnancy due to severe mental and physical harms expected from carrying it to term.

The Present Criminal Revision has been preferred by the revisionist through his grandfather under Section 102 of The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 against the judgment dated 22. 10. 2021 passed by Additional Sessions Judge/ Special Judge (POCSO) Act, Siddharth Nagar in Criminal Appeal No. 27 of 2021, whereby the appellate court has rejected the Criminal appeal. The Juvenile Justice Board has rejected the bail application of the revisionist, which has been filed by his natural guardian/grandfather, under Section 12 of 'JJ Act, 2015' in Case Crime No. 118 of 2021, under Sections 354, 363, 366, 376 (3) of the Indian Penal Code and under Section 7/8 and  POCSO Act, P. S. Uska Bazar, District Siddharth Nagar. The revisionist was 13 years, 11 months and 20 days old at the time of the incident. The Juvenile Justice Board declared the revisionist as juvenile. The bail application under Section 12 of 'JJ Act, 2015' has been rejected by the Juvenile Justice Board. The appellate court has affirmed the order without considering the social information report of the Probation Officer in its right perspective. The findings recorded by the court below are against the social information report and are based on surmises. It is a settled position of law that the use of the word 'shall' in sub-section (1) of Section 12 of 'JJ Act, 2015' is of great significance.

[case 379]
X vs State Of Nct Of Delhi (Acting Through Its. .. on 20 October, 2022. The present case raises important questions regarding the child survivors of sexual abuse. Child sexual abuse (hereinafter called "CSA") has been interpreted by the World Health Organisation (hereinafter called "WHO") as the involvement of a child in sexual activity that he or she does not fully comprehend, is unable to give informed consent to, or for which the child is not developmentally prepared and cannot give consent. The impact of the sexual offence is rightly pointed out in Bodhisattwa Gautam v. Subhra Chakraborty, wherein the Supreme Court reiterated that rape is not only a crime against the person of a woman (victim), it is a crime against the entire society. Owing to various emotional, social, and cultural factors, CSA survivors may not be able to express their feelings and experiences. The Law Commissions 154th Report on reforms in criminal procedure discussed concerns related to victimology. The criminal claims the survivors life, if not physically then affecting their mental and emotional state. Therefore, the courts must consider the gravity of the violation and the circumstances of each case, including the severe mental trauma experienced. The passage also specifies that the compensation awarded is to be based on several factors including immediate rehabilitation needs, severity of abuse, and loss of educational opportunities. This judgment is essential for lifting the veil on the severely undercompensated nature of child sexual abuse cases.

C against the petitioner in Crime No. 6 of 2021 on the file of the Inspector of Police, W-10, All Women Police Station, Flower Bazaar, Chennai. The allegation in the F. I. R indicates that both the petitioner and the defacto complainant / 2nd respondent had love affair and thereafter the accused appeared to have refused to marry the defacto complainant, thereby F. I. R. came to be registered for the offence under Section 376, 417 and 506(ii) I. P. C. Now, the petitioner and the defacto complainant appeared before this Court and they were identified by the respective counsel and the investigation officer. Both of them submitted that they are married on 04. 02. 2022 and living happily together now. They have also filed a marriage registration certificate. Though the offence under Section 376 and 417 I. P. C are not compoundable, on a perusal of the F. I. R. , it indicates that the parties had consensual relationship and no intention or deception could be notified to hold that there is no valid consent for intercourse. Further, both of them are married now and F. I. R came to be filed due to stained relationship before marriage. If the F. I. R taken into consideration for entirety, the same would not attract offence under Section 376 I. P. C as there is no ingredients to show that the consent was obtained by misconception of fact.

The victim girl was first sexually abused by her own father, the appellant, when she was studying VI standard and just after she attained puberty. As the victim P. W. 1 deposed, it all started in a very mild manner when she was fondled and made to believe that it was common. Subsequently, the appellant forced himself on her and when resisted he convinced her by mentioning that it happens in every family. The victim girl was in an age at which she was neither a kid nor a teenager. The absence of her mother who was away from home either in the night shift or due to her profession made things easier for the appellant. The appellant also did not have any sort of guilt feeling and continued with his activities forcibly. It is also learnt from the evidence that at one point of time, he went to the extent of threatening his daughter with dire consequences. [case 405]
The present revision is moved on behalf of the accused-applicants involved in Case Crime No. 287 of 2017, under Section 376-D Indian Penal Code, 1860 and Section 7/8 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012, Police Station PGI, District Lucknow. The revision is directed against the order of Addl. Sessions Judge/Special Judge POCSO Act, Lucknow dated 22. 07. 2019. Learned A. G. A. termed the order impugned in this revision as an interlocutory order and argued against the admissibility under sub Section (2) of Section 397 Cr. P. C. The court noted whether the impugned order was passed misconstruing the provisions of Section 38 of the POCSO Act. The victim was a 5-year-old girl who was sexually abused at her school. The order allowing the victim to have an interpreter was challenged by the accused's counsel, claiming that the provision applies only to children with disabilities. The court elaborated on the necessity of providing an interpreter based on the age and ability of the child to communicate. Section 38 allows the court discretion in appointing an interpreter while asserting that being 'unable to communicate' differs from being 'disabled'. The court highlighted that the spirit of Section 38(1) aligns with the provisions of the Evidence Act, emphasizing the importance of ensuring the child can effectively communicate during judicial proceedings. The order was thus considered interlocutory and dismissed as non-admissible under Section 397(2) of Cr. P. C.

[case 416]
The instant writ petition has been filed by the Federation of Obstetrics and Gynaecological Societies of India (FOGSI) challenging the constitutional validity of Sections 23(1) and 23(2) of the Preconception and Prenatal Diagnostic Techniques (Prohibition of Sex Selection) Act, 1994 and seeking direction in the nature of certiorari/mandamus for decriminalising anomalies in paperwork/record keeping. The Society contends that the Act was meant to prohibit prenatal diagnostic techniques leading to female foeticide. Despite this, the Child Sex Ratio has not improved significantly, and the Act is being implemented more in letter than in spirit. The Society argues that the ambiguous wording of Section 23(1) leads to grave injustices, equating clerical errors with serious offences such as sex determination. The inherent weakness in the law has resulted in proper doctors facing harassment without actual evidence of misconduct. Furthermore, Section 23(2) allows for the indefinite suspension of a doctors registration based on preliminary findings, assuming guilt prior to any conviction, violating the fundamental right to a fair trial as guaranteed by Article 21. The Act's presumption of innocence is a cardinal principle that should not be abandoned. In light of this, the Society seeks clarity on how best to address these discrepancies, positing that minor clerical errors should not lead to such drastic measures against medical practitioners.

[case 431]
In the case 'Shailendra Yadav @ Shalendra Yadav vs The State Of Bihar', several juveniles are involved who have been accused of committing serious offences under various sections of the Indian Penal Code and the POCSO Act. The main issue is the rejection of bail applications submitted by the Children in Conflict with Law (CICL) at the Juvenile Justice Board and various Children's Courts across Bihar. The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015, emphasizes the presumption of innocence for minors and states that bail should generally be granted unless specific criteria justify denial. The failure of the courts to provide subjective reasoning for rejecting bail requests and the use of social investigation reports may impact the future judicial treatment of minors implicated in serious crimes. Under Section 12 of the Act, a child should be released on bail unless it is shown that their release would likely lead to exposure to known criminals, moral danger, or defeat the ends of justice. The court also highlighted that the gravity of the offence cannot solely dictate the decision regarding bail. In this case, the court decided to overturn the previous bail denials and grant bail to the CICLs on various conditions, reminding the judicial system of the obligation to ensure the best interests of the child are prioritized rather than punishing them based on the severity of their alleged crimes.

[case 442]
Criminal Original Petition filed under Section 482 Cr. P. C. seeking to quash the proceedings in D. V. C. No. 74 of 2022 on the file of the Additional Mahila Court, Thiruvallur, Thiruvallur District, against the petitioners.
This Full Bench has been constituted under the orders of the Honble Chief Justice on a reference made by our learned brother Justice N. Sathish Kumar to answer the following questions:
- Whether a proceeding under Section 12 of the D. V. Act can be challenged under Article 227 of the Constitution or under Section 482 of Cr. P. C?
- Whether the aforesaid remedy is available to an aggrieved person before approaching the learned Magistrate and, if necessary, the Court of Sessions by way of an appeal under Section 29 of the D. V. Act? The D. V. Act was enacted with the avowed purpose of providing more effective protection of the rights of women, who are victims of violence of any kind. Under the scheme of the said Act, an aggrieved person or a Protection Officer may present an application before the Magistrate. The various reliefs that can be granted are civil in nature, with clearly defined procedures and remedies available under the Act, emphasizing speedy and effective redress for domestic violence victims.

S. Mishra, J. The petitioner has filed the present application under Section 528 of the BNSS, 2023 r/w Section 482 of the Cr. P. C. , 1973, seeking quashing of the criminal proceedings arising out of Nayagarh P. S. Case No. 60 of 2022 due to a situation where the victim no longer wishes to pursue the charges against the accused. This case brings to the light the question of how the legal system balances the rights of the victim against the necessity of prosecuting serious crimes, particularly in instances where the victim has matured into adulthood and has reconciled with the accused. What legal mechanisms exist to ensure that the interests of justice are served without undermining the protective measures intended for minors under the POCSO Act?

[case 488]
HIGH COURT OF JUDICATURE AT ALLAHABAD. This case (X vs State Of U. P. And Another) revolved around a revisionist who was a juvenile involved in a criminal case where he faced charges under the IPC and POCSO Act. On 10 May 2023, the court heard arguments about the rejection of the juvenile's bail application by the Juvenile Justice Board. The revisionist was noted to be young, approximately 14 years old, and was claimed to have been falsely implicated in the matter. His defense pointed out the improbability of the charges against him, arguing that he was in protective custody and had no previous criminal records. The court discussed the significance of the Juvenile Justice Act regarding bail provisions, emphasizing that a juvenile should ordinarily be released unless strong evidence suggests otherwise. The arguments surrounding the juveniles upbringing, the lack of discipline and supervision from parents, and the necessity to ensure the child's best interests during judicial proceedings were critically analyzed. The court highlighted the importance of a social investigation report to aid its decisions and determined that the reasonings in the lower courts were not adequately based in law, which led to the eventual ruling that allowed the juvenile to be granted bail under certain conditions.

P. C. and Sections 7 Criminal Law Amendment Act, Police Station Maholi, District Sitapur. The revisionist, through his uncle, argues that he is an innocent child with no criminal background and the courts overlooked important factors regarding bail for juveniles under the Juvenile Justice Act. Hence, the need for proper assessment of the conditions set forth in Section 12(1) of The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 is emphasized. The case highlights child protection laws and their implications on judicial decisions. The order dated 22. 3. 2023 allows the bail application with specific conditions for monitoring the juvenile's rehabilitation.

Shaju@Shaju vs State Of Kerala on 1 September, 2022. The charge in the above case is of the father of a minor girl having repeatedly committed rape on her, at times against the order of nature, threatened the girl with dire consequences if it was revealed. In addition to the offence under Sections 376 & 377 of the IPC, commission of aggravated penetrative sexual assault, under the Protection of Children From Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short 'POCSO Act') was also charged. The appellant is the accused, who stood trial in which the prosecution led evidence through 17 witnesses marked 18 documents and produced 5 material objects. The appellant stood convicted under Ss. 376, 377 and 506(1)of the IPC and sentenced to undergo imprisonment for life under 376(2)(f)&(i) of IPC which is for the remainder of his natural life and a fine of Rs. 1 lakh. Under S. 377 IPC the appellant was sentenced to five years of rigorous imprisonment (RI) and a fine of Rs. 50000/-. A further RI for six months under S. 506 of IPC was also imposed. The appellant was also sentenced to RI for three years and a fine of Rs. 25, 000/- under S. 7 r/w S. 8 POCSO Act. Appropriate default sentences were ordered and S. 42 of the POCSO Act was reckoned, to not impose a separate sentence under S. 5(l)&(n) r/w S. 6 of the POCSO Act.

[case 524]
Surendran M. @ Kalyani Surendran vs State on 10 March, 2021. The prosecution has charged a case of abject moral depravity in which five persons, aged between 48 to 79, were alleged to have ravished a minor girl, as complained of by the victim and her mother. The prosecution case rests squarely on the evidence of the victim. The revision and prayer for conversion as an appeal: The appeals are filed by the accused and after hearing commenced and continued for two days, requested for conversion of the RP into an appeal under Section 401(5) of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973. The victim is enabled to file an appeal against such order of acquittal as per the proviso to Section 372 of the Cr. P. C. In this case the prayer for enhancement of sentence can be considered in the revision itself. However, the technical difficulty in retaining the revision for enhancement of sentence and converting a portion of it as an appeal must be noted. The allegations of abuse occurred after this date; thus we find no reason to interfere with the order of acquittal. The Court held that the evidences led by the accused cast serious doubts about the credibility of the victim's testimony, leading to the dismissal of the charges against the accused.

[case 537]
R. M. Vinod Kumar vs State Of Kerala on 16 June, 2020. The conviction of the appellant and the sentence imposed on him in S. C. No. 503 of 2012 on the files of the First Additional Sessions Court, Thalassery are under challenge in this appeal. The victim in the case is a girl aged 17 years. The accusation in the case is that on 01. 05. 2011 at 3. 00 p. m. , and on several subsequent dates till 05. 07. 2011, the accused committed rape on the victim girl at her residence. The court found the accused guilty under Section 376 of IPC, convicted him and sentenced him to undergo rigorous imprisonment for ten years and to pay a fine of Rs. 1 lakh. However, the appellant contested the conviction claiming an inordinate delay in registering the case and the unreliability of the victim's testimony. The trial provided the background of the case. The victim girl deposed that after her parents left for work, the accused took advantage of her vulnerability. After the incidents were revealed through counseling at school, the case proceeded legally but concerns about the credibility of witness accounts were contested. The court justified the conviction and reduced the sentence to 7 years considering the time and circumstances of the crime.

[case 542]
The present application under Section 482 Cr. P. C. read with Section 528 Bharatiya Nagrik Suraksha Sanhita, 2023 has been filed for the following main relief: 'That this Hon'ble Court may graciously be pleased to quash/set aside the Impugned Charge Sheet under section-363, 366, 376 of Indian Penal Code & 5 J(II)/6 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. It is stated that a perusal of allegations levelled in the FIR lodged by the opposite party no. 2, father of the opposite party no. 3/victim, would show that the victim, aged about 16 years, at the time of lodging of FIR, was enticed away by the applicant. [case 543]
In the case of Manu Sharma vs State Of U. P. and Another, the High Court addresses a serious charge involving sexual offences against a minor under the POCSO Act. The case centers around Manu Sharma, who is accused of raping a minor student, who was under his tutelage. The prosecution contends that the victim initially did not disclose the abuse due to threats and the nature of their tutor-student relationship. It is revealed that the victim, who was 15 years old at the time of the offence, later became pregnant, prompting her parents to file a report against Sharma. Legal representatives for Sharma argue that the relationship was consensual, citing the victim's declared age in her high school documents. The Court discusses the importance of protecting minors under the POCSO Act, referencing constitutional provisions that empower the state to make special provisions for children and maintain standards for their protection from sexual offences. After considering both sides, the Court found the plaintiff's application to dismiss the charges was unmerited, emphasizing the legal protections in place for minors under sexual abuse allegations and the need for proper judicial proceedings in such sensitive cases.

[case 544]
Sabari @ Sabarinathan @ Sabarivasan vs The Inspector Of Police on 9 January, 2019
Criminal Appeal No. 490 of 2018 is filed against conviction under Section 363 IPC and Section 5(l) r/w Section 6 of POCSO Act, resulting in five years imprisonment for the appellant, Sabari. The case arose when he allegedly kidnapped a 17-year-old girl from her grandparents' custody and repeatedly assaulted her sexually. The victims family filed a complaint after she went missing, but the victim later testified inconsistently. During the trial, several key witnesses turned hostile, questioning the evidence against the appellant. The trial court relied heavily on circumstantial evidence and presumption, raising concerns about the adequacy of the evidence leading to conviction. The appellate court found significant discrepancies and lack of solid proof, ultimately ruling that the prosecution failed to prove its case beyond a reasonable doubt. The appellant was acquitted, and the court raised important discussions on the handling of sex offenses against minors under the POCSO Act, emphasizing the need for careful consideration of consent and the resultant consequences on young individuals involved in consensual relationships.

[case 548]
In the case Gargian Sudheeran vs State Of Kerala, the accused, Gargian Sudheeran, is involved in two separate criminal cases concerning the disclosure of a victim's identity under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act (PoCSO Act) and the Indian Penal Code (IPC). The first case, registered under Crime No. 2/2023, alleges that Sudheeran disclosed the identity of the victim in Crime No. 2113/2016 on May 28, 2022. The second case, registered under Crime No. 516/2023, involves similar allegations but regarding incidents on March 11 and 23, 2023. The accused has sought to quash both cases on the grounds that they arise from the same event, arguing that the prosecution is abusing the process of law by registering multiple FIRs for the same offence. The court examined arguments from both sides regarding the legitimacy of pursuing charges in multiple FIRs for allegations that, according to the defense, should be treated as a single incident. It was determined that the cases involve distinct actions that occurred at different times, hence they are not duplicative but rather different offenses that warrant separate legal proceedings, ultimately leading to the dismissal of the quashment requests.

[case 551]
Sri Javed Shafiq Rao vs State Of Karnataka on 10 February, 2025
This petition is filed under Article 226 of the Constitution of India along with Section 482 of the CR. P. C. to quash the Complaint dated 08. 02. 2024 for offences punishable under Sections 149 and 304 of the Indian Penal Code. The petitioner argues that he cannot be held responsible for the electrocution incident that caused the death of a child, as he had already transferred responsibility to the Homeowners Association prior to the incident. The complaint essentially states that the Association and its contractors had neglected their duty to provide a safe environment, which directly led to the tragic incident involving the respondent's daughter. The prosecution suggests that several others, including the petitioner, were criminally negligent. Nonetheless, the petitioners counsel points out that there are no specific allegations against the petitioner that would warrant him being held liable for the incident, as responsibilities were officially transferred well before the occurrence. After hearing both sides, the Court determines that these proceedings constitute an abuse of the legal process and consequently quashes the complaint.

[case 556]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. The Allahabad High Courts judgment in the Satyaprakash case presents a critical reflection on how sensitive allegations of sexual offences against minors are approached within the legal system. The applicant's request for bail amidst serious charges under the POCSO Act incites careful deliberation about the legal implications of safeguarding child welfare. The court acknowledges the strong societal pressure surrounding such cases while reiterating the foundational legal principles including the presumption of innocence and the right to fair trial. Judicial proceedings also highlight the necessity for courts to adopt a rigorous approach towards evidence in sexual assault cases, particularly in safeguarding the rights of child victims while ensuring legitimacy in legal proceedings. Ultimately, the court's decision to grant bail is accompanied by strict conditions closely monitoring the applicant's actions to mitigate potential risks to the victim and society. This demonstrates an adherence to justice balanced with protective measures reflecting a comprehensive understanding of the ramifications of sexual crimes against minors.

[case 564]
Rajasekar vs The State Rep. By on 3 February, 2017 Crl. A. No. 176 of 2017
The appellant is in custody. This criminal appeal is filed to set aside the judgment dated 03. 02. 2017, passed by the Sessions Judge, Magalir Neethimandram, Coimbatore in Spl. C. C. No. 61/2014, in convicting the appellant herein under Section 3(a) r/w 4 of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and sentencing him to undergo ten years and fine of Rs. 5, 000/- in default simple imprisonment for three months. The accused and victim girl, who is aged about 16 years, were friends. The victim girl is reported to be in six months' pregnancy at the time of medical examination, after having been subjected to repeated sexual assault by the appellant. The court held the prosecution has proved the charges of penetrative sexual assault beyond reasonable doubt. The law considers a person under the age of 18 as a child, thus rendering the victim's consent immaterial in this case. The victim expressed willingness to compound the offence, but the court rejected this claim based on legal precedents and provisions under the POCSO Act, identifying it as a non-compoundable offence. The appeal is dismissed.

[case 568]
The victim in this case was aged 7  years on the date of the alleged occurrence. The Appeal arose out of conviction of the offence under Section 376 of IPC. The Accused is a Buddy of Lieutenant Colonel. Vivek Singh Thakur. The victim is the daughter of Lieutenant Colonel. Vivek Singh Thakur and Major. Prashasti. The victim's family left from the Bhatinda in Punjab State to Willington on the transfer of Lieutenant Colonel, Instructor Defence Services Staff College, Wellington in Nilgiris District. On July 19, 2012, the mother of the victim went shopping, leaving her children under the care of the Accused. Upon return, the mother found her daughter missing and later discovered her in another room, visibly upset. The victim disclosed that the Accused had been inappropriate with her, leading to medical examinations that pointed to sexual assault. A complaint was filed, and legal proceedings ensued, culminating in a conviction under Section 376 of IPC. The Accused appealed the conviction based on procedural irregularities and lack of concrete medical evidence. During the appellate proceedings, it was revealed that forensic examinations did not support the prosecution's claims.

[case 569]
The judgment discusses a criminal revision by a juvenile, X, representing his claim for bail under Section 12 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015. The bail application had been rejected by the Juvenile Justice Board, citing concerns about the juvenile's possible association with known criminals and risks to his moral, physical, or psychological safety. The case involves serious charges under Sections 392, 302, and 411 of the Indian Penal Code. Despite the juveniles' claims of innocence and assertions that the case was based merely on circumstantial evidence, the Juvenile Justice Board and Appellate Court affirmed the rejection of bail. The court emphasized the importance of the social investigation report in making informed decisions regarding the juveniles welfare and the implications of his association with known criminals or risk factors. Finally, the court found that the previous judgments lacked proper consideration of the statutory provisions in favor of juvenile rehabilitation. Consequently, it allowed the juvenile's appeal, ordering his release on bail with specific conditions to monitor and support his reintegration into society.

He found three boys under the age of 18 years working in the unit. They were found mixing cement with gravel and sand. Out of the three boys, two were from West Bengal. The third boy was questioned and he revealed that one of the boy was aged 18 years and the other was 16 years of age. They were working in the Hollow bricks manufacturing unit for the last three months and they were being given a sum of Rs. 150/- per day towards wages. A mahazar was prepared and later a crime was registered against the employer under Section 26 of the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2000. Investigation was conducted and final report was laid before the jurisdictional Court. The Case is now pending on the files of the Additional Sessions Court, Thiruvananthapuram as S. C. No. 779 of 2013. The said proceedings are sought to be quashed in this petition filed under section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure.

[case 571]
Gaurav Kumar @ Gautam Kumar @ Gaurav. .. vs The State Of Bihar on 4 April, 2024. These batch of Revisions are filed, challenging the orders passed by the Children's Court rejecting bail of the Child in Conflict with Law (hereinafter referred to as 'CICL'), who have been made accused in different criminal cases concerning heinous offences. It is alleged by the petitioner that he was falsefully implicated in a case under Section 364/120(B) of the Indian Penal Code when he was aged about 16 years and 7 months. The principle of presumption of innocence applies to any child under 18 years old, with all decisions based on the child's best interests, and any rejection of bail must be justified based on specific conditions outlined in the Juvenile Justice Act. The court emphasizes that granting bail is the rule rather than the exception, and any decision must involve a thorough assessment of the child's situation and environment. The goal is to protect the child's development while ensuring they do not associate with known criminals upon release. The balance between protecting society and respecting the rights of the child remains a cornerstone of the juvenile justice system.

[case 576]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. The court proceedings highlight significant legal arguments related to the credibility and timeline of allegations leading to the arrest of Satyaprakash. The FIRs delay raises questions regarding its validity, particularly in cases impacting minors as stated under the POCSO Act. The defense claims procedural delays and inconsistency in the victim's statements, as well as the absence of physical evidence from medical examinations. The rights of the accused under Articles 21 of the Constitution are emphasized; nonetheless, the court holds the need for caution when dealing with sexual offenses against minors, considering the potential trauma inflicted and the integrity of legal systems designed for victim protection. The court is required to weigh the evidence along with the legal premise that the victim's testimonial credibility is given considerable weight in sexual assault cases, reflecting the complexity of judicial processes in sensitive matters where allegations against minors are concerned. The judgment ultimately emphasizes the necessity of fair trials while protecting the victims' rights.

[case 577]
In the case of State Of Karnataka vs Sri Brahmadeva, the Karnataka High Court addressed a criminal appeal involving acquittal of an accused charged under the POCSO Act. The victim, a 14-year-old girl, alleged that the accused, her Physical Training Teacher, had abused her repeatedly from IV to VI standard. After a significant delay in reporting the abuse, the victim revealed the incident to her mother, which led to initial investigations. However, the trial court acquitted the accused based on various reasons including the lack of corroborated evidence, the testimony of alleged witnesses turning hostile, and unexplained delays in lodging the complaint. The prosecution argued the delay was due to the need for internal approvals, but the trial court found no indication that the victim was unable to report the abuse timely due to any external pressures or fear. The prosecution also failed to satisfy the legal requirements concerning corroboration of victim testimony as detailed in sections 29 and 30 of the POCSO Act. Ultimately, the appellate court upheld the trial court's decision on grounds of insufficient evidence and credible doubt about the accusations.

[case 582]
In the State Of Karnataka vs R Rangaraju @ R Babu case, the Karnataka High Court dealt with a criminal appeal following the acquittal of the accused under multiple charges including wrongdoing related to domestic violence and murder. The case revolved around the death of Vimala, who was allegedly subjected to severe cruelty and later killed. The prosecution presented eyewitness accounts, including that of a child, to support their claims of murder and abetment, asserting that the accused had a history of demanding dowry and inflicting mental and physical violence on Vimala. However, the defense challenged the reliability of these eyewitnesses, suggesting that the death may have been a suicide rather than a murder. The High Court ultimately found failures in the prosecution's case, particularly regarding the credibility of the child witness and medical evidence, leading to a mixed ruling on the charges, successfully convicting the accused for Section 498A (cruelty) but not for murder. The judgment highlighted the necessity of corroborating eyewitness accounts with substantial and scientific evidence to establish guilt beyond reasonable doubt.
