[case 585]
In the matter of reference under Section 395 of Cr. P. C. made by the learned Sessions Judge, Mahilar Court, Tiruchirapalli, in his letter in D. No. 238/2016 dated 17. 03. 2017. The Government of Tamil Nadu, under G. O. Ms. No. 217 dated 02. 04. 2013, sanctioned the constitution of 22 Fast Track Mahila Courts in 22 different districts in the cadre of Additional Sessions Judges to try the cases of offences against women. Subsequently, under G. O. Ms. No. 514 dated 16. 07. 2013, 22 posts of Additional Sessions Judges were sanctioned, known as the Judges of the Fast Track Mahila Courts to preside over these 22 Courts. Thus, by constitution, these Fast Track Mahila Courts are presided over by Additional Sessions Judges. They exercise all the powers conferred upon them under the Code of Criminal Procedure as Additional Sessions Judges. These Fast Track Mahila Courts were later on specified to be the Special Courts under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences, Act (for short the POCSO Act under G. O. Ms. No. 1087 dated 04. 12. 2013. Thus, these Additional Sessions Judges (Fast Track Mahila Courts) have been functioning as Special Courts under the POCSO Act.

[case 594]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. The Allahabad High Court considers the implications of the charges faced by Satyaprakash under the POCSO Act, forcing an analysis of legal principles entwined with the framework established for safeguarding children against sexual offenses. The court must consider arguments raised by defense counsel versus those of the prosecution regarding the victim's age, the credibility of the FIR's claims, and fundamental rights of the accused framed by the presumption of innocence. Key to the bail decision is the judicial responsibility to clarify the potential risks to the victim and society when evaluating the nature of allegations against a minor. Ultimately, the ruling to grant bail to Satyaprakash indicates a nuanced understanding of the legal standards necessary in such cases while firmly stressing the importance of protecting minors. The court sets out clear conditions for the bail's validity aimed at maintaining integrity within the judicial process, demonstrating an overarching commitment to uphold justice within the criminal framework while protecting victim rights.

[case 603]
In the case of Arul Daniel vs Suganya on 4 May 2022, the Madras High Court addressed several petitions filed under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cr. P. C. ) which aimed to challenge various proceedings initiated under the Protection of Women from Domestic Violence Act, 2005 (D. V. Act). The court discussed the nature of proceedings under the D. V. Act, clarifying that these proceedings are civil in nature but are dealt with under the framework of the Cr. P. C. The court recognized the complexities surrounding legal remedies when it comes to domestic violence cases, particularly the conflicting views among different High Courts regarding the jurisdiction of Family Courts versus Magistrates. The court emphasized that a petition challenging a proceeding under Section 12 of the D. V. Act is not maintainable under Section 482 Cr. P. C. and that while the jurisdiction of the Magistrate is civil, the mechanism for enforcement follows criminal procedural guidelines. The judges reaffirmed the need for proper jurisdictional understanding and the importance of statutory rights of appeal in the context of domestic violence cases.

[case 612]

As the court reviews the bail plea submitted by Satyaprakash, significant emphasis is placed on previous judgments and legal standards surrounding sexual offenses, particularly against minors. The defense challenges the lack of direct evidence, citing delays in the FIR and arguing for the applicant's presumption of innocence. However, the respondent argues that the absence of physical evidence does not diminish the severity of the allegations and cites precedent cases that position the victim's testimony at the forefront of the judicial process. Central to the court's decision-making process is the principle that while the accused is presumed innocent, the nature of the accusations under the POCSO Act necessitates a thorough examination of the circumstances. Particularly, the emphasis is on judicial responsibility to afford protection to minors and the fundamental impacts of sexual crimes on their well-being. Overall, the nature of the offense, the victim's rights, and the broader implications for social justice interlink throughout the proceedings.

[case 613]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. The court's ruling reflects broader implications for cases involving allegations of sexual violence against minors under the POCSO Act. The applicant, Satyaprakash, has been implicated in serious offenses involving a minor and is seeking bail while contesting claims made against him. The proceedings highlighted the necessity for the judicial system to address the complexities resulting from delayed FIRs, evolving victim statements and medical examinations that may not provide the expected clarity. The emphasis on the minors well-being underscores the importance of decisions that do not compromise victims safety or inhibit legal recourses for redress. Furthermore, the role of public sentiment and societal attitudes towards sexual offenses is significant; any ruling must be approached with caution to protect future victims while balancing the rights of the accused. Ultimately, the court's decision to grant bail illustrates a judicial commitment to fair process but acknowledges the persistent risk and potential for harm that the legal context brings.

[case 625]
Shaharbanu vs The Sub Inspector Of Police on 27 November, 2018. This application is filed under section 439 of the Cr. P. C. The applicant herein is the 2nd accused in Crime No. 149 of 2017 of the Mankada Police Station registered under Sections 376(2)(i), 376(2)(n) of the IPC and under Section 4 r/w. 3(a), Section 6 r/w. 5 and Section 17 r/w. 16 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. The victim is the minor daughter of the applicant. She was aged 8 years. In her statement, the child alleged that in the year 2013 and 2014, she was taken to a lodge by the 1st accused and the child was sexually molested by him. It is alleged that the applicant actively aided the 1st accused to commit the said horrendous act. The learned Public Prosecutor has opposed the prayer, arguing that the applicant had provided all assistance to the principal accused to commit the heinous act. The applicant appears to come from the most backward strata of the society and is living in absolute penury, having been in custody since 17. 9. 2018. The application for bail now stands allowed under certain conditions.

[case 627]
Ajay Kumar Jatav vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 6 January, 2023. This application coming on for hearing this day, the court passed the following: This is the second repeat bail application under Section 439 Cr. P. C filed on behalf of the applicant. The applicant is in custody since 22. 08. 2022 in connection with Crime No. 249/2021 for the offences punishable under Sections 363, 366, 376, 506 of IPC and Section 3/4 of POCSO Act. Per contra, learned Panel Lawyer opposes the bail application with submissions that the stories coined by the applicant and by the prosecutrix are far from truth. Upon hearing learned counsel for the rival parties, it is directed that the applicant be released on bail on furnishing personal bond with various stringent conditions.

[case 628]
Deepak (A) Deepak Kumar vs The State Of Tamil Nadu on 7 June, 2022. .. Crl. O. P. No. 10435 of 2022. .. The case of the prosecution is that the defacto complainant who is aged about 17 years fell in love with the accused and had sexual intercourse which resulted in registration of FIR. .. . The defacto complainant is about to complete the age of 18 in another six months when the alleged offence reported. She submitted that she is no longer interested in prosecuting the accused, since she voluntarily fell in love with the boy/accused. Though said consent of the minor is not permissible under law, the very object of the POCSO Act is to prevent the sexual offence on the minor children. .. . The provisions of the POCSO Act, as it stands today, will surely make the acts of the boy an offence due to its stringent nature. An adolescent boy caught in a situation like this will surely have no defense if the criminal case is taken to its logical end. .. . Therefore, quashing of the proceedings will not affect the society, in fact it will pave the way for both the victim as well as the accused for their future.

[case 630]
Rakesh @ Chandan vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 24 March, 2025. [case 633]

[case 634]
X -Juvenile vs State Of U. P. And Another on 27 February, 2023. The Present Criminal Revision has been preferred by the revisionist through his mother under Section 102 of The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 against the judgment dated 22. 9. 2022 passed by Special Judge (POCSO Act), Mirzapur. [case 635]
In the case of M. Sai Koushik vs State Of Karnataka, the High Court of Karnataka, dated 20 January 2025, examines a petition for anticipatory bail filed by M. Sai Koushik, who is accused of serious offences under IPC and the Dowry Prohibition Act. The petition was filed after the complainant Smt. Bhavani reported being subjected to physical and mental cruelty, alleging dowry demands and forced abortion. The Court noted the allegations of dowry demands post-marriage, detailing that significant dowry, including gold and a car, was expected by the petitioner. The complainant also mentioned that she was assaulted and coerced into terminating her pregnancy. The High Court was presented with arguments from both sides, with the petitioner claiming that the complaints filed were retaliatory due to his prior divorce petition. Although there were substantial charges against the petitioner, the court decided to grant anticipatory bail under strict conditions, including his cooperation with investigations and restrictions on leaving jurisdiction to ensure the safety of the complainant and witnesses.

[case 636]
In the Supreme Court of India, the case of Ms. Eera Through Dr. Manjula Krippendorf vs State (Govt. of NCT of Delhi) addresses significant legal concerns regarding the interpretation of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (POCSO Act). The central issue includes whether the definition of 'child' can encompass not only biological age but also mental age. Here, the appellant, Ms. Eera, is biologically 38 years old but is mentally disabled, with a mental age of approximately 6 to 8 years due to cerebral palsy. The law emphasizes protecting the child's dignity and ensuring judicial proceedings are conducted in a child-friendly atmosphere. The High Court had previously instructed necessary steps to ensure the trial was suitable for a child with such needs. The interpretation of 'child' as defined under Section 2(d) of the POCSO Act is key, where it is stated that 'child' means any person below the age of 18 years. This case deliberates the necessity of staying true to legislative intent while also ensuring the effectiveness of the legal protections intended for children.

[case 637]
Dr. L Veena vs The State Of Karnataka on 29 August, 2017 The petitioners have been charged in cases filed under various sections of the POCSO Act and the IPC. These cases originate from allegations by parents claiming their children were sexually abused at a preschool. The allegations also focus on the negligence of the school management in ensuring a safe environment for the children. There are legal discussions surrounding the validity of the charges, particularly concerning the necessity of complaints from public servants for certain offences under the IPC, specifically Section 188. The petitioners, who are staff at the preschool, argue for the quashing of these charges, citing that no due process by a public servant has occurred in the complaint filings. They express that any charges against them should not hold without proper legal basis and the court proceedings should respect the legal frameworks that govern such complaints, particularly emphasizing the POCSO Act for child protection and actions mandated to be taken by school authorities in safeguarding children under their care.

[case 639]
Satyaprakash vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 28 February, 2025. The court's analysis reflects an understanding of the complexities involved in cases under the POCSO Act, and the necessity to establish a secure environment for minors who have experienced abuse. The matter presented involves allegations where a minor girl was enticed away and possibly subjected to sexual activity. The legal framework surrounding the POCSO Act aims to implement robust protections for minors against sexual offenses, including strict consequences for perpetrators. While the applicants counsel argues for bail based on the absence of direct evidence, the prosecution explores legal precedents underscoring the judiciarys role in maintaining societal protection for children, which is reflected in the nature of charges and the sensitivity required in adjudication. A crucial aspect of these proceedings is ensuring that any decision made considers both the accused's rights and the paramount need to safeguard the victim, emphasizing the role of the judicial system in providing justice in cases involving minors.

[case 642]
In the case of Sayyed Usman S/O Sayyedmohiddin vs The State Of Karnataka on 15 January, 2025, the Karnataka High Court convened to address allegations against the petitioners, who were accused of participating in a child marriage. The petitioners were the President and a Member of the Jamia Masjid, and together with others, they reportedly solemnized the marriage of a minor boy on July 5, 2021. The prosecution initiated action based on a complaint from the President of the Child Welfare Committee. The law applicable to this case revolves around the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, where Sections 10 and 11 lay out the penalties for those involved in the solemnization or promotion of child marriages. The court examined the prosecution's evidence against the petitioners and found that there was no specific allegation pointing towards their direct involvement in the event nor a clear indication they were aware of the minor's status. Therefore, the continuation of legal proceedings against them was deemed an abuse of legal process, leading to the quashing of the charges against them.

[case 643]
Lalli Sharma @ Laliya @ Lalli Singh @ Lali. .. vs The State Of Bihar on 4 April, 2024. These batch of Revisions are filed, challenging the orders passed by the Children's Court rejecting bail of the Child in Conflict with Law (hereinafter referred to as 'CICL'), who have been made accused in different criminal cases concerning heinous offences. The petitioner was aged about 15 years 7 months 29 days. The CICL prayed for bail before the Juvenile Justice Board (hereinafter referred to as 'JJB'), Gaya, which was rejected. It is stated by the petitioner that he was minor on the date of commission of the alleged offence. The gravity and nature of offence are immaterial for consideration of bail of a juvenile. The Court emphasized the necessity of considering the best interests of the child based on the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act. The provisions of bail in juvenile cases were interpreted to ensure that the presumption of innocence is maintained, alongside considering the specifics of each case rather than relying solely on the severity of the alleged offence.

[case 644]
Mahalakshmi vs The District Collector on 19 January, 2021. W. P. (MD)NO. 659 OF 2021. This Court ordered notice to the respondents. Dr. R. Rajalakshmi, Assistant Surgeon, after examining the minor girl, opined that her gestational age is about 10-11 weeks and that continuing the pregnancy may endanger her physical and mental health. Considering the urgency of the matter, the Court directed the termination of the pregnancy. The law states that no pregnancy of a minor, who has not attained the age of eighteen years, can be terminated except with written consent from her guardian. In this case, the minor's father is deceased, and her mother is mentally unfit. Furthermore, her uncle seeks to have the pregnancy terminated. The minor initially was unwilling but later agreed to the termination. The passage discusses the relevant legal provisions surrounding the termination of pregnancy for minors and the involvement of medical authorities. It also highlights the considerations of trauma and psychological impact due to the circumstances of her pregnancy, arising from criminal acts against her.

[case 645]
Juvenile -X vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 24 March, 2023. The Present Criminal Revision has been preferred by the revisionist through his mother under Section 102 of The Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 against the judgment by the Special Judge (POCSO Act), which rejected the bail application of the revisionist under Section 12 of "JJ Act, 2015. " The Juvenile Justice Board had previously declared the revisionist as juvenile. It was submitted that the revisionist was falsely implicated and that there were several contradictions in statements provided by involved parties. The finding recorded by the court was deemed cursory, evaluating factors not based on sufficient evidence. The gravity of the offence was argued to not be a sufficient reason to deny bail. After careful consideration of the submissions from both sides, the Court found that there was no reasonable ground to believe that release would lead to the juvenile associating with known criminals, thus allowing the revision and granting bail with specific conditions for monitoring and welfare.

[case 646]
The case of X vs State of U. P. involved significant discussions regarding the rights of juveniles within the judicial system. The court highlighted how the juvenile justice system is designed to ensure the protection and rehabilitation of minors rather than punishment. The arguments presented indicated that the juvenile, who was just over 14 years old during the incident, had been held in custody following grave charges against him. The court considered whether the legal foundations used by the Juvenile Justice Board and the Appellate Court were adequate, particularly focusing on the procedural requirements pertaining to denying bail. Various sections of the JJ Act were cited which imply that a juveniles liberty ought to be prioritized unless certain reasonable grounds indicate otherwise. Additionally, the court emphasized the importance of a social investigation report in evaluating a juvenile's home environment and potential risks associated with their release into society. This highlighted the states responsibility to ensure juvenile offenders are treated fairly and justly.

[case 655]
X vs State Of Nct Of Delhi (Acting Through Its. .. on 20 October, 2022. Owing to various emotional, social, and cultural factors, CSA survivors may not be able to express their feelings and experiences. The main rationale for this is that children are traumatized and are unsure of the proper words to express their encounter. CSA has long-lasting negative effects on mental health. It becomes imperative that the survivor of the crime is not overlooked and rehabilitation for the sufferings of the survivor is not overlooked. The Justice Verma committee in its report stated: "No woman in India must feel a sense of shame or stigma in the event of sexual assault. She is entitled to the redressal of that injury and that offence and she is therefore statutorily and constitutionally capable of access to the rule of law. " The prevention of sexual violence is of fundamental importance to survivors sense of justice. It entails the transformation of society into one that understands and recognizes the harms of sexual violence and that actively makes efforts to reduce its prevalence.

[case 667]
In the case of Raju Yallappa vs The State Of Karnataka, the appellant, Raju Yallappa, was convicted for raping a 9-year-old girl belonging to a Scheduled Tribe. The incident occurred on December 22, 2014, when the accused lured the victim to a sugarcane field under the pretense of offering her a rupee. Upon hearing the victim's screams, her grandmother intervened, leading to an investigation and subsequent charges under the POCSO Act and the SC/ST Act. While the trial court convicted the accused, the defense argued that there was insufficient evidence to support the conviction, citing discrepancies in witness testimonies. However, the prosecution presented multiple witnesses, including the victim and medical evidence, sustaining the conviction despite challenges. The high court acknowledged potential issues with the conviction under the SC/ST Act, however, upheld the verdict related to sexual assault under the POCSO Act. The appeal concluded with partial success for the appellant, as certain charges were overturned, but the core conviction was preserved.

[case 677]
The court's decision involved an analysis of witness testimonies, particularly the prosecutrix's contradictory statements regarding her age, her consent, and her circumstances while staying with the appellant. The examination of legal frameworks, particularly the POCSO Act and relevant court precedents, guided the assessment of whether the prosecutrix was truly a minor at the time of the incident. The court highlighted that in cases involving minors, the prosecution bears the burden of thoroughly establishing this status to uphold any charges of sexual offenses. The prosecutrix's sustenance of a clearly expressed desire to protect the appellant from legal consequences alongside her lack of consistent assertions against him weakened the position of the prosecution. As such, emphasizing the weight given to the testimonies and the need for a strong evidentiary basis to uphold sexual offense charges against the appellant underlines the complexities of cases involving perceived victimhood versus actual consent.

[case 683]
The Karnataka High Court in the case of Mr. Vivek George Jacob vs State of Karnataka on March 27, 2024, dealt with a writ petition filed by the petitioners to quash an FIR that had been registered against them for various offenses, including dowry harassment. The allegations stemmed from a complaint by Mrs. Elizabeth George, the wife of the first petitioner, claiming continuous mental and financial abuse by her husband and in-laws. She reported that her husband had demanded dowry prior to their marriage and continuously harassed her for money after that, even taking control of her finances. [case 688]
Neelam vs State Of U. P. And 3 Others on 20 April, 2023. .. The case under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (for short, 'the Act of 2012') is not a private dispute or an offence of a kind that may be so limited to the interest of the informant and the accused, that the State may not have much to say about. To the contrary, the Act of 2012 is a special statute, which has been enacted with objects and reasons that read: "STATEMENT OF OBJECTS AND REASONS. .. " It is, therefore, proposed to enact a self-contained comprehensive legislation inter alia to provide for protection of children from the offences of sexual assault, sexual harassment and pornography with due regard for safeguarding the interest and well-being of the child at every stage of the judicial process, incorporating child-friendly procedures for reporting, recording of evidence, investigation and trial of offences. The Bill would contribute to enforcement of the right of all children to safety, security and protection from sexual abuse and exploitation.

[case 698]
The legal framework under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection) Act, 2015 emphasizes the necessity of safeguarding juvenile offenders from negative influences and allows for their rehabilitation rather than punitive action. The passage specifies that a juvenile arrested or detained should be released on bail unless there are reasonable grounds that their release would expose them to risk. To evaluate bail pleas for juveniles, courts must analyze the nature of the offense, the minors role, their family background, and their associations. This holistic approach is vital as highlighted in recent judgments where the courts emphasized that juvenile cases ought to be handled with care, focusing on rehabilitation. Moreover, the passage touches on a significant ruling by the Supreme Court which underlines the necessity to uphold the rights of juveniles against wrongful detention. This judgment serves as a crucial reference point for juvenile cases, highly advocating for their rights and appropriate treatment in legal contexts.

[case 700]
In the case of State Of Karnataka vs Sri Brahmadeva, the Karnataka High Court reviewed a criminal appeal where the accused was acquitted of charges related to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. The victim, a minor girl, reported prolonged sexual abuse by her teacher, which was not promptly reported to the authorities, thus raising issues concerning the responsibilities of custodians and the legal framework around the timely reporting of such incidents. The trial court raised concerns about the credibility of the victim's testimony due to the absence of corroborative evidence and the contradictory statements from other witnesses who had firsthand knowledge of the incidents. The prosecution's failure to provide satisfactory explanations for the delay in reporting the abuse further compounded the case leading to the acquittal decision. The appeal was dismissed as the appellate court found the trial court's conclusion was well-supported by the principles of law applicable to sexual offenses against children.

[case 701]
In the case of Santosh Yadav vs State (NCT of Delhi), the appellant was convicted under Section 10 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 (POCSO Act) and various sections of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) for the sexual assault of a five-year-old girl. The trial court sentenced him to five years of rigorous imprisonment and fines. The case began when the victim's mother reported the incident after the girl returned from a shop indicating she had been sexually assaulted. Evidence from the victim, her parents, and the medical examination corroborated the allegations against the appellant, prompting the court's conviction. The defense claimed false implication due to prior enmity, but failed to provide substantive evidence. The appellate court reiterated the importance of treating child witness statements with a high degree of credence due to their vulnerability. In determining sentencing, it was found that the trial court properly recognized the serious nature of the offence, given the age of the victim.

The High Court examined these objections before affirming the conviction but modifying the sentence to three years of imprisonment. [case 719]
In the High Court of Gujarat at Ahmedabad, a case titled 'Prakashbhai Gordhanbhai Metal vs State Of Gujarat' was recently heard. The applicant sought regular bail under Section 439 of the Code of Criminal Procedure. The applicant was arrested in connection with F. I. R. for offences punishable under Sections 363, 366, and 376 of the IPC, as well as under sections 4, 6 and 18 of the POCSO Act due to the involvement of a minor girl in the case. The prosecutrix, being 17 years and 07 months old, was considered a minor, and it was stated that the question of consent does not arise. The court took a serious view of the sexual offences against minor girls, noting that a minor must be protected under the law. Although the girl left her home voluntarily and was in a romantic relationship with the applicant, the court upheld that her age made her consent irrelevant. The bail application was ultimately granted with specific conditions to maintain the integrity of the investigation and protect the victim's interests.

[case 721]
State Represented By vs Kathir on 10 October, 2022. The judgment was concerning the acquittal of Kathir under the POCSO Act where the prosecution argued that the evidence provided was sufficient to convict him for the aggravated penetrative sexual assault of a child. The Special Judge found the evidence of the victim and her parents inconsistent and not trustworthy, leading to the acquittal. This prompted the State to appeal against the decision, suggesting that sole evidence of the victim could suffice for conviction under the POCSO Act if deemed trustworthy. The appeal raised points about the proper appreciation of evidence, with emphasis on the reliability of the child's statement and the statutory presumption under the POCSO Act. After reevaluating the evidence presented, the appellate court found that the trial court had erred in acquitting the respondent, leading to a reversal of the acquittal and a conviction under Section 6 of the POCSO Act, thereby imposing a sentence of ten years imprisonment.

[case 729]
In the case of Ashok vs Public Health Department, the petitioner has filed a writ petition seeking direction from the respondents to terminate her pregnancy under the provisions of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971. The case arose after the petitioner, a 17-year-old girl, was reported to be pregnant due to criminal offences under IPC and POCSO. She argued that continuance of pregnancy would cause grave injury to her mental health, causing great mental agony, and socio-economic problems. A medical board recommended termination of the pregnancy, affirming that the pregnant womans mental health is significantly impacted in such distressing situations. The court stated that the law has provisions for the termination of pregnancy up to 20 weeks under specific circumstances, including the mental health of the affected woman. The court emphasized the importance of survivor rights and permitted termination under the legal framework provided by the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971.

In the case of Yunusbhai Usmanbhai Shaikh vs State Of Gujarat on 23 September 2015, the facts outlined that the applicant, Yunusbhai, was accused of kidnapping a minor named Namira, which was litigious and contentious due to the nature of personal law applied to the parties involved. It was stated that Namira, aged 16 years and 4 months at the time of the alleged offense, was said to have left her parental home of her own free will and subsequently married Yunus. The respondent argued the marriage violates the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act, 2006, which emphasizes the illegality of child marriages, defining a child as a female under 18 years and a male under 21 years. The applicant's defense included points on personal law that purportedly allowed the marriage without parental consent at such a young age, leading to questions about the protection rights of minors under the coercive voices of societal norms against the statutory laws designed to safeguard children from early and forced unions.

[case 749]
Sonali Gupta vs Amit Gupta @ Sachin & Ors. on 25 February, 2025. Delhi High Court. Author: Jasmeet Singh. Petitioner Sonali Gupta alleged physical and mental abuse by her husband and in-laws. A Domestic Violence complaint was filed, but the court declined to summon her in-laws. The appellant argued that all involved should be called based on her claims. The judges referenced previous legal definitions regarding 'domestic relationships' within the Domestic Violence Act, affirming that not all must share a household simultaneously to be summoned in cases of alleged abuse. They emphasized the need for applicable judicial scrutiny of vague allegations and the definition of domestic violence. Recognizing that lack of specific proof of abuse could weaken an applicant's case, the judges upheld the lower court's decision that did not compel the summoning of all alleged abusers. Therefore, the appeal was dismissed, allowing for a chance for the appellant to provide adequate proof of her claims.

[case 751]
In the context of the passage, the provisions outlined in the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015 significantly prioritize the welfare of juveniles involved in criminal proceedings. The highlighted case of Satyam Yadav reveals that the juvenile justice framework ensures that minors are separated from adult offenders and given a chance for a more supportive environment tailored to their rehabilitation. The legal parameters suggest that juvenile offenders should be placed in observation homes rather than prisons and that any bail consideration must take into account their mental, physical, and emotional states. Hence, the focus is on creating a framework that fosters better outcomes for young individuals rather than limiting their opportunities through traditional punitive measures. Moreover, judicial oversight is crucial in ensuring that all decisions align with the child's best interests as indicated through case law emphasizing humane treatment and attention.

In relation to FIR No. 60, dated 15. 3. 2013, for commission of offence, under the provisions of Section 376 of the Indian Penal Code, registered at Police Station Sadar, Una, Himachal Pradesh, accused Gurmukh Singh, hereinafter referred to as the accused, was charged to face trial for having committed offence punishable under the provisions of Section 4 of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012 and Section 376 of the Indian Penal Code. On the strength of the evidence led by the prosecution, the accused was convicted of the offence punishable under these provisions and sentenced to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of seven years and pay a fine. The case involved a young girl who was assaulted in a forest, highlighting the seriousness of child sexual offences and the legal frameworks designed to protect minors. The prosecution's case rested on the victims testimony and corroborative evidence from family members and medical reports.

[case 786]
In a case before the Allahabad High Court, a juvenile identified as X sought bail from the Juvenile Justice Board under the Juvenile Justice (Care and Protection of Children) Act, 2015. His request was denied on grounds indicating that his release could lead him to associate with known criminals and that there was no effective control by the parents. The judgment highlights the balance the Juvenile Justice Board must strike in protecting the juvenile's rights while considering the gravity of the offenses, which include robbery and murder. The court ultimately found the Board's reasoning inadequate, stressing that the law mandates a presumption of innocence and that bail should ordinarily be granted unless compelling criteria based on evidence suggest otherwise. It pointed out the necessity of closely evaluating social investigation reports that can portray the juvenile's true circumstances, including any risks linked to his prior associations or situation.

[case 794]
In the case of Ramesh vs State represented by the Inspector of Police, the Madras High Court confirmed the judgment convicting Ramesh under Section 4 of the POCSO Act for committing penetrative sexual assault against a minor girl. The victim, aged 17 years and 4 months at the time, reported that Ramesh, her neighbor, had followed her while she was attending nature's call and sexually assaulted her after inducing her under false pretenses. The prosecution provided substantial evidence, including testimonies from the victim's parents and medical examinations, supporting the claims of assault. The trial court sentenced Ramesh to seven years of rigorous imprisonment and ordered him to pay a fine of Rs. 25, 000, to be given as compensation to the victim. The appeal against this conviction was subsequently dismissed by the Madras High Court, reaffirming the conviction of the accused based on the weight and credibility of the evidences presented in court.

[case 805]
In the case of State vs. Hitesh, the court examined the prosecution's claims regarding a 17-year-old girl who alleged she was involved in a sexual relationship with the accused. The prosecution failed to establish the victim's age beyond reasonable doubt, which is crucial under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act. The trial court acquitted the accused, noting that the victim had consented to the relationship. The High Court of Delhi upheld this decision, emphasizing that without conclusive evidence regarding the victim's age, the case could not support a conviction under the POCSO Act. The prosecution did not sufficiently substantiate the victim's age based on school records and other forms of identification, ultimately leading to the dismissal of the appeal by the state, stating the victim, despite being close to the age of majority, had consented to the relationship and hence, the case lacked the grounds to proceed.

[case 806]
In the case of Dinesh @ Dineshkumar vs State, reported on 8 March 2024, a key issue revolves around the actions of the accused who allegedly had physical relations with a minor girl. The girl, P. W-1, left her home on 26 June 2014 with the accused and was later found under circumstances that led to criminal charges being brought under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. The prosecution provided evidence claiming that the girl was taken from her lawful guardians and subjected to sexual assault. The court had to consider various factors including the age of consent, the nature of their relationship, and the factual circumstances surrounding her departure from home, which ultimately led to a conviction for the accused. However, upon review, the appellate court found that the original trial might have erred in interpreting the evidence, especially regarding the voluntary aspect of the girl's departure and her subsequent actions.

In the case of Irfan Mehmud Pathan vs The Sr. Police Inspector on 17 October 2018, the Bombay High Court reviewed two criminal appeals related to the rejection of bail applications under the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes (Prevention of Atrocities) Act, concerning serious accusations against the appellants for a crime that involved the abuse of two minor children from a Scheduled Caste. The court heard the arguments from both sides, including the seriousness of the offenses, the evidence presented, and the implications of the actions taken by the appellants. The decision highlights the need for sensitivity towards the legal protections afforded to vulnerable populations under child protection laws and the obligations of the court to uphold these laws vigorously.

[case 818]
In the case of X vs State (NCT of Delhi) & Anr. , the petitioner seeks to set aside an order granting bail to the respondent No. 2, who has been accused of raping a woman suffering from bipolar disorder. The prosecutrix, represented by her father, had initially shown mental vulnerabilities that were manipulated by the accused. The argument is based on a failure of the court to recognize the effect of her mental state on her ability to consent, alongside the serious nature of the crimes committed. The court evaluates various factors in determining the bail conditions and eventually the application for bail was cancelled due to the gravity of the charges and the apparent manipulation of the prosecutrix's condition by the accused. The learned Additional Sessions Judge noted contradictions and failures in the statements given during the bail hearing, ultimately leading to the decision that bail was improperly granted and should be rescinded.

The court also dealt with the appeals of other appellants who were acquitted of all charges. The victim had reported harassment before the incident, and evidence corroborating her account was provided by multiple witnesses including her parents and sisters. The judgment highlighted the admissibility of the victim's statement made in the ICU, acknowledging it as a dying declaration under Indian law. Apart from addressing the convictions, the court analyzed legal precedents regarding dying declarations and sentencing, ultimately converting Azhar's life sentence into one that allows for remissions.

The judgment elaborates on the legal framework surrounding juvenile bail under the Juvenile Justice Act, specifically Section 12, which traditionally presumes bail should be granted unless there are strong reasons against it. [case 866]
The ruling emphasized the legal necessity of determining the prosecutrixs exact age as a fundamental aspect of ascertaining whether the provisions of the POCSO Act could be enforced. [case 883]
The issue before us is limited but one of considerable public importance  whether sexual intercourse between a man and his wife being a girl between 15 and 18 years of age is rape? Exception 2 to Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860 (the IPC) answers this in the negative, but in our opinion, sexual intercourse with a girl below 18 years of age is rape regardless of whether she is married or not. The exception carved out in the IPC creates an unnecessary and artificial distinction between a married girl child and an unmarried girl child and has no rational nexus with any unclear objective sought to be achieved. The artificial distinction is arbitrary and discriminatory and is definitely not in the best interest of the girl child. The artificial distinction turns a blind eye to trafficking of the girl child and surely each one of us must discourage trafficking which is such a horrible social evil.

[case 887]
In the case of Arul Daniel vs Suganya decided on 4 May 2022, the Madras High Court examined the remedies available under the Domestic Violence Act, particularly concerning petitions filed under Section 482 Cr. P. C. The court emphasized that the proceedings under the D. V. Act are essentially civil but are governed by the procedural laws set forth in the Cr. P. C. The legislation aims to provide civil remedies for victims of domestic violence. The court highlighted how different High Courts have interpreted the question of the maintainability of proceedings and the jurisdiction of Magistrates versus Family Courts. The court concluded that although a Magistrate exercises civil jurisdiction under the D. V. Act, a petition under Section 482 Cr. P. C. to challenge such proceedings is not maintainable. Further, the court noted that there is an adequate appellate remedy available under Section 29 of the D. V. Act.

The case of Arul Daniel vs Suganya emphasized critical issues surrounding the proceedings of the Domestic Violence Act, thereby collating various case references evaluating if a legal case initiated under this act could be maintained or dismissed through different legal channels. It examined whether the established judicial protocols allowed for a robust response to domestic violence complaints or if such responses could be subjected to dismissal using the inherent powers granted under Section 482 of the Criminal Procedure Code. The Madras High Court reaffirmed that the proceedings had to be looked at through the specific lens of civil remedies and rights specific to domestic violence complaints, thereby clarifying the protections afforded to victims. The bench found that the original legislative intent was to allow victims recourse without being deterred by the complex procedures of criminal law.

[case 896]
In the case State (Gnct Of Delhi) vs Mr X. on 2 April, 2019, the respondent is the father of the victim, leading to redaction of identities in the judgment. The Trial Court previously discharged the accused from charges under IPC sections 354 and 376(2)(f), prompting this petition that highlighted inadequate protection of the victim's rights. The victim revealed extensive sexual abuse spanning several years, starting when she was six. The ruling cited the accused's blindness and the victim's delay in reporting as key reasons for discharge, which the High Court found problematic as it undermined the gravity of the allegations and the dominant role of the father. The High Court concluded that the charges warrant reconsideration and remitted the case back to the Trial Court for appropriate charges to be framed, thereby addressing the urgency of child protection and rectifying the earlier oversight.

[case 908]
Vidhi Ka Ulanghan Karne Wala Balak vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 3 March, 2022. The Madhya Pradesh High Court addressed the case of a Child in Conflict with Law concerning allegations under the Indian Penal Code and the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act. The court emphasized the principles of the Juvenile Justice Act, stating that juveniles cannot be treated as under trial prisoners in the context of criminal procedures. Therefore, the provisions regarding the maximum detention period for undertrials do not apply to them. The specific conditions under which a child could be imprisoned are to be reformed and rehabilitated, and detention is only meant for serious offenses. Hence, the petition for release based on the completion of the half-period of detention was dismissed, reaffirming that the primary focus should be on the welfare of the child rather than punitive measures.

Abhorrent child abuses and inexcusable indifference to the crime are one of the gravest social evils prevalent in the present society. A child can be abused in many ways. Mental, physical and sexual abuses are some of them. Multi-dimensional complexities of human life, misuse of social media platforms and changed socio-economic conditions expose the children to new and different forms of abuses. It includes causing mental and physical injuries, neglecting, blaming, forced sexual serfdom, incest exploitation, etc. Child abuses take place in their homes, schools, orphanages and residential care facilities. Even on the streets, in work places and in prisons too such violations occur. Violence in any form will cause a deep impact and leave an indelible scar in the mind of the child. Child abuse results in a real or potential harm to the child's health, personality development and dignity.

In the matter of:  SC No. : 62/02/13 FIR No. : 127/13 Police Station: Dwarka South Case ID No. : 02405R0233062013 Under Section: u/s 342/34 & U/s 323/34, U/s 109 of Indian Penal Code, 1860 and U/s 4 of The Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act, 2012. While initially contributing significant information leading to a filed FIR, upon further examination, the child victim disavowed her prior allegations, stating that she acted under the influence of an external individual who encouraged her to fabricate claims. The trial concluded with the acquittal of the accused due to a lack of corroborative evidence. The court highlighted that under the framework of the POCSO Act, despite the circumstances of false allegations, the child victim cannot face repercussions.

[case 936]

The victim stated that she is leading a happy life with the first petitioner and does not wish to pursue the case. The case has been registered for offences under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act and the POCSO Act. It is well settled law that the High Court can quash proceedings even for non-compoundable offences if the dispute is settled. In the current case, the court found the parties have settled voluntarily and quashed the criminal proceedings.

[case 937]
The State Of Karnataka vs Sri Brahmadeva ruling from the Karnataka High Court involved significant legal determinations regarding child protection laws and the evidentiary requirements for prosecuting sexual offenses against minors. The victim in this case reported her traumatic experiences of abuse over two years while under the care of a Child Care Institution but faced an acquittal of the accused due to a lack of corroborative evidence and witness challenges. This raised crucial questions about how child testimonies are treated under the law and the expectations for corroboration or additional substantiation of claims made by young victims. The trial court effectively highlighted the critical balance needed between protecting the rights of the accused and the rights of the child victima balance that remains a contentious issue within the framework of child protection laws.

[case 938]
The appellant - accused is before this Court challenging the legality and correctness of the judgment passed by the III Additional District and Sessions Judge, Special Court under POCSO Act. The prosecution alleged that the victim girl was sexually assaulted by the accused, Ramappa, and forced to consume pesticide. The evidence presented included testimonies from the mother of the victim and medical evidence stating that the victim was treated for injuries related to the alleged incident. After evaluation, the court found inconsistencies in the testimonies and questioned the credibility of the witnesses, particularly noting that the charge of sexual assault could not be substantiated beyond reasonable doubt. Ultimately, the convictions for severe charges were set aside, but one for Section 324 of IPC regarding assault was upheld, leading to a partial acquittal for the accused.

[case 949]
The case under discussion in the Karnataka High Court involves serious accusations against a political leader pertaining to misconduct with a minor. The Court deliberates on the procedures necessary for taking cognizance of these allegations as outlined under the Criminal Procedure Code concerning the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences. The emphasis is placed on a magistrate's duty to analyze all relevant documentation, including but not limited to FIRs, witness statements, and any evidence gathered as part of the investigation. This requirement is crucial in determining whether the charges establish a prima facie case sufficient to warrant consideration in court. Furthermore, failures in this procedural aspect can lead to direct injustices, as improper cognizance may inadvertently strip victims of their rights and compromise the integrity of the judicial process.

The outcome of this judgment underscores the importance of substantiated claims for domestic violence cases to succeed, considering the challenges of evidence requirements and potential misuse of legal provisions. [case 964]
In the case of X vs State of U. P. , significant attention was drawn to the stipulations of the Juvenile Justice Act, specifically the principles guiding the care and protection of children involved in legal issues. The court reviewed the implications of denying bail to the juvenile, who had been involved in a serious incident yet was recognized as being at a vulnerable age. It noted that the severity of allegations should not solely dictate bail decisions for juveniles; rather, the nature of the case, the juvenile's social background, and the potential risks associated with their release must be evaluated fairly. [case 975]
In the proceedings of the State Of Karnataka vs Sri Brahmadeva, the court examined various legal arguments surrounding the responsibilities of both the prosecution and the defense in child sexual abuse cases. The victim in this case was subjected to repeated abuse by her teacher, which was initially disclosed through a complex channel involving school authorities and psychological counselors. The trial court's decision to acquit the accused rested heavily on the credibility of witness statements and the absence of multiple substantiating testimonies. This verdict not only reflects upon the challenges faced by child victims and the inadequacies often present in their protection but also calls into question the broader implications of how the judicial system processes allegations of sexual abuse and the need for clear guidelines on handling such sensitive cases.

[case 976]
Karnataka High Court ruling on 7 February, 2025, involves Ravindra Chidanand Gadiwaddar and the State of Karnataka. The court examined criminal petitions regarding accusations related to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences Act and the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act. A private complaint was lodged claiming that the petitioners had facilitated the marriage of a minor. Subsequently, the trial court referred the case to police for investigation leading to an FIR and judicial custody of the main accused. Eventually, the complainant sought to withdraw allegations stating mutual resolution and hardship from trial proceedings. The court acknowledged the complainant's claim of being above 18 years at the time of marriage and quashed the FIR, allowing the primary accused's release, citing the potential for an abuse of process if the proceedings continued.

The parents of the victim filed the aforesaid application for intervention. [case 978]
Bachpan Bachao Andolan vs State Of Kerala on 17 November, 2021. The petitioners include the Bachpan Bachao Andolan, a charitable society, and a program director representing the organization. The petition requests information on the appointment process of members in the State Commission for Protection of Child Rights and the performance of state child protection bodies. This highlights the commitment to address child welfare comprehensively, aiming to reduce case pendency and improve the quality of services for children needing care and protection.

[case 979]
On January 15, 2025, the Karnataka High Court adjudicated a petition filed by Sayyed Usman S/O Sayyedmohiddin and another regarding accusations under the Prohibition of Child Marriage Act. The assertion against the petitioners involved their alleged role in solemnizing the marriage of a minor boy in their capacity as President and Member of the Jamia Masjid. Following the filing of an FIR by a child welfare advocate, the petitioners argued the absence of direct involvement or intent concerning the allegations. The court reviewed the pertinent sections of the law, concluding that the lack of conclusive evidence supporting direct actions on the petitioners' part warranted the quashing of the proceedings, as continuing would infringe upon their rights. This ruling underscores the critical examination of accusations against those in distinguished community roles.

[case 981]
Madhya Pradesh High Court case on March 22, 2022. In this case, Ajit is charged with sexual offenses against a minor under the POCSO Act. The court deliberates on the concept of consent for a minor under 18 years of age. The victim's age is established, and her claim of consent is contested. The court reviews the definitions under POCSO and implications on judicial proceedings for child protection. It emphasizes the necessity of offering children a protective environment against abuse and the legal perspectives on consent involving minors. In light of the preceding case laws, the discussion navigates the complex intersection of societal maturity expectations, legal definitions, and child protection laws. Ultimately, the court finds sufficient material against the applicant for conviction, prioritizing the protective intentions of the POCSO Act in its ruling.

An essential component of these rules is the rehabilitation of children who have faced abuse, ensuring they receive adequate psychological and emotional support. A child-friendly judicial process is to be followed, with a strong emphasis on individual assessments and case histories, ensuring that each child's unique needs and experiences are acknowledged and addressed.

The court actively examined the framework of Sections 10 and 11 regarding engagement in child marriages, ultimately finding that the charges against the petitioners lacked sufficient evidential basis for prosecution due to the absence of specific allegations of their involvement. This led to the dismissal of the case against them and reinforced the need for legal justification in child marriage matters.

[case 1069]
In the case of N. Balaji vs The State Rep. By on 20 August, 2018, the petitioner is undergoing a trial under the POCSO Act for allegedly sexually abusing a minor girl. The victim (PW1), aged about 15, along with three other witnesses (PW2, PW3, PW4), had already testified, but the accused failed to cross-examine them in time and instead filed for a deferral which the trial court dismissed. P. ) for an offence under Section 363 and Section 366 of the IPC, as well as under Section 376 (A)(B) with a death sentence. [case 1099]
Sri Javed Shafiq Rao vs State Of Karnataka on 10 February, 2025
The Court faced the challenge of deciding whether legal responsibility could be maintained against a petitioner after they had formally transferred the operational duties of a residential facility, wherein negligence led to a childs death. The assertions highlighted the lack of adequate safety measures, and the petitioner stated that control was relinquished well before the occurrence. There were no substantive allegations against him, leading the Court to conclude that the petitioner's dismissal was warranted to prevent an abuse of legal proceedings. The ruling invokes the essence of clearly defined duties in protecting child welfare in shared living environments and points towards a need for responsible transfer practices across property management.

[case 1100]
The Supreme Court of India on 11 October 2017, ruled that sexual intercourse with a girl child below 18 years is considered rape, contrary to Exception 2 of Section 375 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) which allowed such intercourse if the girl was married and above 15 years. The Court emphasized the need to address child marriage laws, asserting that a married girl child still retains her right to bodily integrity and reproductive choice, which should not be compromised due to marriage. The ruling was a response to the petition by Independent Thought, aimed at protecting the rights of girl children who marry young, often leading to inhumane conditions, neglect of their education, and health. The ruling aligns with Article 15(3) of the Constitution, allowing special provisions for the protection of women and children.

[case 1101]

This is in line with the guidelines under the MTP Act which states that in cases where the health of the mother is at stake, and in particular for minors, termination must be carried out with utmost priority and consideration for the victim's condition. The judgment reinforces the adult protection in legal settings, particularly extending to minors, thus advocating a framework that prioritizes both the rights of the victim and the legislative intent.

The prosecution's failure to establish the victim's age was critical in this decision, as the law guards minors from exploitation. The High Court of Delhi underscored that while the statutory age of consent is vital, it is equally important to consider the context, maturity, and nature of relationships involving minors. The acquittal hinged on the lack of definitive proof regarding the age of the victim and her own statements about consenting to the relationship, which complicated the application of the POCSO Act. The court insisted upon rigorous standards for evidence, affirming that a minors consent cannot be misinterpreted to undermine legal protections.

This scenario raises questions about legal remedies in cases involving minors and the complexities of the law surrounding their protection.

The said provision reads thus: '19. Reporting of offences - (1) Not withstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (2 of 1974), any person (including the child), who has apprehension that an offence under this Act is likely to be committed or has knowledge that such an offence has been committed, he shall provide such information to, - (a) the Special Juvenile Police Unit; or (b) the local police. ' For the failure on the part of the respondents, now they are answerable for the punishment under Section 21 of the Act which reads thus: 'Punishment for failure to report or record a case. '

[case 1168]
The learned counsel for the appellant submitted that there are absolutely no signs of penetrative sexual assault and at the best, the report only shows that there could have been a sexual assault. We are not in agreement with this submission made by the learned counsel for the appellant. The victim child has described the incident, when she deposed before the Court and she has specifically stated that the appellant had placed his penis over the vagina of the victim child. Section 3 of the POCSO Act explains penetrative sexual assault and Section 3(a) of the POCSO Act makes it clear that there is no requirement that the penis should have completely penetrated the vagina. Hence, sexual assault as described by the victim child clearly satisfies the requirement under Section 3(a) of the POCSO Act.

Nonetheless, the court determined that continuing the case would be an abuse of legal process and quashed the FIR.

[case 1187]
In the reference of the case Arul Daniel vs Suganya, the Supreme Court dealt with the conflicting interpretations surrounding the Domestic Violence Act concerning the legal pathways available for victims seeking redress against domestic violence. This included an intricate analysis of whether judicial proceedings initiated under the D. V. Act could be dismissed or challenged using provisions within the Cr. P. C. The decision underscored that while the reliefs sought under the D. V. Act are civil in nature, the framework required to address these issues must be adhered to diligently by ensuring the rights of victims are respected. The court established that victims retain rights to pursue civil remedies, with the legislative intention prioritizing victim protection over procedural complexities.

[case 1188]
Rakesh Charandas Lonbale (In Jail) vs The State Of Maha. , Thr. P. S. O. , P. S. .. . on 7 June, 2017
In this case, the conviction of Rakesh Charandas Lonbale under severe charges signified profound implications regarding the legal context of protecting child victims like 'K'. The investigative process involved medical examinations and multiple witness testimonies that contributed to the charges laid. However, the appeal questioned the sufficiency and coherence of the evidence presented, which reflects on the judicial processes that determine the states capacity to provide adequate legal protections for victimized children under the POCSO framework. The defense argued for potential inconsistencies in testimonies, emphasizing the importance of reliable evidence in convicting a suspected abuser.

[case 1189]
Shivlal vs The State Of Madhya Pradesh on 12 June, 2023. The High Court evaluates an application for bail under Section 439 of the Cr. P. C. regarding serious charges, including kidnapping and the sexual exploitation of a minor under the POCSO Act. The FIR brought by the prosecutrix, a 17-year-old, describes prolonged abuse and the emotional turmoil following betrayal by Devlal, who falsely promised marriage. The concern arises when threat allegations surface against Shivlal, implicating him indirectly. His request for bail reflects a guarantee of his presence during trial, sanctioned by judicial authority under certain conditions. It also reflects the courts assessment of the need for balance between the accused's rights and the sanctity of the prosecutrixs trauma and protection mandates.

[case 1190]
The case Ashok vs Public Health Department illustrates the legal mechanisms available for minors seeking to terminate pregnancies resulting from sexual abuse. The petitioner, a 17-year-old girl, filed for the termination of her pregnancy through a writ petition, emphasizing her right under the Constitution of India to live with dignity and liberty. The court emphasized the importance of medical evaluations by the committee, which supported the termination based on the mental health impacts of unwanted pregnancy due to rape. The passage outlines the procedures that need to be followed under the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, highlighting the necessity of obtaining consent from guardians for minors, underlining the importance of safeguarding the rights and well-being of young victims.

[case 1191]

[case 1192]
In the ruling for Ashok vs Public Health Department, the importance of immediate medical intervention for minors who are victims of sexual abuse was highlighted. The petitioner sought to terminate her pregnancy due to the psychological and socio-economic implications of being a young survivor of a crime. The court recognized that mental health aspects are taken into account when assessing the need for termination under the provisions of the Medical Termination of Pregnancy Act, 1971. Two registered medical practitioners evaluated the case and agreed that the minor's mental health was significantly at risk and suggested termination. This ruling underscores the jurisdiction's approach towards protecting minors and responding to their unique circumstances in the realm of reproductive rights.

[case 1193]
Joseph Kevin Selvadoray's struggle against allegations under the POCSO Act amidst a contentious custody battle reveals how familial tensions can give rise to legal challenges that not only threaten parental rights but also impact the wellbeing of affected minors. The High Court's approach highlights the importance of ensuring justice is not only done but perceived to be done in cases involving serious accusations. With ongoing debates surrounding custody and visitation, the judicial system faces the dual challenge of protecting vulnerable children from real harm while minimizing potential wrongful implications for parents involved in protracted disputes. The High Court's rulings underscore the necessity of a detailed investigation into the facts before any legal repercussions are enacted.

[case 1194]
Rakesh Charandas Lonbale (In Jail) vs The State Of Maha. , Thr. P. S. O. , P. S. .. . on 7 June, 2017
The present appeal is directed against the judgment and order of conviction passed by the learned Additional Sessions Judge, Chandrapur in Sessions Case No. 108/2003. The appellant is convicted under the IPC and POCSO Act, both providing a framework for the prosecution of offenses against children. The prosecutrix, referred to as 'K', lodged the FIR detailing her experience, which led to the trial. Testimonies were presented including medical examinations affirming her claims. The case against Rakesh Charandas Lonbale was constructed based on various evidences and testimonies, raising the issue of the reliability of such evidence in court and the implications for the victim's legal protections.

[case 1195]
In the case of Puran Lal @ Bhaskar vs State, the appellant was convicted under Section 376(1) of the Indian Penal Code and Section 4 of the POCSO Act for the penetrative sexual assault on a minor girl. The incident occurred on 17. 04. 2017, and the victim, a 13-year-old girl, initially reported the assault to her mother, who then contacted the police. The court highlighted the importance of the child's testimony and the corroborative evidence from her mother and a medical examination. The appellant was sentenced to seven years of rigorous imprisonment and a fine, which could lead to further imprisonment if not paid. The need for appropriate correctional programs for the appellant during his incarceration was also noted, emphasizing the importance of rehabilitation in preventing recidivism.

[case 1196]
The ruling in the case of S. Amutha vs C. Manivanna Bhupathy dated 2 February 2007 by the Madras High Court revealed substantial issues surrounding child witnesses. The father in this case attempted to present his minor son, Aravind, to testify against his mother in divorce proceedings, raising concerns about the psychological pressure imposed on the child. The trial court's decision to dismiss the mothers request against the child's testimony highlighted the complex interplay between children's rights to express their preferences and the risks of influenced testimony given their vulnerable age. The ruling emphasized the necessity of safeguarding the childs interests and confirmed that the child's testimony should only be assessed when it doesn't interfere with their emotional integrity.

[case 1197]
Vinod Kumar @ Sheshnath vs State Nct Of Delhi on 24 August, 2015. The case highlights how the judicial system addressed the serious charges against Vinod Kumar regarding the sexual abuse of his daughter 'X', underscoring the meticulous process of gathering and validating evidence. Statements from both the victim and her mother played crucial roles in substantiating the allegations, while the lack of credible defenses offered by the accused led to his conviction under the POCSO Act. This outcome reflects not only legal accountability but also sets a precedence for prioritizing child welfare and safety in cases of sexual offenses. The importance of these proceedings is deeply rooted in the responsibilities law enforcement and the judiciary have toward the protection of children from abuse.

[case 1198]
The legal proceedings in State Of Karnataka vs Sri Brahmadeva illustrated the shortcomings in addressing sexual abuse allegations when dealing with minor victims. The victim's report of sexual abuse by her Physical Training Teacher was complicated by delays in reporting, leading to an acquittal based on insufficient evidence and witness challenges. The trial court acquitted the accused primarily on the basis that the victim's testimony was not corroborated and that key witnesses failed to support her claims. The judgment emphasizes the need for a robust framework for child protection laws that comprehensively covers the processes following allegations of abuse, ensuring timely interventions and appropriate legal action while mitigating the emotional impact on the young victims involved.

[case 1199]
Abdulla Ainulhaq Ansari vs The State Of Maharashtra And Anr on 16 December, 2021. The judgment in this case reflects the importance of corroborative evidence in convictions concerning sexual abuse of minors. The passage outlines that despite the accusatory statements made by the victim, the lack of consistent evidence raised doubts regarding the credibility of the testimonies. While the POCSO provisions allow for a conviction based on the sole testimony of a victim, the appellate court observed that without clear corroboration, the testimonies become less reliable. The ramifications of this case underscore the need for robust evidence collection and verification methodologies in handling cases under the POCSO Act, where the integrity of victim testimony can make or break a prosecution.

[case 1200]
State vs. Lakhan S/O Sh. Rameshwar Dayal on 10 June, 2016. FIR No. : 436/2013. Under Sections: 323/354-B IPC & 8 POCSO Act. Brief facts of the prosecution case are that on receipt of DD No. 18-A, regarding molestation of a girl by a drunkard at 60' Road, Bhagwan Pur Khera, SI Ashwani Ambariya along with Ct. Sulekh reached at the informed place where he met the complainant/victim girl, aged 13 years who stated that accused Lakhan caught hold of her hand and slapped her. On this basis, an FIR was registered, and Lakhan was arrested. At trial, both material witnesses, the prosecutrix and her mother, turned hostile and did not support the prosecution case, claiming misunderstanding. The court ultimately acquitted the accused citing the prosecutions failure to prove its case against him.
